DOC.HEAD: Secretary of State Baker Meets ANC Activist, Tours Soweto
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III toured this huge black township Friday and decried the contrast with the wealth of the country's whites. He said the comparison is ``quite distressing, and that's why I said the system of apartheid should be abolished as soon as possible.'' A day after giving South Africa's white minority government a pat on the back, Baker met with anti-apartheid activist Walter Sisulu at his home here in a neighborhood of small, brick houses near Johannesburg, Africa's wealthiest city. Sisulu is a leader of the African National Congress, the leading anti-apartheid group. The secretary also visited community centers, a day-care center across the street from Sisulu's house, and drove past a squatter camp that has risen up on an old golf course. Later Friday, Baker flew to Kinshasa, Zaire, for meetings with President Mobutu Sese Seko and Angolan guerrilla leader Jonas Savimbi. Baker already has met President Jose Eduardo dos Santos of Angola as part of U.S. efforts to negotiate an end to the civil war in that country. Moments before Baker arrived at Sisulu's home, some children, perched on a jungle gym, shouted ANC slogans and sang songs honoring ANC Deputy President Nelson Mandela. But Baker didn't see or hear the children, and when he visited their day-care center a Baker aide lined them up to shake hands with him. Sisulu said, ``I told the secretary of state we are very grateful to the people of America for the support they gave us over the years and that we are hopeful but we are only making a beginning and we will expect more support as the day goes by.'' He said the talks had been ``very fruitful.'' The ANC openly opposed Baker's meeting on Thursday with President F.W. de Klerk, but the subject wasn't mentioned Friday until reporters pressed. Sisulu said, ``The United States realizes no fundamental change has been made but that some encouragement should be made.'' The ANC position had been that the Baker visit, the first by a U.S. secretary of state in 12 years, would suggest de Klerk has made fundamental reforms of the apartheid system of racial segregation and white domination. Despite this difference, ANC leaders greeted Baker warmly at meetings in Soweto, Cape Town, and Windhoek, Namibia, where he attended independence celebrations. Sisulu said de Klerk has not yet met the ANC's conditions for negotiations, though the two sides are to hold preliminary talks April 11.

DOC.HEAD: Pact Will Open Japanese Market to US Supercomputers
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 6th graf: ``Treasury Secretary,'' with 3 grafs on Brady-Hashimoto meeting in Los Angeles
DOC.TEXT: Negotiators on Friday reported the first breakthrough in a host of contentious trade disputes with Japan _ an agreement designed to open the Japanese market to American-made supercomputers. Officials at the U.S. trade office said they had achieved major concessions that should boost supercomputer sales in the important Japanese government market, estimated to total about $130 million annually. Terms of the agreement were hammered out late Thursday following a two-day bargaining session. The U.S. side had demanded that the Japanese remove various restrictions that effectively barred U.S. companies from selling supercomputers to Japanese universities and other government agencies. ``We believe the results reached last night, when finalized, should give us full and effective access'' to the Japanese government market, said U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills. The accord reached on supercomputers marked the first resolution of a variety of trade disputes straining relations between the two economic giants. It gave U.S. officials hope that progress will be made in other areas in coming weeks. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, in Los Angeles for talks with Japanese Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, said the agreement showed ``we can make some progress.'' ``Are they (supercomputer concessions) all we want? No. Are we going to get more? Yes. When, I can't say. I hope soon,'' Brady said. Brady called the session ``just a meeting to talk.'' Asked about a report that Japan might issue bonds denominated in dollars to support the sagging yen, Brady said, `The matter never came up.'' The discussions were a followup to a hastily arranged summit meeting earlier this month between President Bush and Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. Bush pressed the Japanese government to do more to open their markets to U.S. products as a way of reducing America's $49 billion trade deficit with Japan, accounting for almost half of the U.S. deficit. A U.S. trade official said the Japanese exhibited a new sense of urgency in the latest round of computer talks this week. ``Their negotiators came with instructions to make a deal. There has been a lot of high-level political pressure,'' said the official, who spoke on condition that his name not be used. ``We hope the Japanese will perceive the same kind of guidance in the other issues.'' In addition to supercomputers, the administration is holding talks on Japanese purchases of satellites and lumber products. Negotiators in these areas, however, have reported little progress thus far. The Japanese are facing a June 19 deadline to show a willingness to open their markets or face the prospect that the administration will retaliate by raising tariffs on Japanese products sold in America. Members of Congress said the supercomputer agreement, which could be signed formally as soon as next month, was encouraging but would need to be followed by concrete results. ``Japan must recognize that promises without performance are simply unacceptable,'' said Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo. Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., noted that a 1987 agreement by the Japanese to buy more American supercomputers had not produced results. He said it would be a mistake for U.S. negotiators to declare victory too soon. ``Nonetheless, progress is always encouraging. I hope this is a sign that the United States and Japan can jointly work out their trade frictions,'' said Baucus, who is chairman of the Senate trade subcommittee. The talks on specific industries are being conducted under a section of the 1988 trade law known as Super 301. The administration also is conducting separate discussions aimed at eliminating broader structural impediments to trade that make it difficult for U.S. firms to get their products to Japanese consumers. Negotiators on these issues met at a remote hideaway in the Virginia countryside earlier this week in advance of more formal discussions in Washington on April 2 and 3. However, U.S. officials said the discussions near Warrenton, Va., had failed to make any progress. But there have been reports from Tokyo that Kaifu is preparing an array of trade concessions in these areas in an effort to dampen growing protectionist sentiment in Congress. Under the computer agreement announced Friday, the Japanese promised to open the procurement process for supercomputers to foreign firms and to base government purchase decisions on quality as well as price. Access to the government supercomputer market has long been a point of contention between the two countries. U.S. firms, in particular Cray Research Inc., have dominated the global market for the sophisticated machines but have been unable to sell their products to the Japanese government. Dennis McGrath, a spokesman for the Minneapolis-based Cray, said his company would withhold comment until it reviews the agreement's details. ``We hope this is more than just a process thing, but something that will translate into sales in the marketplace,'' McGrath said.

DOC.HEAD: Vexed Videos: It's Bottoms' Up on This Wedding Video
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: It was to be a videotape of Robert and Christine Petitti's best day: the joyful tolling of wedding bells, the solemn exchange of vows, a close-up of the maid of honor. But her face, not her derriere. Newlywed Petitti and his wife are vexed over a videotape he says is a cross between Fellini and ``America's Funniest Home Videos.'' The suburban chemist sued Fred Fox Studios Ltd., and settled Wednesday for an undisclosed sum. A gag order prevented both sides from talking Thursday about the tape of the May wedding. But Fox has said he stands by his company's work, and what's more, it's the first time the family business, set up by his father in 1919, has been sued. Wedding videomakers be warned: As more and more weddings go video, so grow the hazards. ``People really get bent out of shape on this stuff,'' said Paul Seitz, whose Arlington Heights company, Design Videotaping, filmed more than 100 weddings last year. ``It is a very emotional day _ probably the most emotional day of anyone's life,'' Seitz said. ``You can't explain to them there are certain things that we just can't do. They are so used to seeing TV and movies where it looks like magic. Real life situations aren't like that.'' One bride, he recalled, was upset because the doors at the back of the church were left open during the ceremony, and appear that way in the film. ``She felt that was our responsibility, but we're already rolling the cameras as she walks down the aisle. What are we supposed to do, put the cameras down and close the doors?'' Seitz said good camera operators know when to film, and when not to. Capturing a wedding fist fight for posterity is a no-no, as is including footage of guests fainting at a hot summer wedding. ``You kind of make sure the camera moves away when the bridesmaids start to sway,'' he said. Petitti, 37, has said Fred Fox Studios was lax on precautions. In fact, he said, the tape of his wedding is not to be believed. Superimposed titles on the film provide the wrong name of the church, he complained. The cameraman caught only the last three seconds of the processional, Petitti said. The angle is such that Petitti's 27-year-old bride, the former Christine Beauchamp, can barely be seen during the ceremony, he said. ``You get the back of my bald head saying the vows,'' Petitti said. Then there's what Petitti described as ``a blatant advertisement in the middle of my wedding tape'' _ a camera shot of an easel holding a sign for Fred Fox Studios. Worst of all, he said, was the tendency of the cameraman to focus on the guests' posteriors while filming the dancers. Those shots, since replayed several times to guests, have gotten less-than-favorable reactions. ``Twenty years from now, I won't know whose rear ends those are,'' Petitti moaned.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Lithuania
DOC.TEXT: Through half a century of international oblivion, Lithuania has maintained a diplomatic presence in the United States through a legation headquartered about 15 blocks up the street from the Soviet Embassy. The legation is headed by Dr. Stasys Lozoraitis Jr., the son of the man who took up the lonely post of keeping alive the diplomatic flame of a nation that ceased to exist independently. It is here that the Lithuanian parliament voted Friday to transfer its power in the event of an emergency. There was no asnwer at the legation Friday night, and there is no telephone listed in the Washington area for Lozoraitis. In a profile of the legation this month, The Wall Street Journal quoted a message Lithuania's last foreign minister sent to his diplomats 50 years ago: ``If catastrophe strikes, please consider Stasys Lozoraitis chief of our nation's diplomatic corps.'' The senior Lozoraitis held that post until he died four years ago at 88. On top of having to function in a world that extends it no formal diplomatic recognition, the Lithuanian legation has had to pay its bills without a government to bankroll the operation. This has been done from the gold reserves transferred out of Lithuania to Sweden when the Soviet Union took over in 1940, the Journal reported.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Captain Buzzes Hometown
DOC.TEXT: An Air Force captain flying a classified mission dipped his Boeing 707 to 1,500 feet and buzzed his old neighborhood to say hello to mom. The Air Force was not amused. Capt. Grant Phifer said Thursday he flew for about 15 minutes at 1,500 feet while on a coast-to-coast trip Wednesday so that he could see Pine Bluff High School, the town's airport and his mother's house. ``(The) main reason I did it is because of my mom being there and with me over 2,500 miles away, the flight was the closest she can come to seeing me,'' Phifer told the Pine Bluff Commercial in a telephone interview from California. Sgt. Jim Harper, a public information officer at Little Rock Air Force Base, said Phifer's flight from Andrews Air Force Base, Md., to McClellan Air Force Base at Sacramento, Calif., was dangerous and under investigation by personnel at McClellan. ``He knows better, especially at that level,'' Harper said. ``Any pilot is risking revocation of his license and possible jail time by doing what he did.'' The Air Force said it was looking into the matter. But Phifer said his conscience is clear. ``I violated no Air Force regulations and I wouldn't have done it if I was,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Reagan, During Fund-Raising Trip to Boston, Comments on Iran-Contra
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan says he can't remember details of the Iran-Contra affair because he met with so many people during his eight years in office. In Boston on Thursday to raise money for a cancer institute, Reagan said his meetings with more than 400 heads of state contributed to his memory lapses in his videotaped testimony in the Iran-Contra trial of John Poindexter. ``I had to say `I don't remember' so many times,'' Reagan told reporters. ``How do you go back and remember who you met on a certain day?'' Responding to the trial judge's ruling Thursday that he did not have to turn over parts of his personal diaries as evidence, Reagan said taking away the tradition of executive privilege might ``invade'' the presidency. Lawyers for Poindexter, the former national security adviser, had argued they needed the diaries because Reagan could not recall many details of Iran-Contra, including when he learned of a November 1985 shipment of missiles to Iran. On Thursday during the trial in Washington, Poindexter's lawyers finished showing nearly eight hours of Reagan's videotaped testimony. Reagan was in Boston to visit the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute and attend a fund-raiser for the institute's Jimmy Fund. During a ceremony at the institute, the former president was presented with a glass sculpture and a baseball cap by cancer patients Ashley Fitzgerald, 5, and Julie Green, 15. Other children suffering from cancer also gave the Reagan a poster with all their names emblazoned on it. ``I was able to tell them it's going to be hung in the presidential library,'' Reagan told reporters after his tour. Green, a straight-A high school sophomore who has Hodgkin's disease, said she just found out a week ago that she was going to meet Reagan _ so she didn't have time to get excited. ``I'm really amazed they called me,'' she said. ``I really like President Reagan. I feel very lucky.'' After meeting the children, Reagan was whisked to a Jimmy Fund benefit. At the banquet, Boston Mayor Raymond Flynn presented the former president with jellybeans on behalf of the city, forsaking the traditional Revere Bowl or Lantern of Liberty. ``We just knew that wouldn't be appropriate enough,'' Flynn said.

DOC.HEAD: Fire That Threatened Rare Monkeys is Now Under Control
DOC.TEXT: Helicopters carrying water-filled ``Bambi buckets'' have helped officials control a fire that threatened to destroy the world's first project to restore rare captive monkeys to the wild in Brazil. ``We were probably days away from the extinction of a species,'' said Benjamin Beck, associate director of the National Zoo in Washington, D.C. The fire was fought with two helicopters belonging to the Brazilian federal police. When a call came to Washington alerting Beck to the fire, the Friends of the National Zoo and Wildlife Preservation Trust of Philadelphia immediately raised $6,000 to send two ``Bambi buckets'' to the reserve, Beck said Thursday. ``From the time the request came to me, until they were in use in Brazil, was less than 72 hours,'' he said. A Bambi bucket, Beck explained, is a large vessel that hangs beneath the helicopter and allows the aircraft to dip into bodies of water, without landing, and drop the water on the fire. ``The fire is, we feel, under control, but it's still burning deep in turf in the swamps,'' Beck said. Enough organic matter and oxygen are available to keep the fire smouldering, he said, adding: ``If it gets dry and windy, it can break out at any time.'' The National Zoo has been coordinating a project to breed the highly endangered golden lion tamarins and return them to the Poco das Antas reserve in Brazil, about 75 miles northeast of Rio de Janeiro. The fire broke out about Feb. 2 at Poco das Antas, home to about 400 tamarins. They make up about 80 percent of the remaining wild population, Beck said. Sonia Rigueira of Conservation International in Washington said the fire burned about a week. ``They lost control for a while, and then they got the helicopters,'' she said in a telephone interview from Brazil. The fire was confined to the grassy areas that make up about half of the reserve, she said. The other half _ mature forest where the tamarins live _ was undisturbed, she said. ``Had the fire progressed into the mature forest, we would have seen this species come to extinction,'' said Beck. The golden lion tamarin is a cat-size primate with a leonine mane and bright, burnt-orange fur. It is native to Brazil's Atlantic coastal forest, which once covered Brazil's eastern flank but is now reduced to patches comprising only a few percent of its original size. ``It is a beautiful and interesting primate,'' Beck said. ``But probably more important is, if it can survive, virtually the entire ecosystem can survive.'' The golden lion tamarin is what biologists call a flagship species. Its survival depends on the health of the ecosystem it lives in. Saving the golden lion tamarin is inextricably linked with saving what remains of the Atlantic coastal forest, a unique region brimming with plants and animals that live nowhere else on Earth, Beck said. The animals and the reserve could not have been saved without the effort by Brazil, Beck said. ``We ought to give credit to a tremendous response by Brazilian authorities,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: 50 Reported Killed in Rebel Attack on Burmese Town
DOC.TEXT: About 300 Mon guerrillas attacked a southern town of Ye, fighting government troops for six hours in a battle in which 50 people were killed, a state-controlled newspaper said today. Rebels of the New Mon State Party attacked the town of Ye, about 200 miles southeast of Rangoon early Thursday, the Working People's Daily said. It said they retreated six hours later after 43 of them were killed. Four Burmese soldiers and three civilians, including two women and a child were also killed, the paper said. Fourteen Burmese troops and 16 civilians were wounded, the report said. There was no independent confirmation of the attack or the casualties. Western diplomats in Rangoon and other observers consider many reports in the state press exaggerated. The Mon are one of several minority ethnic groups that have fought for decades against central control. In the past 18 months, Rangoon has stepped up its campaign to drive the rebels from their bases along the Thai border.

DOC.HEAD: Famine Deepens in Ethiopia, Sudan
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: A new migration of the damned has begun in the Horn of Africa. Once again, as so often in the past, drought and war have forced tens of thousands of innocent men, women and children from their homes in Ethiopia and Sudan in a desperate search for food. Many will not find it. As the United Nations and private agencies struggle to begin long-delayed relief operations, more and more people are joining the exodus from war-torn villages and parched farms. The United Nations says more than 4 million people are at risk of starvation in northern Ethiopia alone. At least half a million more face the same fate in southern Sudan. Those figures far exceed the nearly 1 million who perished in Ethiopia's famine of 1984-85. ``We could be looking at a repeat of that,'' said a relief agency official in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia's capital. ``If we can't break the logjam soon, people are going to start dying in numbers.'' The official, like many others involved in negotiations to move food through government and insurgent military lines, would not speak for attribution. The crisis is getting high-level attention. In Washington, it was disclosed recently that Secretary of State James A. Baker III had written Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze about the problem. Baker sought a joint U.S.-Soviet effort to obtain a cease-fire between the Addis Ababa government and two insurgent armies. Many aid officials see that as an essential first step in ensuring the free passage of food to the needy in northern Ethiopia and ending the recurrent problem of famine. On Wednesday, Ethiopia renewed preliminary talks with one of the rebel groups in Rome and said it would meet with the other insurgent group in Nairobi next month. Meanwhile, a truck convoy carrying 110 tons of food was allowed to pass safely through the contested area between a government-held provincial capital and a rebel-controlled town in northern Ethiopia at midweek. The first convoy in the relief operation, managed by a consortium of Ethiopian church groups and supplied by American and Western European donors, was described as a trial run, but officials were elated. Still, they acknowledged they would at best be able to reach no more than 1 million people in Tigre and Wollo provinces and, possibly, the extreme southern part of Eritrea _ or about a fourth of those in need. The Tigre People's Liberation Front, with whom the government reopened talks in Rome this week, has controlled Tigre and much of neighboring Wollo and Gondor provinces since last year. The United Nations began appealing last year for 1.1 million tons of food, most of which it hoped to ship to Ethiopia's Red Sea port of Massawa for further distribution inland. But just as the first shipments were arriving in February, the largest of the two insurgent groups, the Eritrean People's Liberation Front, broke a nearly yearlong cease-fire and attacked government troops along a 200-mile front. Within three days the rebels claimed the capture of Massawa. The government, which has never acknowledged Massawa's fall, is reliably reported to have retaliated with aerial and artillery bombardments that destroyed tons of donated grain, killed dozens of civilians and may have ruined port facilities. The fighting has effectively closed the port and the only road inland to the provincial capital of Asmara, which is still held by the government. U.N. and other aid officials say more than 30,000 people already have made the long, dangerous trek from their homes in northern Ethiopia into neighboring Sudan or to government-held areas in Ethiopia's Eritrea province. ``We can't really count all those already on the move, because we don't have access to many areas,'' the relief official in Addis Ababa said. ``We do know this: It's bad and getting worse.'' It was hoped that adequate food distribution throughout the region this year would prevent the mass migrations that occurred in 1984-85, when hundreds of thousands of people trekked to ill-prepared feeding centers. Malnourished and weak, many died en route. Of those who made it, more died of disease caused by overcrowding than starvation. To the west of Ethiopia, in Sudan, a similar situation exists. There, additional tens of thousands have been displaced in recent months by a 7-year-old civil war that already has killed an estimated 500,000 unarmed civilians. A U.N.-sponsored relief effort was credited with savings thousands of people from starvation in southern Sudan last year, and a second phase of the project, known as Operation Lifeline Sudan, is scheduled to start next month. But on Tuesday, the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army objected to the U.N. operation, saying its plan for distributing food favored the government. Without specifically saying so, the rebels indicated they may try to halt the operation unless the plan is altered.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Richard Nixon's longtime friend Charles ``Bebe'' Rebozo said the president laughed when he first heard of the break-in at the Watergate headquarters of the Democratic Party. Rebozo, who owns the Key Biscayne Bank, gave a rare interview to The Miami Herald to help promote a benefit he and Nixon are holding for the Boys Club. He said Nixon was visiting him at his Key Biscayne home in June 1972 when they first heard news of the incident that, two years later, led the president to resign in disgrace. ``We were swimming at Key Biscayne in front of my house,'' Rebozo said in the interview published Thursday. ``They came out and told him. He said, `What in God's name were they doing there?''' Then, said Rebozo, ``We laughed and forgot about it.'' The banker said the subsequent scandal, in which he was also investigated, was a ``terrible experience,'' but seeing Nixon deal with the crisis helped him. ``The truth of the matter is, I don't think I could have taken it had I not seen what he was taking, and how he was surviving,'' Rebozo said.

``Batman'' and ``Beetlejuice'' director Tim Burton is being deliberately vague about his latest project _ ``Edward Scissorhands,'' a suburban fantasy film about a man created with shears of metal for fingers. ``It's very different,'' Burton said. ``We're going to sort of make it up as we go along.'' Burton and stars Johnny Depp, Dianne Wiest and Winona Ryder arrived here Thursday to start three months of production on the film, scheduled for Christmas release. According to 20th Century Fox, ``Scissorhands'' is about a man who was created, not born. He was given everything he needed to lead a full life, except one thing: His inventor's untimely death left Edward with sharp shears of metal where his fingers should have been. He lives in seclusion until he is discovered by an earnest Avon lady and his life changes forever. Preparations for filming have been made in a Tampa neighborhood, where several homes have been painted garish colors to create a surreal suburban atmosphere.

Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca received an unexpected welcome when he visited an alternative school aimed at salvaging school dropouts _ a rendition of the ``Iacocca Rap.'' ``Lee Iacocca, for all you do, we dedicate this rap to you,'' Aaron Bolton, 20, began when Iacocca visited Rich's Academy, based in downtown Rich's Department Store, on Thursday. Bolton, with the help of a friend who kicked out a drumbeat by using his mouth as a percussion instrument, began swaying to the beat as he rapped for a wide-eyed Iacocca: ``He left Ford Motor Company with a plan on the double. ``Became Chrysler's CEO, found out they were in trouble. ``He designed a new automobile, they called the `K.' ``His new car and charming wit surely saved the day.'' Iacocca toured the alternative school, formed in 1981, to see if he could use it as a model for similar schools through the Iacocca Institute, the philanthropic arm of Chrysler housed at Lehigh University, his alma mater. Iacocca exhorted about 80 students to find a subject they like and to stay with it. ``It's that basic,'' he said. ``I don't know what else to tell you.''

Singer Mick Jagger said there's nothing wrong with the Rolling Stones taking commercial sponsorship for their first European tour in eight years because, ``We are all in a business in one way or another.'' Jagger spoke at a news conference Thursday announcing the 12-country tour. Asked why the tour needed the sponsorship of a U.S. beer company, Jagger told reporters: ``We are all in a business in one way or another. We've got sponsorship and you have got advertising. I don't even remember a time when it was amateur.'' The tour starts in the Netherlands May 18 and includes dates in Austria, Britain, Denmark, France, Ireland, Italy, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden and West Germany. Rolling Stones publicist Bernard Doherty said more than 150,000 tickets were sold within hours for two London concerts at Wembley Stadium, and a third Wembley show was being organized to meet demand. He said negotiations were under way to end the tour with a concert in Moscow in August, but agreement had not yet been reached.

The Rev. Daniel Berrigan must pay a $500 fine for contempt of court by Monday and cannot put off payment while he appeals the citation, a federal judge said. The 68-year-old anti-war activist was among 24 people convicted of disruption in a federal building during a Dec. 1 sit-in protesting U.S. military aid to El Salvador. U.S. District Judge Peter Beer found Berrigan in contempt of court and fined him $500 on Feb. 8 for failing to appear for his arraignment Dec. 14. Attorney Bill Quigley of New Orleans said the fine should be put off pending an appeal. Beer rejected that argument Wednesday. ``It's conceivable that Father Berrigan will refuse to pay and face another jail term,'' Quigley said Thursday. Or, he said, Berrigan might let his supporters pay the fine.

DOC.HEAD: Health Officials Stumped by Supplement's Link to Blood Disorder
DOC.TEXT: After receiving reports of more than 1,400 cases of a rare and sometimes fatal blood disorder, federal health officials are still puzzled by its connection to the dietary supplement L-tryptophan. They have found no contaminant or bad batch of raw material, no single brand that seems to be the culprit. ``We have analyzed hundreds of products, but we have not been able to single out any brand, manufacturer or supplier that would explain why people are getting sick from taking this stuff,'' said Chris Lecos, a spokesman for the Food and Drug Administration. Even so, the FDA announced Thursday that it was expanding its recall of L-tryptophan supplements to include products that contain even small amounts of it. The initial recall, announced last Nov. 17, was for supplements in which L-tryptophan was the sole or major component and would provide a daily intake of more than 100 milligrams. But now at least one case has been reported in which the person developed the newly recognized blood disorder after taking less than 100 milligrams a day. The disorder is called eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome, or EMS. So far, 1,411 cases have been reported in all states, including 19 deaths. EMS is marked by severe muscle and joint pain, breathing difficulties, swelling of the arms and legs, skin rash, fatigue, cough and sometimes fever. In some cases, victims show signs of congestive heart failure or develop a condition that causes progressive weakness and sometimes leads to paralysis. L-tryptophan, an amino acid, has been around for many years and occurs naturally in some foods, including milk, beef, turkey and beans. L-tryptophan supplements are usually sold over the counter in health food, drug and grocery stores under different brand names. They are taken for insomnia, appetite control, depression, premenstrual syndrome, stress reduction and other problems. ``There are literally hundreds of brands involved here with various levels of L-tryptophan in them,'' the FDA's Lecos said. In a typical recall, the FDA knows who made the product, how much was produced and where and when it was distributed. ``But here's a situation where the only unequivocal fact is that people who come down with EMS are people taking L-tryptophan before they became ill,'' he said. ``As our investigation has continued, we have discovered that many of these people were taking not just one brand, but six or more brands.'' The expanded recall applies to all L-tryptophan products in tablet, capsule, caplet, powdered or liquid form, as well multi-ingredient, non-protein supplements that contain L-tryptophan, the FDA said. The only products containing L-tryptophan not being recalled are some protein supplements, infant formulas and special dietary foods, intravenous and oral solutions, in which small amounts of L-tryptophan are needed for nutrition fortification, the FDA said. No cases of EMS have been linked to any of those uses, the agency said. However, it was not clear whether certain products like diet and body-building supplements containing L-tryptophan would have to be recalled. Some of these are formulated according to FDA regulations, but others are not and may contain large amounts of it. The FDA said it would issue a clarification further defining what is subject to the recall. L-tryptophan is not an FDA-approved drug ingredient, so it cannot be included in any medications, prescription or over the counter. The Council for Responsible Nutrition, which represents companies that make nutritional supplements, said virtually all of its member companies that make L-tryptophan products have removed all brands and dosage forms from their distribution channels and have notified retailers.

DOC.HEAD: No Veto Override Here _ Executive Order Dooms Veggies
DOC.TEXT: Read his lips: no more broccoli. George Bush on Thursday demonstrated just how far presidential power can go when he insisted he would just say no to vegetables. ``I'm president of the United States and I'm not going to eat any more broccoli!'' Bush proclaimed, resolving to stand fast against his wife's mealtime entreaties. Broccoli-booster Barbara Bush tried to put a good face on her husband's rebellion. Asked what example the 65-year-old president was setting for America's children, the first lady replied crisply: ``He ate broccoli until he was 60. Tell them to eat it until they're 60.'' She said the president's 88-year-old mother, Dorothy Walker Bush, still eats her broccoli. Bush's taste in food runs to pork rinds, olives, taco salads and Tabasco sauce. He set some new culinary standards in December when he was spotted crunching bits of Butterfingers candy bars into oat bran. Bush's bravado has not gone unanswered by the broccoli industry. California growers are shipping 10 tons of the vegetable to soup kitchens and shelters in the nation's capital. Bush, accused at times of indecisiveness, was bold about broccoli. ``I do not like broccoli and I haven't liked it since I was a little kid and my mother made me eat it and I'm president of the United States and I'm not going to eat any more broccoli,'' Bush declared at the end of an alfresco news conference. And he said that was his last word on the subject. ``There are truckloads of broccoli at this very minute descending on Washington. My family is divided,'' he acknowledged. ``For the broccoli vote out there: Barbara loves broccoli. She has tried to make me eat it. She eats it all the time herself,'' Bush said. ``So she can go out and meet the caravan of broccoli that's coming in.'' The broccoli brouhaha erupted when a news magazine reported Bush had banned the vegetable from Air Force One. The president said he simply informed stewards, ``Don't you dare bring me another sprig!''

DOC.HEAD: How Will It Play in Lima?
With PM-Bush-Broccoli
DOC.TEXT: This may sound like a corny caper, but President Bush is giving broccoli the kohlrabi shoulder. He's often bean told to eat vegetables. But no longer will meekly respond: mustard I? I carrot stand it, he finally said of the cruciferous greenery. It makes me artichoke, lettuce have it no more. Let's cauliflower a vegetable. And he isn't sorrel about the decision. It didn't take long for word to leek out that the president would turnip his nose at veggies. The news left the president with eggplant on his face as far as farmers were concerned. The growers didn't take an endive, though, and tomato story worse, they've stalked the president and given him lots of truffle. They are exercising freedom of spinach to defend their produce. They beet it to the phones and called charitable groups in Washington, offering to donate 10 tons of broccoli to the poor. It's their way to protest at the presidential parsnip-ishness. That's okra with us, said the charities. They never look a gift horseradish in the mouth. Wilt that end the kale. It remains to pea seen. It's the kind of story that, if not nipped in the bud, can just go onion and onion.

DOC.HEAD: Italy Stops Auction of Mussolini Papers
DOC.TEXT: Auctioneers say the Italian government has stopped them from selling papers connected with dictator Benito Mussolini. ``The Italian government told us that under a law of 1943 all material owned by Mussolini's National Fascist Party belonged to the government, so we withdrew the 10 lots of Mussolini papers'' from a sale Thursday, said Nina Drummond, a spokeswoman for the Phillips auction house. The most important of the documents was the original telegram summoning Mussolini to Rome to form a government in 1922. The telegram, signed by an aide of King Victor Emmanuel III, had been expected to sell for up to $15,900. The telegram gave Mussolini power that he retained until his support dwindled during World War II and he was overthrown in July 1943. Resistance fighters killed him in April 1945. ``What puzzled us was that some of the material was sold at Sotheby's in 1982 and apparently the Italian authorities took no action at that time,'' Ms. Drummond said. Leonardo Visconti, press attache at the Italian Embassy, said authorities in Rome were able to act because of the publicity surrounding the Phillips sale. ``We are taking legal steps to reclaim this material from Phillips,'' he said. Other material withdrawn from the sale included the autographed draft of a speech by Mussolini in 1925 and his identity card from 1913. Phillips did not identify the owners nor discuss how the material ended in private hands. ``I think some or all of it was gathered up in the chaos of the last months of the war,'' Ms. Drummond said.

DOC.HEAD: Handicapped Hail Rule Making it Easier to Take the Bus
DOC.TEXT: Disability-rights groups are praising a Bush administration decision to require federally aided bus lines to buy only buses accessible to wheelchairs and provide door-to-door service for the handicapped. The Transportation Department announced a tentative rule Thursday that matches key provisions of legislation that the advocacy groups have been trying to urge through Congress with protest action. More than 150 people were arrested in Washington during demonstrations for the bill last week. Dennis Kouba, a spokesman for the American Public Transit Association, said most bus operators already are purchasing only vehicles equipped with lifts or other devices. But he said officials were assessing other provisions of the proposed rule. Operators currently have a choice of either accessible buses or special door-to-door service to serve hundreds of thousands of people who have difficulty taking ordinary buses. Nearly all public transit systems receive some federal funding. Timothy Cook, spokesman for the National Disability Action Center, said the rule would give handicapped Americans ``everything they have been fighting for.'' ``My clients are very, very pleased. They will finally get access to services they need to get going,'' said Cook, whose organization has been involved in litigation on behalf of the handicapped. Wade Blank, head of Americans Disabled for Accessible Public Transportation, said he was ``delighted that the administration finally has followed through on its commitment to persons with disabilities.'' The rule is expected to become law in September after a period for public comment that could lead to some changes in its provisions. Requiring both access and special services for all systems is expected to ``increase significantly the amount and quality of service available to persons with disabilities,'' the Transportation Department announcement said. ``The Bush administration is committed to policies that will ensure that people with disabilities have the opportunities available to other persons to use our mass transit system,'' said Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner. Announcement of the proposed rule met the requirements of a Philadelphia federal court order that required the department to examine and change existing regulations but did not mandate what the changes should be. The order came in a suit by more than a dozen disability-rights groups. The department is asking for comment on several options for exempting transit companies that would find it too costly to provide special services for the handicapped, but no exemptions would be allowed for accessibility equipment on all new buses. The rule does not require that wheelchair lifts or other devices be retrofitted onto existing buses, but it would apply to all new and refurbished buses and require operators to attempt to buy only used buses with such equipment if available. Estimates of the number of Americans who use wheelchairs range from 750,000 to 1.5 million.

DOC.HEAD: Brief Look at Recent Events in Lithuania
With PM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a glance at events in Lithuania the past month leading up to and following the republic's declaration of independence from Moscow:

Feb. 25 _ Lithuanians vote in local elections, giving an overwhelming victory to the Sajudis political movement and others seeking independence from Moscow. March 10 _ After hurried runoff elections, the republic's new Supreme Soviet legislature meets in Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital. March 11 _ The legislature elects the first non-Communist president of a Soviet republic, music professor Vytautus Landsbergis. It changes the republic's name and seal, and declares complete independence from Moscow. March 12 _ The Congress of People's Deputies national parliament meets in Moscow, and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev reports that the situation in Lithuania is ``alarming.'' Fellow Communist Party Politburo member Yegor K. Ligachev promises the Kremlin will not use force. March 13 _ Gorbachev declares Lithuania's move ``illegal and invalid.'' Lithuanian legislators declare they are taking part in the Congress as observers only. March 15 _ Gorbachev is elected the Soviet Union's first executive president and is given authority by the Congress to deal with the dispute with Lithuania. March 16 _ Gorbachev, in a telegram to Landsbergis, gives Lithuania three days to begin returning to the Soviet fold. March 17 _ Lithuania tells Gorbachev he no longer has authority in the republic. March 19 _ Gorbachev warns Lithuania will not be allowed to set up customs points, introduce its own currency or take over factories. March 21 _ Lithuania protests Soviet military exercises in the republic. Gorbachev, in a decree, gives Lithuanians seven days to turn in any firearms they own. March 22 _ Soviet armor rumbles through Vilnius in a show of force. Gorbachev demands Lithuania stop signing up its own volunteer force. Lithuania appeals for worldwide support.

DOC.HEAD: Brief History of Lithuania
With PM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Following is a brief chronology of events in Lithuania: 1795-1915 _ Lithuania is part of Czarist Russia. 1915-1918 _ During World War I, Lithuania is occupied by the German army. 1918 _ In December, Lithuania is declared a Soviet republic. 1919 _ The Soviet government is overthrown by Polish, German and nationalist Lithuanian forces and a democratic republic is established. 1939 _ Secret protocol between Germany and the Soviet Union cedes the greater part of Lithuania to the Soviet Union. 1940 _ Soviet Union issues ultimatum demanding formation of a government acceptable to the Kremlin. An assembly applies for admission to Soviet Union and Lithuania is incorporated into Soviet Union by decree of the Supreme Soviet on Aug. 3. Soviet forces carry out deportations and executions of Lithuanians they consider enemies. 1945 _ World War II ends with Lithuania once more in Soviet hands, after having been occupied by Nazi Germany. Another wave of deportations is carried out involving Lithuanians accused of collaborating with the Nazis. Guerrilla resistance to Soviet power continues for several years. 1988 _ The political movement Sajudis emerges as a political force. 1989 _ Sajudis calls for independence. In March, candidates supported by Sajudis win elections to the national Congress of People's Deputies. In December, the Supreme Soviet ends the Communist Party's monopoly on power. Lithuania's Communist Party breaks away from the central Communist Party and breaks into two factions, one of them loyal to the Kremlin. 1990 _ President Mikhail S. Gorbachev visits the republic in January in an effort to persuade the Lithuanian party to reverse its decision to break free. FEBRUARY _ Sajudis wins a majority in elections for Lithuania's Supreme Soviet. MARCH _ The Supreme Soviet declares Lithuania independent, changes its name to the Republic of Lithuania and renames the legislature the Supreme Council. The Congress of People's Deputies convenes to strenghen Gorbachev's presidential powers. Using his new powers, Gorbachev decrees that Lithuania may not open its own customs posts, take over factories owned by Moscow ministries, or issue its own currency. He orders the confiscation of all Lithuanians' firearms and demands Lithuania stop signing up volunteers for a new volunteer force.

DOC.HEAD: Differences Remain Between U.S. and Poland on Unification Talks
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is refusing to give Poland a greater voice in talks on the reunification of Germany or to endorse Warsaw's demands for an early treaty guaranteeing its borders. ``I think we may have a nuance of difference here,'' Bush said Thursday after concluding talks with Polish Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki. After three days in Washington, Mazowiecki was heading to Chicago today after a speech at the National Press Club. Bush gave an upbeat assessment of their meeting, saying he assured Mazowiecki ``we see an important role for a free, democratic and independent Poland as a factor for stability in Europe in the future.'' Speaking at a news conference, the president said he sees no need for Soviet troops to be stationed in Poland or anywhere else in Eastern Europe _ ``and the sooner they get out of there, the better.'' Mazowiecki, however, has said he wants the Soviet troops to stay until issues of German reunification and the Polish border are resolved. Bush said Mazowiecki had not given him any assurances on the Soviet troop issue. Separately, Mazowiecki told reporters that his government is prepared to start talks ``that will eventually lead to total withdrawal'' of Soviet forces in Poland. Poland, fearing a reunified Germany might try to reclaim territory ceded to Poland, wants the United States to back its request that East and West Germany sign a treaty recognizing the current Polish borders before reunification talks get under way. Bush said such a treaty is ``a matter for the Polish prime minister to discuss with the leaders of Germany.'' ``They are very, very close now,'' he added. ``So let them sort it out.'' The president also praised West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl for recent statements supporting the current Polish border. He said Kohl had ``come a long way in his view'' since earlier remarks that the border question should be decided by a reunified Germany. Bush said Poland will have a voice at the reunification talks among the two Germanys and the four chief World War II victors _ the United States, the Soviet Union, France and Britain _ whenever issues related to Polish borders are raised. Poland wants a greater role in the talks, asking to be present whenever issues affecting its security were discussed. But Bush reiterated the limited role for Poland in the discussions, saying, ``We don't see this as the group that is going to determine the fate of all of Europe.'' Mazowiecki said that he was ``very pleased'' with his meeting with the president and that ``there are no problems between us'' on Bush's desire to see Soviet troops out of Eastern Europe. ``The only problem is to persuade both our German partners that it needs to be done swiftly and finally,'' Mazowiecki said.

DOC.HEAD: Juvenile Justice Nominee Headed for Senate Floor Action
DOC.TEXT: Conservative Robert Sweet's fight for confirmation as head of the government's juvenile justice program is headed for Senate action. Three of the eight Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee joined six Republicans as the panel voted 9-5 to send Sweet's nomination to the Senate floor for a final vote on confirmation. ``Objectivity won out over partisan politics,'' Sen. Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H., said following approval of the 52-year-old Sweet, a veteran of political turmoil at the Education Department in the Reagan administration. Humphrey said the margin in committee ``makes it likely the nomination will be confirmed on the floor, though I'm sure we can count on further opposition from left-wing groups, like the national teachers' unions.'' One of Sweet's chief Senate critics, Sen. John F. Kerry, D-Mass., wrote committee members on Wednesday, urging a vote against Sweet. He said a confirmation hearing three weeks ago showed the nominee's ``relative indifference to the programs and policies that are at the heart of juvenile justice and delinquency prevention.'' Kerry said Sweet's ``approach to juvenile justice is naive at best and in any case not congruent with the statutory requirements of the position to which he has been nominated.'' By law, the administrator of the Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention in the Justice Department must have experience in the juvenile justice field. The $70 million program distributes grants to state and local governments to help combat delinquency. Sweet says his background in education fulfills the requirement. He is a former high school teacher and textbook salesman and served as an Education Department official and White House education adviser. He also headed the New Hampshire affiliate of the Moral Majority, founded by the Rev. Jerry Falwell. ``Bob Sweet has devoted his entire life to working with youth and is well qualified to serve,'' Humphrey said. Some criticism appears to stem from fierce political infighting at the Education Department. Former Education Secretary Terrel Bell said in his memoirs, ``The Thirteenth Man,'' that conservative activists sought to control the department. He cited Sweet as one of them. Democrats who voted to send the nomination to the floor were Sens. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz.; Howell Heflin, D-Ala.; and Herb Kohl, D-Wis. They joined Sens. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C.; Orrin Hatch, R-Utah; Alan Simpson, R-Wyo.; Charles Grassley, R-Iowa; Arlen Specter, R-Pa.; and Humphrey. Opposing the nomination were committee Chairman Joseph Biden, D-Del.; and Sens. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass.; Howard M. Metzenbaum, D-Ohio; Paul Simon, D-Ill.; and Patrick Leahy, D-Vt.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Leader Says Filibuster Over Abortion Bill To End
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Senate giving final approval to compromise ending filibuster. Picks up 8th graf pvs. `Democratic Sen. ...'
DOC.TEXT: The Maryland Senate early Friday approved an agreement to end an eight-day anti-abortion filibuster by turning the emotional issue over to voters come November. Under the compromise, the Senate approved two bills, an abortion rights measure ratified by a 29-18 margin, and a more restrictive bill favored by abortion opponents, which won 24-23 approval. Both measures now go to the House of Delegates, where they are expected to receive quick attention. It is anticipated that at least one of the bills will be petitioned to referendum, giving voters the opportunity in November to select which they prefer. The abortion rights bill would become law unless rejected by voters. In that case the restrictive law would become law, unless it also was rejected by voters. House Speaker Clay Mitchell has said he would bring the House in on Saturday if the Senate passed a bill by Friday. The two measures, Senate President Mike Miller told the Senate, would present voters with ``a very, very clear choice. This is participatory democracy at its very best.'' But some abortion-rights supporters were not pleased. The compromise was merely a face-saving device to end the filibuster, said Sen. F. Vernon Boozer, a pro-choice Republican, and ``I don't think it's a good idea.'' ``I think the concept is ridiculous,'' agreed Patricia R. Sher, a Democrat. Democratic Sen. C. Bernard Fowler, who opposes abortion, characterized the agreement as ``a long roll of the dice.'' Anti-abortion forces took the gamble because ``we feel we may never have this opportunity again,'' Fowler said. ``We don't know that we can hold a filibuster together again next year.'' Abortion rights forces had been trying for a week to muster the 32 votes they needed to shut off the debate. They moved to within a vote of ending the debate Tuesday when they lost a cloture vote by a 31-16 margin. Thirty-two votes, or two-thirds of the 47-member Senate, are required to shut off debate. At stake in the battle was a measure that would allow unrestricted access to abortions until the point in a pregnancy when a fetus is able to survive outside the womb. After fetal viability, abortions could be performed to save the life of the mother or to protect her health. The pro-choice bill also also would require doctors to notify parents when their unmarried teen-age daughters seek an abortion. Anti-abortion forces thought the bill was too liberal. They insist that abortions after the fetus becomes viable should be restricted to those needed to save the life of the mother. The anti-abortion forces also wanted to limit abortions before fetal viability to cases of rape or incest or to protect the woman's health.

DOC.HEAD: Moderate Fat Reduction in Diet Can Reduce New Blocks In Arteries, Study Finds
DOC.TEXT: Even a small reduction in a person's dietary fat intake can mean a sharp drop in the risk of developing new clogs in the heart arteries, a study released today shows. Dr. David H. Blankenhorn, director of the Atheroslerosis Research Institute at the University of Southern California School of Medicine in Los Angeles, said the 82 middle-aged male heart bypass patients who were studied were ``all free-living citizens who selected their own diet.'' ``These were not really austere diets,'' he went on. ``The idea may be out there that you've really got to eat a restricted diet or lose weight. ... These guys didn't lose weight.'' He said all had diet counseling, adding, ``but some of them listened a little harder than others. The ones who reduced high-fat meats and milk and substituted low-fat meat and low-fat milk were the ones who didn't get new lesions.'' The two-year study was of men who had undergone heart bypass surgery and had been advised to reduce their total fat consumption to 26 percent of total calories _ including specified reductions in saturated fats, polyunsaturated fats and monounsaturated fats. In the typical American diet, fat accounts for 40 percent of total calories consumed. The results of the study were reported in today's Journal of the American Medical Association. Subjects underwent angiograms, dye-enhanced X-rays of the heart, before and after the two-year period, during which they were quizzed semi-monthly about all the food they'd eaten in the previous 24 hours. After two years, 18 of the men had developed new fatty deposits in their coronary arteries, and 64 men had not. ``The question is why? What's the difference between these two groups?'' said Dr. Linda Cashin-Hemphill, an assistant USC professor and a colleague of Blankenhorn's. Dietary analysis revealed that men who were free of new fatty deposits, or lesions, had reduced their total fat consumption, while the men who had developed new lesions had increased total fat consumption. ``Knowing that polyunsaturated fats decrease cholesterol, instead of decreasing total fat, they (men with new lesions) increased polyunsaturated fats _ not a good idea,'' Ms. Cashin-Hemphill said in a telephone interview. Excess blood cholesterol is one of the three main modifiable traits associated with increased risk of developing heart disease. The others are high blood pressure and smoking. ``The bottom line of the study is that total fats should be reduced,'' Ms. Hemphill said. The men who were free of new lesions at the study's end had begun with a mean total fat intake of 32.9 percent of calories consumed. They lowered their total fat to 27.5 percent of calories consumed, the researchers said. In contrast, the men who developed new lesions had started at a fat intake of 31.1 percent of calories consumed and went up to 34.1 percent, the researchers reported. Consumption of saturated fats _ found in high-fat meats and dairy products as well as in tropical oils _ had gone down in both groups, but was reduced more in the group with no new lesions, the researchers found. Consumption of polyunsaturated fats in both groups had gone up, but consumption in the group with new lesions had gone up more than twice as much as the other group. Dr. Dean Ornish, director of the Preventive Medicine Research Institute at the University of California at San Francisco School of Medicine, said, ``This is an important study, because it demonstrates that even moderate changes in diet can help prevent the formation of coronary artery blockages.'' Previous research has shown that cholesterol-lowering drugs are effective in preventing existing lesions from growing, but this is the first study showing that diet alone can prevent formation of new lesions, the authors said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Higher in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 30,372.16, up 528.82, or 1.77 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Abrupt Halt in Use of Beta Blockers Can Bring on Heart Attacks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Spelling of `Psaty' in 3rd graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: High blood pressure patients taking medications known as beta blockers temporarily increase their risk of suffering heart pain or heart attack if they abruptly stop taking the medication, a study says. The research published in today's edition of the Journal of the American Medical Association said the increased risk extends even to patients with no history of heart disease. Patients who suddenly withdrew from the beta blockers showed a temporary four-fold increase in risk, according to the study by Dr. Bruce M. Psaty and colleagues at the University of Washington in Seattle. ``If patients need to withdraw from use of beta blockers, they should probably taper the dosage gradually over a period of several weeks,'' the authors said. Beta blockers act to relieve stress on the heart, lungs and blood vessels by blocking adrenaline from overstimulated nerves supplying those tissues. Beta blockers are prescribed for problems with a wide range of severity. They are given to relieve high blood pressure in patients with no history of heart trouble; to ease problems linked to definite heart disease, such as heart pain and abnormal rhythms; and to ward off second heart attacks. Though it was known that patients who abruptly stop taking beta blockers could experience a sudden return of their symptoms, patients who take the drugs only for high blood pressure and who have no known heart disease had been considered at low risk for heart problems, the authors said. They based their conclusion on a study of 248 cases of new heart problems from 1982 through 1984 among people enrolled in a Washington state health-maintenance organization. Records on more than 700 other enrollees without heart problems but with high blood pressure were used for comparison. All of the patients had been taking beta blockers: propranolol hydrochloride, marketed generically and as Inderal; nadolol, marketed as Corgard and Corzide; metoprolol tartrate, marketed as Lopressor; and atenolol, marketed as Tenoretic and Tenormin. The report focused on ``recent stoppers,'' defined by the authors as regular beta-blocker users who did not fill their prescriptions soon enough to be regarded as complying with dosage instructions to an 80 percent level. Eleven patients were identified as recent stoppers, based on pharmacy records. Of the 11, four were from the group with no heart problems, and seven from the group with new heart problems. One of the seven suffered from heart pain, three had non-fatal heart attacks and three had fatal heart attacks, the researchers said. The eleven had taken beta blockers for an average of 2.9 years, they said. Researchers estimated that the 11 patients stopped taking their medication about 12 days before they were admitted to the hospital or died.

DOC.HEAD: Nunn Sees Gaps in Defense Budget
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's $307 billion defense budget contains several major gaps in assessing the overall threat to the West and shaping military strategy, says the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee. But Defense Secretary Dick Cheney urged critics to examine what the Pentagon is doing to restructure U.S. forces, contending that his department had done a ``complete rethinking of missions and strategy.'' In a rhetorical skirmish between two of the leading players in the battle over the defense budget, Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., said Thursday that if the Pentagon wants to stay credible, it must fill the large holes in the spending blueprint. ``I hope these blanks will be filled in by the Defense Department, but the Congress will have to act if the Defense Department doesn't,'' the Armed Services chairman said in a speech on the Senate floor. Nunn cited at least five ``big blanks'' in Bush's budget: the absence of an assessment of the threat to U.S. national security, a military strategy in response to the threat, the future size of the armed forces, how to meet required budget cuts and the need for major weapons. Bush's budget, he said, is based on a 1988 threat and a 1988 strategy. ``Essentially, the administration took the level of spending and programs for fiscal year 1991 that was developed back in 1988 and reduced it for fiscal reasons,'' Nunn said. ``They have not adjusted the underlying assumptions about threat and strategy.'' But in a speech to the National Press Club, Cheney accused lawmakers of offering ``complaints instead of solutions.'' Cheney prefaced his speech by noting that Nunn had just spoken on Capitol Hill but said his comments should not be construed as being directed at the senator. The defense secretary said he has told the military to take into account the assumptions that Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev will be ``at least partially successful'' in domestic reforms. In addition, he said, planners should assume that the superpowers will implement successful arms control agreements in conventional and strategic forces; that all Soviet forces have withdrawn from Eastern Europe and that democratically elected, non-communist governments are in their place. While such assumptions are ``a rosy scenario,'' Cheney said, he has used them to design the defense budget from now through 1997, and to help the service chiefs plan for the mid-1990s. Nunn said he found ``fragmentary answers'' from the administration to the question of what effect the push for democracy in Eastern Europe and the changes in the Soviet Union will have on the traditional threats to U.S. security. ``We should expect that the changes in the threat would be more apparent in the Defense Department's budget request,'' Nunn said. The budget for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 includes more than $16 billion for five major weapons programs _ the B-2 stealth bomber, the C-17 transport plane, the Advanced Tactical Fighter, the Advanced Tactical Aircraft and the Strategic Defense Initiative. Cheney said those programs are being reviewed and the results will be ready in time for Congress' budget process. Elsewhere on Capitol Hill, a senior Pentagon official refused to rule out a possible trade of the rail-garrison MX nuclear missile for the Soviet's SS-24 missile as part of the negotiations to reduce strategic weapons. ``This is obviously a serious proposal advanced by serious people and needs to be given serious consideration,'' Stephen Hadley, assistant secretary of defense for international security policy, told a House Armed Services Committee policy panel. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., the committee chairman, criticized the administration's current proposal in U.S.-Soviet talks to reduce strategic arms for legitimizing the B-2 bomber and two land-based, nuclear missile systems. Aspin and several other committee members said chances were slim that Congress will approve the full fleet of 132 B-2 bombers and future funds for the single-warhead Midgetman and the multiple-warhead MX missile. ``We're not going to buy 132 and I maintain it's not a responsible position for the U.S. government to pursue arms control based on buying 132,'' said Rep. John Kasich, R-Ohio, an opponent of the B-2 bomber. ``I can't tell you how many we're going to buy, I can't tell you the plan's going to work.''

DOC.HEAD: Discovery Astronauts Excited to Launch Hubble Space Telescope
DOC.TEXT: The commander of the upcoming Discovery shuttle mission says the Hubble Space Telescope his crew will put into orbit should help scientists unlock mysteries about the heavens. The powerful $1.5 billion astronomical observatory, the most expensive unmanned spacecraft ever built, will be put in orbit 370 miles above the Earth where it can provide scientists a clearer view of space because it will be unhindered by atmospheric distortion. If all goes according to plan, Hubble will be deployed a day after Discovery and its five crew members blast into space from Cape Canaveral, Fla., on April 12. ``We're getting very excited,'' Discovery commander Loren J. Shriver said Thursday at the crew's final news conference before the mission. ``We've been training for a long time. This is a major milestone ... We're glad to be finally this close to launch.'' The 25,000-pound, 43-foot-long telescope originally was scheduled for launch in late 1983 but technical problems postponed liftoff until 1986. The Challenger accident on Jan. 28, 1986, delayed the mission until 1989, and concern over the shuttle's solid rocket boosters pushed it back yet again. It has been a long wait for the scientists waiting to use the telescope. ``They're beaming with pride at the prospect of finally getting the space telescope that they've worked with for so long ... to finally see it getting so close and producing results in the near future,'' said Shriver, an Air Force colonel commanding his first shuttle flight. Hubble will allow astronomers to study stars and galaxies so distant that their light has been traveling toward Earth for 14 billion years _ meaning that scientists will see what the objects looked like near the creation of the universe, an estimated 15 billion years ago. The telescope's location above Earth's atmosphere will enable it to detect light of all wavelengths, including ultraviolet, before it is absorbed or distorted by the atmosphere. It will look seven times more deeply into space and detect objects 50 times fainter and with 10 times greater clarity than the best ground-based observatory. Its eight-foot primary optical mirror is the most precise ever made. Such a view into space could explain how the universe was created. ``I think they're going to make some discoveries and answer some questions we've got now and probably raise a lot more than we know about right now,'' Shriver said. Using the shuttle's 50-foot robot arm, mission specialist Steven A. Hawley will maneuver the telescope out of the shuttle's cargo bay and hoist it away from the shuttle before letting go of it. Shriver and the pilot, Marine Col. Charles F. Bolden Jr., will then steer the shuttle away from Hubble. Mission specialists Kathryn D. Sullivan and Bruce McCandless, a Navy captain, will be prepared to perform spacewalks should a problem occur during the deployment. The veteran crew also has trained to return Discovery to the telescope during the mission should ground controllers have trouble making Hubble operational.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Moving to Cut Aid to El Salvador
DOC.TEXT: Sentiment is growing among congressional Democrats to cut aid to El Salvador. Rep. David Obey, D-Wis., chairman of the House Appropriations subcommittee on foreign operations, became the latest lawmaker to complain that millions of dollars have done little to end the civil war or improve the Central American country's human rights record. After 10 years and $3.8 billion, ``In many ways we are pretty much at ground zero,'' Obey said Thursday. ``I don't want to be in the perpetual motion of throwing money down a rat hole.'' Obey said he sees little improvement in the country where between 40,000 and 50,000 people have been killed in the last decade. ``I personally don't feel I can vote for Salvador money,'' he said. Bernard Aronson, assistant secretary of state for inter-American affairs, urged caution in testimony to Obey's subcommittee. He said prospects have never been better for a negotiated settlement between the Salvadoran government and the left-wing rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, known as the FMLN. The two sides say they will begin negotiations next month as a first step toward ending the war. Moreover, Aronson said the ouster of the leftist Sandinista government in Nicaragua that supported the Salvadoran rebels eventually should weaken the FMLN. ``Let's not rush to do something that would screw this up,'' he said. ``I think we can end this war.'' Obey also questioned whether the government of President Alfredo Cristiani is able to exercise enough control over the Salvadoran military to proceed with negotiations. ``There is a high degree of dubiousness and I share it,'' he said. Obey joins a number of House members and senators who have raised questions about the aid and suggested cutting it or making it conditional on a cease-fire or improvement in human rights. Heightened interest in the subject comes at the 10th anniversary of the slaying of Archbishop Oscar Romero in San Salvador. His unsolved killing and the resurgence of right-wing death squads prompted the United States to throw its support behind the centrist government in 1980. Sens. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., and John Kerry, D-Mass., have introduced different bills that would place new conditions on Salvadoran aid. Rep. Joe Moakley, D-Mass., head of a congressional task force on El Salvador, wants to cut aid by 50 percent based on a negotiated cease-fire. If the government broke the cease-fire, all aid would end. If the rebels violated the agreement, the government could realize 100 percent of its aid. Meantime, Moakley's task force interviewed a U.S. Army major about his knowledge of possible Salvadoran military involvement in the killing of six Jesuit priests in San Salvador last Nov. 16. Moakley said details of the meeting were secret, but lawmakers wanted to interview the man face-to-face. The task force plans to issue a report on the killings in a few weeks. The United States is providing El Salvador with about $315 million in economic and military aid in the current fiscal year, and the administration is seeking about $375 million for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Pushes Plans to Tighten Down on Money Laundering
DOC.TEXT: Congress is moving to tighten the screws on bankers who cooperate with money-laundering operations of drug traffickers. ``Banks that knowingly handle dirty drug money should not be permitted to do business in this country,'' Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., said Thursday as he and other senators introduced money-laundering legislation. A similar bill won 48-0 approval from the House Banking Committee on Thursday amid heightened concern over drug profits being laundered through Caribbean tax havens and centers of bank secrecy and then returned to the United States. The Senate bill would require federal regulators to hold a hearing on whether to close any bank convicted of money laundering. The House version would require such a hearing if the officers and directors of the bank were also convicted. Under both measures, the bank's charter could be revoked or regulators could appoint a conservator. Federal officials already have the power to shut down banks that are operated improperly. Hearings under the bill would specifically apply to money laundering and would be mandatory. Such hearings would have to consider the extent of management involvement in the offense, whether the bank had the means to block money laundering, the degree of cooperation with law enforcement and whether new procedures had been put in place to prevent a recurrence. Banking Committee Chairman Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, described the House version as a compromise that would not only punish those who ignore money laundering but also provide due process for bankers. He hailed Reps. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill.; Thomas R. Carper, D-Del.; and Bill McCollum, R-Fla.; for working out a compromise version. Citing estimates of $300 billion in annual drug profits worldwide, Annunzio declared that the ``vast quantities of cash may provide drug dealers with their greatest vulnerability to detection.'' ``The drug dealer is caught in a never-ending blizzard of cash every day,'' Annunzio said. The House bill also calls for removal of bank officials convicted of money laundering or structuring transactions to evade requirements of the Bank Secrecy Act. Those found guilty would be prohibited from affiliating with other financial institutions. It would require the Treasury Department to set forth regulations aimed at halting money laundering by wire transfer. It would raise the fine for negligent non-compliance with money-laundering reporting requirements from $500 to $5,000.

DOC.HEAD: Speaker Says Motive in Seeking Court Delay Wasn't Political
DOC.TEXT: House Speaker Thomas S. Foley says he sought to delay Supreme Court review of the federal flag-burning law so the House could better defend it, not to deny Republican candidates an issue this fall. ``I emphatically state that there was no political motive ... in the filing of this brief other than to undertake the fullest defense of a statute of this House,'' the Washington Democrat said Thursday in an unusual speech on the House floor by a speaker. Foley spoke after an embarrassing loss to his chamber's Republican minority. In a 309-101 vote, the House ordered its legal counsel to withdraw a Foley-supported legal brief asking the high court to delay review of the flag-burning law until October. If successful, that probably would take the flag issue, a GOP favorite, out of the campaign leading up to the November elections. House Republican leader Robert Michel complained that he found out about the brief only after it was filed and said ``this is part of a pattern ... (of) insufficient consultation.'' Michel, R-Ill., said the brief mispresented explicit language included in the legislation last year that calls for expedited review of any constitutional challenge. He offered a resolution chastising the House counsel and calling for withdrawal of the brief. And after other Republicans cast the issue as one of which party is better at protecting the flag, dozens of Democrats deserted their leadership to hand Foley his defeat. After the vote, Foley and Republican leaders met and agreed to submit a new brief that would not address the question of timing of the court review, said House Counsel Steven Ross. The law against desecration of the flag recently was ruled unconstitutional in courts in Washington state and the District of Columbia. The Justice Department appealed to the Supreme Court and asked for speedy consideration. The court has asked the defendants in the flag-burning cases to file their responses to the appeal by March 26. The defendants have already stated they believe expedited review was aimed at the political campaign and, since there is no emergency, they should have more time to prepare their side.

DOC.HEAD: Mitchell Stymied in Effort to Schedule Vote
DOC.TEXT: Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, wants a final vote on a clean air bill within a week, but fellow senators are refusing to be pinned to a specific deadline. Faced with scores of amendments not yet considered and several unresolved controversies, Mitchell said Thursday that without an agreed deadline he's not sure when the bill will be finally acted upon. Late Thursday night, Mitchell sought approval from fellow senators to establish a specific deadline for a final vote on the measure before 6 p.m. March 29. But such a time deadline requires unanimous consent, and several senators made clear their objections to being rushed to a final vote with many amendments still to be considered. The legislation, the first tightening of federal air pollution control in 13 years, would impose tougher restrictions on automobiles, industry and electric power plants. Mitchell, who in February engineered a compromise agreement with the White House on the bill in hopes of assuring quick passage, said he had hoped to tell President Bush today that the end ``is in sight.'' ``I obviously will have to call him with different news,'' Mitchell added. In the House, meanwhile, the Energy and Commerce Committee took another step Thursday in crafting its own clean air legislation by reachng a compromise on tougher controls on smog in major cities. By a 38-2 vote, the committee approved provisions to: _Expand controls on smog-causing pollutants to include smaller businesses in areas with the dirtiest air. _Eliminate waivers that would exempt some states or cities from complying with pollution control measures if the cost of the controls exceed a certain amount. _Preserve a requirement that the Environmental Protection Agency impose an air pollution control plan in a city if local officials fail to act. The Senate had rejected similar measures earlier this week. The tougher provisions likely will be one of many differences that eventually will have to be reconciled between the House and Senate. The House committee vote came after two days of negotiations involving Chairman John Dingell, D-Mich., and other senior members of the panel. Many members first saw the inch-thick legislation only minutes before voting on it. The House bill is not expected to reach the floor until May. Among the issues still confronting the Senate is what to do about the appeal from Sen. Robert Byrd, D-Va., to provide financial assistance to coal miners who lose their jobs because of tougher sulfur dioxide emissions control on Midwest utility plants. Mitchell had hoped to resolve the issue Thursday, but by day's end Byrd was reported to be considering a compromise proposal crafted by Mitchell's staff and was not expected to respond until next week, according to aides. Byrd wants $500 million over three years to help the coal miners, but the White House has said that is too expensive and violates the compromise agreement reached with Senate leaders. Meanwhile, Mitchell said he will continue to ``do everything I can'' to push ahead with final action on the clean air bill by the end of next week, although the prospects for keeping that deadline are uncertain.
