The Senate is scheduled to resume action on the legislation on Monday and Mitchell warned the senators to be prepared for late-night sessions _ perhaps even all-night sessions _ running into next weekend if necessary.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Approves Abortion Consent Decree
With PM-Idaho Abortion, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge's approval of the settlement of a lawsuit challenging state abortion-clinic restrictions came under immediate attack from anti-abortion groups. ``It represents the absolute triumph of politics over law,'' said Victor Rosenblum, attorney for the Illinois Right to Life Committee, when informed of Thursday's decision by U.S. District Judge John Nordberg. Nordberg approved a consent decree worked out between Illinois Attorney General Neil Hartigan and the American Civil Liberties Union of Illinois, which represented the plaintiff, Dr. Richard Ragsdale. ``The court finds the proposed consent decree lawful, fair, reasonable and adequate,'' Nordberg said in his 13-page opinion. The consent decree eases state restrictions on abortion clinics that Ragsdale had challenged as medically unnecessary for clinics serving women fewer than 18 weeks pregnant. The decree establishes a new regulatory system mandating two distinct kinds of abortion facility. For women fewer than 18 weeks pregnant, abortions can be performed in clinic settings; the original regulations, which required full service surgical facilities like those in a hospital, will still apply in pregnancies of more than 18 weeks. ``I think it's a good decision. I think Judge Nordberg carefully conducted a fairness hearing,'' said Hartigan, the Democratic candidate for governor, whose office represented the state in the case. Colleen K. Connell, director of the ACLU of Illinois' Reproductive Rights Project, said: ``Under the settlement, women in all parts of Illinois will have access to safe, affordable abortion services.'' But a coalition of anti-abortion groups will appeal Nordberg's decision, possibly as early as today, said Joseph Scheidler, president of the Pro-Life Action League. ``Basically, what we have is back-alley abortion. There is no regulation'' under the ruling, Scheidler said. ``There is no evidence to support this contention,'' Nordberg wrote. ``Far from leaving women unprotected, the settlement creates a network of statutes and rules regulating the provision of abortion services.'' The settlement was reached Nov. 24, removing the case from the U.S. Supreme Court docket only days before that court had been scheduled to hear it. Abortion opponents had wanted the case to go to the high court in hopes that it would lead to further tightening of federal restrictions on abortion. In a telephone interview from his Rockford clinic, Ragsdale said he was pleased with the ruling on his 1985 lawsuit. ``The only reason for opposing the issue as a whole is ignorance of the facts,'' he said. ``Anyone who would tamper or seek to further restrict abortion through legislation or intimidation is seeking to have many women impoverished and humiliated and some women maimed and dead.'' The clinic restrictions, which went into effect in 1978, were suspended after Ragsdale won decisions in U.S. District Court and in the 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. At issue were elaborate state requirements for non-hospital surgical centers. Clinics were required to provide in-house counseling, meet certain building-code specifications and prove they were not duplicating similar services in their areas. Ragsdale contended the requirements were medically unnecessary and discouraged abortion providers by forcing them to build ``the equivalent of a small hospital,'' an expensive proposition that effectively hampered access to abortion.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Considering Possible Rescue Attempt
DOC.TEXT: NASA is considering sending astronauts to repair a stranded satellite or to bring it back to Earth, but will meet with aerospace company officials again before making a decision. ``Those are the options they're looking at, either reboost (to a higher useful orbit) or retrieve,'' said Kyle Herring, a spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. NASA officials met for about seven hours at Johnson Space Center on Thursday with representatives from Intelsat, the satellite's owner, and Hughes Aircraft Co., which built the spacecraft. Although no decision was made regarding a rescue attempt, NASA officials are ``obviously showing some interest,'' Herring said. The uninsured $150 million communications satellite was launched by a Titan 3 booster rocket March 14 from Cape Canaveral, Fla., but wound up in the wrong orbit after failing to separate properly from the second stage of the rocket. Intelsat engineers managed to separate the satellite and later boost it to a higher parking orbit using computer commands. The Intelsat VI satellite is whirling uselessly about 276 miles above Earth, 22,000 miles lower than it should be. ``They're comfortable where it is,'' at least for now, Herring said. Herring said NASA and officials from the two companies discussed the possibility of attaching a motor to the spacecraft that would boost it to where it should be. Such an attempt would require a spacewalk by astronauts to draw the satellite into the shuttle's payload bay, he said. ``While the discussions were very preliminary, no insurmountable technical issues were identified,'' NASA said in a statement. Thursday's meeting ``was devoted to fact-finding only and no decisions were made as to whether such a mission could be accomplished,'' the space agency said. ``Additional meetings are being planned to further discuss aspects of the Intelsat VI status and rescue options.'' William Reeves, lead flight director for next month's trip by the shuttle Discovery to deploy the Hubble Space Telescope, said there were no plans to incorporate any rescue attempt in the five-day mission. Martin Marietta Corp., which launched the rocket and satellite at a cost of $270 million, has blamed the failure on a design error. It was Martin Marietta's second commercial launch of a payload into orbit and the fourth by an American company. The Intelsat VI satellite was intended to transmit three TV channels and up to 120,000 telephone calls simultaneously for more than 13 years. Intelsat, a not-for-profit international consortium, operates a global communications satellite system.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Rebounds, Dollar Rises Further Against Yen in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange bounced back Friday, one day after a hectic sell-off pushed the market's main index to its lowest close in 15 months. The dollar kept rising against the yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which lost 963.85 points Thursday, gained 528.82 points, or 1.77 percent, to close the week at 30,372.16. Friday's advance followed a 2,773.1-point decline in the Nikkei index in three previous trading days this week. There was no trading on Wednesday because of a national holiday. ``The stock market is gradually recovering, and individual investors have begun bargain-hunting for issues at low share prices,'' said Kumiko Takahashi, a dealer with Nikko Securities. In foreign exchange, the U.S. currency ended the week at 155.07 yen, up 0.24 yen from Thursday's close of 154.83 yen. After opening at 154.75 yen, the currency ranged between 154.65 yen and 155.25 yen. Currency dealers have blamed the yen's weakness on the stock market drop. The price of the benchmark No. 119 Japanese government bond was quoted higher at 86.61 points as of 3 p.m., up from Thursday's close at 86.54 points. Its yield slid to 7.220 percent from 7.235 percent the previous day. Many institutional investors remained on the sidelines awaiting account settlement for fiscal 1989, which ends March 31, dealers said. The Nikkei fell 963.85 points, or 3.13 percent, to 29,843.34 on Thursday, its lowest close since it ended at 29,741.28 on Dec. 24, 1988. It was the fourth biggest decline so far this year, in which the market has plunged more than 20 percent. The dollar-yen rate moved narrowly before a weekend meeting between Japanese Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto and U.S. Secretary of Treasury Nicholas Brady in Los Angeles, said Minori Takeuchi, a trader with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. Hashimoto said Friday he was ``extremely concerned'' about the current levels of the yen and Tokyo share prices. He said an international accord for cooperation on exchange rates must be reconfirmed at his meeting with Brady. News reports that the Bank of Japan and the Finance Ministry began intervening the stock and currency markets accelerated market players' fears that the situation could seriously damage Japan's economy. Nihon Keizai Shimbun, Japan's leading economic daily, reported Friday that the Finance Ministry has requested securities houses to limit certain activities in an attempt to prevent excessive market declines. Analysts said the stock market's tumble on Thursday stemmed from heavy selling by institutional investors who were desperate to offset earlier losses or cash-out losing positions before closing their books for the fiscal year ending March 31. Thursday's drop brought the Nikkei's losses so far this year to 9,072.53 points, or 23 percent. Dealers blamed the market pessimism on the yen's continuing depreciation against the dollar, despite the Bank of Japan's increase in the discount rate. The central bank on Tuesday raised the key rate by 1 percentage point to 5.25 percent in an effort to stem inflation and support the yen. But analysts said delays in the long-anticipated increase had destabilized Japan's financial markets.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Urges Soviets to Stop Intimidation of Lithuania
DOC.TEXT: The Senate is calling on the Soviet Union to stop intimidating Lithuania, and is warning that the use of military force ``would have severe repercussions for U.S.-Soviet relations.'' A resolution approved 93-0 late Thursday also urged President Bush to consider the Lithuanian government's request for diplomatic recognition. The day before, a resolution urging the president to grant such recognition had been defeated 59-36. ``The Soviet Union has no right to use force against Lithuanians peacefully exercising their democratic rights,'' declared Thursday night's resolution, which is not binding but indicates ``a sense of Congress.'' It said Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev and other Soviet leaders ``should clearly understand that the use of force against the Lithuanian people would have severe repercussions for U.S.-Soviet relations.'' Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., sponsor of the resolution that lost Wednesday night, chastised his colleagues for sending ``mixed signals,''saying there was little difference between his resolution and the one that passed unanimously. But Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., who voted against Helms' resolution, said he favored the newer resolution because it ``gives greater flexibility to the president.'' While the approved resolution urged Bush to consider the request from the Lithuanian government for recognition, it did not urge the president specifically to grant it, as did Helms' resolution. Earlier in the day two House Republicans, Reps. William Broomfield of Michigan and Mickey Edwards of Oklahoma, introduced a resolution warning that any Soviet crackdown on Lithuania would be met by U.S. trade sanctions. The House did not vote on the resolution.

DOC.HEAD: Mystery Shrouds Reservation Suicide, Investigation Continues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Jeffery in 2nd graf and single names Apesanahkwat and Waupanoh are cq.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MI1
DOC.TEXT: The coroner called the young Menominee Indian's death suicide. Tribal medicine men who invoked the victim's spirit said it was accidental. But a protracted FBI investigation has fueled rumors of foul play. Jeffery Cloud, 20, died of a pistol shot to the head Nov. 22. His body was found in a pickup truck owned by Apesanahkwat, then tribal chairman. The .357-caliber pistol was taken from Apesanahkwat's home that day. Apesanahkwat's teen-age daughter, who was Cloud's girlfriend and says she was the lone witness to the suicide, has refused to take a lie-detector test, the tribal police chief says, though her father denies that. Menominee County Coroner Rick Herrera says he ruled Cloud's death a suicide, without talking to Apesanahkwat's daughter, because of evidence he found at the scene. ``When it was obvious like that, we don't do an autopsy,'' Herrera said. Apesanahkwat (pronounced ah-peh-SAHN-eh-kwat) said Cloud's spirits were contacted in an Indian religious ceremony two weeks after his death, and tribal medicine men are convinced the shooting was accidental, not a suicide. ``He didn't realize there were bullets in the gun. That is almost a direct quote that was interpreted to me by the medicine men,'' Apesanahkwat said. The FBI, meanwhile, says it is continuing its investigation but won't say why. The agency has jurisdiction to investigate felonies on the reservation. That has stirred questions on the Menominee nation's reservation of about 3,000 people, 45 miles northwest of Green Bay in east-central Wisconsin. Apesanahkwat, who decided two months after the death not to seek a fourth one-year term as tribal chairman, acknowledged he has heard rumors that he is a suspect and that Cloud witnessed some kind of drug deal before dying. He called the rumors ``totally groundless and ridiculous.'' The former tribal chief, known as Melvin Chevalier before he switched to his Indian name several years ago, is a 41-year-old Vietnam war veteran, actor and Indian lobbyist. He says he has no idea why the FBI is keeping the case open. Tribal Police Chief Kenneth Paddo Fish said the FBI continues investigating because 16-year-old Bernadette Chevalier, whose Indian name is Waupanoh, has refused to take a lie-detector test. FBI agent Tom Martin of Green Bay would neither confirm nor deny that. Waupanoh (pronounced wau-PAH-nah) said in an interview last week, ``I know what happened. He (Cloud) knows what happened. The Great Spirit knows what happened.'' But in a news conference Thursday, Apesanahkwat disputed that his daughter refused to take the test. He said the FBI had requested the test, but a technician who was going to administer it told his wife that his daughter was too upset to take it. Apesanahkwat said there was no further need for her to take a test. Cloud's mother, Isabel, 47, refuses to believe her son committed suicide. ``He had a lot of things going for him,'' she said last week. A high school dropout, Cloud was a ``happy-go-lucky'' guy who would ``boogie'' to avoid trouble, his mother said. Miss Chevalier said that on the night he died, Cloud, her boyfriend for nearly two years, and she had argued and he went into the tribal chairman's home and grabbed a gun. The gun belonged to one of Apesanahkwat's friends, Apesanahkwat said. Cloud started walking away, alone, and Miss Chevalier said she jumped into her father's pickup after him, crying and asking him to come back. Cloud got into the vehicle. At some point, she said, he put the gun to the left side of his head, she tried to pull it away and it went off. Frantic, she drove back to her home, where investigators found the body in the truck. He had been depressed, unhappy with his life and cried about it, she said. ``He had said, `One of these days I am going to take a walk and I am not going to come back.''' Ms. Cloud said her son loved Waupanoh but had other girlfriends. ``To kill himself over a girl, why should he, when he had all these other girls?'' she said. ``I just lay back and in my prayers for my son I tell him, `Someone is going to get paid back for what they did to you if anybody did that to you.' That is what I keep telling myself,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Hazelwood Maintained Stoic Demeanor, Silence Throughout Trial
With PM-Hazelwood Trial, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: He is not as notorious as Captain Bligh or Captain Ahab, but Captain Joseph Hazelwood, former skipper of the Exxon Valdez, has sailed unwillingly into America's lore of the sea. While cartoonists sketched him as a liquor-swigging villain and TV comics parodied the infamous grounding of his ship, the passionately private Hazelwood returned to Alaska this winter, nearly a year after the nation's worst oil spill, determined to clear his name. ``I'd like to get rid of the misconception that I got drunk, ran the ship aground and just shrugged my shoulders and walked away, because that's just not what happened,'' he said after the grounding of the Exxon Valdez had tarred his reputation along with hundreds of miles of rocky shore. On Thursday, a jury found Hazelwood innocent of the most serious charges against him, convicting him only of a misdemeanor charge of negligent discharge of oil. He faces up to 90 days in jail and a $1,000 fine. He was acquitted of charges of second-degree criminal mischief, reckless endangerment and operating a vessel while intoxicated. Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., was the only person charged criminally in the environmental calamity. He was accused of being drunk on duty and being away from the ship's bridge when it rammed a charted reef. He came back to Alaska with some trepidation and kept a low profile outside court. Many nights he stayed in his hotel room watching old movies about sea captains rather than risk being recognized in public. In court, the balding, bearded Hazelwood sat mute, watching in stoic silence as his crew members told their stories. His demeanor was not unusual. Joe Hazelwood had always been a man of few words. ``His actions always spoke louder than his words because his words were not that many,'' said attorney Michael Chalos, Hazelwood's former maritime college classmate who put together his defense team just days after the Exxon Valdez grounding made headlines. In school, says Chalos, the low key Hazelwood was ``a natural leader ... very quiet but very determined.'' He was captain of the lacrosse team and did well academically, Chalos recalls, but was something of a rebel when it came to military authority. His rebelliousness later would bring him into conflict with Exxon executives over company policies. When he graduated from New York State University Maritime College at Fort Schyler, Hazelwood signed on with Exxon Shipping Corp. ``It was a plum appointment,'' recalls Chalos. ``If you got a job with Exxon, you'd made it.'' He rose in the seagoing ranks, obtained his master's license, won the fleet award for efficiency in 1986 and, in 1987, was given command of the brand new Exxon Valdez, the most advanced, high-tech vessel in the Exxon fleet. He rarely spent more than three or four months at a time ashore. But between voyages he returned to Huntington where he and his wife, Suzanne, live with their teen-age daughter, Alison. ``I get stark crazy when I am too far from the salt water,'' he has said. If there was a fatal flaw in Hazelwood's smooth history of achievements, it was his drinking. He lost his New York motor vehicle driver's license after two drunken driving convictions and in 1985, with Exxon's knowledge, he went through a 28-day voluntary alcohol rehabilitation program. Was he drunk aboard the Exxon Valdez on the fateful night? His crew members testified they saw no signs of intoxication although they had seen the captain put away a few drinks in town. His blood alcohol reading was .061 in a test taken 10{ hours after the grounding. Evidence was inconclusive on what his blood alcohol was earlier. Hazelwood, true to his taciturn nature, chose not to testify and never commented on the intoxication issue. Why didn't he testify? Attorneys said they were confident about their case and did not want to subject Hazelwood to unnecessary, grueling cross-examination. They had another reason, too. ``Sitting here at the defense table, he's still the captain, someone special,'' said Chalos. ``If he had gotten up on the witness stand, he wouldn't be special anymore. He'd be just another witness.''

DOC.HEAD: Exxon-Valdez Chronology
With PM-Hazelwood Trial, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of the Exxon Valdez oil spill, its cleanup and related developments:

March 24: The 987-foot tanker Exxon Valdez runs aground on Bligh Reef some 25 miles south of Valdez, Alaska, spilling nearly 11 million gallons of North Slope crude oil into Prince William Sound. March 26: Alaska fishermen's union spokeswoman Riki Ott says the group wants full compensation for damage from the spill. More than 250 lawsuits will be filed against Exxon in the following months. March 30: Exxon fires tanker captain Joseph Hazelwood after tests reveal he was legally drunk 10 hours after the accident. April 4: U.S. Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan calls the spill the oil industry's ``Three Mile Island.'' Oil now covers 1,000 square miles, leaking out of the sound to foul beaches along the Gulf of Alaska and Cook Inlet. June 19: Exxon and other big oil companies announce plans for a voluntary network of response teams capable of handling big spills anywhere in U.S. coastal waters. Estimated cost: $250 million. Sept. 15: Exxon suspends its beach cleanup for the winter, claiming it has left 1,100 miles of oiled beaches ``environmentally stable'' and saying its 25-week cleanup involving more than 10,000 workers was a job well done. Alaska officials disagree and announce their own $21 million winter cleanup plan. Oct. 10: State officials warn people not to consume shellfish in areas affected by oil. Oct. 27: The National Wildlife Federation says Exxon has resigned from its corporate advisory board. Exxon calls the conservation group unfair in its criticism of the oil spill; the group calls Exxon ``a corporate pariah.'' Nov. 8: The U.S. House of Representatives passes a bill preserving states' ability to adopt stricter oil spill liability laws than the federal government. The Senate also is working on a bill, but agreement is put off until 1990. Dec. 4: U.S. Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner says Exxon's cleanup has cost the company $1.9 billion, and praises Exxon for ``a very substantial, good-faith effort.'' Dec. 31: Wildlife officials report that more than 1,000 sea otters, 140 bald eagles and nearly 36,500 seabirds have been found dead in the spill area.

Jan. 5: The Alaska Oil Spill Commission issues a report calling for an overhaul of the nation's oil transportation system. It blames the Valdez spill in part on the Coast Guard's ``unduly friendly relationship with industry,'' and a reckless rush to profits by the oil industry. Jan. 22: Hazelwood goes on trial in Anchorage, facing charges of criminal mischief, reckless endangerment, negligent discharge of oil, and operating a vessel while intoxicated. Feb. 20: The Coast Guard orders Exxon to resume its cleanup May 1 and to submit a plan by March 15. Feb. 27: A federal grand jury indicts Exxon and its shipping subsidiary on five criminal counts. Officials say that if convicted on all counts, the company could be fined up to $1.6 million and could be assessed an additional $700 million in penalties. March 21 _ Hazelwood case submitted to jury. March 22 _ Jury finds Hazelwood guilty of negligent discharge of oil but innocent of the more serious charges.

DOC.HEAD: Jurors Center Debate on Maxim That Captain is Responsible for His Ship
With PM-Hazelwood Trial, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Jurors who acquitted tanker skipper Joseph Hazelwood of the most serious charges against him said there was no proof that alcohol played a role in the Exxon Valdez oil spill. And while there was considerable debate about the maxim that a captain is responsible for his ship, jurors said they were forced to recognize that the law doesn't say so. ``In fact, that caused some difficult times while we were in there,'' said juror Terrill Smith. ``We considered the fact that Hazelwood was captain of his ship and the actions of his crew. ``But when it come down to making a verdict, we could not say that because that was not the law.'' Smith said he and the other jurors based their decision on the law and evidence, and ``the state just didn't have the evidence.'' Asked who then was responsible for spilling nearly 11 million gallons of North Slope crude oil into Alaska's Prince William Sound last March, Smith said: ``I don't know. I can't answer that. The only gentleman who was on trial was Captain Hazelwood.'' Hazelwood, acquitted of charges of drunkenness and recklessness, faces a possible fine of $1,000 and 90 days in jail on the misdemeanor count of negligent discharge of oil. Smith and juror Jeff Sage said the state could not prove that alcohol played a role because authorities failed to give Hazelwood a blood alcohol test until 10{ hours after the grounding. Sage said he did not buy the prosecution's effort to prove Hazelwood was intoxicated through backward calculations starting from his alcohol blood level when tested _ a level well below the Alaska standard for drunken highway drivers. ``We all agreed. It was obvious in court that he had had something to drink prior to'' the grounding, Smith said. ``But with the time involved,'' it was not possible to determine beyond a reasonable doubt that alcohol played a role. Smith faulted the Alaska laws under which Hazelwood was prosecuted, saying, ``I think that there needs to be a long hard look taken at a lot of the laws pertaining to the navigational waters of our state.'' He did not elaborate. Sage said he felt the jury rendered the only decision possible under the law. ``It's been a privilage. I'm glad to stand here today and say that justice has been done,'' Sage said. Smith and Sage said the jury believed that Hazelwood's decision to leave the bridge shortly before the tanker hit a charted reef was not reckless as the state contended, but only negligent. Thus, the jury had no problem convicting him on the misdemeanor charge of negligent discharge of oil, Smith said. Sage he said he thought Third Mate Gregory Cousins and Helmsman Robert Kagan probably were not the right team to leave on the bridge when Hazelwood went below. But Smith noted that Hazelwood apparently felt the ship was in competent hands. Sage also criticized the Coast Guard monitoring system for failing to warn the Exxon Valdez that it was nearing a reef after it changed course to avoid floating ice. ``It's a joke,'' Sage said. ``Seventy million bucks. What did they spend it on? They're there to avoid collisions and groundings.'' According to testimony, the Coast Guard radar monitor said the Exxon Valdez disappeared from radar at some point before the disaster. The jury did not feel Hazelwood was a scapegoat for Exxon and political forces, as the defense argued, Smith said. However, he added, ``Personally, I felt there was a possibility that may have been happening.''

DOC.HEAD: Maryland Voters May Decide Abortion Issue
DOC.TEXT: The Maryland Senate today approved an unusual plan, passing both an anti-abortion bill and an abortion rights bill and giving the state's voters a chance to decide which should become law. Acceptance of the two-bill plan shortly after midnight broke an eight-day filibuster in the Senate, where abortion rights forces had the 24 votes needed to pass a liberal abortion law but were one vote shy of the 32 required to end debate. Under the compromise that Senate leaders worked out, the abortion rights bill permitting unrestricted abortions during the early stages of pregnancy will become law unless it is petitioned to referendum and rejected by voters in November. If that happens, then the bill sponsored by anti-abortion senators will become law _ unless it also is defeated by voters. Leaders on both sides of the issue in the House said after the compromise was revealed Thursday that they would have to look at the two bills before deciding whether they could accept them. The measures are structured so that both would have to be passed by the House of Delegates and signed by the governor; if one of the measures is rejected, the other one dies. Gov. William Donald Schaefer's spokeswoman, Louise Hayman, said the governor would not comment on whether he would sign or veto the bills. ``It is paternalistic, patronizing, demeaning and degrading to women,'' Sen. Barbara Hoffman said of the anti-abortion bill. Sen. Vernon Boozer said if the anti-abortion bill becomes law, ``it would seriously impair the health and welfare of the women of this state.'' The only response from anti-abortion senators came from Norman Stone, who said he considered the abortion rights bill ``the worst bill that has ever come before this body.'' Under the anti-abortion bill, before the fetus is viable, or capable of living outside the womb, abortions could be performed in cases of rape or incest, to protect the mother's life or if the pregnancy would produce serious and adverse effects on the woman's health. After viability, abortions could be performed only to save the mother's life. The abortion rights bill would allow unrestricted access to abortions until viability. After that, it would permit abortions to protect the mother's life or health. Anti-abortion groups have already formed a committee to collect signatures to put an abortion rights bill on the ballot if one is passed and signed by the governor, in hopes of defeating it in a referendum. Pro-choice lobbyists said they were unsure what they would do if the two-bill package is accepted by the House and signed by the governor.

DOC.HEAD: Darman Asks Senators to Help Launch Deficit-Reduction Talks
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's budget chief is appealing to 21 mostly junior senators for help in finding a way to get deficit-reduction talks started between the White House and congressional leaders. The bipartisan group of lawmakers gave a favorable reception to Budget Director Richard Darman's plea Thursday, but Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn., dismissed the meeting. Sasser, who did not attend, predicted there would be no serious talks unless the administration expressed willingness to make deep cuts in the budget. Darman has been trying unsuccessfully to persuade congressional leaders to begin deficit-reduction talks since Bush released his fiscal 1991 budget proposal in January. He launched his latest offensive two weeks ago after Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., unveiled a plan to raise taxes and cut spending to save $512 billion over the next five years. Sasser is one of several top senators, including Majority Leader George Mitchell of Maine, who have had poor relations with the budget director since last fall, when disagreements over deficit-cutting erupted. Sasser said he has not had a conversation with Darman since. Various congressional budget writers regarded Darman's visit as an attempt to mend fences or to pressure Senate leaders to come to the table. The budget director said the lawmakers with whom he met expressed ``some sense of frustration'' with the deficit-reduction efforts of the congressional budget committees. ``It's not clear they will be able to produce anything substantive,'' he said. Darman came to Capitol Hill after being invited to appear before a bipartisan group of senators who meet informally to discuss budget problems. ``There is an intense desire to do more'' about deficit reduction, said the group's leader, Sen. Kent Conrad, D-N.D., who when elected in 1986 promised to only seek a second term if the federal budget deficit were under control. Darman told lawmakers it will probably take $45 billion to $50 billion in deficit reductions to reduce next year's projected shortfall to $64 billion because the economy weakened late last year. The Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law requires the deficit be reduced to $64 billion next year. Sasser said that for serious deficit-reduction talks to occur, the administration ``would have to make a presentation that they'd be interested in getting $50 billion in hard deficit reduction that would persist.''

DOC.HEAD: Committee Asks Bush to Intensify Efforts
DOC.TEXT: The House Foreign Affairs Committee is urging President Bush to intensify efforts to win freedom for American hostages in Lebanon. The measure unanimously approved Thursday was sponsored by Rep. Louise Slaughter, D-N.Y., who asked Congress to pass a bill requiring Bush to appoint a special envoy to work for the hostages' freedom. But the administration and some members of Congress said the appointment of such an envoy would confuse efforts already under way to free the captives. As amended, the resolution says the president should ``accelerate efforts to secure the immediate and unconditional release of the hostages'' through increased diplomatic efforts. Additionally, Bush should urge multinational efforts to work for the hostages' release, the resolution said. The measure now goes to the full House. Eight Americans are among the 18 Westerners held hostage in Lebanon. They are thought to be guarded by pro-Iranian Moslem Shiites. Terry Anderson, the longest-held American hostage, marked the end of his fifth year in captivity on March 16. He is a correspondent for The Associated Press.
DOC.HEAD: Commerce Department Issues Ban on Capture of Bottlenose Dolphins
DOC.TEXT: The federal government has ordered a ban on the capture of bottlenose dolphins in the Gulf of Mexico as scientists try to determine the reason for more than 190 dolphin deaths this year. Dozens of dolphins have been stranded and died since Jan. 1 in five Gulf States, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration _ 118 in Texas, 40 to 45 on the barrier islands of Louisiana and Mississippi, 21 in the Alabama-Florida panhandle, and 10 in Florida's Tampa Bay. The dolphins have been stranded at four to five times the usual rate for the time of year and the deaths are continuing, a NOAA spokesman said. NOAA announced a halt in dolphin captures late Wednesday, to remain in effect through at least June 15. William W. Fox Jr., NOAA's assistant administrator for fisheries, said the National Marine Fisheries Service retains the option to extend the ban. Although cold weather is believed responsible for the deaths of 26 dolphins in Texas' Matagorda Bay, the NOAA spokesman said ``this thing could involve a number of reasons.'' Adult dolphins have been the victims, but scientists in the past week or so have begun watching to assess how the calving season, which began during the second week of March and goes into April, will be affected. Under the Marine Mammal Protection Act, bottlenose dolphins are considered a protected, but not endangered or threatened, species. According to NOAA, 11 organizations hold permits to collect live dolphins, but only three do the actual collecting. The dolphins can be taken for educational purposes such as aquariums or marine-type theaters.
DOC.HEAD: US-South Korea Sign Agreement To Phase Out Tariffs, Quotas
DOC.TEXT: South Korea will phase out all quotas and tariffs on American beef entering the country, according to Sen. Phil Gramm. Gramm, R-Texas, said the agreement sets up a three-year ``transition period'' in which current American sales to South Korea, which are running at 63,900 tons, would grow to 68,300 tons this year and 72,800 tons next year. Gramm said the agreement signed Thursday by U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills and South Korean officials ``sets out procedures to eliminate all quotas and tariffs on American beef going into Korea.'' ``This is another major step toward opening the world market to the joys of eating American beef,'' Gramm said. Gramm said he believed the agreement, which was not immediately announced by the trade representative's office, would vastly increase demand in Korea for beef, which has been kept artificially high due to quotas and tariffs.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0459 to fix cycle designator.
New Yorker Expected To Be Tapped As Kennedy Center Chairman
DOC.TEXT: A search committee today is expected to recommend that James D. Wolfensohn, chairman of Carnegie Hall in New York City, be named chairman of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, a spokeswoman says. The committee was to recommend Wolfensohn to the center's board of trustees when it meets today, said Laura Longley, a Kennedy Center spokeswoman, said Thursday. ``I don't think that's any great secret,'' Ms. Longley said. Ralph P. Davidson, the Kennedy Center's current chairman and president, asked that his contract not be renewed when it expires in February 1991. While Wolfensohn is to be named chairman, he will not also hold the post of president, The Washington Post said in today's editions. Wolfensohn, 56, is president of his own investment banking firm.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Company Checks Crews for Drunken-Driving Arrests
With PM-Hazelwood Trial, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Ashland Oil Co. wants its towboat crews free of alcohol so the company is checking them for drunken-driving arrests to help avert pollution and public-relations disasters like the Exxon Valdez oil spill. ``There's no place for alcohol on a boat. It's too dangerous,'' said Mary Hale, a cook aboard the Ashland, a towboat working the Ohio and Mississippi rivers. For pilots and crew members, alcohol is more dangerous than the eight barges of gasoline, diesel and crude oil they were pushing on a recent Ohio River run from Kenova, W.Va., to Louisville, Ky. The only alcohol aboard is in medicine cabinets. ``You have to recognize danger while you still have time to do something about it,'' said Skip Muscovalley, one of the Ashland's captains. ``If we have the tiniest mistake, our jobs and lives are at stake,'' Muscovalley said. ``If you sink a grain barge or a coal barge, well, it happens and you just go on. Sink one of these dudes and you make the news. You're the new Joe Hazelwood.'' Hazelwood, 43, a veteran mariner from Huntington, N.Y., was captain of the Exxon Valdez when the tanker ran aground and spilled nearly 11 million gallons of oil into Alaska's Prince William Sound a year ago Saturday. It was the nation's worst oil spill. A state jury in Anchorage acquitted Hazelwood on Thursday of criminal mischief, reckless endangerment and operating a vessel while intoxicated. But the jury convicted him of negligent discharge of oil, which carries a maximum sentence of 90 days in jail and a $1,000 fine. Authorities said a review of Hazelwood's driving record uncovered two drunken-driving arrests and three license suspensions. Ashland Oil officials thought reviewing its pilots' driving records might find trouble spots before the company suffers a waterborne accident of its own. ``We found a few people with DUIs in their history,'' said Zane Meek, Ashland's administrator of marine transportation. ``We told them our side of the story and told them we didn't want to see any kind of habit like that.'' No pattern of abuse has developed and no one has been disciplined, Meek said. ``We're not after someone who has one incident. Any of us could have that occur,'' said John Joeckel, company manager of fleet operations. ``We really are trying to keep this a non-punitive type of program because we want people who think they have a problem to come forward.'' Skippers say crews welcome the checks and understand Ashland's need to protect its investment on runs from Pennsylvania to Louisiana to Texas. ``The cost of equipment has gone up and there's so much money involved that they couldn't afford any problems on their boats,'' said Merle Adams, an Ashland skipper. ``The company is looking out for its own welfare as well as your own.'' Ashland crews have 30 days on and 30 days off. The tugboats run 24 hours a day and crew members alternate six-hour shifts, grabbing sleep and meals in their time off. ``I know what to look for; any kind of strange behavior,'' said David Smith, captain of the Valvoline, another vessel in Ashland's fleet. ``We have 10 men on the boat ... If you work with the same men for a month, you know if they're acting differently.''

DOC.HEAD: Hazelwood Verdict Shifts Attention to Oil Industry
DOC.BYLINE: With PM-Hazelwood Trial, Bjt ^By JOHN ENDERS
DOC.TEXT: Environmentalists and public officials said they were disappointed a jury absolved Joseph Hazelwood of most charges in the nation's worst oil spill, and vowed not to let the oil industry off the hook. ``The whole system is culpable and Exxon and Hazelwood are just two agents in a very complicated and very flawed system of extraction and transportation of petroleum,'' said Mei Mei Evans, coordinator of the Oil Reform Alliance, a group of residents affected by the spill. Hazelwood was convicted Thursday of a misdemeanor charge of negligent discharge of oil but acquitted of three other more serious counts, including drunkenness and recklessness. He faces a possible 90 days in jail and a $1,000 fine. Exxon said the verdicts seemed to confirm the spill last year of almost 11 million gallons of crude from the company's Exxon Valdez tanker was an accident. But former Valdez Mayor John Devens said the issue never was Hazelwood. ``There will always be Joe Hazelwoods,'' Devens said. The spill showed that industry does not have the technology to deal with oil spills of that magnitude, and that prevention must be stressed, he said. ``The real issue confronting the state of Alaska is whether industry is prepared to prevent another oil spill,'' Devens said. The state filed a civil lawsuit against Exxon on Aug. 15, joining more than 150 other civil litigants. ``The result bears out the fact that there are other people responsible for this, other than Capt. Hazelwood,'' Gov. Steve Cowper said. Exxon officials in New York reacted with apparent optimism following the verdict. ``We are pleased that the ordeal of the trial is over for Capt. Hazelwood and his family. The verdict would seem to confirm the view that the grounding of the Exxon Valdez was an accident,'' said Exxon spokesman Jim Morakis. ``In light of pending litigation any other comment would be inappropriate,'' the company said. In Juneau, Alaska Attorney General Douglas Baily said that he was pleased with the verdict, which he said should not have any major effect on pending civil and criminal cases against Exxon. ``I suppose in an ideal world we would have preferred to have been more successful on some of the other counts,'' Baily said. ``But we certainly accept the jury's verdict.'' But Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole, who argued the case, said he was disappointed and remains convinced that Hazelwood was drunk when the ship ran aground. Defense attorney Dick Madson said the defense plans to appeal on grounds that federal law preempts state law concerning oil spills and that a person who reports an oil spill, as Hazelwood did, is immune from prosecution. Marnie Isaacs, spokeswoman for Alyeska Pipeline Service Co., the consortium of oil companies that run the trans-Alaska pipeline, said, ``Many, many factors contributed to the grounding of the Valdez, in addition to the actions of the captain.'' The Hazelwood verdicts are only the beginning of determining responsibility for the disaster, some environnmentalists said. Bruce Manheim, spokesman for the Environmental Defense Fund in Washington, D.C., said, ``We're certainly disappointed with that result but, nonetheless, we believe the real trial has yet to begin.''

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: As sisters go, Karen Marie Gehrke and Mary Ann Plante are pretty close. They live a few doors down from each other and go shopping and do a lot of other things together. Early Thursday, Mrs. Gehrke, 26, and Mrs. Plante, 28, delivered babies less than three hours apart. Both babies were boys. Each weighed 7 pounds, 9 ounces. ``You couldn't have planned it this way,'' said obstetrician Charles Lomax, who spent Thursday morning shuffling between the two mothers at Wesley Long Community Hospital. Mrs. Plante arrived at the hospital first, but Mrs. Gehrke was first to deliver. Michael William, her second child, was born at 1:21 a.m. In the next room, at 4:19 a.m., Mrs. Plante delivered Thomas Joseph. ``When (Lomax) came to see me, he asked if this was a conspiracy,'' Mrs. Gehrke said. ``This is such a wild coincidence. We couldn't believe it,'' Mrs. Plante said. ``Neither one of us was trying to get pregnant. It just kind of happened.''

Her friends and relatives joke that at 40, Libby Swindle is just reaching her peak. On her 40th birthday, she climbed to the peak of a mountain _ 10 times. ``I thought of a half-marathon or a cruise, but I thought this would be more fun,'' Ms. Swindle said after completing her eighth trip up a rocky 1{-mile trail to the summit of Pinnacle Mountain. The climb began 5:45 a.m. Wednesday, part of her tradition of climbing the west summit trail at Pinnacle Mountain State Park at sunrise. Each time the Hot Springs woman returned to the base, more friends or relatives had arrived, some from as far away as San Antonio. They set up camp complete with a decorated picnic table, scrapbook and a dozen roses placed in a cooking grill. Nearby, a white sheet was strung between two trees with balloons and messages from well-wishers. ``It's all downhill from here,'' one note said. ``You're nowhere near your peak,'' said another. Ms. Swindle's mother, Patsy Swindle, was busy taking photographs. She said the climb is typical of her daughter. ``I'm not surprised, I just thought 10 times was a bit too much,'' she said. ``But I'm real proud of her.'' She began training in January and decided to try and climb Pinnacle 40 times by her birthday. She made it 43 times _ the last 10 climbs taking her 12 hours. She hasn't made plans for her next birthday.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks, Dollar Rise in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The main index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange bounced back today for its first gain this week, while the dollar moved higher against the yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which lost 963.85 points Thursday, gained 528.82 points, or 1.77 percent, to close the week at 30,372.16. The leading index had fallen 2,773.1 points during the three previous trading days this week. The stock market was closed Wednesday because of a national holiday. Volume on the market's first section was estimated at 600 million shares, up from 580 million shares on Thursday. The Nikkei index fell in early morning trading because of profit-taking by institutional investors, securities dealers said. But the index rose sharply toward end of the day, with stock futures being bought back, in part because of a series of buy orders by arbitrageurs, they said. Arbitrageurs profit from price differentials between the futures and spot markets. ``The market is slowly but gradually recovering, helped by relative stability in the currency and bond markets,'' said Akira Shimoda, an equity analyst with Yamaichi Securities. Shomoda said the Finance Ministry's approval Thursday of a measure that allows Japan's four major brokerage houses to handle more than 30 percent of the purchase orders of any particular stock in a month would ``greatly help'' activities at the securites firms and strengthen the market. Japan's four major securities firms _ Nomura Securitiies, Daiwa Securities, Nikko Securities and Yamaichi Securities _ had asked the Finance Ministry to ease the restriction, a rule set up to check insider trading, he said. The four securities firms account for about half of the market's total turnover, a market analyst said. In the foreign currency market, the dollar closed the week at 155.07 yen, up 0.24 yen from Thursday's close of 154.83 yen. After opening at 154.75 yen, the U.S. currency ranged between 154.65 yen and 155.25 yen. ``The demand for the dollar basically remains strong,'' said Toshio Takahashi, a dealer with the Industrial Bank of Japan. ``The American economy is good, despite cautiousness over inflation'' among U.S. monetary authorities, he said. Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto was to leave later today for a weekend meeting focusing on exchange-rate movements with Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady in Los Angeles. Hashimoto told a parliamentary budget committee session today that he will seek U.S. cooperation in keeping currencies stable within the framework of policy coordination among the Group of Seven major industrialized countries. The price of benchmark No. 119 Japanese government bonds closed at 86.97, up from Thursday's 86.54. The yield fell to 7.145 percent from 7.235 percent the previous day.

DOC.HEAD: Apocalyptic Gathering Overloads Phone System in Rural Montana
DOC.TEXT: Contractors are doing a booming business in fallout shelters, but the influx of hundreds of members of a religious group preparing for nuclear Armageddon is jamming telephone lines in this rural community. ``We go through periods where the phone doesn't ring at all, an hour, two hours at a time,'' Tim Barnes, general manager of the Chico Hot Springs resort, said Thursday. ``Then the phone might suddenly come open and we'll have a flood of calls.'' The local population of members of the Church Universal and Triumphant mushroomed this year after spirtual leader Elizabeth Clare Prophet warned members that March and April are dangerous times, and suggested they come to Montana to make preparations for a possible nuclear war or accident. The influx has meant a boom for area contractors building fallout shelters for church members in the scenic mountain valley just north of Yellowstone National Park. But it also has led to an increased demand for telephone service that has overloaded the valley's antiquated central telephone system. ``We have had in the last month some rapid and unexpected growth in the Paradise Valley,'' said Crystal Shors, spokeswoman for US West Communications. ``It's basically exhausted the call-switching capability'' of the system. The church sponsors two housing developments at Emigrant in southwestern Montana, where Park County officials say as many as 45 private underground fallout shelters exist. Officials said in January that about 500 people lived at the developments, and that the numbers have increased since then. Shors said new telephone equipment will be installed within two weeks to improve service, but that a more complete system will not be ready until fall. And while Barnes worries about losing summer reservations because of problems with the telephone lines, that doesn't mean his business has hard feelings for Church Universal members. Some are even staying at the resort while they try to find a place to live. ``We've always had the policy that everyone is welcome here,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher's Conservatives Routed In Special Election
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with final results, Kinnock comment; picks up 7th pvs, `The previous...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LON5
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's candidate suffered a spectacular defeat in a special parliamentary election, losing a Conservative Party stronghold in a rebuke of a new tax and high interest rates. The opposition Labor Party today rejoiced in seizing the prosperous central England district of Mid-Staffordshire, overturning a majority of more than 14,000 for the Conservatives' worst loss in a special election in half a century. The Conservative loss Thursday was likely to renew speculation that worried rank-and-file legislators might try to dump Mrs. Thatcher as leader before the next general election, due by mid-1992. Labor leader Neil Kinnock today called the victory ``monumental'' and said it marked a turning point for the Conservatives who ``are going to have to make up their minds how quickly they get rid of Mrs. Thatcher.'' Labor candidate Sylvia Heal, a social worker, more than doubled the party's votes from the last election in 1987 to win 49 percent and a 9,449-vote plurality. ``There has been a significant change in attitude of the people of this constituency and I believe of the country,'' Mrs. Heal told cheering supporters. The Conservatives' Charles Prior got 33 percent and the centrist Social and Liberal Democratic Party candidate 11 percent. The remaining vote were scattered among the Greens, a splinter centrist party and fringe candidates. The swing to Labor from the Conservatives was 21.33 percent, with 77.5 percent of eligible voters casting ballots. Mrs. Heal polled 27,649 votes, Prior 18,200 votes, and Social and Liberal candidate Tim Jones, 6,315 votes. Eleven other candidates got a total of 4,195 votes. The previous Conservative member of Parliament, who committed suicide in December, won Mid-Staffordshire with 50 percent of the vote in Britain's 1987 general election. ``This is a bad result,'' said Conservative Party chairman Kenneth Baker. ``However, the government has had to take difficult decisions over inflation and the economy.'' Baker blamed the loss on protest votes cast against Mrs. Thatcher's government and its new community charge tax. The tax, dubbed a poll tax and designed to replace property taxes in financing local government, has caused ``temporary unpopularity,'' he said. Under the tax, each district charges a set amount per head regardless of income. A BBC survey Thursday night of the four latest opinion polls showed Labor surged to a 21-point lead nationally. It was Labor's biggest lead since Mrs. Thatcher came to power 11 years ago. A year ago, the Tories had a 10-point lead nationally. ``This is a stunning victory for Labor,''' said Jack Cunningham, the party's campaign manager. ``It is a political landmark that proves that Labor can win across Britain.'' Thatcher aides had braced for defeat in Mid-Staffordshire, but Labor's victory margin was wider than expected. Exit polls by Harris and National Opinion Poll said voters also showed antipathy toward Mrs. Thatcher personally. Harris reported that 84 percent of defecting Conservatives said Mrs. Thatcher should resign before the next general election and National Opinion Poll said 38 percent wanted her to go. Cunningham said voters were ``absolutely fed up with Mrs. Thatcher.'' ``She is out of touch, she doesn't seem to understand their problems ... and she doesn't seem to care,'' he said. The contest in the 71,200-voter constituency attracted national attention as the first since nationwide rallies erupted against the new tax. In what Labor Party members called an ``ignominious retreat,'' Mrs. Thatcher on Thursday extended poll tax rebates to Scotland, where the tax was introduced a year ago. Another campaign issue was interest rates, which have doubled to 15 percent in under two years. The government is trying to curb inflation with high interest rates, but with little success so far. Inflation runs at 7.7. percent. The government is counting on a drop in inflation by early next year so it can lower interest rates in time for the general election. The Mid-Staffordshire district includes skilled blue-collar workers who voted Conservative through the 80s and now have been hit hard by high home loan rates. Despite the loss, Mrs. Thatcher kept overwhelming control of the 650-member House of Commons, where she has 374 seats and Labor has 229. The Social and Liberal Democrats have 19 seats, and the rest are held by minority parties.

DOC.HEAD: Rights Group: Violations at Worst Levels Since Early 1980s ^By DOUGLAS GRANT MINE ^Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Respect for human rights in the war-ravaged nation has deteriorated to its lowest level since death squads killed thousands in the early 1980s, a U.S. monitoring organization reported. Americas Watch said in a 272-page report issued Thursday that the deterioration underscores ``the failure of U.S. human rights policy in El Salvador throughout the decade.'' Washington has provided $3.8 billion in aid to El Salvador since 1980, but several U.S. congressmen have expressed reluctance to continue the funding. The report contends there has been an increase in torture by security forces, escalation of death-squad activity, assassination of civilian officials by leftist rebels, indiscriminate use of homemade guerrilla mortars and several instances of massacres by government troops. The November offensive by fighters of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, of FMLN, signalled the worsening in human rights conditions, according to the report. ``The military crisis exacerbated tensions within the military and thrust extremist elements to the fore. The rhetoric of high officials reflected the charged intensity of the moment, and spurred some units to engage in lawless actions. Targeted killings by both the Armed Forces and the FMLN increased,'' it said. The report cites the Nov. 16 murder by army troops of six Jesuit educators, their housekeeper and her daughter at Central American University as cause ``to wonder at how little things have actually changed in El Salvador.'' A colonel, three lieutenants and four soldiers have been arrested and charged in the Jesuit massacre. ``Despite limited progress in the prosecuttion of the Jesuit case, there is a real danger that the true authors of crime may not have been identified, and that the highest ranking officer implicated so far will not be convicted or punished,'' said Americas Watch, which is based in New York. Between 1980 and 1984, officially sponsored or tolerated right-wing death squads killed up to 30,000 suspected leftists. ``While the numbers of targeted killings in recent years do not approach the carnage of the early 1980s, the trend has not been towards steady improvement,'' the report said. ``Moreover, declining numbers of political murders do not indicate greater respect for human rights within the armed forces or enhanced freedom to express political dissent. The level of violence is still such that it is dangerous to express certain views or maintain certain associations.'' The report recalls the March 24, 1980 assassination of Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero. Though evidence implicating extreme rightists was compiled by the 1984-89 Christian Democratic government, no one has been charged with involvement in that murder. ``The murder of Archbishop Romero in 1980 and the slaying of the Jesuits in 1989 stand as bookends to the decade offering harsh testimony about who really rules El Salvador and how little they have changed. Ten years later, priest-killing is still a preferred option for those who simply will not hear the cries for change and justice in a society that has had too little of either,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: 100,000 Deaths a Year From Alcohol, CDC Says
DOC.TEXT: Federal health officials, while characterizing alcohol abuse as a major health problem, say it's difficult to determine how many drinks it takes to cause such diseases as cancer or tuberculosis. The national Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday that its researchers used computer software to project how often various causes of death are related to drinking. Then they projected the loss of life _ and lost life-years _ from drinking. In 1987, the latest year for which projections are available, 105,095 Americans died either from drunken injury or diseases linked to drinking. When the victims' life expectancy was figured in, alcohol robbed them of more than 2.7 million years of life _ or about 26 years each. The leading booze-related cause of death: injuries, chiefly in drunken-driving crashes. Unintentional injuries related to alcohol killed 30,205 Americans in 1987, 29 percent of alcohol-related deaths. Second were digestive diseases, including alcoholic cirrhosis of the liver; they killed 19,556. ``This does not mean a problem for everyone who drinks,'' said Dr. James Shultz of the University of Miami School of Medicine, the lead researcher for the CDC report. He noted that tens of millions of persons drink, adding: ``So a minority of those who drink have a fatal outcome.'' But the deaths from booze _ nearly 300 a day _ mean that ``alcohol is a major problem,'' Shultz said. ``Now, it's for policy-makers to assess that problem, and make determinations on ... appropriate policy.'' Studies of alcohol-related sickness and death are subject to much conjecture over ``who's in and who's out,'' and just what ``alcohol-related'' should mean _ binge drunkenness, heavy drinking or even moderate, life-long drinking, Shultz said. Shultz's study used estimates from previous research for various conditions: For example, mouth cancer deaths are believed alcohol-related 50 percent of the time, and respiratory tuberculosis deaths are alcohol-related 25 percent of the time. Even then, researchers disagree over the question of how much drinking makes someone's death ``alcohol-related,'' and not simply the natural death of someone who drank. But Shultz said most deaths from booze fall into two patterns: sudden, violent deaths from a dangerous drunken episode, and long-term, debilitating, heavy drinking that brings on disease. ``If we had everyone who drinks drinking very occasionally, at levels not likely to produce injury-prone, dangerous behavior, you'd have very few alcohol-related deaths,'' he said. The costs of alcohol-related deaths are high, the CDC said. In a related report from Wisconsin health officials, the CDC reported that 1,949 alcohol-related deaths occurred there in 1988, robbing victims of 46,052 years of life and wreaking economic costs _ from health care, police, lost productivity and other factors _ of $1.47 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``I'd like to go back to the sea. That's what I do.'' _ Exxon Valdez skipper Joseph Hazelwood after he was acquitted of the most serious charges involving the worst oil spill in U.S. history.

``The people of Idaho have said strongly what millions of Americans believe, that abortion is not an acceptable means of birth control.'' _ National Right to Life Committee legislative director Doug Johnson on the Idaho Legilature's approval of the most restrictive state abortion law.

``A military attack would be the end of perestroika, and Gorbachev's policy and his authority ... I don't think Gorbachev would take such a measure.'' _ Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene of Lithuania saying Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has too much to risk through the use of force to quell the republic's independence movement.

DOC.HEAD: Mattox Presses Drug Claim Against Richards
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Jim Mattox conceded he has no proof, but said he still believes his opponent for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, state Treasurer Ann Richards, has used illegal drugs. In calls to several news organizations Thursday, Mattox again raised the drug use question that Ms. Richards refused to answer in the weeks before the March 13 primary. ``I do not believe that a person who takes the Fifth Amendment can then go on and lead a war on drugs,'' Mattox said. The Richards campaign responded by producing the results of a blood test Ms. Richards took last weekend in Austin. The results were negative. Ms. Richards gathered the most votes in the primary, but not did not get a majority. She will face Mattox in a runoff April 10. Before the primary, Ms. Richards said she has not taken mood-altering substances since her release from a Minnesota alcohol dependency program in 1980. She has said that to comment further would discourage people who have recovered from drug and alcohol problems from seeking office. In his media blitz Thursday, Mattox said of Ms. Richards: ``The only logical question that always must be asked is `What kind of things did you use before 1980? And where did you get them? How often did you use them? Who supplied them to you?''' He told WOAI in San Antonio that he's ``not in doubt'' that Ms. Richards has used illegal drugs. Richards' spokesman, Monte Williams, said the candidate took a drug test last weekend in response to questions about Democratic candidates' willingness to take such a test. Mattox has not taken a drug test, but a spokeswoman said he would. Mattox has persistently said he has never taken illegal drugs.

DOC.HEAD: Fadlallah Speaks of `New' Hostage Situation
DOC.TEXT: Lebanon's most influential Shiite Moslem cleric today spoke of a ``new situation'' regarding the fate of the Western hostages held by pro-Iranian underground factions in Lebanon. However, Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, the reputed spiritual leader of the Iranian-backed Hezbollah group, said he had no specific information about when any of the hostages might be freed. Most of the 18 Westerners missing are believed held by Shiite Moslem groups loyal to Iran. A statement released by Fadlallah's office said the clergyman, asked about the possibility of a hostage release in a radio interview, replied: ``A new situation has emerged, but I don't know when, how and where.'' No further remarks on the issue were included in the release. Also today, the weekly magazine Ash-Shiraa said Fadlallah had replied through an intermediary to questions from former President Jimmy Carter on the issue. The story dealt with the hostages' whereabouts and the possibility of releasing them, but gave no specific examples. Fadlallah visited Damascus during Carter's visit to the Syrian capital earlier this month. Diplomatic sources have said the two did not meet. Fadlallah said Feb. 23 that the issue of the Western captives was being exploited to distort Islam's image and called for a humanitarian approach to free them. His remarks echoed an earlier editorial in the English-language Tehran Times newspaper in Iran, which often reflects the thinking of President Hashemi Rafsanjani. The past month has seen a series of contradictory statements over the fate of the hostages, indicating a fight over the issue within the Tehran government. Moderates led by Rafsanjani have said the hostage issue was moving toward a solution, while radicals lead by Parliament member Ali Mohammed Mohtashemi have encouraged the captors to hold onto the hostages. The radicals are believed to hold more sway over the factions in Lebanon actually holding the Westerners, with Hezbollah considered an umbrella group for them. The Revolutionary Justice Organization, which holds two of the eight American hostages, said in a statement March 7 no hostages will be freed. Addressing Fadlallah, without referring to him by name, the statement expressed sorrow over ``irresponsible declarations by local friends'' to free the hostages. ``We call upon them (friends) to concentrate their humanitarian attempts on areas that can be more positive,'' the statement added. Most of the hostages have been held for more than three years. The longest-held is American Terry Anderson, the chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985. In another report, Ash-Shiraa said alleged U.S.-Iranian negotiations have ``reached their final stages after agreement was reached on almost all topics, including the issue of the foreign hostages. '' ``What's left is only carrying out the agreement according to acceptable scenarios that would save face for Iran and guarantee for Washington...its return to strategically vital Iran,'' said the report, which cited no sources. Ash-Shiraa gained international recognition in 1987 for breaking the story that the Reagan administration was trading arms for U.S. hostages. However, its frequent reports over the past two years that a hostage release was imminent have not proved accurate. Both Iran and the United States have denied a spate of recent reports that they are negotiating directly on the hostage issue.

DOC.HEAD: Man Convicted in 33-Year-Old Murder Case
DOC.TEXT: A jury found a man guilty of murdering his 11-year-old cousin, 33 years after the boy was found sodomized and hanging from a clothesline. Richard Ruff, 53, was found guilty Thursday of murdering his cousin, William Ruff Jr., on Aug. 31, 1957. The verdict ended what authorities said was the longest unsolved homicide investigation in state history. Ruff showed no emotion when the verdict was read. Mildred Ruff, the victim's mother, sobbed quietly as she sat with family members in court. ``Everything is at rest now and we'll be at peace,'' Ms. Ruff said. Two medical witnesses for the prosecution said ``Billy'' Ruff was sodomized and strangled before being hung from a clothesline attached to a tree in a brush-covered lot near the family's suburban Albany home. Richard Ruff, then in the Air Force, was home on leave at the time of his cousin's death. In convicting Ruff of first-degree felony murder, the jury concluded that he killed his cousin in the commission or the attempted commission of sodomy. He faces a maximum sentence of life in prison without parole. Judge Thomas W. Keegan set sentencing for April 19. Ruff is already serving a state prison sentence of four to 12 years for sexually molesting two girls in Hoosick Falls in Rensselaer County. Ruff, who served on the Albany police force for several months in 1958, was not a suspect in the unsolved murder until 1988. That was when Christopher Ruff, the victim's brother, spotted a wanted poster for Richard Ruff on the child sex abuse charges in Hoosick Falls. Christopher Ruff, an Albany County sheriff's deputy, alerted investigators. State police tracked Richard Ruff down in Orlando, Fla., and he was returned to New York. ``Billy is in peace,'' said Christopher Ruff after the verdict. Public defender Joseph McCoy contended William Ruff Jr. was hanged accidentally while swinging from a tree. McCoy said he will appeal the verdict.

DOC.HEAD: Eighth Cabinet Minister Acknowledges Recruit Donations
DOC.TEXT: An eighth member of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's new Cabinet today acknowledged receiving donations from a company at the center of an influence-buying scandal. ``I would like to make a sincere apology,'' said Takashi Fukaya, the post and telecommunications minister, at a nationally televised meeting of the upper house budget committee. Fukaya said his support group received more than $5,200 from Recruit Co. over 3{ years until July 1988, when the scandal surfaced. He also said his support group ``mistakenly'' continued to receive Recruit money until that November but returned all contributions made after August. Fukaya had earlier said he did not receive donations from Recruit after July 1988. In a news conference last week, he promised a further review of his records when asked about allegations he received money after that summer. He said the ``inaccuracies'' resulted from ``my lack of explanation, misunderstandings and insufficient communciation with my office staff.'' Twelve politicians, public officials and Recruit executives are facing charges of bribery in connection with the Recruit stock deals. Former Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita resigned to take responsibility. The scandal contributed to a major election loss and cleared the way for the rise of Kaifu, who took office with a clean image and promises of political reforms but has since acknowledged receiving $102,800 in Recruit donations. The information conglomerate offered thousands of cut-rate stock shares to powerful lawmakers and business leaders before the shares were listed for public sale. The company has also been criticized for doling out millions of dollars in political donations. Kaifu today promised he will investigate whether Fukaya's actions violated ethical guidelines, and said he will announce by early April whether punishment is in order. At a parliamentary session in early March, Kaifu said he and six other members of his new Cabinet had received donations from Recruit. Kaifu said all of these ministers had received donations before the Recruit scandal had surfaced. Though the statement followed numerous comments by the prime minister that he would try to keep politicians tainted with Recruit case or other scandals out of his administration, he has taken no action against the ministers. The prime minister said Fukaya did not identify himself as a recipient of donations from Recruit when he was choosing members of his second Cabinet following a Feb. 18 election victory by the governing Liberal Democratic Party. Meanwhile, Socialist Ryosuke Yasutsune demanded Kaifu comment on a report by a mass-circulation weekly magazine Shukan Bunshun that Kaifu had received $170,000 from Recruit. ``Why don't you take action, such as demanding Bunshun publish a correction and apology, to gain the public understanding if the story is false?'' said Yasutsune. ``I also want to remind you that you should follow your predecessors and take responsibility in case any new facts about you are revealed.''

DOC.HEAD: Ad Company Has Designs on Berlin Wall
DOC.TEXT: Part of the Berlin Wall, which was a symbol of socialism and a barrier to capitalism for nearly three decades, could be turned into a giant billboard. The East German advertising firm WuVA has acquired local government rights to a 3,300-foot section of the Berlin Wall, the newspaper Neues Deutschland said Thursday. Company chief Andreas Dademasch wants to paint the wall white and recruit German companies to rent space on the structure, huge sections of which already have been demolished by freedom lovers and souvenir seekers. Some of the money would go to the city and posters advertising such vices as cigarettes, alcohol or sex-related products would not be allowed, he said. The wall, tightly guarded since East Germany erected it in 1961, was opened in November after huge demonstrations forced hard-line Communists from power. Dademasch said his plans for part of the wall would be consistent with the trumpeting of capitalism by Christian Democratic Union chief Lothar de Maziere, whose party leads an alliance that won Sunday's election in East Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Hong Kong to Ban Ivory Trade in July
DOC.TEXT: The Hong Kong government today proposed to outlaw trade in ivory in this British colony by July. Under legislation introduced today, the import or export of ivory will be banned as part of an international agreement to save Africa's elephants, whose population has dropped from 1.5 million in the 1970s to about 600,000. Poachers kill the elephants for their tusks, which are used here to make intricate ivory artwork. The proposal is open for public and legislative comments. If passed, it will become law on July 17, said Mary Leung, spokeswoman for the Agricultural and Fisheries Department. An international conference agreed in October to ban worldwide trade in ivory from January. Hong Kong's ivory traders and carvers condemned the decision, claiming it would destroy their livelihood. Hong Kong was eventually allowed a six-month delay on the ban to allow it to eliminate a 670-ton stockpile of ivory, worth an estimated $128 million. ``The bill fully demonstrates that Hong Kong has no intention whatsoever of extending ivory trade beyond the six-month reservation period,'' the Agricultural and Fisheries Department said in a statement.

DOC.HEAD: Snow in Northern Plains; Cold Snap Threatens Livestock
DOC.TEXT: Snow fell across the northern Plains today as it followed a cold snap that is threatening livestock in Kansas. Snow was falling today in central Montana, western South Dakota, much of Nebraska and east-central Wyoming as the cold front moved eastward. Advisories for stockmen were posted in Kansas late Thursday until Saturday. The sharp change to cold and wet weather will be hazardous to very young livestock, it said. In the Southwest, temperatures were unseasonably warm Thursday. Records for the date were broken for El Paso, Texas, where it was 84, and three cities in Arizona. Phoenix was 94, Tucson 90 and Flagstaff was 67. Colder temperatures with gusty winds moved across Washington state Thursday, bringing snow flurries to the eastern portion of the state. Snow was falling early today in Spokane. Authorities lifted one flood warning in Georgia Thursday, but some residents along the Flint and Ocmulgee rivers prepared to evacuate. The Flint was expected to crest today, and the Ocmulgee on Saturday. The high temperature for the nation Thursday was 97 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif. Marie 21 snow; San Antonio 62 cloudy. _West: Albuquerque 50 fair; Anchorage 23 fair; Boise 53 showery; Casper 14 snow; Fairbanks 18 fair; Great Falls 09 snow; Honolulu 70 fair; Las Vegas 68 fair; Los Angeles 56 foggy; Medford 47 fair; Pendleton 32 rain; Phoenix 71 fair; Portland, Ore., 49 cloudy; Reno 47 fair; Salt Lake City 50 cloudy; San Diego 57 cloudy; San Francisco 52 drizzle; Seattle 39 rain; Spokane 26 snow. _International: Calgary 01 fair; Montreal 46 rain; Ottawa 43 cloudy; Regina 03 fair; Toronto 36 partly cloudy; Winnipeg 01 fair; Merida 68 partly cloudy; San Juan 72 partly cloudy.

DOC.HEAD: Pryor Hospitalized After Heart Attack in Australia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with agent saying Pryor in good condition, spirits; picks up 9th pvs, `Pryor has...'
DOC.TEXT: Richard Pryor was hospitalized after suffering a mild heart attack in northeastern Australia, and his agent said today that the comedian and actor was in stable condition and in good spirits. Pryor was admitted to Wesley Hospital three days ago with chest pains, a hospital statement said today. It said Pryor was diagnosed as having suffered a minor heart attack. Pryor, 49, was expected to be released early next week, said his agent, Guy McElwaine. ``Obviously, something like this tempers anyone,'' McElwaine told Austrlaian Associated Press. ``It scares me and it scares him. But he's in good spirits and making a few jokes. ``He said to me: Now you'll see what I'll go through to create new material,'' said McElwaine, who flew to Australia from Los Angeles to see him. The Australian news agency said the comedian had been vacationing at the Sanctuary Cove resort in northeastern Queensland state. McElwaine, Pryor's agent for 15 years, said Pryor was taken to a hospital near the resort after complaining of chest pains and then transferred to the Wesley for tests. The hospital spokeswoman, Janice Wyatte, said Pryor was on a private visit. She did not say when he arrived in Australia or how long he planned to stay. ``He is in a very stable condition. He had some more tests this morning,'' Ms. Wyatte said. Pryor has appeared thin and in poor health in recent public appearances. The comedian was very nearly killed in 1980 while ``free-basing'' cocaine, which involves heating the drug over an open flame. Pryor has starred in several movies based on his stand-up comedy performances, including ``Richard Pryor Here and Now,'' ``Richard Pryor Live in Concert'' and ``Richard Pryor Is Back Live in Concert.'' The comedian recounted his drug and other experiences in the films ``Richard Pryor Live on the Sunset Strip'' and ``Jo Jo Dancer, Your Life is Calling.'' Other film credits include ``Harlem Nights,'' ``Stir Crazy,'' ``See No Evil, Hear No Evil,'' ``Brewster's Millions'' and ``Critical Condition.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th item, Neubacher obit, to CORRECT name in second sentence of 4th graf to Neubacher sted Blanchard.
DOC.TEXT: Jim Neubacher, a Detroit Free Press columnist who became an outspoken advocate of handicapped rights after developing multiple sclerosis, died Thursday. He was 40. The cause of death was not available. Neubacher joined the Free Press staff in 1971. He worked as a city desk reporter and was the newspaper's first Canada correspondent. In 1980 at age 29, Neubacher was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis. He returned to Detroit two years later and began to write his weekly column, Disabled in Detroit. Neubacher became a leader for disabled activists across the state. Neubacher is survived by his parents, James and Margaret, a brother and three sisters.

DOC.HEAD: Man Charged With Possessing Stolen Rare Books Has 20-Year Arrest Record
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to include full first reference to Blumberg.
