DOC.TEXT: A man charged with possessing $20 million worth of stolen rare books has a 20-year history of arrests on theft charges, but kept getting off lightly, according to a police officer investigating thefts at a university library. ``I know his measurements. I know his mannerisms, but I've never met him. But I'd know him if he walked in the door,'' Cpl. J. Steve Huntsberry of the Washington State University Police Department at Pullman, Wash., said Thursday. ``I've traced his trail throughout the United States.'' Stephen Carrie Blumberg, 41, was arrested Tuesday in Ottumwa, in southeastern Iowa, and charged with possessing stolen goods worth more than $5,000 and knowingly taken across state lines. The FBI said 11,000 rare books and documents at his home in Ottumwa were stolen from universities and private collections across the country. The FBI began work Wednesday trying to match the thousands of books with reports of stolen materials. ``It's going to take months _ it could stretch well over a year,'' said FBI agent Larry Holmquist. Huntsberry said he was assigned full-time in December 1987 to study the theft of $500,000 worth of books from Washington State University's Holland Library. He said he had not determined if any of the Holland Libary's books were seized in Ottumwa. He chronicled Blumberg's arrests from Riverside, Calif., to Dubuque, Iowa, for an article in the February issue of ``Library & Archival Security'' magazine, a trade journal published by Haworth Press of Binghamton, N.Y. Blumberg kept getting off with ``a slap on the wrist,'' Huntsberry said. Don Nickerson, an attorney representing Blumberg, said Thursday, ``As far as I'm concerned, that's just unverified information.'' Officials in Riverside, Calif.; Greeley, Colo.; and Dubuque, Iowa, confirmed the arrests on charges of possessing burglary tools, larceny and theft. Huntsberry said Blumberg was first arrested at age 19 in Dubuque on charges of stealing antique doorknobs. Dubuque police confirmed that warrants were issued for Blumberg in December 1967 for carrying a concealed weapon and in February 1968 for larceny. There was no word if the cases resulted in prosecution; the Dubuque County attorney's office said records that old were not available. Huntsberry said the first arrest linking Blumberg to rare books was in 1974 in Fort Lupton, Colo., near Greeley, where he ``had his car just stuffed from the rafters to the floor with books'' from universities in Iowa, Nebraska, Minnesota and Colorado. Tom Quammen, an assistant district attorney in the area, said Blumberg was charged with felony theft in April 1974, but a judge dismissed the case later that year. Huntsberry said he discovered that a man arrested at the University of California-Riverside Library on charges of possessing burglary tools and trespassing had the schedule for Holland Library in his briefcase. The man gave the name Matt McGue but fingerprint comparisons identified the man as Stephen Carrie Blumberg, Huntsberry said. The district attorney's office in Riverside County, Calif., said a charge of possessing burglary tools was filed against a Matt McGue in April 1988. The Riverside Municipal Court said the man pleaded guilty to trespassing and to possessing instruments with intent to break and enter, and was fined $1,065 and given three years summary probation. Blumberg's father, Henry, a retired physician from Shoreview, Minn., described his son as ``kind of an eccentric genius. This son of mine is an oddball if you ever saw one.'' He said his son, who lived off a family trust fund, had a 30-year history of mental problems and had spent time in psychiatric hospitals in Minnesota, Ohio and Kansas.

DOC.HEAD: Successful Surgery on Singer's Broken Back
DOC.TEXT: The doctor who operated on Gloria Estefan's spine says the surgery was a success and he expects the singer, known for her energetic dancing on stage, will fully recover in three to six months. ``She'll be able to do everything, including dance,'' Dr. Michael Neuwirth said at a news conference Thursday at the Orthopedic Institute Hospital for Joint Diseases in Manhattan. Estefan, 32, star of the Latin-pop group Miami Sound Machine, was brought to the hospital by helicopter Wednesday after her tour bus was hit by a truck in Pennsylvania. The operation involved implanting two steel rods into her spine. She fractured two vertebrae. Estefan felt numbness and weakness in her legs after the accident. Neuwirth said monitors recorded ``substantial improvement in the electrical conduction of the nerves to her left leg'' during the surgery. ``We were able to accomplish all our initial goals of surgery, which was to restore the normal line of the spine and remove the pressure that existed against the spinal cord,'' he said. Estefan probably would be released from the hospital in a week to 10 days but will be required to wear a plastic brace and undergo therapy, Neuwirth said. Her husband, Emilio, 37, thanked the doctors and Estefan's fans for their concern and support. ``I don't care if she never danced again,'' he said. ``I'm just happy she's alive.'' He received minor injuries in the accident and appeared at the news conference with a bandaged right hand. Their 9-year-old son, Nayab, suffered a broken collarbone. The Cuban-born singer and her group were headed to Syracuse on Tuesday for a concert when their tour bus was struck from behind by a tractor-trailer on a highway near Tobyhanna, Pa. Estefan was thrown from a couch where she was sleeping. Pennsylvania State Police said Thursday that an inspection of the truck showed it had faulty brakes. The trucker, Heraldo E. Samuels, was cited for driving at an unsafe speed and will face additional charges, police said. Well-wishers have included President Bush, who met Estefan Monday to talk about her anti-drug work; Elton John; Madonna; Bruce Springsteen and Jon Bon Jovi. Miami Sound Machine hits include ``Rhythm Is Gonna Get You,'' and ``Anything for You.'' Estefan was nominated for a Grammy in February for ``Don't Wanna Lose You,'' a cut from her solo album.

DOC.HEAD: Government Complains Marcos Lawyer Talks Too Much to The Press
DOC.TEXT: The judge in the fraud trial of Imelda Marcos used humor to respond to government complaints that the attorney for the former Philippine first lady was talking too much to the press. ``You're not going to be on `60 Minutes' again?'' U.S. District Judge John F. Keenan asked Mrs. Marcos' attorney, Gerald Spence. The judge referred to a profile of Spence the CBS News show aired several years ago. ``It depends on what you're going to do to me,'' Spence said. ``How about `Saturday Night Live'?'' the judge said with a smile. The exchange took place during the third day of jury selection Thursday after Assistant U.S. Attorney Debra Livingston gave Keenan a letter charging that Spence's numerous interviews threatened ``the government's right to a fair trial.'' The interviews the prosecutor referred to were excerpts from an NBC-TV ``Today Show'' broadcast on Tuesday and comments made to several newspapers before the trial began in federal court. The judge gently admonished Spence to cut back on media appearances but stopped short of a gag order. By the end of the court day Thursday, Keenan had selected a pool of 31 potential jurors. A final panel of 12 jurors and six alternates is to be chosen from the pool next week. Mrs. Marcos, 60, is charged in the alleged illegal transfer of more than $160 million from the Manila government and defrauding banking institutions of another $165 million. Her husband, former Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos, was named in the original 1988 indictment but died in Hawaii Sept. 28. Also on trial is Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi, accused of helping the Marcoses conceal a series of New York real estate deals allegedly financed in part with money stolen from the Philippines treasury.

DOC.HEAD: Poll Puts Opposition Ahead on Eve of Australian Election
DOC.TEXT: An opinion poll released today showed a last-minute swing toward the conservative opposition, indicating Prime Minister Bob Hawke might be thwarted in his bid for a record fourth consecutive term. Hawke, the Labor Party leader, has said Saturday's parliamentary election was the most important in more than 40 years. He said the vote would set Australia's course into the 21st century. Hawke, in office seven years, is the most enduring and popular Labor Party leader and goes into the election on his record of economic reform. His opponent, Liberal Party leader Andrew Peacock, 51, has hammered the government over high interest rates, which at a record 18 percent hurt home buyers and small businesses. But few issues were discussed in the campaign. The Hawke government, first elected in 1983, then again in 1984, and 1987, faces other domestic problems as well. The foreign debt stands at $100 billion, and a lengthy pilots' dispute has crippled tourism. Earlier polls indicated a close result, but Morgan Gallup said today taht Peacock's coalition of the Liberal and National parties led the government 42 percent to 39.5 percent. The poll results, shown on national television, did not say how many people were surveyed or give a margin of error. Australia has 10.6 million voters and voting is compulsory. Most major newspapers today threw their support behind the 60-year-old prime minister. The Sydney Morning Herald said, ``The Hawke government should be re-elected, not because its record of economic management is perfect, but because it is more likely than Mr. Peacock to solve economic problems.'' Editorial writers have called it an election without issues, noting that foreign policy and defense have not been questions. Australia is a close U.S. ally, and President Bush today said he wanted to visit Australia soon, but not before the election. ``If there is any national mood overall, it is that an angry electorate wants to kick Hawke in the teeth to teach him a lesson but cannot quite bring itself to vote for Peacock,'' wrote the Courier-Mail newspaper of Brisbane. Campaigning has been muted. The Herald observed: ``Each party leader has the combined charisma of a wet salad sandwich.'' Peacock, a former foreign minister, is making his second attempt to become prime minister and is widely regarded as fighting his last political battle. He drew charges of racism this week after saying his coalition would scrap a Japanese proposal to build a multibillion-dollar futuristic, high-tech city in Australia. Peacock said he was opposed to ceating an ``enclave.'' Hawke responded that Peacock was against immigrants, a serious charge in a country whose first settlers were prisoners expelled from Britain. When the campaign began last month, Hawke said: ``I believe the election is the most important one since 1949,'' referring to a Labor loss that began 23 years in power for the Liberals. ``The election will essentially determine the character of the nation that we are going to have in the 21st century,'' Hawke said.

DOC.HEAD: Panama Expels Cuban Ambassador
DOC.TEXT: The government ordered Cuba's ambassador to leave the country within five days because he refuses to recognize the new administration of President Guillermo Endara. The Cuban government's position has been one of ``harassment, hostility and rejection,'' Foreign Minister Julio Linares said Thursday after telling Cuban Ambassador Lazaro Mora Secades he had to leave by Tuesday. ``We're not going to let a goverment that is saying it doesn't recognize President Endara maintain accredited diplomatic missions in Panama.'' Endara was installed at the beginning of the Dec. 20 U.S. invasion that ousted Panama's military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, who maintained friendly relations with Communist Cuba and shared President Fidel Castro's hostility toward the United States. Noriega took refuge at the Vatican Embassy before giving himself up to U.S. authorities and was flown to Florida to face federal drug trafficking and money-laundering charges. Several members of Noriega's family took refuge in the Cuban Embassy in Panama City after the American invasion. They have since been given safe conduct out of the country. Endara has ``a legitimacy that no other Latin American government enjoys, since no Latin American leader has been elected with an overwhelming 3-1 mayority,'' Linares said, referring to the May 1989 election Noriega anulled. The expulsion ``puts us on the edge of breaking of diplomatic relations'' with Cuba, Linares said. But, he added, ``Cuba can answer by breaking off diplomacy. That's its problem, that's its decision.'' Panama maintains a diplomatic mission in Cuba. Linares said that if diplomatic relations are broken, Cuban diplomats should take with them Luis Gomez, a leader of the paramilitary Dignity Battalions and a former congressman, who took refuge in the Cuban Embassy. Linares has said Panama refuses to let Gomez out of the country because two charges of assassination have been filed against him.

DOC.HEAD: American Loses Appeal of Murder Conviction
DOC.TEXT: An American who belonged to the Irish Republican Army lost an appeal today of his conviction for the 1975 murder of a London policeman. The Court of Appeal upheld the conviction of William Quinn, 42, who was extradited to Britain and sentenced to life in prison in February 1988 for shooting a 21-year-old constable, Stephen Tibble, while fleeing arrest. Quinn had appealed, claiming faulty identification by a policeman who saw the shooting. It ``offended against almost all the rules designed to safeguard suspects from misidentification,'' argued his attorney, Michael Mansfield. Lord Lane, presiding over the three-judge panel, conceded that it was ``very far from being the best sort of identification evidence.'' But ``it was relevant evidence of significant weight,'' and ``did not have such an adverse effect upon the fairness of the proceedings'' that it should have been disqualified, he said. After the shooting, Quinn went to Ireland, where he was jailed for 12 months for IRA membership. It was at that trial that he was secretly identified by a Scotland Yard detective, Adrian Blackledge, as Tibble's killer. Mansfield argued that such an identification was inadmissible in court, and that by failing to inform Quinn of it, the prosecution deprived him of an opportunity to establish an alibi. After his release from Irish prison, Quinn returned to the San Francisco area. Britain requested his extradition, and after a five-year legal fight he was flown to London by the FBI.

DOC.HEAD: Pakistan Parades Its Military Might
DOC.TEXT: Pakistan showed off its military muscle today during celebrations marking the 50th anniversary of a decision to create a Moslem nation from predominantly Hindu India. President Ghulam Ishaq Khan's speech at the Pakistan Day military parade was laced with warnings to India and promises that Pakistan would stand behind ``freedom movements.'' He referred specifically to the 2-month-old uprising in the disputed state of Jammu-Kashmir, where Moslem militants are fighting for independence. Ishaq Khan urged India to ``learn history's lesson that liberation movements cannot be suprressed or crushed with the use of might.'' The former princely state of Kashmir was divided between Pakistan and India following the end to British colonial rule in 1947. The president, who has been aligned with often hostile opposition parties, smiled and chatted with Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto throughout the two-hour parade, an indication that the two had reached an amicable understanding. Since taking power on Dec. 2, 1988, Ms. Bhutto and her right-wing opposition have been at loggerheads and periodically engage in so-called war of rallies, with each trying to eclipse the other in attendance. Ms. Bhutto's populist Pakistan People's Party staged a rally Tuesday in the eastern Punjab capital of Lahore, her opposition's homeground. Hundreds of thousands attended. Today, the opposition retaliated with its own rally. Local journalists said turnout was similar.

DOC.HEAD: House Approves Aid For Development in Rural America
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS 3rd graf to make it read, Coleman, R-Mo...., NOT R-Okla.
DOC.TEXT: Residents of small towns that are losing business and population because there are fewer farms in the United States are closer to getting help from the federal government. A rural development bill was approved 360-45 by the House and sent on Thursday to a conference committee for negotiators to work out differences with the Senate version. ``They can be meshed,'' said Rep. Glenn English, D-Okla., who wrote the House version with Rep. Tom Coleman, R-Mo. English said a key provision would establish state review panels to set priorities on how federal money should be used. He said the experts on those 16-member panels will represent many resources in the states and have access to money beyond that available in Washington. ``They probably are going to make the big difference when it is all said and done,'' English said. ``The concept of the panels is that it brings all the resources together.'' Representatives would come from government, business, and local community organizations. The bill was hung up for a week because of a dispute over how states could use about $800 million in three separate funds in the bill. Rep. Charles Rose, D-N.C., led a movement to stop the bill's authors from pooling the funds _ $600 million in sewer and water, $100 million in community facilities and $100 million in business and industry development. English and Coleman wanted to let states decide for themselves how to use the money so they could direct funds from the overall pool to where local officials decided it is most needed. But Rose successfully argued that the sewer and water fund might be depleted, leaving communities in worse shape than they're in now. On Thursday, the House reached a compromise that frees up $90 million of about $450 million government loans that can be used for either sewer and water or community facilities. It freezes all the grant money in the three categories as it is now. And, it allows the shifting of guaranteed loans among the three categories.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: After the LBJ Book, Should Ortega Monitor US Elections?
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS 8th graf, Can you ... to make it Gramm, R-Texas, sted D-Tex.
DOC.TEXT: In Panama last year and Nicaragua this year, the demand from Washington was unambiguous: hold a free and fair election. It's hard to imagine elections anywhere that were scrutinized more closely. Now comes a book by Robert Caro suggesting one of the most important U.S. elections of the post-war era was, in fact, rigged by Lyndon Johnson. Caro makes the case that the outcome of the 1948 Senate Democratic primary race in Texas did not reflect the will of the voters because Johnson stuffed ballot boxes with 35,000 phony votes, giving him an 87-vote margin over Coke Stevenson. Johnson, of course, went on to become Senate majority leader and president. The course of history was altered by what happened in 1948, assuming Caro got his facts straight; thus far, credible evidence to refute him has not surfaced. That election is not the only one about which questions have been raised. The public probably will never know whether John F. Kennedy actually beat Richard Nixon in 1960 because of strange happenings on election night in Illinois. The furor over Caro's book, arising as Nicaraguans were preparing to vote, raises the question: Does the U.S. have the moral authority to demand purity in foreign elections in light of the spotty record at home? The election run by Daniel Ortega was certainly more honest than the Texas primary Caro describes. Perhaps Ortega, soon to retire, should offer to monitor U.S. elections to ensure the will of the American people is not trampled on. Can you envision Ortega paying a visit to Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, on election night next November and asking him to respect the outcome of his bid for another term? ``To do otherwise would strike a blow at the democratic process,'' statesman Ortega might counsel Gramm. Kidding aside, the founding fathers got it right: government can't be trusted. There are pious moralisms in public statements and, at times, an anything goes attitude behind the scenes. All governments, for example, are very selective about when to express indignation. When an anti-communist is slain, say, in El Salvador, the U.S. government is quick to blame leftist guerrillas. When someone from the left is killed, U.S. officials invariably say they are puzzled about who did the deed. For years, the United States had been saying the big problem in Afghanistan was the Soviet military presence. Well, the Soviets have been gone for more than a year but the fighting persists, partly because U.S. weapons deliveries are still going to the Afghan rebels. John F. Burns, a New York Times reporter, writes that rebel rocket attacks killed an estimated 1,000 people in Kabul, the capital, last year and several times that many across the country. Among Afghans, Burns writes, ``the damage to American prestige has been immense.'' They now look on the United States as a distant power that sanctions ``the routine killing of civilians,'' he says. The State Department attitude is to say as little as possible about the rebel abuses. On the other hand, virtually every election abuse committed by the Sandinistas last winter was dealt with as a matter of utmost gravity. The U.S. government, of course, has no monopoly on hypocrisy and probably comes out better than most countries. Many Latin American presidents who attended the recent presidential inaugural in Chile took steps to avoid being photographed with the departing Augusto Pinochet. A dictator is one thing, but being associated with an unelected president was too much. But that high principle was set aside last year when the same Latin American presidents rallied behind Cuba for one of the coveted hemispheric seats in the U.N. Security Council. There are almost 20 countries in Spanish-speaking Latin America. Cuba is now the only one without an elected president, but now sits proudly in the Security Council. Of course, Cuba itself sometimes leaves itself open to allegations that it deviates from high principle. Government propagandists call Cuba ``the first free country of the Americas.'' Anyone who disputes that claim runs the risk of imprisonment.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: George Gedda has covered foreign affairs for the Associated Press since 1968.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Patrol Bogota After Assassination Sparks Protests
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with troops patrolling Bogota, drug baron denying involvement, army claiming evidence implicating him, 1 death and new casualty figures in fighting. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BOG1 of March 22
DOC.TEXT: Armored cars and jeeps mounted with machine guns patrolled the quiet capital today after the assassination of a left-wing presidential candidate caused fierce clashes between police and protesters. The government blamed a drug baron for Thursday's killing of Patiotic Union candidate Bernardo Jaramillo _ the second presidential contender slain in seven months. It said the killing marked a new anti-government offensive by drug traffickers. The head of the Medellin drug cartel, Pablo Escobar, sent a letter to a leftist leader denying any involvement in Jaramillo's death and suggesting that other drug traffickers were to blame, according to the Colombian radio networks RCN and Caracol. Jaramillo was shot Thursday morning at Bogota's international airport by a a young man who reached out as if to greet the candidate, then shot him with a submachine gun hidden in a newspaper. His bodyguards shot and wounded the gunman, a 16-year-old boy who carried false identification papers, before he was captured. At least two other people were reported wounded. Jaramillo, 38, was the 1,044th Patriotic Union Party member to be killed in the past six years. Many of the slayings have been attributed to right-wing death squads. Authorities say the squads are run by drug traffickers. Others say Colombia's army and police are involved in the squads to quell a leftist guerrilla insurgency. Jaramillo's body lay in state in the Capitol building. His killing caused battles Thursday between police and leftist protesters, who burned five buses and shattered store windows in downtown Bogota. Police said the fighting killed one soldier and wounded four policeman and a civilian. Armored cars with 20mm cannons and jeeps mounted with machine guns cruised the city of 6 million people this morning. The government banned alcohol sales and closed all private schools in Bogota. The city was calm. The Patriotic Union urged a national strike, but President Virgilio Barco appealed to Colombians to unite to confront ``the new offensive by the violent ones.'' A communique from the National Security Council said Escobar contracted Jaramillo's killer for about $750. Police intercepted a communication between Escobar to an associate in which they discussed the deal, the communique said. The head of the country's intelligence police, Miguel Maza Marquez, _ himself the target of attacks by drug traffickers _ said the young gunman told police the cartel was planning more attacks. The commander of the army brigade in Medellin, Gen. Harold Bedoya, said in an interview today with radio Caracol that the army had irrefutable proof of Escobar's guilt in the killing. He did not elaborate. Escobar this morning sent a letter to Diego Montana, the president of the Patriotic Union, according to the two radio networks. Both networks said they were sent copies of the letter, written in longhand and bearing what appeared to be the authentic signature and a fingerprint of Escobar. Escobar's letter reportedly said that another Medellin cartel leader, Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, had ordered the killing of Jaramillo last year. Escobar reportedly wrote that he intervened to stop the assassination. Rodriguez Gacha was killed Dec. 15 in a gunbattle with police on Colombia's north coast, but it is known that the head of his private army, Fidel Castano, has kept the Rodriguez Gacha faction together and wields great power among the traffickers. A man claiming to represent the Medellin cartel said in a telephone call to the Caracol radio network that Jaramillo's killing was the beginning of a new terrorist offensive. He said the next target would be Cesar Gaviria, the governing Liberal Party candidate in the elections May 27. ``He (Gaviria) could have 100 bodyguards or wear a bulletproof vest, including over his head, but he will be the next one,'' the caller said. Gaviria served as campaign chairman for Sen. Luis Carlos Galan, who was killed by traffickers at a political rally Aug. 18. Hours after Galan's death, Barco launched a crackdown on drug barons and began efforts to extradite them to the United States. In Colombia, traffickers often intimidate or bribe judges to ensure light sentences or no sentences. The Medellin drug cartel responded to Barco's crackdown with bombings that killed 209 Colombians before the group announced a truce on Jan. 17. The caller said the cartel renewed its attacks because Barco rejected its offer to surrender in exchange for an end to extraditions. The government has extradited 14 drug trafficking suspects to the United States. Barco has said the government will make no concessions to traffickers and that they should turn themselves in. The caller responded: ``Yes, we will turn ourselves in, but dead. Before that this country is going to be half destroyed because tomorrow we are going to renew terrorist attacks, especially against government and leftist objectives.'' ``You journalists, before you see our bodies, will see the bodies of other distinguished people in this country like Jaramillo.''

DOC.HEAD: General Now Doubts American Was Involved in Coup Attempt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Fixes spelling to impostor in grafs 1 and 9.
DOC.TEXT: A Filipino general who claimed a U.S. intelligence agent offered weapons to mutineers in the December coup attempt said today he now thinks the man was an impostor. Brig. Gen. Alejandro Galido, who spied on coup plotters, had said an American claiming to be a U.S. Air Force colonel and representative of the U.S. Defense Intelligence Agency told him in July that the agency ``favors the overthrow of the (President Corazon) Aquino government.'' Galido's statement released Wednesday said the man, who identified himself as Harold Magleo, promised to deliver weapons for the rebellion and that the U.S. Defense Intelligence Agency wanted Ferdinand Marcos returned to power. But in a television interview today, Galido, the former chief of the Southern Luzon Command, said he thought the man was posing as a U.S. agent. ``I really do not know his true identity. He could be one of those impostors, one who pretends to be an intelligence officer of the DIA,'' Galido said in an interview with Channel 2. The chief of staff, Gen. Renato de Villa, described Galido as a spy who infiltrated the ranks of the coup plotters and reported to him on the progress of the planned rebellion. The Dec. 1-9 coup attempt, which left at least 113 dead and 600 wounded, was sixth and most serious bid to topple Mrs. Aquino, who came to power after a popular uprising that ousted Marcos in 1986. Marcos fled to Hawaii, where he died in September. Defense Secretary Fidel Ramos also said he believed the man who spoke to Galido was an impostor. ``Now I have a feeling that this Magleo is an adventurer posing as a government agent or as a government official and we have all kinds of people like that whose services are for sale for a price, willing to undergo any dirty job,'' Ramos said. ``And so I think the best thing to do is look for this person.'' Mrs. Aquino said she was convinced Galido's sworn statements ``were prompted by his sense of patriotism.'' A U.S. Embassy spokeswoman, Victoria Middleton, said in a statement Thursday that allegations of U.S. government involvement in the coup attempt was ``totally false and without foundation.'' U.S. jet fighters provided air cover for loyal troops on the first day of the mutiny, turning the tide of the rebellion in favor of the government.

DOC.HEAD: Long Island Village Charged With Keeping Minorities Out of Subsidized Housing
DOC.TEXT: Federal prosecutors are charging a Long Island village and some of its officials with defrauding the government by scheming to keep minorities out of federally subsidized housing. The civil lawsuit, which seeks at least $10.5 million in damages plus the forfeiture of six Island Park homes illegally obtained by the defendants, was filed Thursday in federal court in Brooklyn. It is the first government lawsuit naming a HUD official since allegations of influence-peddling at the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development surfaced in 1988. Island Park officials, including the mayor and a former top aide in the New York HUD office, were accused of manipulating the housing ``to favor relatives, friends and associates, and employees of the Village of Island Park,'' court papers said. Federal prosecutors also have been looking into reputed soliciting of political funds for Sen. Alfonse M. D'Amato from builders who received HUD funds, but the Long Island Republican is not named in the lawsuit. Andrew J. Maloney, the U.S. attorney for the Eastern District of New York, has removed himself from the investigation because of his close connections to the senator. Maloney was recommended for the position by D'Amato. According to the complaint, Island Park Mayor Michael A. Parente and Geraldine McGann, a HUD official and village trustee; Harold Scully, the village clerk and others conspired to exclude blacks and Hispanics from housing in Island Park. Parente, who chose not to seek re-election, will be replaced as mayor on April 2. He was in Florida and no telephone number was available for him. Beginning in 1980, 44 single-family homes ranging in price from $40,000 to $63,700 were built in three phases under a HUD program, and federal officials had intended for at least 17 to go to minority families. While the village agreed to advertise the availability of the subsidized housing in black and Hispanic newspapers, the eventual buyers of the homes had been selected before the ads appeared, the lawsuit said. Ms. McGann's son, Daniel, and his wife purchased one of the subsidized homes, even though they were not eligible to receive one, according to the lawsuit, which also names McGann and his wife as defendants. According to the complaint, Ms. McGann became a paid trustee of the village in August 1982, while serving simultaneously as the special assistant to Joseph Monticciolo, the HUD regional administrator for Region II. In serving in the two roles, Ms. McGann on several occasions allegedly breached her ``fiduciary duty'' to HUD by voting for land dealings that ultimately were not in the best interests of the agency, the lawsuit maintains. She also was allegedly aware of the other defendants' manipulation of the husing program to the exclusion of blacks and other minorities. Ms. McGann, now assigned to HUD's Washington offices, is on leave until next month and her office could not provide a telephone number where she could be reached for comment. HUD said in a statement Thursday it began termination proceedings against Ms. McGann.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian President: Moscow Waging `Psychological Warfare'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 18 grafs to UPDATE with Lithuania sending letter to Soviet Parliament, new quotes from Landsbergis, Gorbachev military adviser. Pickup 9th graf, `It is....' Edits thereafter to tighten.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto VIL2
DOC.TEXT: Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis today accused Moscow of waging ``psychological warfare'' to force his Baltic republic to renounce its declaration of independence. And, in a letter to the Soviet Parliament, he said that any attempt by the Soviet government or military to interfere with the enforcement of Lithuanian law would be a violation of international law. Soviet armor rumbled through the Lithuanian capital's streets on Thursday, prompting the republic's leaders to issue a worldwide appeal for support and express concern that increasing Kremlin pressure would lead to violence. The appeal followed orders from Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev that Lithuania stop signing up its own volunteer forces. He gave Landsbergis two days to reply, and ordered citizens to surrender their firearms within a week. At the same time, Soviet military authorities ordered Lithuanian soldiers who deserted in the wake of independence to return to their units by Saturday, touching off fears that the rounding up of deserters would be used as a pretext to use military force. Landsbergis said he was ``concerned'' that both deadlines fell on Saturday. In Moscow, Gorbachev's military adviser, Marshal Sergei Akhromeyev, told reporters that the army would act in accordance with Soviet laws in dealing with deserters. Asked if mass arrests might not cause disruption in Lithuania and make Moscow look bad, Akhromeyev said: ``Whether it looks good or looks bad, there's an established order, even if some people don't like it.'' He said deserters would be detained and sent back to their units, where their fate would be determined. Some Lithuanians have deserted their units after complaining that fellow soldiers beat them in retaliation for their republic's declaration of independence. Landsbergis said the Kremlin ``was going from economic warfare to psychological warfare'' in its attempts to make Lithuania renounce its March 11 declaration, according to Rita Dapkus of the Parliament's information center. ``New troops and maneuvers suggest that this is a psychological war,'' Landsbergis told parliament today. Landsbergis' attitude toward Gorbachev appeared conciliatory. ``Perhaps he faces obstacles,'' he said, adding that he still believed in the Soviet leader and hoped his good sense and moderation will lead a resolution of the problems. Landsbergis appealed directly to the Soviet legislature for negotiations to solve the issues that Gorbachev has raised. A three-page letter was sent to the Supreme Soviet. ``Any attempt by the government or military organizations of the U.S.S.R. to interfere in enforcement of Lithuanian law in Lithuania will be viewed as a violation of generally recognized principles of international law,'' the letter said. The letter added that in a 1920 treaty, the Soviet Union recognized ``for all time'' the sovereign rights and independence of Lithuania. Landsbergis opened the session with an account of the U.S. Senate's resolution Thursday night urging Moscow to stop intimidating Lithuania and asking President Bush to consider granting the republic diplomatic recognition. ``The reaction was applause,'' Dapkus said. The Kremlin has said it would not use force to bring Lithuania back into the Soviet Union. But Lithuanians have become increasingly concerned by the growing Soviet military presence in their Baltic republic. ``It is clear that another republic is going to use force against Lithuania and its citizens,'' said a Lithuanian government appeal to the world issued late Thursday. ``We are asking people to prevent this by protesting the possible use of violence against a member of the world community, against Lithuania and its citizens.'' A Lithuanian journalist identified only as R. Valatka said Thursday on late-night Lithuanian television that KGB officials had been going around to police stations asking for counts of their weapons. The republic's police force has not been asked to turn in its arms, but Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene said the KGB ``might even try to take weapons from the police, I don't know.'' ``We need support, we need help,'' said Ludwigas Sabutis, the republic's parliamentary secretary. Landsbergis told the Supreme Council legislature Thursday that the republic would not use weapons, even if the Soviet Union crushed its drive for full independence. ``If tanks are sent to take away shotguns and hunting rifles, we won't shoot at the tanks,'' he said. ``Our resistance will be non-violence.'' Gorbachev, in a telegram to Landsbergis, demanded a halt to formation of volunteer brigades in Lithuania that he said were intended to replace Soviet border guards and part of the uniformed police. He gave Landsbergis two days to repond. Although volunteers are signing up for the squads in Lithuania, no brigades have been formed and there are no indications they would be armed. The official Soviet news agency Tass said border controls and exit and entry in Lithuania were being tightened in keeping with a directive Wednesday from Gorbachev. Gorbachev has called Lithuania's declaration of independence illegal but has also said he would not use force to keep it from seceding from the Soviet Union. Lithuania was independent from 1918 until 1940, when the Soviet Union forcibly annexed it along with Latvia and Estonia. So far, no foreign country has officially recognized Lithuania as independent. The republic of 3.8 million had rushed to declare its independence before Gorbachev gained broad powers that include authority to impose direct presidential rule on areas of the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Donald, Ivana and Marla _ All Under One Roof
DOC.TEXT: Not only has Donald Trump kept the whereabouts of his alleged mistress Marla Maples a close secret, he has kept her close, according to a published report. Ms. Maples is living in the Trump Tower across the hall from Trump, gossip columnist Liz Smith reported in today's editions of the Daily News. Ms. Maples moved into the building in December, Smith said, and has been coming and going during the past 5{ weeks of intensive media scrutiny. After Trump's separation from his wife, Ivana, became public in February, Donald moved in across the hall, Smith said. Sources told the News that Ms. Maples has evaded detection by driving into a side entrance and taking a service elevator directly her 63rd floor apartment. Ivana Trump reportedly was infuriated that Ms. Maples was living just three floors below the triplex apartment where she lives with her children. ``I am shocked and saddened that Donald could subject me and the children to such shameful behavior,'' the News quotes Mrs. Trump as saying. It was reported Thursday that Trump was ``dropping'' Ms. Maples. But Smith called this a ruse designed to ``soften up'' Mrs. Trump and prevent her from making legal moves that might embarrass Trump before he goes before the New Jersey Casino Control Commission on Thursday. Trump is seeking final license approval for the Taj Mahal, his mega-casino slated to open April 5 in Atlantic City. Trump's spokesman has refused to comment on the alleged affair.

DOC.HEAD: Sununu Associate Considered for Disaster-Relief Post
DOC.TEXT: An associate of White House chief of staff John Sununu is undergoing background checks as a prelude to being named chief of the government's embattled disaster-relief agency, sources said today. Wallace Stickney, the New Hampshire transportation commissioner, is the leading candidate to run the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), sources said, and his name has been submitted to the FBI for the lengthy clearance procedure. FEMA has been without a director since President Bush took office, prompting criticism from Republicans and Democrats. There also was criticism of the agency for its performance after Hurricane Hugo and the San Francisco earthquake. After being cleared, Stickney would have to be formally nominated by President Bush and approved by the Senate. When Sununu was governor of New Hampshire, Stickney was his environmental assistant. Later, Sununu named him state commissioner of transportation.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Bradley Orders Water Rationing Plan for L.A.
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Tom Bradley has ordered development of a stringent water rationing plan that could be carried out this summer during a fourth year of drought. Continued dry conditions could result in a 12 percent decline in Southern California's water supplies, affecting 13 million customers. Most of the agencies that distribute water for the giant Metropolitan Water District say they don't have the power to enforce water conservation programs. They add that they must be backed by residents in the 300 communities across the six-county region the district serves. ``We have to rely on the cooperation of our sub-agencies,'' said Tom Salzano, assistant general manager of the Central Basin Water District in Downey. The district acts as a liaison between the Metropolitan Water District and more than two dozen small water districts. Council President John Ferraro also put out a call to be water stingy. ``Now is the time for other Southern California communities to join Los Angeles in enacting mandatory water conservation ordinances which can be easily implemented,'' Ferraro said Thursday. Bradley last week, without public announcement, requested the city's Department of Water and Power to develop a plan that includes large fines for violators. This week, the Metropolitan Water District ordered the Los Angeles water department and the other 27 agencies that are district members to draw up mandatory rationing plans. ``It's complicated,'' said Ronald Palmer, general manager of the Foothill Municipal Water District in La Canada, which serves seven smaller agencies. The district would have to rely on the county Board of Supervisors to enact water rationing laws, Palmer said. Robert Bammes, public works administrator and chief of water supplies for Beverly Hills, said he was unaware of the Metropolitan Water District's request. Some Southern California communities, including Santa Monica, already have conservation systems in place. Under a mandatory conservation law, Santa Monica reduced its total water usage by nearly 10 percent in the past two years. ``With voluntary programs you're only reaching those people who are already convinced, said Atossac Soltani, Santa Monica's water conservation chief. ``For the rest, you need mandatory programs.'' Ferraro said a 10 percent water use reduction looms for Los Angeles. The nation's second-largest city has conserved water for the past two years by banning hosing down of driveways and sidewalks. Restaurant customers don't get water glasses filled unless they request it, and showers and toilets that use less water have been installed throughout the city.

DOC.HEAD: Second Relief Convoy Goes Into War Zone
DOC.TEXT: A truck convoy of emergency food rolled through a war zone in northern Ethiopia today, but it carried less than half its planned load because of a damaged bridge. Eleven trucks, each loaded with 10 tons of food, left the provincial capital, Dessie, on a 75-mile journey over a mountainous road to Kobo, said Yohannes Abraham, an official of the Catholic Relief Services in Addis Ababa. It was the second truck convoy this week. An initial convoy of 11 trucks covered the same route Monday in what relief officials said was a trial run. Its drivers reported the damaged bridge. ``Until it can be repaired we cannot use trailers,'' Abraham said. Each truck with a trailer can carry up to 22 tons. A consortium of Ethiopian churches is taking the food into the area, which is contested by government troops and the rebel Tigre People's Liberation Front. The Tigreans, who control most of northern Wollo and the whole of Tigre provinces, are fighting a 15-year-old war to oust President Mengistu Haile Mariam. The rebels want a government patterned after that of Albania, the last hard-line Marxist state in Eastern Europe. The emergency food comes largely from private donors in the United States and Western Europe. The operation aims at feeding 1 million people, a quarter of the number the United Nations says is threatened this year with famine caused by war and drought in northern Ethiopia. The United Nations has appealed for 1.1 million tons of emergency food. Although a formal cease-fire doesn't exist, both the rebels and the government have promised safe passage for the convoys. But wary relief officials say the first three drives north will be exploratory.

DOC.HEAD: `America's Dairyland' Moves To Ban Synthetic Milk Hormone
DOC.TEXT: The nation's leading dairy state will temporarily ban the use of a synthetic, milk-producing hormone in cattle if Gov. Tommy G. Thompson approves a bill passed by the Legislature. Sen. Russell Feingold, the bill's sponsor, said if Thompson signs the bill, Wisconsin will become the first state to enact a ban on the genetically engineered bovine growth hormone, or BGH, that is injected in cows to make them give more milk. ``This has been a long, hard battle,'' said Feingold, a Democrat from Middleton. ``We won. We are sending a loud and clear message to the governor that we don't want unlabeled BGH out there.'' The governor said after the Legislature adjourned its session Thursday that ``I am not ready to say what I am going to veto or sign.'' The temporary BGH ban approved by the Senate Thursday on a 21-12 vote would forbid farmers from using the substance until July 1, 1991, or six months after it is approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, whichever comes first. The bill, which was amended and passed by the Assembly on Wednesday, would allow use of the synthetic hormone for research. The Food and Drug Administration has allowed private companies to run limited on-farm tests of BGH and the milk has been reaching consumers, industry officials say. Supporters said the ban would allow for more research on the product, answering questions of whether it could have harmful health effects. Industry officials also were concerned that by increasing milk production and milk supply, the hormone could put some small farmers out of business. Critics of the ban said the hormone is safe and banning it will put dairy farmers in Wisconsin, by far the nation's biggest milk producer, at a competitive disadvantage. The final passage in the Senate was delayed when Republican Sen. Timothy Weeden staged a two-hour filibuster against the ban, insisting the measure could someday change the state license plate motto of ``America's Dairyland'' to read: ``Wisconsin, the nation's former dairyland.'' Jeffrey Remsik, a lobbyist for a group called the Animal Health Institute that favors use of the hormone, called the Senate vote a ``real victory for food terrorists who scare people and the Legislature into thinking there is something wrong with biotechnology.'' Remsik said the four companies that produce the hormone are likely to sue the state, adding pressure on Thompson to veto the bill. BGH is an experimental hormone that is designed to boost cows' production by as much as one-third.

DOC.HEAD: Zeffirelli Production of `Don Giovanni' Bows
DOC.TEXT: The Metropolitan Opera has a remarkably effective new production of Mozart's ``Don Giovanni,'' and for once Franco Zeffirelli's design and direction doesn't look like Cecil B. de Mille taking to the stage. Pillars and other reasonably sparse effects move in and out between every scene and backdrops change. But the motion comes between scenes, and doesn't distract the audience in the middle of glorious music, the way some recent Zeffirelli productions of Puccini and Verdi operas have done. The cast at Thursday's premiere was led by Samuel Ramey. No one could be faulted; it was a grand ensemble effort. Ramey has a beautiful and elegant tone. His acting was assured, as he strode around with youthful vigor, arrogantly assuming that all women belonged to his harem. His mop of hair, single earring and costumes emphasizing his slim legs indeed made him the image of a rakish lover. Ferruccio Furlanetto sang Leporello in a richer but less beautiful voice that was at times rough. It'll be interesting to hear these two men when they trade parts later. Carol Vaness sang Donna Anna with an exquisite, pure small column of sound. Karita Mattila made her Met debut as Donna Elvira. Her soprano is of a different type than Miss Vaness', with larger tones, some rosy undertones and the ability to convey much emotion. Both sang wonderfully in quiet passages and both had plenty to give when volume was required. Dawn Upshaw as Zerlina, the village bride, displayed a more mellow and mature voice than the young country chirp sometimes heard. It was a most attractive sound, and her acting kept Zerlina young. Kurt Moll has the dark bass just right for the Commendatore. And Jerry Hadley has the right tenor for Mozart _ good head tones and never spreading the tone as tenors must in some Italian operas. Julien Robbins did well with the thankless part of the bridegroom. James Levine and the orchestra played with spirited reverence. Zeffirelli did nothing eccentric. He did not have long pleated pages fall out of Leporello's book, which audiences are thoroughly tired of seeing. The Commendatore's statue is tall and golden, sitting upstage center with other graveyard statues on each side. When the Commendatore walks forward, in armor, his statue remains in view. When Don Giovanni goes to hell, the statues slide in again, with creatures writhing on them. He may be getting a preview of hell, as the Commendatore drags him toward the back of the stage where a fiery pit has opened. Gil Wechsler did lighting and Anna Anni did costumes. However, at one moment dawn looked like a sunset, and Miss Vaness' costume made the trim singer look fat. This production reassures operagoers who loved the 1957 Eugene Berman one it replaced.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Missing in Sinking of Fishing Vessel in Bering Sea
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Coast Guard now saying nine missing, search unlikely to resume today, survivors still in fishing vessel en route to Aleutian Islands, not in clinic as previously thought. Picks up 8th graf, `The rescued...' DELETES now redundant 10th graf pvs, bgng `None of...'
DOC.TEXT: Nine crew members remained missing and were presumed drowned today after a fishing vessel capsized and quickly sank in the frigid Bering Sea, the Coast Guard said. Twenty-two crew members were rescued Thursday after the 162-foot Seattle-based Aleutian Enterprise sank about 60 miles south of the remote Pribilof Islands town of St. Paul, Coast Guard spokesman Christopher Haley said in Juneau. The search for missing sailors was suspended late Thursday. Coast Guard Lt. Brian Flory said this morning that it was unlikely the Coast Guard would resume the search. ``We had a very good search yesterday,'' he said. ``We think we would have found anyone who was afloat. I don't think that of the nine missing that anyone got off the vessel.'' The cause of the capsizing was not immediately known. The site is north of the Aleutian Islands chain and southwest of the Alaska mainland. The Coast Guard had previously reported that 10 were missing; the figure was revised to nine today without explanation. Haley said none of the crew was wearing wearing survival suits. Coast Guard officials said a person probably couldn't survive more than 30 minutes in the frigid waters without such suits. The survivors, all in life rafts, were picked up soon after the ship sank Thursday afternoon by two sister ships, the Northern Enterprise and the Pacific Enterprise. A Coast Guard C-130 transport plane was on the scene to provide rescue communications and medical advice, Haley said. About six fishing vessels were in the area and had assisted in the rescue and search, said Dan Roberts, executive vice president of Arctic Alaska Fisheries Corp., which manages the Aleutian Enterprise for a partnership that owns it. Although Haley had said late Thursday he thought the survivors were taken to a St. Paul clinic, Flory said today they were still aboard a fishing vessel that was en route to Dutch Harbor, on the Aleutian Island of Unalaska. The vessel, the Bristol Enterprise, was expected to arrive sometime during the afternoon. The rescued crew members were ``in relatively good shape,'' Roberts said Thursday night. ``My understanding is only a couple of people have minor injuries.'' He said 15 of those rescued, including the captain, are from the Seattle area. ``We are in the process of notifying the survivors' and the other crew members' families.'' Fair weather was reported in the area Thursday, with visibility to seven miles, mild winds and seas to 6 feet, Haley said. The Aleutian Enterprise is a factory trawler, a large vessel that catches bottom fish, processes and freezes them on board. Trawlers normally fish for cod and pollock in the Bering Sea in the early spring, Roberts said. Most of the crew members likely are from Alaska, Washington and Oregon, he said. The vessel, about 10 years old and worth about $6 million, is owned by Aleutians Enterprise Ltd., a California-based partnership that contracts with Arctic Alaska for management and marketing services, Roberts said. Arctic Alaska's 22 other vessels that operate in the Bering Sea comprise the largest trawler fleet in the region, Roberts said. In December 1988 the company lost a trawler in rough weather in the Bering Sea. Two crew members died when the Arctic II sank, Roberts said.

DOC.HEAD: Environmental Movement's Elder Statesman As Active As Ever
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate graf with 2 grafs to CORRECT that Rainbow Bridge not flooded but several other natural arches were when Colorado River was dammed.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto SK1
DOC.TEXT: The man considered the father of modern environmentalism lives in a redwod house, is fascinated by high-tech equipment and admits he's no Thoreau when it comes to living his conservationist's vision. David Brower presents a large target for his wife, Anne, who considers his two cars, four color televisions, two video cameras, three video recorders and dozen tape recorders evidence of rampant consumerism. ``He has been a tremendous consumer of late. I've been strenuously objecting to that because it costs the Earth,'' she said. ``But he rationalizes, saying it ill help him in his work to save the Earth.'' At 77, the former executive director of the Sierra Club still lives in his native Berkeley, Calif., and has completed an autobiography to be published April 22, the 20th anniversary of Earth Day. ``The Life and Times of David Brower'' is dedicated to Anne, his wife of 46 years and mother of their four children _ two more, he notes, than the environmentally sound pair. But if Brower good-naturedly concedes some personal inconsistencies, he does so against the backdrop of a stormy half-century of environmentalism in which he tilted with colleagues as fiercely as he fought public apathy. ``He has been without any question the most effective partisan in the environmental wars in the whole 20th century,'' said author Wallace Stegner, who joined the Sierra Club when Brower held the reins in the early 1950s. Brower's boundless energy compels him to attempt things that often are beyond the financial resources of the groups he supports, Stegner said. Nor is he an organization man, Stegner added. ``It's hard to deal with him because he's so far ahead,'' Stegner said. ``I'm really all for Dave, except for in the organization he's sometimes uncontrollable.'' Brower knows he's difficult to please. Over the years he's started 30 environmental organizations that, at the time, best suited his ideals and methods. Now he seeks to shape the consciousness of a new generation. ``They're not too far gone to be bent,'' he said during a recent interview in Salt Lake City, where he spoke at the University of Utah and met with his publisher. ``When I talk to young audiences, I feel euphoric. ``I can't look at a small child and feel good about anything at all if I don't give that child a chance to grow up.'' It was childhood expeditions to California's Sierra Nevada that kindled Brower's love of the outdoors. It grew as his mother's blindness compelled him to describe the world she could no longer see. Brower's early skirmishes with government and corporate giants were attempts to preserve wilderness, national parks and endangered animals. Eventually his battlegrounds came to encompass global warming, ozone depletion and acid rain. Active today as ever, he sits on the boards of the Sierra Club and Earth Island Institute, which he founded. He has come an elder statesman's full circle, returning to the fight to preserve wilderness. His suggested method is to start over, restoring what has been damaged and protecting what has survived. ``It's Thoreau thinking,'' he said. Brower often is compared in print to the 19th century American philosopher Henry David Thoreau, who championed wisdom through association with nature. ``We must rise above the frailty and, dammit, it can be done,'' he said. ``We can't go on this way. The resources aren't there to ransack anymore. We're killing our planet.'' For all his triumphs, Brower still regrets what he views as his one spectacular failure. As Sierra Club director he failed to intervene in time to halt the damming of the Colorado River at Page, Ariz. Southern Utah's Glen Canyon and several of its natural arches carved by water and wind were lost beneath Glen Canyon Dam's Lake Powell. The water encroached on Rainbow Bridge National Monument, but spared the chief attraction. Brower wrote of his grief, and guilt, in a 1961 issue of the Sierra Club Bulletin: ``The future may not forgive or understand the citizen who, not being able to care less, is silent.''

DOC.HEAD: De Maiziere Announces Candidacy For Prime Minister
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with de Maiziere announcing his candidacy for prime minister and denying links to secret police. Pickup 12th graf `Alliance officials...'; DELETES 17th graf `Kohl wants...' to conform.
DOC.TEXT: The leader of the party that won East Germany's first free elections today denied allegations that he was linked to the disbanded Communist secret police and announced his candidacy for prime minister. As recently as Thursday, Lothar de Maiziere of the Christian Democrats had said his candidacy for the top job depended on the outcome of talks between his party and others about forming a coalition government. But today, de Maiziere, whose party favors speedy German reunification and whose campaign was supported by West Germany's governing conservatives, said at a news conference that he is willing to head the government. Without prompting, he also again denied he was an informer for the hated Stasi secret police and said he never took money from them. Helmut Lueck, spokesman for de Maiziere's Christian Democrats, told the news conferece the party leadership opposes a proposed investigation of legislators elected Sunday to see if they are linked to the secret police. Lueck said such an investigation ``would not serve the interests of truth and would endanger the inner peace of our country.'' ``An escalation of mistrust, suspicions and slander is not in the interest of our young democracy,'' he said. Earlier today, East Germany's chief prosecutor rejected a proposal by church leaders that the investigation be held. Dieter Plath, spokesman for chief prosecutor Hans-Juergen Joseph, said such a probe would be illegal before the new Parliament is sworn in. He said lawmakers are immune from such probes, unless Parliament decides otherwise. Although other candidates for prime minister had been mentioned, it was widely expected that de Maiziere would seek the post. Parliament must meet within 30 days of the election and vote for a prime minister. De Maiziere's three-party Alliance for Germany, which also includes the Democratic Awakening and the German Social Union, captured the largest share of seats in the 400-member body but failed to clinch an absolute majority. Alliance officials said they were near an agreement with three parties close to West Germany's Free Democrats, a junior partner in the Bonn government coalition. Talks were to continue next week, according to Democratic Awakening's chairman, Rainer Eppelmann. Eppelmann also renewed a coalition offer to the Social Democrats, who finished second in the balloting. The Social Democrats agreed to talks but said they would not cooperate with the German Social Union, the most right-wing party in the Alliance for Germany. Final official election results published today gave the Alliance for Germany one less seat and one more to the Social Democrats. The alliance now hold 192 seats, and if they are able to add the 21 Liberal seats they would have a majority of 213 seats in Parliament. But without the support of the 88 Social Democrats, the ruling coalition would not have a two-third majority needed to push through laws that would speed unification. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who backs the alliance and wants quick unification, on Thursday reiterated calls for a ``grand coalition'' with the Social Democrats. But concern that many newly elected lawmakers may have worked as informers for the former secret police overshadowed the political jockeying. The government official overseeing the dismantling of the force, Werner Fischer, said there were suspicions de Maiziere, a lawyer, collaborated with the Stasi. ``There are indications. There is no proof,'' Fischer told West Germany's ZDF television. He said citizens' groups sifting through secret police files in East German cities made allegations against de Maiziere. Asked whether he took the allegations seriously, Fischer said, ``Very.'' During 40 years of rule, the Communists intimidated many people into collaborating. Until earlier this year, the Stasi had 85,000 agents and hundreds of thousands of informers. By official count, about one of every 80 East Germans once either worked for or cooperated with the force. But many people say even more were involved in helping longtime Communist leader Erich Honecker keep the 16.3 million people under firm control. Honecker was ousted Oct. 18 following nationwide protests.

DOC.HEAD: Study: No Link Between DPT Vaccine and Neurological Problems
DOC.TEXT: A vaccine commonly administered to youngsters five times by their fifth birthday does not increase the risk for epilepsy and other neurological problems, researchers say. Previous reports indicated a possible link between one component of Diphtheria-Pertussis-Tetanus vaccine and such disorders. ``Our study provides reassurance to parents that DPT vaccine does not cause serious diseases of the brain,'' Wayne Ray, an associate professor of preventive medicine at Vanderbilt University, said Thursday. DPT vaccine is given to tens of thousands of children each week. Children typically are immunized three times in their first year of life, again at about 18 months and for the last time at around 5 years of age. The vaccine frequently causes low fevers and some swelling at the point of immunization. Earlier case reports and lawsuits filed by parents against pharmaceutical companies have alleged that the pertussis, or whooping cough, component of DPT vaccine has caused seizures and even death. But the study, reported in today's Journal of the American Medical Association, when seen in conjunction with other recent studies of the vaccine, should provide great reassurance to parents that there is no such link, Ray said. Ray and the co-authors of his study examined the Medicaid records of 38,171 Tennessee children who received more than 107,000 DPT immunizations in their first three years of life. They compared the rate of neurological events such as seizures that occurred immediately following immunization with the rate of such events that occurred 30 or more days after inoculation. ``No child who was previously normal without a prior history of seizures had a seizure in the zero to three days following immunization that marked the onset of either epilepsy or other neurological or developmental abnormality,'' the authors wrote. Alec Walker, an associate professor of epidemiology at Harvard School of Public Health in Boston, said the work appears to confirm research he has done on the vaccine. Walker studied 26,000 children in the Seattle area and found no increase in any serious neurological problems immediately following pertussis vaccination. His results appeared in a 1988 issue of the journal Pediatrics. ``The only reasonable interpretation of the data is that there's an absence of evidence'' for any effect of DPT on serious neurological disease, Walker said in a telephone interview.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Secretary of State Tours Soweto
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6th grafs to UPDATE with Baker flying to Kinshasa. Pickup 7th graf `In February...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto JOH1
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III toured this sprawling black township today and blamed apartheid for its poverty. Baker said the contrast between Soweto and the wealth of South Africa's whites in nearby Johannesburg is ``quite distressing and that's why I said the system of apartheid should be abolished as soon as possible.'' The visit came one day after he said the white-run government was committed to ending the system of racial separation. Baker met with Walter Sisulu at the African National Congress leaders' home in a neighborhood of small brick houses, visited community centers, a day-care center, and drove past a squatter's camp erected on an old golf course. Baker then flew to Kinshasa, Zaire, for meetings with President Mobutu Sese Seko and Angolan guerrilla leader Jonas Savimbi. Baker already has met Angolan President Jose Eduardo dos Santos as part of U.S. efforts to negotiate an end to the Angolan civil war. On Thursday, Baker met with South African President F.W. de Klerk. A senior U.S. official said Baker told him, ``what he had done so far was courageous in light of the obvious political pressures and restraints he is subject to.'' In February, de Klerk lifted a 30-year ban on the ANC, released black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela from jail after 27 years, and announced other reforms aimed at clearing the way for black-white negotiations. Moments before Baker arrived at Sisulu's home, children, perched on a jungle gym, shouted ANC slogans and sang songs honoring Mandela. Baker didn't see or hear the children. Sisulu said, ``I told the secretary of state we are very grateful to the people of America for the support they gave us over the years and that we are hopeful but we are only making a beginning and we will expect more support as the day goes by.'' Sisulu's organization publicly opposed Baker's meeting with de Klerk but the subject wasn't mentioned today until reporters questioned Sisulu, who appeared to put the issue behind him. ``The United States realizes no fundamental change has been made but that some encouragement should be made. We've had that,'' Sisulu said. Before Baker's arrival, the ANC had said Baker's visit, the first by a U.S. secretary of state in 12 years, would suggest de Klerk has made fundamental reforms of the apartheid system. Despite this difference, ANC leaders greeted Baker warmly during meetings in Soweto, Cape Town, and in the neighboring country of Namibia, where he attended independence celebrations. Asked about Baker's praise of de Klerk for moving to dismantle apartheid, Sisulu said, ``Mr. de Klerk is making an effort, which we appreciate. However, we would like to urge him to a bit speedy about things.'' Sisulu said de Klerk has not yet met the ANC's conditions for negotiations, although the two sides are to hold preliminary talks April 11. The ANC wants the state of emergency lifted and all political prisoners freed before negotiations begin with the de Klerk government on sharing power with the nation's disfranchised 28 million black majority.

DOC.HEAD: Precede UNDATED
Democrats Mount Offensive Against Bush
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Tops with 16 grafs to UPDATE with Bentsen, Nunn, Brown speeches. Picks up 13th graf pvs, `Brown has'
DOC.TEXT: Democratic leaders took the offensive today against President Bush's high approval ratings, accusing the president of broken promises and timid leadership and vowing to end his ``free ride.'' Sen. Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, the vice presidential nominee on the party's losing 1988 ticket, told the Democratic Leadership Council that Bush's campaign pledge of no new taxes has become ``pure Bushlips.'' Bentsen said the administration has proposed an array of ``crypto-taxes'' such as user fees, surcharges and other levies. He also accused Bush of being too worried about public opinion to help emerging democracies around the globe. ``Can you imagine Harry Truman hesitating to unveil the Truman Doctrine or the Marshall plan or the Berlin airlift because he feared public opinion polls? Can you imagine John Kennedy doing a poll before he dealt with the Cuban missile crisis?'' Bentsen asked. The same theme was sounded by Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga. ``Precisely as our principles and values are prevailing throughout the world, America's trumpet is sounding an uncertain note,'' Nunn said. The often-fractious Democrats were trying to play down their differences today as two major party groups met in separate cities to plot strategy for their next attempt to recapture the White House. While the leadership council, dominated by elected officials, met in New Orleans, the Democratic National Committee was meeting in Indianapolis. Democratic Party Chairman Ronald H. Brown, who was shuttling between the two meetings, told the New Orleans group that the Democrats need not be intimidated by Bush's popularity in the polls. ``It's time for us to point out that the Bush administration has been getting a free ride, that we hear a lot of sweet jargon but we don't see any action,'' Brown said. Brown has been one of the most aggressive Democrats in attacking President Bush, despite the Republican president's high ratings in opinion polls. Bush's 80 percent approval marks are often cited as the reason few Democrats are making any moves toward challenging him in 1992. Democrats have lost five of the last six presidential elections. The DNC, the party's governing body, was expected to endorse Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan's call for a cut in the Social Security payroll tax. In his speech to the leadership council, Brown called Moynihan's proposal a political ``stroke of genius. Substantively it's a blow for fairness, a triumph for honesty.'' Moynihan, D-N.Y., called for a cut in the payroll tax because the huge surplus that has been stockpiled in the retirement fund is being used to mask the true size of the federal deficit. ``It just makes sense for us Democrats to be on the side of cutting payroll taxes for working people,'' said Brown, calling the Social Security tax ``one of the most regressive we have.'' Brown has expressed annoyance in the past with attacks the DLC's more conservative members have made on the national party. The DLC was formed in 1985 with the avowed purpose of stopping what many of its founders considered the party's leftward drift. As its members prepared to fly to New Orleans, the council issued a long statement outlining positions on a range of issues, including the payroll tax. Although not specifically endorsing the Moynihan proposal, members said, ``We cannot continue to allow the cynical use of the Social Security surplus, raised from a regressive tax on labor, to mask the true scope of America's fiscal crisis.'' In a preamble to what they called ``The New Orleans Declaration,'' the DLC said, ``This is no time for caution and complacency from our leaders. The measure of a president is not his standing in the polls, but America's standing in the world.'' The word ``abortion'' did not appear in the DLC statement, but the document said ``government should respect individual liberty and stay out of our private lives and personal decisions.'' That mirrored the strategy followed by Wilder when he made abortion an issue in the Virginia governor's race last year. Wilder framed his pro-choice position as support for a woman's right to make the decision rather than leave it to government officials.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle to Attend Nicaraguan Inauguration
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle will represent the United States at the April 25 inauguration of President-elect Violeta Chamorro in Nicaragua, the White House announced today. President Bush said on Thursday that he would not attend the inauguration of the U.S.-backed candidate but would like to visit Nicaragua another time. Mrs. Chamorro was elected Feb. 25, defeating leftist Sandinista President Daniel Ortega. Quayle will lead the U.S. delegation to the ceremonies, said a statement by White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater. It will be Quayle's sixth trip to Latin America as vice president.

DOC.HEAD: Steppenwolf Presents `The Grapes of Wrath' on Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 4 grafs with what other critics said. No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: It would seem an impossible task: to adapt for the stage ``The Grapes of Wrath,'' John Steinbeck's monumental story of 1930s Dust Bowl farmers and their journey from Oklahoma to the Promised Land of California. Not only does the play have to compete with the powerful prose of Steinbeck's best novel but with the images of the John Ford film version that starred Henry Fonda as Tom Joad. Yet the play, which opened Thursday at Broadway's Cort Theater, can stand tall beside the book and the movie. It's an extraordinary piece of theater, a stirring ensemble production by Chicago's Steppenwolf Theater Company that rises to and meets the challenge of Steinbeck's epic tale. The hero of the evening is director and adapter Frank Galati who has fashioned a remarkably coherent version of the Steinbeck story. True, some of the narrative has disappeared in order to keep the audience from sitting in the theater all night, but Galati has remained faithful to the mythic spirit of the novel. The essentials are there. The Joad family anchors the play, particularly the stoic Ma Joad, played by Lois Smith as sort of a Midwest Mother Courage. She gives a beautiful, heartbreaking performance. Watch her as she sees Tom for the first time since he got out of prison or near the end of the play, when he must flee for his life. There are other wonderful portraits in the large, 35-member cast including Gary Sinise's shrewd, hot-headed Tom; Robert Breuler as the fatalistic Pa; Jim True as Tom's lusty brother Al; and Sally Murphy as the life-giving Rose of Sharon. In the play's other major role, Terry Kinney is fine as the grizzled, cynical preacher turned labor organizer, a man who may have deserted his church but not his flock. Steinbeck's novel has a relentless rhythm as the Okies push their way West. Galati and crew have captured that drive perfectly. What gives the play so much atmosphere is the physical production the director receives from his design team, especially Kevin Rigdon who did the evocative sets and lighting. The story is played out on a set of weathered wooden planks. But the setting is not as simple as it initially seems. Various trap doors are used for campfires. At one point, a trough near the rim of the stage becomes the Colorado River and during the memorable scene in a railroad boxcar when Rose of Sharon gives birth to her stillborn baby, rain pours from near the proscenium arch. Then there is the Joad jalopy, loaded down with passengers and possessions. The old pickup maneuvers around the stage as easily as if it really were driving along Route 66, the road the Joads took to California. Their journey westward is accompanied by music composed and played by Michael Smith and a small band of musicians. There is a wondrous moment at the end of Act 1 when the Joads reach California. A golden glow floods the stage, and the migrants stand there, transfixed. But unlike the movie, which sinks into a gooey sentimentality about the nobility of the downtrodden, the stage version quickly shows the reality of what the Joads found in their new home. They have traded one form of servitude for another. Galati is unstinting in his depiction of the desperation of these Depression-era homeless. The parallels to the present day are striking. It's almost uncomfortable to watch their hardships. But more importantly, it's impossible to forget.

What other critics said: Frank Rich, The New York Times: The production at the Cort, an epic achievement for the director, Frank Galati, and the Chicago theater ensemble at his disposal, makes Steinbeck live for a new generation not by updating his book but by digging into its timeless heart. Howard Kissel, the Daily News: There is something heartening about seeing such a large, deeply committed company engaged in serious work, but what they achieve is something far below Steinbeck's galvanizing vision. Clive Barnes, the New York Post: This is, overall, a thrilling theatrical achievement that gets its power from the still sharp relevance of its human message ... and its entertainment quality from the performance by an ensemble you should walk miles to see.

DOC.HEAD: PTL Attorneys Say Former Board Members Are Liable for Debt
DOC.TEXT: PTL attorneys say former board members, including actor Efrem Zimbalist Jr., are liable for the $50 million-plus damages suffered by Jim Bakker's former television empire. The board members ``failed to inquire, much less make diligent inquiry'' into the business affairs of Bakker's PTL television ministry, the attorneys said in papers filed Wednesday in U.S. Bankruptcy Court without public announcement.
