As a result of that ``wrongful misconduct,'' conditions existed that caused the Internal Revenue Service to revoke the ministry's tax-exempt status and claim back taxes of more than $50 million, the papers allege. PTL attorneys are asking the court to force a Pittsburgh insurance company to make good on its $10 million policy that covered the board members in the event of legal action against the ministry. National Union Fire Insurance Company is refusing to pay, claiming that Bakker made a fraudulent misrepresentation when he took out the policy in 1984. Bakker stated at the time that he knew of no pending legal action against him or PTL. The insurance company said Bakker knew or should have known that Jessica Hahn was claiming damages from the minister because of his sexual liaison with her in 1980. That incident led to Bakker's resignation from PTL in March 1987. He is serving a 45-year sentence for defrauding his ministry's supporters out of millions of dollars. Zimbalist, who starred in ``The FBI'' television series from 1965 to 1974, was on the PTL board from 1981 to 1986 and testified at Bakker's trial in September that the board was a sham. ``It was called a board of directors, but ... I never assumed I was responsible for anything because I wasn't,'' he testified. ``It wasn't that kind of board.'' Besides Zimbalist, other former PTL board members named in the action are Charles Cookman, North Carolina district superintendent of the Assemblies of God; Aimee Cortese, a New York minister; A.T. Lawing Jr., a retired Charlotte, N.C., businessman; the Rev. Don George, a Texas minister; Evelyn Carter Spencer, a California minister; and Ernest Franzone, a retired Florida businessman. The claim filed in bankruptcy court said the board members failed to see that officers and directors were properly supervised, failed to prevent depletion of corporate assets and allowed a situation to exist in which officers and directors were self-dealing with corporate assets.

DOC.HEAD: Black Panther Released Without Bail After Nearly 19 Years in Prison
DOC.TEXT: A former Black Panther Party leader who served nearly 19 years for allegedly machine-gunning two police officers has been freed without bail pending a new trial. A Manhattan courtroom broke out into shrieks and shouts of celebration as Dhoruba bin-Wahad, formerly Richard Moore, was released Thursday. He was convicted in the May 19, 1971 wounding of two police officers who were guarding the home of then-Manhattan District Attorney Frank S. Hogan. State Supreme Court Justice Peter McQuillan, who reversed the 1973 conviction last week, said he was freeing bin-Wahad in his own recognizance because the prosecution's case against him at this time appeared weak. The judge's decision surprised bin-Wahad, 45, and his lawyers. Defense attorney Robert Bloom said he had expected the judge to set bail at $50,000 or more. McQuillan said he overturned the conviction because the prosecution had withheld from the defense relevant information about prosecution witnesses. After hearing the judge's decision, bin-Wahad's wife, Tanaquil Jones, screamed with joy and then burst into tears. Another one of his lawyers, Elizabeth Fink, also started to cry with joy. Counting the time he served in jail before he was convicted, bin-Wahad would have served 19 of the minimum 25 years this June 5. Outside the court, bin-Wahad told his supporters: ``I would hope there is another trial to see exactly how little evidence they have against me.'' Manhattan District Attorney Robert Morgenthau issued a statement saying he was displeased about bin-Wahad's release. ``We are extremely distressed that the discovery of meaningless and inculpatory information has provided this defendant with a basis for overturning a conviction obtained after a fair trial. We will, of course, press this position in our appeal,'' the statement said. Assistant District Attorney James Kindler told the judge, ``Let us not forget the crimes which brought us to this courtroom _ the machine-gunning of two police officers at point-blank range.'' Kindler told the judge that two weeks after the shooting, bin-Wahad was arrested with the machine gun in his possession. Fink disputed this and suggested that police, FBI agents and other witnesses lied at bin-Wahad's trial with the prosecution's blessings. Bin-Wahad maintained he was framed and now fears for his safety. ``I don't think we're going to live in the United States,'' said his wife. ``It's not safe here for political activists.''

DOC.HEAD: Puppy Swallowed by Python Survives
DOC.TEXT: A couple saved a 7-day-old puppy from the belly of a python after they heard faint yelping inside the snake and forced it to cough up the pet, a newspaper reported Friday. Two other puppies died. Magda and Hennie Botha were quoted as telling The Star newspaper they heard their terrier barking frantically outside her kennel on their farm near Nelspruit, 15 miles west of Kruger National Park. When they rushed outside, the python was curled up inside the kennel, the puppies were gone, and the couple said they heard faint yelps from inside the snake's stomach. Botha said while his wife held the snake's tail, he shook the head up and down and rubbed its bulging stomach. The reptile's jaws gaped, and out came the three puppies. Two were dead. Mrs. Botha massaged the third puppy's chest and moved its front legs until it began breathing again, The Star said. The snake was kept in the bathroom overnight to keep it away from other animals, then was dropped off several miles away the next day, the newspaper claimed.

DOC.HEAD: Two Organizers Charged in Thrill-Seeker's Death
DOC.TEXT: Two leaders of a group of thrill-seekers who jump from high places with elastic cords tied around their ankles were charged with involuntary homicide in connection with a jumper's death. It was the first such court action in France resulting from the fad, in which jumpers attach elastic cords to their ankles and to the base of the platform from which they leap. The accident occurred during a festival in eastern France in June. The government banned elastic-band jumps a month later, then legalized them again in October after implementing new safety rules. The victim of the June 26 accident, Raymond Saputa, 24, was the 72nd person that day to leap from a 180-foot-high crane set up for jumpers. Saputa's elastic gave way during his second bounce, and he crashed to the ground. A magistrate filed charges Thursday against Marc Gapp, director of the jumping club, and Bertrand Blancher, a club employee stationed at the top of the crane to assist jumpers. There have been conflicting accounts of why the accident occurred. According to Blancher, Saputa jumped before he was supposed to, and the elastic was in the wrong position. According to a witness on the ground, Blancher detached the elastic prematurely after Saputa jumped. New safety rules were implemented after three jumping deaths in early 1989. They require all jumpers to undergo heart exams; require the elastic bands to be changed after every 150 jumps; and limit the number of jumps per hour from each set of elastic.

DOC.HEAD: South Korea Said to Consider Parole for Bomber of KAL Flight
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors will seek parole for a North Korean agent convicted of bombing a South Korean jetliner with 115 people aboard in 1987, newspapers reported Friday. Local newspapers said the request would be made to President Roh Tae-woo next week. Prosecutors refused to comment. Kim Hyon-hee, 27, was sentenced to death in connection with the Nov. 29, 1987 bombing. She said she planted a bomb on the Korean Air jetliner on orders from North Korean leaders. North Korea denied involvement. Kim and her accomplice, an elderly North Korean man, placed a sophisticated pair of bombs in the overhead luggage bin of the Boeing 707, which was flying from Baghdad, Iraq, to Seoul on Nov. 3. The bombers got off the plane during a stopover. Several hours later, it vanished over the sea near Burma. After the pair was arrested in Bahrain, the man committed suicide. Kim's suicide attempt failed, and she was extradited to Seoul. Government officials have said Kim's release would be considered because she had cooperated in the investigation and fully repented.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Propose Consular Ties With South Korea
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has proposed opening full consular ties with South Korea as a prelude to establishing formal diplomatic relations, South Korean news reports said Friday. The reports said Soviet officials made the proposal Thursday to Kim Young-sam, leader of South Korea's governing party. Kim arrived in Moscow on Thursday for a nine-day visit. The reports quoted Kim as saying, ``I don't see any reason to oppose the Soviet proposal.'' Kim said, however, that South Korea's basic position is to move directly to formal diplomatic ties without going through an intermediary step, the reports said. In December, the Soviet Union and South Korea opened ``consular departments'' in their trade offices in each other's capitals and began limited consular service. The arrangement restricts the functions of the departments and the qualifications of officials working there. The departments cannot fly national flags, and officials working there are denied normal diplomatic privileges. The Soviet proposal would upgrade the consular departments to the level of general consulate this summer, a step below full diplomatic relations, the reports said. The Kremlin already has diplomatic relations with Communist North Korea, South Korea's rival. In earlier dispatches, reporters accompanying Kim on the Soviet trip said the South Korean leader met secretly with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in the Kremlin. Kim refused to confirm or deny the reports. He said, ``I met an important Soviet figure but I can't disclose who, because I promised Soviet officials not to make it public now.'' On Friday, Foreign Minister Choi Ho-joong signed an agreement in Prague establishing formal diplomatic relations with Czechoslovakia. Bulgaria's BTA news agency said Friday that South Korea also established diplomatic ties this week with Bulgaria. Last year, Poland and Hungary set up ties with South Korea.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Hurl Paint Bombs at U.S. Consulate; Two Arrests
DOC.TEXT: Demonstrators protesting the United States' ``interventionist conduct'' in Central American hurled paint bombs at the U.S. Consulate on Friday, and two people were arrested, police said. One policeman was slightly injured in scuffles that broke out during the incident. Police spokesman Klaas Wilting said about 200 people took part in the protest. He said one or two paint bombs hit the consulate building near Amsterdam's famous Rijksmuseum. A spokesman for the demonstrators said the protest was aimed at ``recent U.S. interventionist conduct in Nicaragua, Panama ... and an imminent action in El Salvador.'' The spokesman was referring to U.S. government support for the anti-Sandinista forces in Nicaragua and the U.S. invasion of Panama in December. In El Salvador, the United States backs the government in its civil war with leftist insurgents. The spokesman did not elaborate on his claim of ``imminent action'' in that country.

DOC.HEAD: Striking Bus Drivers March at City Hall
DOC.TEXT: About 1,200 striking bus drivers and several thousand of their supporters marched to city hall Friday to press their demands for a 35 percent pay raise. The demonstrators filled the city hall plaza to overflowing, chanting slogans against centrist Mayor Agustin Rodriguez Sahagun and his administration. ``Fare increases no, salary increases yes!'' one banner proclaimed. The strike is in its second week, and there is no end in sight. It has forced more than 1 million commuters to seek alternative transportation, aggravating the city's traffic problems and increasing crowding on the metro system. An average city bus driver earns about $15,500 a year before taxes, according to Municipal Bus Co. officials.

DOC.HEAD: Inflation Rate Falls to 7.5 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Britain's annual inflation rate fell to 7.5 percent in February from 7.7 percent in January, but it is expected to increase in the coming months, the government said Friday. Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major warned in his annual budget statement Tuesday that inflation would worsen before it improved. Economists are expecting the annual inflation rate to move up to 9 percent. Major reiterated that fighting inflation with high interest rates, now at 15 percent, is the government's No. 1 economic priority. The inflation and interest rates, in addition to a new municipal tax system, have diminished Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's popularity. Her Conservative Party's standing in recent polls was at its lowest level in years. The report said February food prices were up 8.6 percent from a year ago, the highest increase since June 1982. March figures will be boosted by an increase in excise duties announced in the new budget, and mortgage rate increases. The introduction of the new municipal tax, higher water rates and increases in public housing rents will further boost the retail price index in April, the office said.

DOC.HEAD: Second Relief Convoy Passes Through War Zone
DOC.TEXT: A convoy of trucks carried 110 tons of emergency food Friday to a war zone in the northern part of Ethiopia, but a damaged bridge prevented it from carrying all its planned load. The bridge was not strong enough to handle trucks with trailers attached, so each truck carried just 10 tons of food instead of the 22 tons that would have been possible with trailers, said Yohannes Abraham. Abraham is an official of the Catholic Relief Services in Ethiopia. Eleven trucks made the 74-mile journey from the provincial capital of Dessie over a mountainous road to Kobo. Another convoy of 11 trucks covered the same route Monday in what relief officials said was a trial run. Its drivers reported the damaged bridge. Both trips went without a hitch. A consortium of Ethiopian churches is ferrying the food into the area, which is caught in the conflict between government troops and the rebel Tigre People's Liberation Front. The Tigreans are fighting to oust President Mengistu Haile Mariam and establish a government patterned after that of Albania, the last hard-line Marxist state in Eastern Europe. The emergency food comes largely from private donors in the United States and Western Europe. It is intended to feed 1 million people deprived because of the war and drought. A formal cease-fire does not exist, but the rebels and government have promised safe passage for convoys. The church groups hope to extend their distribution network from the north to southern Eritrea province, where another war is under way between the government and the secessionist Eritrean People's Liberation Army.

DOC.HEAD: Mongolia Abolishes Guarantee of Communist Monopoly on Power
DOC.NOTE: EDS: One name only cq for Ulanhu.
DOC.TEXT: Mongolia's Communist legislators formally abolished their party's guaranteed monopoly on power Friday and approved of elections with more than one candidate. However, the election law was drafted before Mongolia's recent pro-democracy protests and does not mention a role for opposition parties, officials said. The 370-seat Hural, Mongolia's parliament, voted 324-10 in favor of amending two sections of the constitution that say the ruling Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party is the leading force in society and the state. The other deputies abstained. The changes are in keeping with Mongolia's tendency to follow the lead of the Soviet Union, where the Communist Party recently gave up its monopoly on power. Mongolia is the world's second-old Communist state and is one of the Soviet Union's closest allies. Its constitution now says Mongolians have the right to join parties whose platforms ``correspond to the genuine interests of the people, in order to build up humane and democratic socialism.'' The reference to socialism was added after a heated debate in which many delegates insisted special mention should still be given to socialism and the ruling party. ``The Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party has existed nearly 70 years and has a membership of 90,000,'' one irate deputy said. ``It can't be lumped with other parties.'' Television and radio broadcasts of the proceedings were abruptly cut off during the debate, but radio broadcasts later resumed in time for the vote. Pro-democracy opposition groups said they would hold a demonstration Sunday in front of the government palace to demand the Hural resign. More than 93 percent of the parliament belongs to the ruling party. Opposition groups want a proviional parliament set up with representation for all parties. This body would amend the constitution and oversee multi-party elections, according to their demands. ``It's just a joke,'' Ulanhu, of the new Social Democratic Movement, said of the current Hural. Opposition demonstrations began in Mongolia in December, as pro-democracy revolutions were bringing change to other Soviet bloc countries. The unrest led the Communist Party and government to shuffle their top ranks, installing younger officials less closely tied to the past Stalinist era. However, Mongolian opposition groups say the changes are only cosmetic and intended to placate the public and preserve Communism. The Hural, which began its annual session two days ago, accepted the resignation of three of Mongolia's five deputy prime ministers Friday. One of the replacements is Kinyat Zardykhan, an economist who leads a prominent reform faction in the party. Friday's session also approved laws allowing appeals when government officials abuse citizens' civil rights, and providing for compensation for ``harm caused by investigatory organizations and public prosecutors.'' Details of the laws were not available. The Hural also passed Mongolia's first foreign investment law. The law allows joint ventures with companies of any country, without limit on the percentage owned by the foreign side. As a Soviet bloc state, Mongolia's external investment has come mainly from Moscow and East European countries.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Allows Guam Women to Seek Abortions
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge today issued a temporary restraining order allowing women in this U.S. territory to seek abortions despite a law banning the procedure. The order resulted from a lawsuit filed by Janet Benshoof, director of the American Civil Liberties Union Reproductive Freedom Project, Rachael Pine, staff attorney for the project, said from New York. Pine provided The Associated Press a copy of U.S. District Judge Alex R. Munson's order. Munson scheduled a hearing for Monday at which he will decide whether to issue a preliminary injunction against enforcement of the law until the lawsuit is heard in court, according to Pine. The law prohibits abortions except when a pregnancy endangers the life of the mother. It makes it a third-degree felony to perform abortion or aid in the procedure, a misdemeanor for a woman to solicit or have an abortion and a misdemeanor for a person to solicit a woman to have an abortion. Gov. Joseph Ada signed the measure into law Monday. It was unanimously passed March 8 by the territory's Legislature. Benshoof was charged Tuesday with a misdemeanor charge of solicitation to commit abortion after she tested the law by advising women seeking abortions to travel to Honolulu. She pleaded innocent in Guam Superior Court and is free on her own recognizance. Pine said if the judge grants the preliminary injuction, the ACLU would have grounds to ask that charges against Benshoof be dropped. Guam is an island in the western Pacific Ocean about 1,500 miles east of the Philippines.

DOC.HEAD: One Killed in Soviet Embassy Fire
DOC.TEXT: A fire caused by an electrical short circuit broke out in the Soviet Embassy in west Beirut on Friday, killing one person and injuring another, police said. They said it took four hours to put out the blaze, which began on the embassy's second floor at 3 p.m. Civil defense workers removed one body and rescued a woman, who suffered severe burns, police reported. The identities of the victims were not immediately known. Telephone calls to the embassy were not answered.

DOC.HEAD: Modest Rebound Follows Record Tumble
DOC.TEXT: Orders for ``big-ticket'' durable goods rose 3.3 percent last month, the government said Friday, but analysts said the modest rebound from a record slide in January merely pointed to continued weakness in manufacturing. Cynthia Latta, an economist with DRI@McGraw-Hill in Lexinton, Mass., noted that the February increase followed a 10.7 percent plunge and said, ``Consequently, we didn't get back everything we lost. ``It's hard to find anything that's really encouraging except the fact that it didn't fall again,'' she added. ``The industrial sector doesn't seem to be falling into a deep recession; it's just far from booming.'' Robert G. Dederick, chief economist of the Northern Trust Co. in Chicago, agreed, saying: ``The durable goods sector does not show any sign of sliding over any precipice. It's just in a sideways shuffle.'' The Commerce Department said orders to U.S. factories for durable goods _ items expected to last more than three years _ totaled a seasonally adjusted $121.6 billion. The January decline, revised from the originally reported 10.5 percent, was the biggest since the government began keeping track of such orders 32 years ago and broke the record set in the recession month of February 1982, when orders plummeted 9.2 percent. Transportation orders, which fell 29.4 percent in January and accounted for most of that month's drop, bounced back 11.2 percent last month to $30.2 billion. `Motor vehicles and parts and shipbuilding and tanks showed rebounds from last month's sharp declines,'' the department said, `while aircraft and parts declined for the second month in a row. Excluding transportation, orders were up 1.0 percent.'' Unfilled orders declined 0.4 percent, their first drop since August and only the second since early 1987. ``The fact that it's the first negative in seven months is another indication that things have slowed down,'' said Thomas Runiewicz of the WEFA Group, an economic forecasting firm in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. Runiewicz also pointed to a 5.7 percent decline in non-defense capital goods orders, which came on the heels of a 13.7 percent drop in January. ``It shows the investment structure is slowing also,'' he said of that category of orders, which often is a barometer of business investment plans. Electrical machinery orders rose 4.2 percent to $20.2 billion after falling 15 percent a month earlier. Orders for non-electrical machinery, including computers and a variety of industrial equipment, dropped 1.1 percent to $22.2 billion after advancing 3.0 percent in January. Primary metals orders slipped 3.6 percent to $10.7 billion after a 1.3 percent gain in the preceding month. Steel accounted for most of the loss. The highly volatile orders for defense capital goods jumped 22.6 percent, to $7.95 billion, after plummeting 33.6 percent in January. Virtually all of the increase came from shipbuilding and tanks. Excluding defense, orders rose 2.2 percent. Shipments of durable goods in February increased 5.9 percent to $123.5 billion, more than offsetting January's 4.4 percent decline.

DOC.HEAD: Civil Rights Leader Ralph David Abernathy in Hospital
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting to CORRECT summary line to reflect update.
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Ralph David Abernathy, right-hand man to Martin Luther King Jr. during the peak of the civil rights movement, was hospitalized today for a sodium imbalance, his doctor said. Abernathy was in fair condition in the cardiac unit at Crawford Long Hospital of Emory University, said his physician, Dr. Robert Kaufmann. Though Abernathy's heartbeat was being monitored, he was not suffering from a heart problem, the doctor said. Kaufmann said Abernathy's wife called him Thursday night after Abernathy became lethargic and not as alert as usual, symptoms of a sodium imbalance called hyponatremia. A sodium imbalance can be life-threatening but Abernathy was responding well to treatment, Kaufmann said. ``I don't think he's in great danger at this point,'' the doctor said, adding that Abernathy was alert this morning. Abernathy, the 63-year-old pastor of West Hunter Street Baptist Church in Atlanta, suffered a stroke in 1983 and again in 1986. Following the 1983 stroke, he underwent brain surgery. Abernathy angered many movement veterans last year when his autobiography, ``And the Walls Came Tumbling Down,'' contained a section suggesting that King committed adultery the night before he was assassinated. A Memphis, Tenn., woman last month sued Abernathy for libel over the passage. Abernathy also drew criticism from some black leaders when he endorsed Ronald Reagan for president in 1980. Abernathy, president emeritus of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, has called King ``the best friend a person ever had.'' He succeeded King as the head of the SCLC. In recent years, Abernathy complained many of the top figures of the civil rights movement had lost touch with King's ideals. He has talked about starting a new fight for civil rights.

DOC.HEAD: Government Asked to Bar Ads Equating Pork With Chicken, Fish
DOC.TEXT: The pork people say their products are just as nutritious as chicken, turkey and fish, but a private group says that's hogwash and is asking the government to do something about it. The Center for Science in the Public Interest says an advertising campaign by the National Pork Producers Council _ it touts pork as ``the other white meat'' _ is ``deceptive and dangerously misleading.'' ``The pork industry is trying to dupe consumers into thinking that pork is as healthful as chicken, turkey and fish,'' said Bruce Silverglade, CSPI legal director. His group, which also has criticized producers and sellers of other foods on nutrition issues, filed a petition Friday asking the Federal Trade Commission to stop the pork council's claims and require advertising corrections. But industry representatives say there's no problem to clean up. ``We're confident that our advertising is accurate and can be backed up by substantial scientific evidence,'' said Barry Pfouts, director of marketing for the council. ``All we have said all along is that our products ... are nutritionally comparable to other accepted white meats,'' Pfouts added in defending the ad campaign. The center says the industry has gone too far in claims that pork products are ``low in cholesterol,'' ``low in calories'' and ``low in fat.'' ``Government data show that almost all cuts of pork are considerably higher in fat, saturated fat and calories,'' said Silverglade. But Mike Simpson, executive vice president of the Pork Board said current nutritional assessments of pork are based on decade-old data that don't take into account recent research and improvements in breeding. Newer information does indicate the fat content in pork is getting smaller, said Ruth Mathews, who heads the Agriculture Department's nutrient data research division. The department is examining updated nutrition research in an effort to revise its handbook and table of nutrient composition of foods. Mathews said final changes are expected by mid-1991. ``Early data certainly shows there have been changes in pork over time since we published the handbook in the early 1980s,'' she said. ``It seems to show that pork is leaner ... that it's lower in fat content from the early data that we have,'' she added. Those figures are not publicly available yet. The latest information shows the amount of cholesterol in a 4-ounce serving of cooked pork is about the same as for similar servings of chicken and turkey, said Charles Mitchell, CSPI spokesman. However, Mitchell said the amount and percentage of fat and the number of calories is substantially higher for pork. Mitchell said 4 ounces of pork, trimmed of all visible fat, averages 14.8 grams or 13 percent fat, while a similar serving of skinless chicken averages 8.4 grams or 7.4 percent fat. Turkey weighs in at 2.9 grams or 2.6 percent fat per serving, according to Mitchell. That information indicates the pork ads also violate Agriculture Department requirements that average servings of ``low-fat'' foods must be 10 percent or less fat to make the claim, the center said. ``We have fat measures of pork as low as 2 percent,'' countered Pfouts, of the pork producers council. The council's research indicates the average 3-ounce serving of tenderloin, the best cut of pork, is between 3 percent and 4 percent fat while white meat chicken is 3.5 percent. Pfouts said that serving of tenderloin has about the same 140 calories as a similar serving of skinless white-meat chicken. Mitchell contends similar servings of pork, chicken and turkey contain 264 calories, 215 calories and 171 calories respectively. CSPI said it would also ask Congress to pressure the industry to increase its spending on research to reduce fat in pork. Money for the pork advertising comes primarily from about $25 million collected annually from producers under the 1987 Pork Promotion and Research Act. A House Agriculture subcommittee has scheduled a hearing next week to review the law.

DOC.HEAD: Tanker at Refinery Dock Spills Oil Into Delaware River
DOC.NOTE: Eds: REWRITES throughout to UPDATE with only 150 gallons believed to have spilled
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Hazelwood Trial, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An oil tanker on Friday spilled about small amount of oil into the Delaware River, the Coast Guard said. About 150 gallons spilled, authorities said. Earlier, the Coast Guard and Sun Co. refinery officials had estimated the spill at 1,000 gallons. Workers at the Sun refinery dock noticed the spill as the 865-foot tanker Nike was unloading its cargo of Bonney light crude oil from Nigeria, Petty Officer Joseph Nored said. ``We were lucky,'' Sun spokesman Doug Peters said. ``The wind and tide were with us, keeping the oil right into the dock area.'' Unloading was stopped and floating booms were placed in the water around the Singapore-registered ship. A private anti-pollution contractor also was called in to clean up the spill, Nored said. The spill was reported to the Coast Guard about 6:25 a.m. The cause of the accident was under investigation, Nored said.

DOC.HEAD: CIA Employee Sat In Meetings Where Poindexter Didn't Give Full Story
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 14 grafs with CIA employee's testimony; picks up 3rd graf pvs, ``Did Admiral ...; edits thruout to tighten
DOC.TEXT: A CIA employee testified today that John Poindexter may have withheld some facts from Congress but didn't try to cover up a shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. The CIA employee, Norman Gardner, appeared as a defense witness at the trial of Poindexter, the former national security adviser accused of obstructing Congress, conspiracy and making false statements in the Iran-Contra affair. ``To the best of your knowledge, was Admiral Poindexter involved'' in obstructing or lying to Congress about the Hawk shipment? asked defense attorney Joseph Small. ``No,'' replied Gardner. Gardner acknowledged under questioning, however, that Poindexter never told the House intelligence committee or Sens. David Durenberger and Patrick Leahy on Nov. 21, 1986, that President Reagan had ratified the Hawk shipment. Poindexter tore up the presidential document authorizing the delivery hours after meeting separately with the House committee and then the senators. ``Didn't you speak up'' when Poindexter omitted some facts in his congressional meetings? asked Iran-Contra prosecutor Christian Mixter. ``No ... I just don't do that,'' replied Gardner. Poindexter told the congressmen Reagan didn't approve the Hawk shipment, according to Gardner's notes of the meeting. Gardner knew about the presidential authorization, said Mixter. Gardner recalled that Durenberger was hostile to Poindexter at the start of their Nov. 21, 1986, meeting on the Iran initiative. ``John, if you are not going to give us all the facts we're going to get the hell out of here,'' Gardner quoted Durenberger as saying. On Thursday, former Attorney General Edwin Meese III said ``everything I know'' suggests Poindexter tried to get the facts out about a shipment of missiles to Iran. Testifying as a defense witness at Poindexter's trial, Meese said he never suspected the national security adviser might be concealing from Congress the CIA's role in the arms shipment. ``Did Admiral Poindexter ever tell you a lie?'' defense attorney Richard Beckler asked. ``Not to my knowledge,'' Meese replied. Asked whether Poindexter tried to ``convey an accurate'' story on the missile shipment, the former attorney general replied: ``Everything I know about it is he did.'' ``Did you know that Admiral Poindexter'' was ``involved in that Hawks shipment?'' prosecutor Dan Webb asked. ``No, I did not know that then and I do not know that today,'' Meese replied. Webb showed Meese a copy of a Nov. 20, 1985, computer message from White House aide Oliver North to Poindexter about the impending shipment. Meese responded by saying ``I don't know whether'' Poindexter received it when North sent it to him. Meese attended a Nov. 20, 1986 meeting in Poindexter's office, where North adopted a cover story that no one in the U.S. government knew at the time that Hawk missiles were aboard an air shipment. Asked by Beckler whether he had heard any discussion of a false cover story at the meeting, the former attorney general replied: ``No, I did not. I am sure nothing like that was ever said in my presence at that meeting.'' Meese said Poindexter asked him to attend the meeting to ensure Reagan administration officials could testify `truthfully and accurately'' to Congress about the Iran initiative. Webb asked Meese whether he wasn't suspicious about the assertions of lack of U.S. knowledge after discovering two days after the meeting that the Reagan document, known as a finding, had ratified the missile shipment. ``No, I was not suspicious of that,'' said Meese. He explained that the CIA said it had discovered that Hawks were aboard only as the shipment was under way and the finding was signed by Reagan a week and a half after the delivery. When Meese told Reagan on Nov. 21, 1986 a fact-finding inquiry would be launched of the Iran initiative, did Poindexter ``jump up'' and say he had a copy of the finding in his safe? Webb asked. ``No, he did not,'' said Meese. ``During this time ... did John Poindexter ever tell you he had destroyed this finding that had been signed by the president of the United States?'' the prosecutor asked. ``No,'' Meese replied.

DOC.HEAD: Suspect Goes From the Drink to the Clink
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to restore dropped word `house'
DOC.TEXT: This suspected burglar really did go out on a limb. That's were police officers and tracking dogs located him, perched on a branch hanging over Horeshoe Lake. The man fled Thursday after neighbors saw him and an accomplice trying to break into a vacant house, authorities said. The accomplice was caught. The other suspect ran into the woods and climbed the tree when he saw the officers approaching. ``He was taunting the dogs and the police,'' Capt. Jack Fields of the Madison County sheriff's department said. ``The limb broke and he fell into the water.'' The man stayed in about 4 feet of chilled water for about 90 minutes until officers found a boat and paddled out to him, said Deputy Gerry Owens. Both suspects, whose identities were not released, were taken to the Madison County Jail.

DOC.HEAD: A Year After the Spill, Work Still Remains on the Beaches
With AM-Hazelwood Trial, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The cleanup continues in Prince William Sound a year after the Exxon Valdez struck a charted reef and spilled nearly 11 million gallons of North Slope crude oil. Exxon Corp. said last week that this year's cleanup will be smaller than last summer's $2 billion effort. A multi-agency group is to conduct a shoreline survey in April and turn in a work plan by May 1, said Otto Harrison, Exxon Alaska operations manager. ``Work will start the first of May or as soon as weather will permit,'' Harrison said. Exxon said more than 25 studies have been done during the winter, most showing significant shoreline improvement, excellent water quality, no missing species and no stressed animals. Still, an estimated 120 miles of beaches need cleaning, authorities said. The company will use clean-up techniques this summer ``less intrusive on the environment'' than the hot water and steam-hose baths last year. They include using oil-eating bacteria and removing the oiled sediment. ``To dig it up is the most intrusive thing you can do,'' Harrison said. ``We don't know if the benefits are worth it.'' The 987-foot tanker became impaled on Bligh Reef on March 24, 1989, after veering away from normal shipping lanes to avoid floating ice. The resulting hemorrhage of crude from the tanker created the nation's worst oil spill. The oil tarred hundreds of miles of rocky shoreline, killed countless birds, animals and marine life. On Thursday, Exxon Valdez Capt. Joseph Hazelwood was convicted of a misdemeanor charge of negligent discharge of oil and cleared of felony criminal mischief and two other misdemeanors.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher's Party To Continue Anti-Inflation Policies Despite Election Loss
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said Friday she will press on with unpopular anti-inflationary policies despite her Conservative Party's most stunning by-election defeat in 50 years. ``We are not a fair-weather party. We are not for trimming and turning,'' Mrs. Thatcher said in a letter to party chairman Kenneth Baker after Thursday's upset. The letter was released by the party headquarters. The opposition Labor Party scored a landslide victory in the previous Tory stronghold of Mid-Staffordshire in central England. Labor leaders declared that 11 years after being ousted by Mrs. Thatcher, they are on course to return to power. In Mid-Straffordshire, Labor candidate Sylvia Heal, a social worker, took 49 percent of the vote. The Conservatives' Charles Prior got 33 percent, while other parties took the rest of the votes. The one-seat loss scarcely dented Mrs. Thatcher's control of the 650-member House of Commons, where she has an overall 100-seat majority. But the by-election rout raised new uncertainties about her political future. Recent straw polls have indicated a significant minority of the Tory members of the House of Commons _ who elect the party leader each fall _ want her to retire before the next election. It must be held by mid-1992. Her party and personal ratings are slumping largely because of soaring home loan rates and a new local tax, which will replace property taxes starting April 1 and increase what many Britons pay the government. Some senior Tories acknowledge the new tax, formally known as a community charge, has been a blunder. ``The government has got to be a lot more sensitive ... there have got to be changes in the community charge,'' said Tory legislator John Lee in a radio interview. Lee's north England district, Pendle, is among 76 highly vulnerable Tory constituencies held by majorities of few thousand votes or less. Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock said the victory Thursday was a turning point for the Conservatives, who ``are going to have to make up their minds how quickly they get rid of Mrs. Thatcher.'' ``Her leadership is misleadership, and the sooner she goes the better,'' he said on British Broadcasting Corp. TV. ``We will defeat any Conservative leader at the next election.'' The Conservatives, 10 points ahead in opinion polls a year ago, are now 21 points behind Labor. It is the biggest deficit since Mrs. Thatcher won a third consecutive term in 1987. Government popularity has waned steadily as the Thatcher administration doubled interest rates to 15 percent in less than two years to try to curb resurgent inflation. But inflation is more than 7 percent, among the highest of major industrialized nations. The government is banking on inflation to start falling next year in time to lower interest rates before it has to call an election.

DOC.HEAD: China Defies East Bloc Trends at Party Congress
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Glasnost and perestroika may have brought change to much of the socialist world, but at China's annual people's congress the magic word is ``wending'' _ stability. It is repeated in speeches, discussions and interviews at this year's National People's Congress, the Communist-dominated parliament. Premier Li Peng set the tone in his keynote address Tuesday. ``Now, as we confront pressure from abroad and difficulties at home, preservation of the country's stability is a matter of paramount importance,'' he said. Each citizen, he told the 2,700 deputies, ``should cherish the hard-won political stability and unity as he would treasure his own life.'' Song Ping, a member of the Politburo Standing Committee, told the lawmakers: ``History has taught us that nothing can be achieved without a stable situation.'' The spokesman for the congress, Yao Guang, said political reforms would be ruled out if they ``affect the stability of the situation.'' The passion for stability reflects the insecurities of the aging, unpopular Chinese leadership. They fear the disintegration of socialist values and institutions around the world. They fear the reform movement crushed by tanks last June will revive and students will return to the streets with their pro-democracy demands. They fear a populace made restless by poor working and living conditions. And they remember China's historical lessons that anarchy brings suffering. ``Common people truly want to see the country stable. They have suffered enough from the turmoil, and if the country is plagued with chaos, it is the common people who will suffer,'' one Beijing delegate was quoted as saying. His sentiments are shared by most Chinese who have a cultural aversion to the privations brought on by thousands of years of internal upheavals. Many lived through the economic madness of Mao Tse-tung's 1958 Great Leap Forward and the hysteria of the 1966-76 Cultural Revolution. But the party is now preaching ``stability'' to further its own ends. It is demanding unquestioned acceptance of the status quo, with its ban on political opposition to one-party rule and obedience to the leaders. Stability means forsaking new market-oriented reforms and clamping more state controls over the economy. ``Stability takes precedence over everything,'' the Beijing Daily quoted deputy Tao Dayong, a well-known economist, as saying. ``Otherwise the economy will not have the necessary environment to development,'' he said. Stability also translates into crackdowns on the corrupt and criminal, and suppression of labor unrest, a byproduct of economic austerity measures that have led to plant closings and rising unemployment. ``Only with stability can the country preserve the results achieved through reforms in the past decade,'' trade union official and Shanghai deputy Wu Huifang told the Xinhua News Agency. The official press has made certain no social group is left out. It quoted Li Hong, a law student at Beijing University, as saying ``almost every university student in China desires social and political stability.'' Doje Cering, government chief in Tibet, told the congress, ``We Tibetans who have suffered enough from the turmoil of the Cultural Revolution and riots in recent years understand the importance of political and social stability.'' Wu Yuqian, a deputy representing the People's Liberation Army, said ``last year, some people talked a lot about new concepts and new thinking and they mocked those who talked Marxism and Leninism. Now things have changed, people believe in Marxism and Leninism again.'' That's the message Premier Li hammered home in his concluding remark to the congress. ``Foreign forces hostile to China that engage in subversive activities are bound to fail,'' Li said. ``Come what may, socialist China will stand rock firm in the East.''
EDITOR'S NOTE: Jim Abrams is Beijing bureau chief for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Intensifies Campaign for Central American Aid Package
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today intensified his campaign for his stalled $800 million Central American aid package, saying ``with democracy at stake, we really cannot afford delay.'' Bush prodded Congress on the package, both in opening remarks at a White House luncheon with out-of-town newspaper editors and reporters and during an earlier meeting with Panamanian Vice President Guillermo Ford. He told the news representatives it was ``a matter crucial to the future of democracy in this hemisphere.'' ``Panama and Nicaragua stand in a historic moment on the threshold of democracy. In both nations, the people have spoken in favor of freedom. But the difficult work of democracy-building remains,'' Bush said. He said the western hempisphere ``can become the first where democracy prevails from north to south. But it cannot happen if we in the United States fail to add our strength and support to the forces of democracy. ...with democracy at stake, we really cannot afford delay.'' Earlier, during a White House picture-taking session in the Oval Office with the Panamanian vice president, Bush said, ``We'll keep pushing from our end.'' ``It is absolutely essential that the Congress move to pass this legislation that will bring urgent, needed help to Panama,'' Bush said. It was the second time in as many days Bush has prodded Congress on the package, which he has said must be passed by the end of the month. On Thursday Bush criticized congressional Democrats who are seeking to shift some of the money to new democracies in Eastern Europe. Ford, one of the leaders the United States installed in December after it invaded Panama and toppled the government of Manuel Antonio Noriega, told Bush: ``We are liberated, now we're free. And we're ready to put our act together.'' The Panamanian official, speaking in English, said Panama's $500 million share of the aid package ``will allow us to put the show on the road and not have to come back every year, knocking on doors, asking for additional help.'' Ford said the package would ``jump start'' the Panamanian economy. The remaining $300 million of the package would go to Nicaragua. Bush told his White House visitor, ``I hope you will tell your colleagues when you go back that anything we can do to help, we want to do it. I want to assure you, the priorioty is passage of this legislation.'' He commended Ford for his work in lobbying members of Congress. ``I understand you saw 102 senators, which is pretty good'' since there are only 100 of them, Bush joked. ``Maybe it just felt like that.'' Ford responded: ``It has been absolutely wonderful up on the Hill. I think all the congressmen and the senators have been just very understanding of our need. We have expressed the necessity of doing it as rapidly as possible.''

DOC.TEXT: It was not clear how many journalists would be affected, whether the order applied to correspondents who have been in Lithuania for some time or whether any deadline was imposed. As the Soviets tried over the last few days to maintain authority in the Baltic republic the story of Lithuanian defiance of Moscow has attracted growing attention from the media. President Bush is expected to make a strong statement of protest shortly. Until now, he has guided the administration through a period of admonitions to Moscow not to use force. But U.S. rhetoric has been low-keyed in an effort not to heighten tensions in a touchy situation.

DOC.HEAD: World Reacts With Sympathy, But No Formal Recognition
Wth AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The world offered Lithuania some cautious words of support this week but no formal recognition of its independence, apparently wary of coming down too hard on Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Most governments urged Moscow not to try to solve the problem by force or threats and appealed to it to negotiate with the Lithuanians. Several said that since they had never accepted the Soviet annexation of Lithuania in 1940, there was no need for them to take action now. For many countries, especially Western democracies, the situation posed a quandary: how to acknowledge the Lithuanian people's right to freedom without hurting Gorbachev and his reform program. The Soviet republic declared independence from the Soviet Union on March 11. On Thursday, it appealed for worldwide support after Gorbachev ordered Lithuanians to turn in their guns and disband their volunteer defense force. Soviet troop movements in recent days appeared to be a show of force. Sweden, across the Baltic Sea, put its military on a higher state of alert and said it was urging Moscow to rule out military action. Lithuania's appeal drew a sympathetic response from the U.S. Senate. It voted 93-0 Thursday night for a resolution urging Bush to consider the republic's request for diplomatic relations. While Washington has not extended formal recognition, it also never recognized the forced incorporation of Lithuania into the Soviet Union. Bush on Friday warned the Soviet Union that any attempt to intimidate or use force against the breakaway republic ``is bound to backfire. That is inevitable.'' He coupled his statement with a declaration that the United States stands with the people of Lithuania ``and supports their right to self-determination.'' In a statement late Thursday, Norwegian Foreign Minister Kjell Magne Bondevik expressed the Nordic countries' concern. ``We urgently appeal to the Soviet side to abstain from military, political or economic pressure,'' he said. ``Only patient negotiation and constructive dialogue will make it possible to solve the great challenge both parts are facing.'' Late Thursday, the Danish Foreign Ministry appealed to the Soviet Union to ensure ``that negotiations with Lithuania take place without pressure or threats.'' Belgian Foreign Minister Mark Eyskens said: ``President Gorbachev has a chance to show he is a true democrat and wants to take into account the will of the Lithuanian people.'' Denmark, Norway, Britain, Belgium, Italy and Switzerland are also among governments that said they had never recognized the Soviet annexation of Lithuania and neighboring Estonia and Latvia in 1940. But all said it was too early to consider other official action, such as sending ambassadors to Vilnius. Swiss Foreign Minister Rene Felber said the declaration does not mean de facto independence. U.S. and Swedish officials said independence implies control of territory, which Lithuania does not have. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher told Parliament on Tuesday: ``We recognize especially that Lithuania has expressed a wish to determine her own future. We hope that the position will be satisfactorily resolved between those who express that wish and President Gorbachev.'' On Thursday, the Polish Parliament passed a resolution expressing hope that the process of restoring Lithuania's independence would progress quickly. France, which also never recognized Lithuania's annexation, hoped for ``new relations'' between the Soviet Union and Lithuania. It noted that ``the free choice (by Lithuanians) ... was made possible by the democratization reforms undertaken by Mr. Gorbachev.'' The two German governments made no comment. Nor did Yugoslavia, which has its own problems with separatists. Spain and the Netherlands noted that when they finally recognized the Soviet Union decades after the Communist revolution, Lithuania was already annexed by Moscow. Therefore, they argued, Soviet consent would be a key factor in deciding whether to recognize Lithuanian independence. Spain said it was ``a moment for caution,'' and it was waiting for the 12-nation European Economic Community to adopt a position. ``We must try to help in any way possible so that the conflict over independence does not perturb the overall positive reforms initiated under Mr. Gorbachev's perestroika policy of economic and political restructuring,'' the Spanish Foreign Ministry said. Philippines Foreign Secretary Raul Manglapus noted that many countries have separatist movements and ``a very cautious approach is needed.'' Thai government spokesman Suvit Yodmanee said Lithuanian independence was a Soviet internal affair. Government officials in conservative Persian Gulf Arab states said it is their policy not to interfere in the internal affairs of any state.

DOC.HEAD: Idaho Lawmakers Pass Stiffest State Abortion Law
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 4th graf, ``It's got...' to include judge's order blocking Guam law.
DOC.TEXT: The Idaho Legislature's approval of the most restrictive state abortion law sets the stage for a possible test of the U.S. Supreme Court's commitment to legalized abortion. ``The people of Idaho have said strongly what millions of Americans believe, that abortion is not an acceptable means of birth control,'' said National Right to Life Committee legislative director Doug Johnson. But the American Civil Liberties Union and Planned Parenthood announced they would challenge the measure if it becomes law. ``It's got a wide-ranging impact beyond the understanding of the people who voted for this here,'' said Jack Van Valkenburgh of the ACLU. The ACLU sued today to challenge an even more restrictive law banning abortions in Guam, and a federal judge in the U.S. territory agreed to block enforcement of the new law until a hearing Monday. In Maryland, meanwhile, the Senate approved an unusual compromise today to break an eight-day filibuster: An abortion rights bill permitting unrestricted abortions during the early stages of pregnancy will become law unless it is petitioned to referendum and rejected by voters in November. If it is rejected, then a bill sponsored by anti-abortion senators will become law _ unless it also is defeated by voters. Under that bill, abortions could be performed in cases of rape or incest, to protect the mother's life or if the pregnancy would produce serious and adverse effects on the woman's health. The measures are structured so that both would have to be passed by the House and signed by the governor; if one of the measures is rejected, the other one dies. The Idaho bill was patterned on a National Right to Life Committee model that has been rejected by other states as too restrictive. But it is the version that abortion foes want for the test of the U.S. Supreme Court's commitment to its 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision that legalized abortion. The law would make abortion illegal except in cases of non-statutory rape reported within seven days, incest if the victim is younger than 18, severe fetal deformity or a threat to the mother's life or physical health. An abortion would be illegal in the case of statutory rape, or sex with a minor, on grounds that such behavior implies consent on the part of the female, said Democratic Sen. Claire Weatherell, a supporter of the bill. If it is signed by Democratic Gov. Cecil Andrus, the measure would take effect July 1. Andrus has declined to announce his intentions on the bill but has reiterated his long-held anti-abortion stand. Hundreds of telephone calls, messages and letters flooded the governor's office as lobbying by both camps in the abortion debate shifted to Andrus after Thursday's 25-17 state Senate vote approving the ban on abortion as a method of birth control. The legislation cleared the House two weeks ago. Abortion rights advocates in the Senate said the state was running up a futile legal bill of up to $1 million in passing a measure that would not withstand the high court's scrutiny. They also labeled the bill a draconian product of an out-of-state organization pushing its own agenda. ``This bill challenges values ingrained in Idaho's tradition _ freedom of belief, freedom of action, freedom of privacy,'' said Democratic Sen. Marti Calabretta. But the bill's supporters said the only issue was whether the state would take the lead in protecting the lives of unborn children. ``Abortion is the destruction of life, and what can we say about the future of our society when defenseless victims are destroyed for the convenience of personal choice,'' Republican Sen. Roger Madsen said. The potential legal bill ``is a very, very inexpensive cost for the life of a child,'' said Democratic Sen. Jim Christiansen. Andrus remained silent about his intentions on the abortion ban, standing on his recent affirmation of his long-held opposition to abortion except in the case of rape, incest or to save the life of the woman. Kerry Uhlenkott of Right to Life of Idaho said she was confident the governor would maintain his anti-abortion credentials. ``Idaho is speaking out on this issue,'' she said. ``I don't think he will ignore it.'' But leaders of the fledgling Freedom Means Choice, formed two months ago as the Idaho debate was heating up, refused to give up the battle against a bill that would ban more than 90 percent of the 1,500 abortions performed in Idaho each year. ``The word is not dejected,'' said Sally Trott. ``The word is determined. I don't believe anyone can state what the governor will do.'' At the White House, President Bush said the vote was a state matter but added, ``I have not changed my position at all.'' Bush's opposition to abortion mirrors that of the governor's.

DOC.HEAD: With Irrelevant Data Any and All Change, Chief Bureaucrat Drones
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st graf to DELETE extraneous `the'; SUBS 6th graf, ``As both ...' to DELETE reference to `laconic' drawl
DOC.TEXT: World peace through bureaucracy: It's an idea whose time may have come. After all, the paperwork isn't ready, says the president of the International Association of Professional Bureaucrats. ``Think of the possibilities,'' said James H. Boren. ``We can move closer to preserving the red tape that binds the world together as one great harmonic unit.'' If U.S. and Soviet military bureaucrats can be brought together, well, war couldn't possibily break out because there would be ``peace through inertia,'' Boren said. His tongue-in-cheek group, known as INATAPROBU, was formed 22 years ago to poke fun at bureaucrats. On Thursday, it honored President Bush with its first ``Bureaucrat of the Decade'' award, Boren said. ``In 33 years as an observer of presidents, prime ministers, and non-directive leaders around the world, I have never seen bureaucratic excellence that would surpass that of President George Bush,'' he said. ``As both the environmental president and the education president, he has based his leadership on the same scientific principle which made the thermos bottle a commercial success,'' Boren read in a deep drawl. Boren, a beefy Oklahoman with a long list of government jobs behind him, was a featured speaker at ``Frontier Thinking,'' a three-day conference to find ways to reconcile industrial profits with the environment. ``We believe that progress is our greatest mistake. We believe that nothing should be done for the first time.'' Boren said. ``We believe that the status quo is too progressive, and that's why we're here at this conference.'' He expressed shock at the conference's agenda. ``Creativity!'' he spat in a rare display of emotion. ``We accept creativity, as long as it's creativity with narrowly established guidelines, and it protects us.'' ``But a lot of things we've been hearing at this conference is about changing things. Why, that's shocking. With change, we're liable to have movement, and with movement we're going to get mistakes.'' ``Doing nothing and doing it with style. That's what we're all about,'' he said. His entourage included a Soviet protege, Leonid Florentiev, the international editor of the Soviet humor magazine ``Krokodil,'' who would be establishing ``an affiliate office in Moscow,'' Boren said. It will be called the Soviet Academy of Bureaucratic Arts, or AKABURIS, Florentiev said in a thick Russian accent. `It is the most bureaucratic nation in the world,'' Florentiev said, his face flushed with pride. ``It goes back to Ivan the Terrible'' who got his name because he was a terribly good bureaucrat, Florentiev said. There is much INATAPROBU can learn from AKABURIS once the latter gets going with Florentiev at the helm as ``chief of protocol,'' Boren said. With INATAPROBU members already at desks in 38 nations, Soviet involvement would permit preliminary orbital implementation of a bureaucratic apparatus that no system could crack and change, Florentiev said. ``We could have bureaucrats moving from country to county, a well-coordinated bureaucratic exchange'' that would freeze the entire planet into a memo-writing status quo, Boren observed. AKABURIS, like INATAPROBU, will have powers to confer the Order of the Bird awards on good bureaucrats. The award, a sculpture of a naked, pot-bellied bird, is conferred to bureaucrats able to ``blotate with optimal pappetry, fuzzify, zichify, respond with assentiality, develop rationale for non-reccurrence, innovate within established guidelines, and delay by sending to general counsel.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Warns Against Intimidation, Use of Force in Lithuania
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs pvs graf 3, Administration officials, to say at least some journalists ordered to leave.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush warned the Soviet Union today that any attempt to intimidate or use force against the breakaway republic of Lithuania ``is bound to backfire. That is inevitable.'' Bush coupled his statement with a declaration that the United States stands with the people of Lithuania ``and supports their right to self-determination.'' Administration officials said the Soviet Union today ordered foreign diplomats and at least some journalists to leave Lithuania, as tensions between Moscow and the secession-minded republic mounted. The two U.S. diplomats in Vilnius were given 12 hours to depart and will comply, the officials said. Diplomats from other countries also were instructed to leave, but the officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said they did not know how many were involved. Soviet armor rumbled through the Lithuanian capital's streets on Thursday, prompting concern that increasing Kremlin pressure would lead to violence. Bush told a White House gathering, ``Any attempt to coerce or intimidate or forcibly intervene against the Lithuanian people is bound to backfire. That is inevitable.'' Bush spoke about Lithuania as he opened a news conference with editors and reporters from out-of-town news media. Declaring solidarity with Lithuanians, Bush said, ``this is a complex and sensitive time, when realistic, levelheaded leadership is required on all sides. ``Lithuanian leaders have consistently demonstrated their capacity in this rgard, and the United States will do nothing that will make their task more difficult,'' he said. ``We know the Soviet Union has a longstanding interest in Lithuania but those interests can only be addressed through dialogue and negotiations,'' Bush said. Responding to a question, Bush said he had not seen any intelligence suggesting ``some kind of conflagration over the weekend'' in Lithuania. Nevertheless, he said, ``it is a matter of considerable tension. I hope those tensions can be released through negotiation.'' On other subjects, the president: _ Said that ``I don't think this is the time to change the policy on sanctions'' on South Africa, even though he has been reviewing the sanction issue within his own administration and with congressional leaders. He said dates have not yet been set on visits to the White House of South African President F.W. deKlerk or black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela. _ Said his administration would be delighted to help ``a democratically elected government in Cuba'' if one ever emerges. However, Bush added, ``Castro has not changed. Indeed, he is swimming against the tide.'' _ Defended spending money to aid new democracies instead of putting more into domestic programs, saying it was important to ``help create stable democracies that will actively trade with the United States.'' _ Said the federal government should not set itself up as a censor of controversial art, but declared, ``I am deeply offended by some of the filth that I see and to which federal money has gone and some of the sacrilegious, blasphemous depictions that are portrayed by some to be art.'' He said he had seen ``two horrendous examples of what I would call blasphemous material that has no business of getting one cent of the taxpayers' money.'' Bush did not identify the artists or their works. _ Said his administration is looking into ways of shifting shipping lanes off the coast of California to keep oil tankers further away from beaches. He said it was impossible to deny access to tankers to West Coast ports, but said ``we can go the extra mile in terms of environmental protection.'' _Declared himself opposed to statehood for the District of Columbia. ``This is a federal city and my view is it should remain that,'' he said. ``Put me down as unsympathetic to that particular cause.'' Bush also discussed Lithuania at a news conference Thursday, saying he was pleased Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze had said Moscow would not use force. ``Please continue to exercise that kind of restraint. And remember, no use of force,'' Bush said. He called on the Kremlin and Lithuanians to negotiate their differences. ``They should talk about that,'' Bush said when asked about Gorbachev's demand that the republic's citizens surrender their personal firearms. ``My appeal would again be peaceful resolution through discussion of this difficult question.'' Bush said it would be ``presumptuous and arrogant'' for him to get more detailed and say which side should initiate talks. The State Department was more critical of the Soviet moves. ``We're concerned by the order to have internal security and secret police troops seize private sporting guns unless they are surrendered,'' department spokesman Richard Boucher said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Panamanian Vice President Urge Congress to Pass Aid Measure
DOC.TEXT: President Bush stepped up pressure Friday for Congress to pass his $800 million aid package for Panama and Nicaragua, stating, ``We really cannot afford delay.'' Bush's campaign included an Oval Office meeting with Panamanian Vice President Guillermo Ford, who has been lobbying Congress to approve the aid. The package includes $500 million for invasion-wracked Panama and $300 million for Nicaragua's newly elected government. ``Panama and Nicaragua stand at a historic moment on the threshhold of democracy,'' Bush told a luncheon of regional news editors. ``In both nations the people have spoken in favor of freedom but the difficult work of democracy building remains.'' In pushing publicly for the package for the second day in a row, Bush tried to counter sentiment among some Congress members that the needs of two small countries should not get priority in light of U.S. wishes to help the emerging democracies in Eastern Europe. U.S. aid to Eastern Europe is important, Bush said. But he added, ``There is work to be done, work that I feel is every bit as important in support of democracy right here in our own hemisphere.'' Ford said he had met with Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., one of the leading critics of the Latin Ameria special assistance package. Leahy has said the money is too much for two small countries, even though their dire economic straits are due in significant part to past U.S. policies. Ford said Leahy ``has his own views and I respect them... I think he will be reviewing his own ideas and I sincerely hope that he will back up Panama because we do need the assistance.'' He also told reporters outside the White House that Panama was not going to compete with the Eastern European countries for aid. But he noted that $14 billion in international aid is slated for Poland, and the $500 million Bush is seeking for Panama represents ``a matter of an inadequate proportion.'' Bush said during a photo session with Ford that passage of the aid package is ``absolutely essential.'' He is seeking passage by April 6, when Congress leaves for its Easter recess. Told that Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell had expressed doubts the package could pass by then, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said the aid is ``an urgent need in Panama. It's an important package, a well-studied package.'' The president again stated that if Congress cannot agree on places to cut the defense budget to pay for the aid package, ``I`m ready to make the hard choices. ``With Congress' authorization ... I am ready to select offsets from the defense budget, break the logjam and get these much needed resources moving into the region. With democracy at stake, we really cannot afford delay.'' Ford said the aid would help Panama ``jump start'' its economy and ``will allow us to put the show on the road and not have to come back every year, knocking on doors, asking for additional help.'' The United States installed Ford and President Guillermo Endara in December after Bush sent invasion troops to topple dictator Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. ``We are liberated. Now we're free. And we're ready to put our act together,'' Ford told Bush in the photo session. Bush told his White House visitor, ``Anything we can do to help, we want to do it. I want to assure you, the priority is passage of this legislation.'' Ford told Bush he had received an ``absolutely wonderful'' response on Capitol Hill. Bush's military invasion of Panama resulted in physical destruction and looting of stores, in addition to economic damage left by U.S. sanctions against the Noriega regime. Nicaragua labored for several years under a U.S. trade embargo against its leftist government, which poured large parts of its national resources into fighting the U.S.-backed Contra rebels. The Nicaragua portion of the aid package includes $30 million to help demobilize and resettle the Contras in their homeland. It also includes assistance for the incoming government of Violeta Chamorro to get the nation's agricultural economy back on a sure footing.

DOC.HEAD: De Maiziere Seeks to Head Government, Denies Links to Secret Police
DOC.TEXT: The leader of East Germany's Christian Democrats formally declared Friday his intention to run for prime minister following his party's victory in national elections. But Lothar de Maiziere continued to be dogged by allegations he collaborated with the disbanded Communist secret police. He again denied the accusations when he announced his candidacy at a news conference. De Maiziere, 50, whose Christian Democrats head the three-party Alliance for Germany, had said Thursday his candidacy for the top job depended on the outcome of talks between his party and others on forming a coalition government. But West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl had been pushing de Maiziere to declare his intentions and start forming a government as soon as possible so Bonn and East Berlin can negotiate unification. The Alliance, which also includes Democratic Awakening and the German Social Union, supports speedy reunification. In East Germany's first free elections Sunday, it captured the largest share of seats in the 400-member Parliament but failed to clinch a majority. It was widely expected de Maiziere would seek the prime minister's post, although other possible candidates have been mentioned. Parliament must meet within 30 days of the election and pick a prime minister on a simple majority vote. The West German newspaper Cologne Express said Friday that de Maiziere had a code name, ``Scerny'' in the files of the secret police, who for years enforced the repressive tactics of the hard-line Communist regime. The newspaper cited as its source Werner Fischer, an official in charge of dismantling the hated secret police, or ``Stasi.'' Fischer was quoted as saying he got the information from the same anonymous source who revealed that the former chairman of the Democratic Awakening party had links to the Stasi. The party official, Wolfgang Schnur, resigned as chairman after admitting he had been involved with the Stasi. Fischer conceded he had no proof de Maiziere was a secret police informer but that he took the allegations seriously. The newspaper quoted Fischer as saying it was possible de Maiziere was the target of a campaign to discredit him. In 40 years of Communist rule, the Stasi helped run the country by controlling many aspects of daily and official life, and many people had little choice but to collaborate. The caretaker Communist government began dissolving it after the fall pro-democracy movement that overthrew the hard-line Communist regime. By official count, about one of every 80 East Germans once either worked for or cooperated with the secret police. But many people say even more were involved in helping longtime Communist leader Erich Honecker keep the 16.3 million people under firm control. Honecker was ousted Oct. 18. In seeking a coalition government, alliance officials said they were near an agreement with three parties close to West Germany's Free Democrats, a junior partner in the Bonn government coalition. Talks were to continue next week, according to Democratic Awakening's new chairman, Rainer Eppelmann. Eppelmann also renewed a coalition offer to the Social Democrats, who finished second in the balloting Sunday. The Social Democrats agreed to talks but said they would not cooperate with the German Social Union, the most right-wing party in the Alliance for Germany. Final official election results published Friday gave the Alliance for Germany one less seat in Parliament and accorded one more to the Social Democrats. The alliance now hold 192 seats, and the Social Democrats 88.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Chairman Lee Iacocca went to school, He wanted to groove on that golden rule. Got to rapping with the gang And the Rich Academy guys gave him some slang: ``He left Ford Motor Company with a plan on the double. Became Chrysler's CEO, found out they were in trouble. He designed a new automobile, they called the `K.' His new car and charming wit surely saved the day.'' Student Chris Longino got in the entrepreneurial way: ``I'm going to keep this (song). I might make some money off this one day.'' Translated: The Chrysler Corp. chairman visited the 9-year-old alternative school on Thursday. During his visit, Longino and fellow student Aaron Bolton performed their ``Iacocca Rap.''

Singer Billy Joel won the first round of a $90 million lawsuit he filed against his former manager. State Judge Edward Lehner ordered the ex-manager, Frank Weber, to pay the singer $2 million that Joel contended was stolen from him. Lehner also said Joel was entitled to go to trial on another set of claims against Weber. Joel contends that Weber took $30 million from him in unauthorized management commissions, investments in companies Weber controlled and other alleged embezzlements. Joel also is seeking $60 million in punitive damages from Weber, according to Joel's lawyer, Leonard Marks. In the written opinion Thursday, Lehner dismissed Weber's claim that he had an oral agreement to pay $2 million back to Joel. Marks said he contacted Joel in London and told the singer of the judge's decision. ``Billy is absolutely delighted with this result and regards it as a first-round knockout,'' he said. Marks said he expected the case to go to trial in six months to a year. Weber's attorney, Anthony Conforti, could not be reached for comment Friday because he was on vacation, according to a secretary at his Long Island office.

Donald Trump had his alleged mistress Marla Maples move in next door to him at Trump Tower, much to the dismay of his estranged wife, Ivana, a newspaper reported Friday. ``I am shocked and saddened that Donald could subject me and the children to such shameful behavior,'' Mrs. Trump said, according to gossip columnist Liz Smith's account in the Daily News. Ms. Maples moved into the building in December, Smith said, and has evaded the past 5{ weeks of intensive media scrutiny by using a side entrance and taking the service elevator directly to her 63rd-floor apartment. After Trump's separation from his wife became public in February, Trump moved in across the hall from Ms. Maples, Smith said. It was reported Thursday that Trump was ``dropping'' Ms. Maples. But Smith called this a ruse designed to ``soften up'' Mrs. Trump and prevent her from making legal moves that might embarrass the billionaire tycoon before he goes before the New Jersey Casino Control Commission on Thursday. Trump is seeking final license approval for the Taj Mahal, his mega-casino slated to open April 5 in Atlantic City. Trump's spokesman has refused to comment on the alleged affair. Ms. Maples' spokesman has said the aspiring actress' relationship with Trump was never more than a friendship.

Miss America Debbye Turner says she entered beauty pageants repeatedly and refused to listen to critics who told her a black woman would never win the national contest. She also said she was undeterred when the same critics scoffed at her for being a devout Christian and a marimba player. Ms. Turner, who won the title last September in Atlantic City, told high school students Thursday that her example should show everybody that all dreams are attainable. She said she entered pageants repeatedly, and had two runner-up finishes in Arkansas, before winning the Miss Missouri title and qualifying to go to Atlantic City. ``I said, `Alright, God, do you want me to do this?'' Ms. Turner recalled. ``What's important about the story is, no, I didn't give up.'' Ms. Turner said afterward that she has delivered much the same speech to dozens of school audiences, but that the message of motivating youth to high achievement has remained fresh. ``Although it's the hundredth time, I'm doing something I sincerely believe in,'' she said.

Patricia Kluge, whose husband, John, was ranked America's richest man by Forbes magazine, said his billions have not changed her life dramatically. ``Even though I'm aware that we live a magnificent life and we have magnificent friends around the world ... I'm still my mother's daughter, my brothers' sister and my family's child,'' Mrs. Kluge said Thursday. ``I still see myself as the girl I always was.'' The one-time model married Kluge in 1981. They have lived a largely secluded life on a palatial Albemarle County estate. Kluge surpassed Wal-Mart executive Sam Walton as Forbes's richest man last year.

DOC.HEAD: First Lady Will Welcome Broccoli Caravan to Washington
DOC.TEXT: The White House broccoli saga continued Friday. As the president left to spend a presumably broccoli-free weekend at the presidential retreat in Camp David, Md., the White House announced that his wife, Barbara, will be on hand to greet 10 tons of the chompy green stuff when it arrives in Washington on Monday. Three cases of the vegetable the president loves to hate will be delivered to the White House, representing 10 tons being sent by california growers to Washington soup kitchens. Mrs. Bush will join Ed Downes of the United Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Associations Emergency Services Food Bank in accepting the vegetables. The first lady is fond of broccoli, but the president has put himself on the record as planning never to eat another stalk. After all, he told reporters Thursday, he's president of the United States and he doesn't have to eat it if he doesn't want to.
