His earlier comments about the vegetable provoked broccoli growers to send truck loads of it to the Washington soup kitchens.

DOC.HEAD: Playwright-President Presents Morality Play on World Stage
DOC.TEXT: He mumbles, pulls at his tie, looks uncomfortable when mobbed by celebrities and knows little about protocol. This, plus a simple moral message, is what endears Vaclav Havel to a world weary of made-to-measure politicians. When he made his first presidential journey abroad, to East Germany, his aides had to scramble to get him his passport. It had been confiscated by the ousted Communist bosses. Now, three months after his fairy-tale ascent from prisoner to president, Havel has visited 10 countries. This week it was France and Britain. As usual, he was watched with adoration. Havel is using his position as a platform to expound on a political philosophy developed over 20 years of writing. His voice is gravelly from years of chain-smoking, he sometimes mumbles or bumps into the microphone, but his words are clear, simple and direct: ``Totalitarianism deforms the human soul. People in Czechoslovakia are constantly asking me about ways to implement the new freedom. And I tell them, implement it in any way you wish.'' He is one of a kind, an artist-stateman and the darling of the intelligentsia: Kurt Vonnegut, Zubin Mehta, Paul Simon, Edward Albee in New York; in Paris, an all-star cast led by actor Alain Delon; Tom Stoppard, Harold Pinter and Jeremy Irons among the guests at a reception given by the Royal Shakespeare Company in London. ``In the United States we encountered almost embarrassing adulation,'' said Havel's spokesman Michael Zantovsky. ``They treated him as if he were some kind of modern prophet, and he is not particularly eager to become one.'' Instead he is modest, shy, prone to blush. He deflects attention with humor and irony. He stands behind tables and against walls, away from the center of the room. At one point he even managed somehow to hunch his short frame under a loudspeaker. Except for the suit and tie, there is little to distinguish Havel the harassed dissident from Havel the president. ``The reception he gets is something we have been absolutely unprepared for,'' Zantovsky said. ``It really is too much of a good thing.'' At the London reception Thursday night, in his own milieu of theater and art, Havel looked relaxed. With a cut-crystal glass of white wine and a cigarette in one hand, gesticulating with the other, he chatted with men in ponytails and earrings and women in men's suits. Havel clearly enjoys the drama of his situation and the theatricality of the presidency. The new uniforms he picked to replace the drab khaki of communism on the palace honor guard, for example, were created by the costume designer for Milos Forman's film, ``Amadeus.'' But Havel's performance abroad is unrehearsed and improvisation is not without pitfalls. At his Paris news conference he kept tugging at his tie as if it were a noose around a neck more accustomed to open-necked shirts. A British TV commentary described him as ``refreshingly naive.'' After shaking hands with Prince Philip on the stately steps of Buckingham Palace, he wiped his sweaty palm on his pants, apparently unaware that the nation would see it on TV. But if there were rough edges, they were always softened by Havel's polished and thoughtful words. Like all the speeches he has given over the past three months, they were a logical extension of the limpid essays he has written for 20 years. Introducing him to an audience of intellectuals on Wednesday, political commentator Timothy Garton-Ash called him ``an exceptional example of what I might call moral leadership through language.'' From a moral base built on years of fighting tyranny, Havel preaches political morality at a time when old political blocs and policies are crumbling. His watchwords are ``living in truth,'' preserving the sanctity of words, revering freedom. He insists he will serve as president only until Czechoslovakia has free elections, and these are scheduled for June. But already his impact looks permanent. His words, Ash said, have become ``letters to the world.'' Or, as The Times of London put it: ``Havel is an idea whose man has come.''

DOC.HEAD: FDA Approves Drug for Children with `Bubble Boy' Syndrome
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved a drug officials say will dramatically improve the lives of children born with a rare disease that makes them unable to fight infections. About 40 children worldwide are born each year with severe combined immunodeficiency disease, or SCID, a genetic disorder also called ``Boy in the Bubble'' disease because some children have survived only by living in an enclosed, sterile environment. Peg-ADA was developed with a $169,000 grant from the FDA under the ``orphan'' drug program, which is designed to give companies a financial incentive to develop products for an extremely small patient population. Children with SCID lack adequate immune systems and therefore are unable to fight even common infections, such as chicken pox or pneumonia. Most children with the disorder die before they are 2 years old. The only cure for the disease, the cause of which is believed to be lack of an enzyme, is a bone marrow transplant, generally from a sibling. Peg-ADA, made by Enzon Inc. of South Plainfield, N.J., will allow children for whom bone marrow transplant is not feasible or has failed to survive outside a sterile environment. Only about 20 percent of the children born with SCID find a compatible bone-marrow donor and only about 30 percent to 40 percent of those have successful transplants, said Donna Chappina, a spokeswoman for Enzon. ``It will have a dramatic effect on improving the quality of life for the patients and their families,'' said Dr. James Mason, assistant secretary for health in the Department of Health and Human Services. Once the drug takes effect, children who had been confined to sterile isolation would be able to live a normal life, going to school and interacting with other people, Chappina said. The company said the drug is the first treatment for directly correcting an inherited enzyme deficiency disease. The drug is administered weekly by injection. It is designed to replace the missing enzyme adenosine deaminase, or ADA. Because it does not prompt the body to produce the enzyme, patients must take the injections for the rest of their lives. The product will be marketed under the trade name Adagen.

DOC.HEAD: Bright and Brief
DOC.TEXT: A condominium owner who lost a legal war to keep his pickup truck in front of his home now parks a make-believe tank, complete with fake machine gun, outside. ``I'm standing up for the rights of condo owners who are afraid or intimidated,'' Andrew Zuccala, dressed in combat fatigues, said Thursday about his aesthetic battle. Zuccala's fight with his condo association at the Fox Hollow development began when the anti-truck parking rule was passed two years after he purchased his condo. The truck he owned then was permissible under a grandfather provision, but a replacement was not. After warning Zuccala several times that his 1989 blue pickup was not allowed, the association sued. The Palm Beach County Circuit Court ruled in its favor Monday. Zuccala, 32, responded by painting a 1971 station wagon in camouflage colors installing black cannon turrets on the roof and hood, and adorning it with such slogans as ``War Wagon,'' ``Captain Andrew'' and ``Condo Commando Killer'' on it. Unlike his truck, the ``war wagon'' conforms to condo rules, Zuccala said. ``My blue truck isn't offensive, but it's banned,'' he said. ``This tank is all right because it's a car and not a truck. They have a choice. It's the tank or the truck.'' Michael Gelfand, the condominium association attorney, has not seen the mock tank, but said the group does have restrictions on nuisances and eyesores.

Remember the Land Shark that gobbled up characters on ``Saturday Night Live''? Firefighters summoned to a minor house fire found two sand sharks waiting for them. ``They're not dangerous,'' owner Kerry Martinez told Fire Lt. Howie Carlson. ``They're sand sharks. They're only about 2 feet long.'' Firefighters responding to an electrical fire arrived at the Martinez house in Brooklyn early Thursday to find Martinez, his wife and three daughters outside. Carlson asked if there were any people or animals inside and was told there were two sharks on the living room rug. The 180-gallon aquarium holding them had burst, apparently as a result of the fire. After putting out the blaze, which started in some electrical equipment, the firefighters used shovels to lift the fish into pails of salt water. Since the sharks had lost their aquarium, Martinez said he would donate them to the New York Aquarium at Coney Island.

Defeating students three times his age in a statewide art contest wasn't the hard part for 6-year-old Michael Thaddeaus Bragulla. Drawing God's feet was. ``They're just like mine,'' said Thad, who lives in Belton, south of Kansas City. ``Drawing the toes was the hardest part.'' His poster ``Reflections: Where Does the Sky End?'' was selected recently over 1,826 entries to represent Missouri in a nationwide contest sponsored by the PTA. It will hang for the next couple of months at the PTA's national headquarters in Chicago before being entered in a national competition in June. Thad's poster was done first in pencil and then colored with magic marker. He started by drawing a tree and added his house, in which his mother can be seen washing dishes. Then he added himself, his brother, his father and his dog playing outside. He put a bird's nest atop the tree and a rainbow above that. On up, he added clouds, the moon, Saturn, a spaceship and space creatures. Then angels, and finally, God's feet. Thad emphasizes he was only 5 when he drew the poster. ``My brain sends messages to my mouth,'' he said. ``When my mouth says it's good, that's when I know I'm done.''

DOC.HEAD: New Farmers Home Administration Chief Sworn In
DOC.TEXT: La Verne Ausman, a former Wisconsin state farm official, was sworn in Friday as administrator of the Farmers Home Administration in the Agriculture Department. Ausman joined the department in 1986 and most recently was a consultant to the FmHA. Before coming to Washington, Ausman for five years was Wisconsin state secretary of agriculture, trade and consumer protection. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Ausman brings to FmHA ``a valuable combination of experience, both as a successful farmer and a leader in agricultural policymaking at the state and national levels.'' The FmHA job pays $78,200 a year. The agency, often called the government's rural lender of last resort, operates a variety of programs of credit and development assistance to farmers and communities.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Returns Body of Executed Journalist
DOC.TEXT: The body of executed journalist Farzad Bazoft was flown back to London without ceremony on Friday from Baghdad, where he was convicted and hanged as a spy. The Iranian-born Bazoft, 31, who lived in London, worked for The Observer weekly, which has said he was not a spy and was simply doing his job. A scheduled Iraqi Airways Boeing 747 landed at Heathrow airport with the plain plywood coffin on which Bazoft's surname and the address of a south London undertaker were written with a green felt-tip pen. Bazoft was hanged March 15 despite British-led international appeals to President Saddam Hussein for clemency. Mailbags and suitcases belonging to passengers were with the coffin in the cargo hold. The coffin was unloaded on a mechanical ramp. Three British Airways cargo handlers put the coffin in a van, which drove it to a cargo shed to await collection for burial. ``There was no official from the Foreign Office, no hearse and no relative or friend on the tarmac,'' reported Britain's domestic Press Association news agency. The Foreign Office said The Observer had paid for the body's return and was arranging the funeral because Bazoft had no relatives in Britain. Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd recalled Britain's ambassador in protest and was sending home six Iraqi military trainees. Bazoft was on his seventh visit to Iraq in September in a group of journalists invited to cover elections in Kurdistan. He was arrested trying to check out reports of an explosion at a military installation, where the Iraqis said he made drawings, took photographs and collected soil samples. Daphne Parish, 52, a British nurse working in Baghdad who drove Bazoft to the secret military site, was jailed for 15 years for helping him. A memorial service for Bazoft is being held at the journalists' church, St. Bride's on Fleet Street, on March 28.

DOC.HEAD: US Wool Production Declines
DOC.TEXT: The nation's wool production declined slightly last year after increasing in 1988, the Agriculture Department said Friday. Production was estimated at 89.2 million pounds, down from 89.5 million in 1988, an annual report said. Wool output in 1987 was less than 84.5 million pounds. The report said the total value of wool shorn in 1989 was about $109 million, down from $125 million in 1988. Mohair production was reported at 17.3 million pounds, about the same as in 1988. The value was put at $27.2 million, down from $32.8 million the year before. The report said prices of shorn wool in 1989 averaged $1.22 per pound, compared with $1.38 in 1988. Mohair prices, at $1.58 per pound, were down from $1.89 in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Sewer Workers Discover Remains of Cheops' Long-Lost Temple
DOC.TEXT: NAZLETT EL-SAMMAN, Egypt (AP) _ Sewer workers have discovered remains of a temple that Pharaoh Cheops built for his funeral 4,600 years ago, and Egyptologists are hoping it will tell them more about the mysterious pharaoh of the Great Pyramid. The discovery this month of Cheop's Valley Temple confirms theories about the layout of Giza Plateau for the 70-year period in which the pharaoh, his son and grandson built their three pyramids and monuments nearby. Nazlett el-Samman lies at the foot of the plateau, facing the Sphinx, and sewage from the village often is mentioned as a cause of the Sphinx's dangerous deterioration. A U.S.-financed sewage project began last year, and Egyptologists were assigned to monitor construction because of the probability of finding antiquities. They were on hand in early March as diggers began uncovering mammoth granite and limestone blocks, a flint knife, Roman brick walls and other relics. By mid-March, more remains were turning up, and finally the main prize _ a 59-foot-long row of basalt rocks. The experts identified it as the floor for Cheops' Valley Temple. Because basalt is difficult to carve and expensive, the stone was reserved for royal use, often as flooring for sacred places. Although his pyramid was the largest ever built, Cheops left few other glimpses of his life or his 23-year reign, which ended in 2528 B.C. ``With what we're finding now, we can piece together Cheops' history and reconstruct how this part of the pyramids area would have looked,'' said Zahi Hawass of the Egyptian Antiquities Organization. The newly found ruins lie 13 feet below street level, partially covered with sewage. Getting to them will not be easy. Diggers already are excavating two Roman-era sites in a Nazlett el-Samman alley only a foot from village houses. Archaeologists have to contend with children at play, donkeys and angry villagers worried that antiquities officials might invoke their legal authority to force them from their houses. Cheops' Valley Temple is proving an even greater challenge. Engineers for the sewer project are pumping water from the drainage ditch where the basalt flooring was found. The Giza Pyramids and the structures around them are thought by some Egyptologists to be part of an elaborate blueprint for the dead, precisely planned and executed. But their exact roles in the death and resurrection of the pharaohs are debated. Burial was an elaborate ritual to ensure that neither the pharaoh nor Egypt would ever die. The journey to eternity began in the Valley Temple, where the pharaoh's body was taken for ritual purification, perhaps embalming. For the final rituals, the body was carried up the long causeway to a mortuary temple next to the pyramid. Early travelers' descriptions of the pyramids area had given modern egyptogists a good idea where Cheops' temple should be found. In the fifth century B.C., the Greek Herodotus wrote that he saw Cheops' causeway, covered and decorated with carved animal scenes. The German scholar Karl Richard Lepsius said only traces remained of the ruined causeway by the early 1840s.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Out Of Step On Broccoli
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is out of the mainstream when it comes to broccoli. People love broccoli, and government statistics prove it. ``We called it the vegetable of the 80s,'' said Agriculture Department economist Gary Lucier. He said broccoli consumption more than doubled in the United States between 1980 and 1988, going from an annual average of 3 pounds per person to 6.8 pounds. Back in 1970, Americans on average were eating only 1{ pounds of the vegetable each year. Both fresh and frozen versions move quickly off the supermarket shelves, though most people prefer it fresh, according to statistics. Lucier said health concerns played a major role in the big jump. Broccoli is high in vitamin C and has a substantial amount of vitamin A, says a pamphlet from the United Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Association. Bush's distaste for the food was revealed last week when he banned it from Air Force One's galley. It made headlines when he told questioning reporters on Thursday: ``I do not like broccoli and I haven't liked it since I was a little kid and my mother made me eat it and I'm president of the United States and I'm not going to eat any more broccoli.'' Bush, 65, clearly was one of the early eaters of broccoli. Though the vegetable was discovered thousands of years ago, California farmers began growing it experimentally for the U.S. market in the 1920s, shipping just a few crates East. It's so perishable that it requires the quick transport of modern times to make it to stores any distance from the fields in edible condition. The USDA didn't even keep records of acreage planted in broccoli until 1946 when about 18,700 acres were planted to the crop nationwide. By 1989, the acreage had jumped to 121,500. The amount of broccoli that could be grown on each acre more than doubled in those 45 years. California fills 90 percent of the country's demand for the plant, but it's also a significant cash crop for Arizona, Texas and Oregon and is produced in smaller quantities in other states. Maine, for example, where Bush has been vacationing most of his life, is the biggest supplier in New England. ``We've gone from zero to about 3,000 acres over the past six or seven years,'' said Russell Libby, director of the Maine Department of Agriculture. Maine broccoli farmer Lance Smith said it was too bad the president didn't like broccoli, but he was was entitled to his own opinion. ``But you know, he really hasn't looked good,'' said Smith. ``We've noticed he's looked a little peaked. That could be it.''

DOC.HEAD: New York Investment Banker Becomes Chairman of Kennedy Center
DOC.TEXT: A New York investment banker who heads Carnegie Hall was named Friday as the new chairman of the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, and he promised to make it a pre-eminent international institution. ``We are at the starting line of a new effort to place the Kennedy Center in its rightful place as one of the major performing arts institutions in the world,'' James D. Wolfensohn said after being appointed by a unanimous vote by the board of trustees. ``That opportunity exists.'' Wolfensohn, 56, was born in Australia and is now an American citizen. He was an executive partner of Salomon Brothers in New York and an executive at several other banking and finance firms before starting his own, James D. Wolfensohn Inc. A cellist and one-time Olympic fencer, Wolfensohn is involved in extensive public interest and volunteer efforts. He is a director of CBS Inc. in addition to being chairman of Carnegie Hall. Wolfensohn said Friday he will remain chairman of Carnegie Hall at least through the 1990-91 season, the hall's centennial. He said he will be in Washington for at least two full days a week and probably more than that in the first three to six months. He agreed to take the job after the Bush administration and key congressmen pledged Friday to help eradicate the center's $15 million deficit and to subsidize a backlog of repairs and maintenance. Trustee Melvin Laird said six lawmakers on the center's board agreed to introduce bills providing money to take care of the deficit as well as an additional $30 million over two years for roof and garage repairs and other capital improvements. White House Chief of Staff John Sununu gave assurances that the administration will support the requests, Laird said. ``It is on that condition that I have come down,'' Wolfensohn said, referring to the financial help. ``And if it didn't materialize, we'd have to look at everyone's position, including mine.'' The new chairman said he will appoint a president to manage the Kennedy Center's daily operations and an artistic director to shape its programming. He said the center needs to raise another $20 million to $25 million a year from private sources to bring its programs and management up to world-class standards. ``Excitement unfortunately comes very expensive today,'' he said. ``And to make this place exciting we're going to need a lot of money.'' Wolfensohn called the Kennedy Center ``the cultural heartbeat of this country'' and an international showplace. But he stressed that it is a local institution as well. ``We're committed to warm it up, make it accessible, have it loved, cherished and visited by the people of Washington,'' he said. Kennedy Center officials had been searching for a new chairman since last Oct. 25, when chairman and president Ralph P. Davidson submitted his resignation. Wolfensohn's appointment was effective immediately.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Show Offbeat Sculpture In Lyon
DOC.TEXT: Flattened cars and a stainless steel autopsy table fringed with human hair greeted visitors at Friday's opening of an American contemporary sculpture exhibition. ``Status of Sculpture,'' at the Espace Lyonnais d'Art Contemporain through May 20, looks at what 10 young American sculptors are doing with objects from everyday life. Take Jon Kessler's ``Twin Kings,'' an automated collage of cobblestones from a Paris street, two heads of French kings bought at a museum gift shop, two panes of stained glass, spotlights and a blinking bulb. ``These are objects from my life in Paris, and a commentary on art itself,'' said Kessler, a native of Yonkers, N.Y. For California sculptor Dustin Shuler, whose ``car pelts'' delighted the Lyon audience, the automobile symbolizes life in 20th century America. ``Ever seen the cars on the California freeways? They're herds, migrating,'' said Shuler. ``Cars have replaced buffalos _ I hunt them, skin them and hang them on the wall.'' Currently adorning the outside wall of the Perrache railroad station in Lyon is one of Shuler's most prized ``kills'' _ a flattened Los Angeles Police Department squad car. ``That was a 1978 Plymouth with a hot engine, an endangered species being phased out of service. I still had to get authorization from the Los Angeles City Council to buy the car,'' he said. Shuler, 41, a native of Pittsburgh, said his works are priced at $20,000 and up, depending on the condition and rarity of the car. Also on display are ``juvenile pelts'' made from skinned kiddie cars, and a red Ford pickup truck with its original Texas license plates. ``This is Texas personified,'' he said. Shuler says he looks for cars with a unique character and favors Volkswagens because of their resemblance to animals. ``Look at that VW bus, to me that's a pair of elephant ears,'' he said. The Lyon show will travel to the Institute of Contemporary Art in London next fall and the Kunstmuseum in Hasselt, Belgium next winter. It also features works by Tishan Hsu, Jennifer Bolande, Christian Marclay, Robert Gober, Cady Noland and Laurie Parsons. Organized by Bernard Brunon, an artist and curator based in Houston, the show is an attempt to underscore the ``poetry'' of the banal consumer objects taken for granted. ``Look at the teapot balanced precariously on a cube,'' Brunon said, referring to a composition by New York artist Nancy Shaver. ``It's talking to the pitcher of milk and through the blue glass in the middle.'' Some visitors at the spacious art center _ on the fourth floor of the train station _ weren't sure they were looking at art. An autopsy table fringed with human hair by Phoenix, Ariz., artist Patty Martori raised more than one eyebrow. ``I don't know what it is, but why not, if it's fun,'' said a Lyon gendarme with a shrug.

DOC.HEAD: Mazowiecki Says Bush Is Helping
DOC.TEXT: Polish Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki reported some progress Thursday in winning President Bush's support for international guarantees of Poland's border with Germany. Mazowiecki, discussing separate tensions across Poland's eastern border, also urged Kremlin leaders to avoid any rash actions against the breakaway Soviet republic of Lithuania. During a three-day visit to Washington, Mazowiecki did not win a firm public pledge from Bush that Poland would play a greater role in talks expected to lead to the reununification of Germany later this year, but Bush did agree that Poland's voice should be heard when issues vital to Poland are on the table. Mazowiecki told reporters at the National Press Club that his delegation had ``achieved a greater understanding of our position'' among U.S. leaders. And he said Bush had assured him that the United States recognized Poland as a major player in the transformation of Europe. Many elements of that transformation remain murky at the moment, including whether West and East Germany will guarantee the German border with Poland. One third of Poland's territory consists of lands that were German before World War II. At the close of the war, the Soviet Union annexed the western third of Poland, and Poland received German territory in return. Mazowiecki refrained from instructing the leaders of Lithuania and the Soviet Union how to resolve their differences, but offered them three bits of counsel. ``First talk. Second, talk. And third, talk,'' said Mazowiecki. Neither the Polish nor the U.S. government has recognized the independent government of Lithuania, although the United States never recognized the forced Soviet annexation of Lithuania and its sister Baltic states of Latvia and Estonia during World War II. Another murky subject in the transformation of Europe is the role of the Kremlin-led Warsaw Pact and the continuing presence of Soviet troops on the territory of pact members like Poland. Bush, after meeting with Mazowiecki, said Thursday that he had not obtained from the Polish prime minister a clear picture of when the estimated 58,000 Soviet troops stationed in Poland would leave. Mazowiecki told the news conference Friday that he expected Soviet troops to be withdrawn from Poland as part of multilateral negotiations on conventional force reductions throughout Europe. He declined to establish a direct link between Poland's aquiescence to the continued presence of Soviet troops on its territory and German guarantees of Poland's western border. But he said that ``it is crucial for us to have our our border reaffirmed by a treaty initialled by the two Germanies before reunification (of Germany) takes place.'' ``By defending our Western border, we are defending the inviolability of all borders'' in Europe, he said. In a separate speech at the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, Mazowiecki urged the United States to maintain its political presence in Europe, and to invest in Poland as a means of opening markets in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. ``We have a rich record of working in the Russian market, in building railroads, for example,'' he told the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. ``We could renew that and carry the world of free enterprise into that market.''

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Girl Killed by Army Jeep, Sparks Riot
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli army jeep accidentally hit and killed a 5-year-old girl Friday in a refugee camp in the occupied Gaza Strip, touching off a clash between soldiers and residents enraged by the death, Arab reports said. A 20-year-old was reported wounded in the unrest. The girl, Wafa Nabil Abdul Razit Abu Midin, jumped into the street and was accidentally struck by the jeep, police said. She was brought to a hospital but died shortly afterward, said Yigal Golan, a spokesman for the Gaza District police. Arab reports said news of the death prompted a riot in the Bureij camp. They said the 20-year-old was shot in the leg when troops opened fire on the crowd. The army said it had no reports of unrest but was checking the report. Also Friday, two firebombs were thrown in the occupied West Bank town of Ramallah, the army said. Israel radio reported that the firebombs hit a car transporting television crews from the U.S. network ABC and Visnews of Britain, but there was no damage or injuries.

DOC.HEAD: Army Conducts Group Burial for Seven Green Berets
DOC.TEXT: As a military band played ``The Ballad of the Green Berets,'' the Army conducted a group burial Friday of remains thought to belong to seven Army soldiers and two Vietnamese pilots shot down over Laos in 1968. The burial, which took place at Arlington National Cemetery, had touched off complaints from some POW@MIA representatives, given that only one of the nine individuals had been positively identified from the bone shards and teeth recovered last year from the crash site. But Army officials said they were able to account for those aboard the CH-34 helicopter that was shot down by anti-aircraft fire over Laos in 1968 because of other evidence recovered at the site and eyewitness accounts of the event. Although group burials are not commonplace, they are used when individual bodies can't be accounted for from the forensic evidence available, said Army spokeswoman Maj. Nancy Burt. ``It went very well. Either family members or representatives of the (U.S. soldiers') families were there to accept the flags,'' said another spokeswoman, Shari Lawrence, of the U.S. Total Army Personnel Command. ``The families need to have this time of emotion and grief,'' said Ms. Lawrence, who attended the ceremony. The remains of the one crew member who was identified, Staff Sgt. Richard A. Fitts, of Abingdon, Mass., were buried in his hometown earlier this year. However, his name is also listed with the other six Green Berets on the group's grave marker, given the possibility that some of his other remains might be mixed with those buried on Friday, Ms. Lawrence said. She said all of the families of the late servicemen agreed to have their relatives' names put on the group marker. However, the names of the two Vietnamese were not included because the names ``weren't released to us,'' she said. Ms. Lawrence said she did not know why that was, but that such a situation might occur if the families couldn't be located. Ms. Lawrence said the Army is scheduled to conduct two more group burials next month, one for soldiers from the Vietnam War and another for remains from World War II. Besides Fitts, the group interment included: Sgt. 1st Class Arthur C. Rader, Jr., Atlantic City, N.J.; Sgt. 1st Class Gary R. LaBohn, Wixom, Mich.; Sgt. 1st Class Michael H. Mein, Cape Vincent, N.Y.; Sgt. 1st Class Klaus D. Scholz, Amarillo, Texas; Capt. Rayond C. Stacks, Memphis, Tenn.; Maj. Samuel K. Toomey III, Independence, Mo.

DOC.HEAD: Free Press Columnist Dies; Award-Winning Advocate for Handicapped
DOC.TEXT: Detroit Free Press columnist Jim Neubacher, who became an advocate for the rights of disabled people after developing multiple sclerosis, died Thursday at age 40. Neubacher died at Providence Hospital, where he was taken March 16 after lapsing into a coma at his parents' home in West Bloomfield Township. ``He was an outstanding journalist,'' Gov. James Blanchard said Thursday. ``Through his column he brought strength, understanding and assistance to his readers.'' Neubacher joined the Free Press in 1971 after graduating from the University of Michigan. He worked as a city desk reporter and as the Free Press' first Canada correspondent and columnist. Neubacher's multiple sclerosis was diagnosed in 1980 when he was 29. In 1982, he returned to Detroit and started his weekly column, ``Disabled in Detroit.'' Through the column, Neubacher became a leader for disabled activists across the state. In 1988, Blanchard presented Neubacher with Michigan's first Victory Award. Survivors include his parents, James and Margaret Neubacher, a brother and three sisters. Services were scheduled for Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Israelis Fed Up With Backroom Deals in Race for Power
DOC.TEXT: From shopkeepers to the president, Israelis are expressing growing anger over the latest and most entangled round of backroom deals by politicians struggling to form the next government. ``The Israeli political system has reached its lowest point,'' liberal legislator Amnon Rubinstein said Friday. ``What we are dealing with is not a political process, but a process of political bribery.'' The political horsetrading is a product of Israel's electoral system, which encourages tiny parties. That's because the whole country is a single electoral district, and the cutoff point for gaining a seat is less than 1 percent of the votes cast. This has meant no party has ever gained enough votes to govern alone, leading to coalitions with an array of small factions. The two largest groups, the center-left Labor Party and the right-wing Likud Bloc, have promised for years to push electoral reform, such as direct voting for the prime minister. But reform bills have always been quietly buried in Parliament committees. Avi Pazner, a chief aide to caretaker Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Likud, now says the two big parties should have tried harder to reform the system the past five years, when they governed together in a coalition. ``Both parties were suspicious of one another. Both somehow were afraid that the other one might utilize the changes, and that's why they neutralized each other,'' said Pazner. ``It was a great mistake. We should have pushed forward an electoral system that would put some order in our political life. This is not a desirable system,'' he told The Associated Press. The latest chapter in topsy-turvy Israeli politics opened last week when Labor brought down the Likud-led government with a no-confidence motion in Parliament over Shamir's refusal to accept U.S. Middle East peace proposal. President Chaim Herzog, who asked Labor leader Shimon Peres to try to form a new coalition, issued a warning to all parties this week that Israelis were growing furious with the seemingly endless political maneuvering. Herzog was quoted as saying ``the Israeli public is fed up with the politicians'' and that ``widespread disillusionment could pave the way for a demagogue to rise to power.'' But Herzog's warning was quickly forgotten in the rush by Labor and Likud to break the deadlock. Each side claims the backing of 60 legislators in the 120-member Parliament. The main partners in the game of political seduction are three ultra-Orthodox religious parties that together control 13 seats. They have been offered key Cabinet posts and funding for religious institutions in exchange for their support. For example, the small Agudat Israel party joined the Labor camp after reportedly being promised the ministries of housing, labor and social affairs. Agudat legislator Rabbi Menachem Porush said Likud upped the ante by dangling the valuable Finance Ministry in front of Agudat if it switched affiliations. Many Israelis are angered by the latest wheeling and dealing. ``This is a terrible situation. It's like blackmail, '' said Dan Ben Moshe, 30, who runs a Jerusalem cigarette shop. ``Everybody wants something in exchange for their support, mainly (government) jobs.'' The conservative Maariv daily was even more scathing in an editorial Friday: ``Of all the democratic systems in the world, Israel has succeeded in finding the worst. The politicians have no shame. They use the weaknesses of the government to their advantage.''

DOC.HEAD: Historic, `Trend-Setting' Conservation Agreement Struck
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Bureau of Land Management and the private Nature Conservancy signed a historic agreement Friday to combine their efforts to preserve wildlife and its habitat for future generations. The agreement formalizes a public-private national partnership to save endangered and rare animals and plants on 40 percent of the country's public lands, encompassing 270 million acres. The BLM's domain includes one-eighth of the land mass in the continental United States, with more than 3,000 species of fish and wildlife, 1,000 of which are considered imperiled. ``This is a policy statement down to our local folks that the green light's lit'' for a trend-setting relationship, said BLM director Cy Jamison. The non-profit Nature Conservancy is committed to preserving biology, zoology and natural ecosystems. Started 36 years ago, it has more than 500,000 members in chapters across the country, a $100 million annual budget and employs biologists, lawyers and people with business degrees. Its goal is the acquisition of private lands to keep as wilderness preserves. That can mean ownership or leasing, alone or in concert with governmental agencies such as the BLM, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service or state parks departments. ``What we're really trying to do is to protect our natural heritage,'' said John Sawhill, the conservancy's new president and former federal energy chief. ``The rate of species extinction in this country is increasing dramatically, and we're trying to slow that down. We're trying to preserve species and important natural communities for future generations.'' The Nature Conservancy has acquired more than 5 million acres as nature preserves in the United States and more in Latin America. It maintains a hefty national revolving fund for its state conservancies to tap into for acquisitions such as the Kartchner Caverns in southeastern Arizona. In all, it owns and manages more than 900 nature preserves, the world's largest privately owned system. Jamison said he has no qualms, and sees no conflicts, about a private organization helping set government policy on land acquisition, ``as long as it comes from the ground up.'' He added that in an emergency, the Nature Conservancy can act much more quickly than the federal government, which can take one to three years. ``They can move today, and that's why the partnership is so important,'' Jamison said.

DOC.HEAD: `Silent Cal's' Horse Rides Again
DOC.TEXT: Gerald Ford golfs and George Bush jogs, but long before those chief executives exercised, Calvin Coolidge took his daily constitutional on an electric horse. The machine, a genteel relative of the bucking broncos of western honky-tonks, is a popular relic of presidential whimsy, said Kerry Buckley, director of the Coolidge collection at the Forbes Library. The device was shipped this week from the Northampton library for temporary display in Kansas. ``That seems to be the item that's attracted people's attention,'' Buckley said Friday. ``Mostly we have manuscripts, documents, letters and so forth.'' Coolidge, the nation's 30th president and one of its most conservative, got his political start as Northampton's mayor. He was a state legislator, lieutenant governor, governor, vice president and president on the death of Warren Harding in 1923. ``Silent Cal'' took up the mechanical horse after developing an allergy to horsehair and finding that too many newspaper reporters tagged along on his daily walks. ``He was a man who had firm habits,'' Buckley said. The machine features an English saddle, handgrips and can be adjusted from a sedate gait to an adventurous gallop. Buckley said a 1925 New York Times article described the regimen this way: ``He takes his first ride before breakfast, indulges in a brief canter just after luncheon, and by the shade of the moon an hour or so before retiring for the night, he takes a sharp gallop that brings on the weariness that induces slumber.'' While popular on ocean liners, the mechanical horse was hardly the stationary bicycle of its time and was something of an anachronism in the Jazz Age, Buckley said. ``He represented to the population a president from another era, an era where we had a nation of producers,'' he said. Coolidge, the first president to speak on the radio, earned the nickname ``Silent Cal,'' because of his general reticence. His ambiguous refusal to enter the 1928 election is commemorated in Northampton annually with the ``I do not choose to run'' 10 kilometer footrace. Coolidge retired to Northampton with his wife, Grace. He died in 1933. Since then, Northampton has become a laid-back, liberal college town, but Coolidge's legacy has been preserved at the museum, said Buckley, visiting assistant professor at the University of Massachusetts history department. The mechanical horse was shipped out this week to the Dwight D. Eisenhower Library in Abilene, Kan., the fourth time it has been loaned out by the Forbes. It will be returned in December. ``We'll be glad to get it back,'' said Buckley, who views the cast-iron machine as an allegory for Coolidge's reign as a Massachusetts Yankee in the Great Gatsby era. ``This is a mechanical horse,'' Buckley said. ``What could be more symbolic of a horse and buggy society being kind of transformed electronically in the '20s?''

DOC.HEAD: Moms Sentenced for Letting Men Molest Kids
DOC.TEXT: Two women were sentenced Friday to 40 years in prison for lining up their children so men could pick them for sex. They received the same sentence last week for forcing two children to have sex. Carolyn Wilson and Annette Sanford each were sentenced in Allegan County Circuit Court to 5 to 15 years for third-degree criminal sexual conduct; Wilson got 20 to 40 years and Sanford 10 to 40 years for first-degree criminal sexual conduct. The victims had mixed feelings about their mothers going to prison, said their foster mothers on Friday. ``No matter what happened, she's still their mom,'' said Deb Johnson, who is caring for three of the children. ``I think they do miss their mother, ... even though they feel terrible about what was done to them.'' Dixie Lumbard, a foster mother to one of Sanford's three daughters, said the children are relieved but echoed Johnson's sentiments. ``No matter what happened, they're still their mothers,'' she said. The convictions came from the sexual abuse of Wilson's now-13-year-old son and 15-year-old daughter, who testified their mother and Sanford forced them, their older sister and Sanford's young daughters to line up several times a week so visiting men could select one for sex. Authorities believe drugs or money changed hands. The children said hundreds of rapes and molestations occurred from 1985-88, while the two families lived together in Plainwell. ``You have violated society's trust and respect of these children in the most heinous way I can conceive of,'' Judge George Corsiglia told Wilson during sentencing. The women were sentenced last week to up to 40 years for previous convictions of first-degree criminal sexual conduct for forcing Wilson's son and Sanford's daughter, then 11 and 9, respectively, to have sex while the women watched. Authorities say Wilson, 42, and Sanford, 34, are half-sisters and had a lesbian relationship. With the sentences being served concurrently and credit given for time served in the county jail, Wilson could be eligible for parole in about 15 years and Sanford could be eligible in about 14 years. The children, ages 9 to 19, told of being beaten by their mothers, and a social worker testified they ate from garbage cans because they were not given food. The women have said they are innocent and will appeal the convictions. Their attorneys argued the children concocted the sexual abuse stories so they could stay with foster families after being removed in 1988 from an admittedly neglectful home.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Resolution Says Jerusalem Should be Israeli Capital
DOC.TEXT: The Senate has approved a resolution saying that an undivided Jerusalem should remain the capital of Israel. The Arab League on Friday denounced the resolution, which was viewed as a criticism of President Bush for saying that Jews should not settle in East Jerusalem. ``This irresponsible resolution forfeits any serious or constructive role the U.S. Senate can play in the search for a just peace in the Middle East,'' said Arab League Ambassador Clovis Maksoud, who represents the 22-member organization. The Senate measure, adopted on a unanimous voice vote late Thursday, has no legal status and simply expresses the sense of the Senate. It said senators acknowledge ``that Jerusalem is and should remain the capital of the state of Israel.'' Jerusalem is revered by the Arab world as one of Islam's holiest sites and the rightful capital of a Palestinian state. East Jerusalem is the section of the city seized by Israel in the 1967 Mideast war. Maksoud called the resolution a ``shocking development that demonstrates an incomprehensible and reckless defiance of the international community, the Arab and Moslem worlds and the declared policy of the United States.'' The United States and most other countries have not recognized Jerusalem as the Israeli capital, maintaining their embassies in Tel Aviv. U.S. policy states that while Jerusalem should not be divided again, as it was until 1967, the question of sovereignty over the holy city should be determined in Israeli-Arab negotiations. The Senate ``strongly believes that Jerusalem must remain an undivided city in which the rights of every ethnic religious groups are protected,'' the Senate measure states. Sen. Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., said the resolution ``represents a clear statement by the Senate that President Bush's statements on East Jerusalem were unwise and untimely.'' He said Bush's ``ambiguous statements about the status of Jerusalem'' are not helpful to the peace process. Responding to criticism, Bush has argued that he was merely stating existing policy when he made his remarks earlier this month. ``Our efforts in the peace process are in no way designed to promote the division of Jerusalem,'' Bush said in a letter to Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, D-Minn. Nonetheless, analysts have suggested that his comments about the sensitive issue of Jerusalem derailed attempts to bring Israel and the Palestinians to the negotiating table, at a crucial point in the process. Outrage in Israel over Bush's comments eventually led to last week's fall of the government led by right-wing Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir.

DOC.HEAD: CIA Employee Says Poindexter Withheld Information From Congress
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with National Security Agency aide's testimony, more Gardner testimony, subbing 7 grafs for last 4 grafs pvs; trial finished for the day
DOC.TEXT: A CIA employee testified Friday that John Poindexter left out important facts but didn't appear to be coveing up when he briefed Congress about a 1985 missile shipment to Iran. Testifying as a defense witness at Poindexter's trial, Norman Gardner described how Sen. David Durenberger ``charged right into'' Poindexter's office on Nov. 21, 1986, to be briefed about the Reagan administration's Iran initiative. Durenberger told Poindexter, ``John, if you're not going to give us all the facts, we're going to get the hell out of here,'' said Gardner who was at the meeting taking notes. At the time, Durenberger was vice chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee. ``To the best of your knowledge, was Admiral Poindexter involved'' in obstructing or lying to Congress about the missile shipment? defense attorney Joseph Small asked Gardner. ``No,'' replied Gardner. Poindexter is accused of covering up the U.S. role in the shipment of Hawk missiles by telling the Senate Intelligence Committee he didn't find out about it until January 1986. Poindexter told the House Intelligence Committee in a separate meeting on Nov. 21, 1986, that then-President Reagan did not approve the shipment. But Gardner knew a presidential document, called a finding, had been prepared that ratified the CIA-assisted shipment. And prosecutor Christian Mixter asked why Gardner didn't speak out at the meeting. The finding ``was not done before the shipment,'' but rather was drafted a day or so after it occurred, retorted Gardner. Hours after meeting with the senators and House members, Poindexter tore up the politically embarrassing document, which depicted U.S. arms sales to Iran as an arms-for-hostages deal _ a contradiction of what Reagan was saying publicly. Poindexter told the House committee the U.S. government may have had prior knowledge about the shipment. But prosecutor Mixter said as the Poindexter jury listened that there was ``not just knowledge, there was involvement'' by Poindexter. Gardner has told the FBI that he reviewed CIA cable traffic which said ``this operation is being conducted under instructions from Admiral Poindexter,'' said Mixter. ``I don't recall'' making those statements to the FBI, replied Gardner, who at one point called an FBI interview report about him ``totally inaccurate.'' The same day Poindexter briefed the congressmen, then-CIA Director William Casey testified on Capitol Hill that the CIA had been asked to assist a shipment of ``bulky cargo'' in November 1985. Casey gave no indication the CIA knew the cargo was weapons. Gardner reported Casey's testimony back to Poindexter. ``Did you tell Admiral Poindexter that the cover story wasn't holding up very well?'' Mixter asked Gardner. ``No, I didn't,'' Gardner responded. The CIA employee denied there was any cover story, saying there was ``a great deal of confusion'' when the CIA found out Hawk missiles were aboard the plane heading for Iran. A CIA proprietary airline moved the missiles from Israel to Iran. The National Security Agency's deputy director for plans and policy, Ralph W. Adams, also testified Friday. Congress had intelligence from the agency in November 1985 suggesting the U.S. government might be directing the Contras in Nicaragua, defense attorney Richard Beckler disclosed during Adams' testimony. Beckler's point was that at least a House Intelligence Committee staff member, Richard Giza, had extensive information about the Reagan administration's activities in Central America in 1985, during a congressional ban on U.S. military aid to the rebels. Poindexter is accused of concealing from Congress Oliver North's secret military assistance to the Contras.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Unite in Attack on Bush
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3 grafs for grafs 14-15, bgng: Brown called, to UPDATE with DNC executive committee vote on Moynihan, DELETES last graf pvs to tighten, ADDS 3 grafs rules actions.
DOC.TEXT: Democrats launched a boisterous attack Friday on President Bush's tax and foreign policies as they tried to present a united front from competing conferences 750 miles apart. In New Orleans, Sen. Lloyd Bentsen of Texas told the Democratic Leadership Council that Bush's no-new-taxes pledge was ``pure bushlips,'' accusing him of pushing ``crypto-taxes'' disguised as user fees and surcharges. ``How in the world do you read somebody's lips when they keep talking out of both sides of their mouth,'' Party Chairman Ronald H. Brown asked, sounding the same theme. He tried to downplay Bush's high ratings in the public opinion polls. ``It's time for us to point out that the Bush Administration has been getting a free ride _ that we hear a lot of sweet jargon but we don't see any action,'' he said. Brown was shuttling between New Orleans and Indianapolis, where the Democratic National Committee gathered for its spring meeting. In Indianapolis, he reminded party leaders about their electoral successes last year. ``I don't remember a single year in my lifetime where one party has been so dominant as we were in 1989,'' Brown said. He cited Democratic victories in the year's two gubernatorial races and in capturing the New Jersey state senate and winning six of the eight special elections for U.S. House seats. Brown also pledged that the party would become more aggressive in its opposition to Republicans from the White House on down the ticket. ``We're going to be fair, we're going to be accurate, but we're going to be tough,'' he said. Party leaders also criticized Bush for what they characterized as a timid foreign policy. Bentsen accused Bush of paying too much attention to public opinion polls and reacting too slowly to events in Central America, the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. ``Can you imagine Harry Truman hesitating to unveil the Truman Doctrine or the Marshall Plan or the Berlin airlift because of a public opinion poll?'' he said. ``Can you imagine John Kennedy doing a poll before dealing with the Cuban Missile Crisis?'' Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., echoed the criticism, saying ``precisely as our principles and values are prevailing throughout the world, America's trumpet is sounding an uncertain note.'' Bentsen and Brown parted company over a proposal by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., to cut the Social Security payroll tax. The DNC's executive committee endorsed the Moynihan proposal Friday and the full committee was certain to follow up when it meets on Saturday and make it party policy. ``This is the right thing to do and the right time to do it,'' said John Marino, New York Democratic Party chairman. ``We have to say to middle class Americans that we care about you.'' Brown said he was encountering strong support for the Moynihan plan wherever he travels. But Bentsen, who chairs the Senate Finance Committee, said he opposes the plan because it would mean the loss of $50 billion in revenue. ``My concern is that I don't want to see us get into a bidding war with the Republicans,'' Bentsen said. ``We can't win that one because they don't care how far they go insofar as increasing that deficit by cutting of taxes.'' Brown denied that his difference with Bentsen was a sign of an unbreachable division within the party, whose more conservative wing is represented by those in New Orleans. ``Just because we don't have every `i' dotted and every `t' crossed doesn't mean we are not unified,'' Brown said. ``We're having an open and honest discussion about very complicated matters.'' Party officials in Indianapolis also moved a step closer to adopting the final rules for selecting delegates to the 1992 Democratic National Convention. Endorsed was a proposal to permit states to hold primaries or caucuses starting the first Tuesday in March and ending the second Tuesday in June. The starting date would be one week earlier than it was in 1988. Also backed was a plan to strip states of up to 25 percent of their delegates if they fail to comply with party rules. Brown said that proposal would permit the party to exert reasonable pressure on states rather than be faced with a choice of unseating entire delegations or ignoring rules violations.

DOC.HEAD: Civil Rights Leader Hospitalized
DOC.TEXT: Civil rights leader Ralph David Abernathy remained hospitalized in fair condition Friday for a sodium imbalance, but was ``not in great danger,'' his physician said. Abernathy was brought to Crawford Long Hospital of Emory University Thursday night after his wife reported that he ``wasn't his usual self,'' said Dr. Robert Kaufmann, Abernathy's physician. He was ``somewhat lethargic, and not as alert as he usually is,'' Kaufmann said. Abernathy was diagnosed with hyponatremia _ an electrolytic imbalance, or low sodium count, in his bloodstream. The sodium deficiency was probably triggered by nausea Abernathy suffered two days earlier, coupled with diuretics he takes for high blood pressure, Kaufmann said. A sodium imbalance can be life threatening, but Abernathy is responding to fluids treatment, Kaufmann said. ``I don't think he's in great danger at this point,'' the doctor said, adding that Abernathy was alert Friday morning, asking, ``How'm I doing?'' A possible complication of sodium imbalance is arrythmia, or an irregular heartbeat, and Abernathy is being monitored in the hospital's cardiac care unit. However, he is not suffering from heart trouble. The 63-year-old minister and civil rights leader could be hospitalized a week or so, depending on how he responds to treatment, Kaufmann said. Abernathy, pastor Atlanta's West Hunter Street Baptist Church, has a recent history of health problems, including strokes in 1983 and 1986. He had been hospitalized recently, but Kaufmann declined to say what prompted that hospitalization. Abernathy worked with Martin Luther King Jr. during the early years of the civil rights movement, but his relationship with many former colleagues has been strained in recent years. He angered many of them last year when his autobiography, ``And The Walls Came Tumbling Down,'' suggested that King committed adultery the night before he was assassinated. A Memphis, Tenn., woman last month sued Abernathy for libel over the passage.

DOC.HEAD: $100 Million in Mental Health Funds Squandered, Consumer Group Contends
DOC.TEXT: A federal program to provide community mental health services to the poor and uninsured is an ``abysmal failure'' because up to $100 million was squandered building for-profit hospitals with swimming pools and tennis courts, a consumer group charged Friday. Half of 575 community mental health centers funded under the program are violating federal regulations that require them to be non-profit, to provide certain essential services and to make some services available to the poor, Public Citizen Health Research Group said. ``One of the most visible consequences of the failed program has been a significant increase in the number of seriously mentally ill homeless and an increase in the number of mentally ill persons in jails and prisons,'' the group's report said. ``The Community Mental Health Centers program has been an abysmal failure,'' the report said. A report by the House Government Operations subcommittee on human resources and intergovernmental relations chaired by Rep. Ted Weiss, D-N.Y., said its investigation has revealed the same kinds of violations. Weiss called for a General Accounting Office investigation to determine the extent of the problem. And the inspector general of the Department of Health and Human Services is beginning an investigation of the matter, in response to a request by HHS Undersecretary Constance Horner, a spokeswoman for the inspector general said. Alan Leshner, deputy director of the National Institute of Mental Health, said officials are aware of problems with the program and 10 months ago began to identify centers out of compliance and to seek recoveries. Asked if he were aware of any fraud or abuse, Leshner said, ``I don't know of it and if we do know of it, we will correct it ... That doesn't mean that there aren't centers that are out of compliance, but I don't see any fraud and abuse.'' Public Citizen said that between $50 million and $100 million is owed the federal government by mental health centers that received federal construction grants under the program and are out of compliance. It based the estimate on reports of inspections of 158 centers in the program. The inspections were conducted by a company under contract to NIMH and were obtained by Public Citizen and the National Alliance for the Mentally Ill. Some 575 community mental health centers have received grants under the program since it began in 1967. So far, NIMH has recovered only $3.8 million from 10 of those that received grants but were found to be out of compliance, Public Citizen said. All of this was collected from 1983-86, when Paul Curtis was headed the program at NIMH, the group said. In a statement included in Public Citizen's report, Curtis said that while he found many of the hospitals out of compliance, he was ``actively discouraged from seeking recoveries'' by his superiors at NIMH. Curtis retired in 1986. Grants under the program require a community mental health center to provide five essential services to the mentally ill for at least 20 years, and require that they provide a ``reasonable volume of services'' to the poor. The required services are inpatient, outpatient, partial hospitalization, emergency services and consultation and education. As an example of centers the group contends are seriously out of compliance, Public Citizen cited the Orlando Regional Medical Center in Florida, which received $731,912 in 1967. With some of those funds, ``it built a swimming pool and tennis courts ... hired a gardner, lifeguard and swimming instructor,'' Public Citizen's report said. DePaul Hospital in New Orleans, which received $475,484 in construction funds and opened in 1972, was sold to a for-profit company the next year, the group said. Leshner attributed some of the problems with the 23-year-old program to the philosophy of the program's leaders during previous administrations. ``The previous philosophy was that it's better to provide some service than to shut down a mental health center and have all the money go into the Treasury and not be used for mental health,'' he said. ``Perhaps too much was done to get noncompliance centers into compliance,'' he said. ``At some point, you have to say, `OK, this isn't going to work. We have to get the recovery.''' NIMH was alerted to the problems by the inspection contractor, Continuing Medical Education Inc., and began an audit 10 months ago. The audit found ``no major problems but some procedural changes were called for, and a number of them were put in place,'' Leshner said. The institute also compiled a list of 33 centers in the program that had been identified as having compliance problems. NIMH staff will visit all of those centers by June, Leshner said. The institute also will visit by Sept. 30 the 72 centers that have received waivers of the requirements during the past two years, he said. Leshner said he could not estimate the amount of money NIMH will seek from the centers that are out of compliance.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Decries Obscene Art, Federal Efforts to Control It
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This stands for AM-Bush Rdp, promised on the News Advisory
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Friday he is ``deeply offended by some of the filth'' that passes for art and receives federal grants, but that he's not about to propose government censorship. ``I don't know of anybody in the government ... that should be set up to censor what you write, or what you paint, or how you express yourself,'' Bush said. The president made the comments at a question-and-answer session in the White House with out-of-town editors and reporters. He was asked about his administration's opposition to placing restrictions on financing from the National Endowment for the Arts for controversial art. The administration's position was outlined earlier this week by NEA Chairman John Frohnmayer at a congressional hearing. The agency has come under mounting criticism from Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., and other conservatives who claim it is ignoring a congressional ban, imposed for this fiscal year, on financing obscene art. Some critics have proposed legislation to place even more stringent restrictions on federal arts financing, but Frohnmayer said the White House opposes extending such restrictions into the next fiscal year. Bush supported Frohnmayer and said he opposes any efforts to write art standards into law. ``I am deeply offended by some of the filth that I see and to which federal money has gone; and by some of the sacrilegious, blasphemous depictions that are portrayed by some to be art,'' Bush said. But he said that while he will ``speak strongly out'' against such art, ``I would prefer to have this matter handled by a very sensitive, knowledgeable man of the arts, John Frohnmayer, than risk censorship or getting the federal government into telling every artist what he or she can paint. ...'' ``So I am against censorship, but I will try to convince those who feel differently in terms of legislation that we will do everything in our power to stop pure blasphemy.'' Bush said ``two horrendous examples'' came to mind ``of what I would call blasphemous material that has no business getting one cent of the taxpayers' money.'' But, he added, ``I don't want to offend the American people'' by describing those particular works. Bush engaged in a wide-ranging exchange with the reporters and editors, in which he also: _Said that any attempt by the Soviet Union to use force to put down Lithuania's bid for independence was ``bound to backfire.'' He also reiterated his criticism of Congress for not moving faster on his $800 million aid package for Panama and Nicaragua. _Said that, despite progress on the human-rights front in South Africa, it was still not time ``to change the policy'' of U.S. economic sanctions on Pretoria. He suggested that he first wants a chance to meet with South African President F.W. deKlerk and black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela. Both have been invited, separately, to the White House but dates have yet to be set. _Defended spending money to aid new democracies instead of putting more into domestic programs, saying it was important to ``help create stable democracies that will actively trade with the United States.'' _Declared himself opposed to statehood for the District of Columbia. ``This is a federal city and my view is it should remain that,'' he said. ``Put me down as unsympathetic to that particular cause.''

DOC.HEAD: Construction Site Collapse Kills Two
DOC.TEXT: A 100-foot-long wall being erected atop a warehouse toppled onto an adjoining roof Friday, smashing through in an avalanche of debris that killed two people and critically injured two others, officials said. Ten other people suffered less serious injuries in the collapse at the Century 21 Department Stores warehouse in Brooklyn. The dead and injured included construction workers and employees in the building below. ``I just heard the big noise. It sounded like a building falling,'' Fannie DeBlasio, a neighbor, said of the 9:15 a.m. accident. ``I looked out the window and saw people running.'' Workers were adding a second floor to the one-story warehouse when the new wall _ a foot thick, 14 feet high and 100 feet long _ fell on an adjoining one-story building, also owned by Century 21, officials said. The debris smashed a 30-by-30-foot hole through the roof of the second building, killing a woman working inside, rescuers said. A construction worker also was killed. The Buildings Department had approved construction plans and issued permits for work at the site, but apparently only for a ground-floor extension, not a second-floor addition, said spokesman Vahe Tiryakian. ``They had a permit. But it appears the permit did not include permission to do the work they were doing,'' Tiryakian said. The department was investigating, he said. The permit was issued to a Vortex Contracting Corp. in Queens, Tiryakian said. There was no telephone listing for a Vortex in Queens; officials at a Vortex listed in Brooklyn did not return a telephone call. The city ordered the contractor to shore up another wall it had built atop the 100-by-100 foot warehouse, then to stop work while an engineer determined what caused the accident. Century 21 closed its main outlet for the day. An official at a Manhattan branch, Alex Esarco, said he had no information and was waiting for company officials to return from the site. Some of the injured were trapped initially, but police said all were removed within an hour. Police identified those killed as Luz Serrano, 47, of Brooklyn, who was dead at the scene, and Sean Campbell, 33, a construction worker from the Bronx, pronounced dead at Victory Memorial Hospital. A 28-year-old construction worker and a 20-year-old Century 21 employee were admitted to Lutheran Medical Center in critical condition, said spokesman Robert Walsh. One was in stable condition, the other ``alert'' but more seriously hurt, he said. Another man was admitted to Victory with broken ribs, and two men were treated there for inhaling fumes, and then released, said spokeswoman Angela Canade. The Emergency Medical Service treated seven people at the scene.

DOC.HEAD: Mullins Promises He's His Own Man
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A longer version is on financial circuits
DOC.TEXT: A Treasury Department official nominated to the Federal Reserve Board promised Friday that he would exercise independent judgment rather than serve as an agent of the administration's push to lower interest rates. ``If confirmed I pledge ... I will exercise my independent judgment on matters before the board,'' David W. Mullins Jr. told the Senate Banking Committee. Mullins, 43, is assistant Treasury secretary and one of the architects of President Bush's savings and loan bailout. He has been a professor at the Harvard Business School. President Bush nominated him in November to serve the remaining six years in the term of H. Robert Heller, who resigned. The committee also reviewed the nomination of Edward Kelley Jr., 58, a Fed board member for the past three years, to a new 14-year term. Sen. Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich., chairman of the committee, and Sen. Paul Sarbanes, D-Md., said they worried that Mullins was being appointed to do the administration's bidding at the central bank, which sets the nation's monetary policy and controls short-term interest rates. ``I certainly hope you're going as your own man, with absolute independence of mind and thought,'' Riegle said. Mullins said he would ``seek counsel from all quarters'' but make his own decisions. Sarbanes noted that Mullins had been interviewed by Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, Budget Director Richard Darman, White House Chief of Staff John Sununu and White House economic adviser Michael Boskin. ``I think you're being nominated because you're pretty much on the same wave length as the people who interviewed you,'' he said. Administration officials, from the president down, have periodically criticized the Fed for being overly worried about inflation and keeping interest rates too high. A recent published report quoted an unidentified Bush adviser as saying the president was ``mad as hell'' not inclined to reappoint Alan Greenspan when his term as Fed chairman expires next year. Mullins said he believed accounts of a rift between the administration and the Fed were exaggerated, adding, ``It is not unusual for the president to call for lower interest rates.'' However, he said there was ``no compelling evidence'' that the Fed's current policy of relatively high interest rates is unsound. On other topics, Mullins: _Called for reform of the ``too-big-to-fail doctrine'' in which regulators bail out all depositors of failing big banks, even over the $100,000 insurance limit. He said the Drexel Burnham failure proves that big financial firms can fail without threatening the financial system. _Said he did not believe the central bank should try to improve the U.S. trade deficit by managing the value of the dollar in currency markets. Central bank intervention is appropriate only to steady markets or if the value of the dollar has deviated ``from economic fundamentals.'' _Defended the administration's S&L bailout, saying the major reason for the slow start was ``the massive complexity of the task'' rather than any flaw in last summer's legislation. Riegle said he would support Mullins' nomination.

DOC.HEAD: Carter Finds Calmer Middle East, But Mum on Hostage Talks
With AM-Soviet Jews
DOC.TEXT: Former President Jimmy Carter found a calmer Middle East on his latest fact-finding mission, but a solution to the hostage issue ``is not around the corner,'' according to a Middle East expert who accompanied him. Kenneth Stein, who advised the ex-president on his tour of Egypt, Syria, Jordan, the West Bank and Israel this month, also said that recent Jewish immigration from the Soviet Union had aroused rancor from Arab countries. During his tour, Carter had private conversations with several heads of state about the 18 Western hostages believed held by Shiite Moslem groups in Lebanon, but Stein would not divulge the content of the talks. Carter will meet with Bush administration officials and members of Congress Tuesday to discuss ``sensitive issues'' of his trip and may reveal further details after that, Stein said. Stein said Carter denied reports Friday that he had any communication about the hostages from Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, the reputed spiritual leader of the Iranian-backed Hezbollah group. The weekly magazine Ash-Shiraa in Beirut reported the same day that Fadlallah had responded through an intermediary to questions Carter had posed about the issue, but Carter, in Hawaii, said he had asked no questions, Stein said. Ash-Shiraa gained international recognition in 1987 for breaking the story that the Reagan administration was trading arms for U.S. hostages. However, its frequent reports that a hostage release was imminent have not proven accurate. Stein said Carter had no reaction to Fadlallah, Lebanon's most influential Shiite Moslem cleric, stating that ``a new situation has emerged'' with regard to the possibility of a hostage release. But Stein said Carter was encouraged when during his trip to Syria, that country's foreign minister, Farouk al-Sharaa, said he ``saw no reason to be pessimistic'' about progress toward the hostages' freedom. ``He has since gone to Tehran to urge them to continue to be flexible,'' Stein said. ``I don't think the Syrian foreign minister would make a statement like that unless there was some progress. ... But a solution is not around the corner.'' The United States should be encouraged also that Syrian President Hafez al-Assad is ``bolstering'' the Middle East peace process, Stein said. Syria will announce next month that it is sending an ambassador to Washington and has said it will help negotiate a settlement in Lebanon's civil war. ``These are all signals, noises Washington wants to hear,'' Stein said, but he added that Assad's support of state-sponsored terrorism is still questionable. Stein, an Emory University Middle East expert who accompanied Carter on two previous trips to the region, also said he was surprised that the immigration of Soviet Jews has set Arab nations in turmoil. ``I didn't know how upset they'd be,'' he said. ``Jordan is beside herself at the prospect, the real belief, that these Russian-Jewish immigrants will settle in the West Bank and will drive out the Palestinians. ``In Egypt, Syria and Jordan there are certain voices ... who believe there is a conspiracy between Moscow and Washington with Moscow providing the bodies and Washington providing the money, and doing it intentionally to hurt the Arabs. I was really surprised at that.'' The Carter Presidential Center will use information gleaned from the trip when it hosts an international forum in November to discuss economic means to promote further peace, Stein said.

DOC.HEAD: Psychiatric Hospital Weans Youths Away From Satanism
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf after 5th to CLARIFY treatment status for `Mike'; PsychHealth, 12th graf, cq
DOC.TEXT: At his parents' home, Mike painted his room black, decorated it with black candles and an altar, and put up obituaries and Satanic symbols on the walls. He began driving recklessly, drinking heavily, experimenting with marijuana and threatening his parents. That's when Mike ended up in one of the nation's first treatment programs aimed at weaning disturbed teen-agers from Satanism. ``At the time, Satanism seemed to have, for Mike, a lot of answers that he couldn't find elsewhere,'' said Michael Weiss, a psychologist who specializes in treating adolescents. ``It gave him the sense that he could control all things.'' ``Now that he can find other ways to feel good and have some sense of purpose ... he seems increasingly willing to put aside any Satanic influence,'' said Weiss, of Hartgrove Hospital on Chicago's North Side. ``He successfully went through the in-patient program and at this point is continuing in treatment on an outpatient basis with individual therapy and also some family therapy. To date no major crises and no return to any satanic involvement, that we're aware of at least.'' Mike _ not his real name _ is among about a half dozen youths, ranging from ages 14 to 17, who've received treatment or are undergoing therapy at Hartgrove's Center for the Treatment of Ritualistic Deviance. The center, attached to the hospital's adolescent unit, began receiving patients in October. The in-patient program lasts four to eight weeks, and involves individual as well as group therapy. Most patients are admitted voluntarily based on referrals from mental health workers, police and parents. Weiss said it's still too early to determine the success rate. ``We didn't know what to expect ... but I'm pleased with the way things are right now,'' he said. ``We're certainly finding that we can work with these kids and their families.'' A similar program exists at Denver's Bethesda PsychHealth System. And Hartgrove has received inquiries from hospitals in Texas, Virginia and Wisconsin interested in starting their own Satanism treatment programs, said social worker Dale Trahan. ``I definitely see the problem as growing,'' said Trahan, who's been researching satanic beliefs for three years and was contracted to set up Hartgrove's center. ``The factors that seem to be adding to a growth of the occult don't seem to be going away _ a breakdown in family, an abandonment of traditional values, resistance towards traditional religious beliefs, and an increasing number of youths who feel both alienated and powerless over their lives and future,'' Trahan said. ``So many kids are feeling like they're ... not going to get their needs met using traditional means so they're looking for alternatives ... and there are many destructive alternatives'' such as street gangs, neo-Nazi groups, drugs and Satanism, Trahan said. There has been a marked increase in the number of young people involved in Satanism, said Cynthia Kisser, executive director of the Chicago-based Cult Awareness Network, a non-profit organization that has 30 volunteer chapters around the country. Two years ago, the network got only one or two calls a month regarding Satanism. Now, there are as many as 300 a month, Ms. Kisser said. Weiss cautions that just because parents find that a teen-ager is into heavy metal music or wearing Satanic symbols, it doesn't mean he's a candidate for Hartgrove's program. ``Kids are admitted because they are having emotional or behavioral problems ... coupled with involvement in occult and Satanic beliefs,'' he said. Some warning signs include a sudden drop in school grades, withdrawal from the family, increasing drug or alcohol use and increasingly aggressive behavior, Trahan said. Satanic beliefs often can make traditional treatment approaches unsuccessful because a teen-ager can use the occult as a defensive mechanism, Weiss said.
