Trahan said staff members are advised not to react with shock or fear to Satanic beliefs because this would only encourage the patient to believe in the power of the occult. About 35 to 40 hospital staff members _ psychiatrists and psychologists, physical and recreational therapists, social workers, teachers and nurses _ are involved in the program and have received special training. Trahan said the program doesn't have anything in common with deprogramming _ the radical therapy used to break some youths away from cults that use psychological manipulation to gain members. ``We help them identify constructive alternatives. That's not brainwashing,'' Trahan said. Said Weiss: ``Our overall goal is to have a kid walk out of here who is going to be able to adapt to the world and live a reasonable, safe and sane life.''

DOC.HEAD: Mystery Illness Spreads in Kosovo; Tests Find No Poison
DOC.TEXT: A mysterious illness that has felled hundreds of children in ethnically divided Kosovo province appeared to be spreading there Friday, Tanjug news agency reported. It said tests uncovered no poison. In violence arising from the incident, Slavs were reported to have been beaten by ethnic Albanians Friday in Vucitrn, about 18 miles northwest of Pristina, and at least 10 were hospitalized, Radio Belgrade reported. On Friday morning, police moved into the streets of Vucitrn, filled with demonstrators, to regain control. Representatives of the ethnic Albanian opposition in Kosovo disputed the official Tanjug report, claiming the medical team involved was not impartial. The affliction causes breathing difficulties and eye and stomach pains. The report said nothing about what might have caused symptoms. Opposition leaders earlier claimed an unidentified chemical was poured or sprayed into classrooms, leading to poisoning of teen-age students in several Kosovo towns. But Belgrade medical experts said blood, urine and gastric juice tests revealed no poisoning. Hundreds of children were hospitalized in Pristina, Kosovo's capital, on Thursday. Most were released on Friday when 240 more patients, mostly teen-agers, were admitted with similar complaints, Tanjug said. An official medical team, set up by the Federal Ministry for Health, in cooperation with Serbia's Health Ministry and Pristina's Medical Faculty, said 18 people were admitted to the hospital in Pristina from Monday through Wednesday, complaining of weakness, breathing difficulty, chest pains, dry mouth and fainting. On Thursday, 352 more people, mostly aged 16-18, were hospitalized with the same symptoms, the official report said. Clinical examinations established redness on the cheeks and a mild swelling of the ears, while in a smaller number of patients, conjunctivitis, an eye infection, was also found, Tanjug said, quoting the official medical bulletin. The skin redness disappeared after an hour and special treatment was not needed, the release said. Medical experts also took blood, urine and gastric juice samples for toxicological examination at the Military Medical Academy in Belgrade, the best-equipped hospital in eastern Yugoslavia. Initial results of the analyses do not indicate ``the presence of poisonous substances,'' Tanjug reported. The medical team said that overall, no signs emerged of an epidemic involving an infectious disease or of poisoning. But representatives of Kosovo's democratic opposition, asked for comment by The Associated Press, criticized the medical team's report. Academician Rexhep Qosja of the Albanological Institute of Pristina said the finding was ``not sufficiently clear.'' Ibrahim Rugova, a historian and author, said, ``I doubt the finding since it was not reached by a neutral commission.'' He said the commission representing a federal ministry was not neutral enough and alleged ``manipulation.'' Most of the original patients were expected to be released by weekend, officials said. In clashes with security forces the last 13 months, at least 60 people have been killed as ethnic Albanians were protesting constitutional changes that gave Serbia close control over Kosovo. Serbian leaders contend the changes were necessary to protect minority Slavs from virtual daily harassment by ethnic Albanians.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Abortion Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of measures to restrict abortion laws in the United States following last summer's U.S. Supreme Court ruling in Missouri's Webster case, which gave states more authority to restrict abortions: _The Idaho Legislature on Thursday approved a law that would make abortion illegal except in cases of non-statutory rape reported within seven days, incest if the victim is younger than 18, severe fetal deformity or a threat to the mother's life or physical health. The law is now under consideration by Gov. Cecil Andrus. _In Guam, a new law prohibits abortions except when a pregnancy endangers the life of the mother. Among other things, it makes it a felony to perform abortion or aid in the procedure, a misdemeanor for a woman to solicit or have an abortion and a misdemeanor for a person to solicit a woman to have an abortion. A judge on Friday issued a temporary restraining order on enforcing the law, which is more restrictive than the bill passed by the Idaho Legislature. _In Maryland, the Senate passed an abortion rights bill on Friday permitting unrestricted abortions during the early stages of pregnancy. It will become law unless it is petitioned to referendum and rejected by voters in November. If it is rejected, then a bill sponsored by anti-abortion senators will become law _ unless it also is defeated by voters. Under that bill, abortions could be performed in cases of rape or incest, to protect the mother's life or if the pregnancy would produce serious and adverse effects on the woman's health. _In South Carolina, lawmakers approved legislation that requires minors to get permission from a parent or a judge before having an abortion. Parents who deny a daughter's request for an abortion would have share legal and financial responsibility for her child until the young mother turns 18. _In Pennsylvania, the governor in December signed a bill that requires married women to notify husbands about abortion plans. The law also bans abortions after the 24th week of pregnancy and compels women to wait 24 hours after learning of their pregnancy before getting an abortion.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Hazelwood Sentenced to Clean Up Prince William Sound
DOC.TEXT: A judge, denouncing the ``shame'' that Joseph Hazelwood brought upon himself in the Exxon Valdez disaster, sentenced the skipper to help clean up the beaches of Prince William Sound and said he must pay $50,000 in restitution to the state. Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone, in sentencing Hazelwood to 1,000 hours of community service in the clean-up, said he was disappointed that Hazelwood had not publicly apologized for his role in the grounding of his tanker. He said he felt Hazelwood was wrong to drink before he boarded his ship and believed he violated at least some Coast Guard regulations. The judge, who presided over the fired skipper's seven-week trial, also gave Hazelwood 90 days in jail and a $1,000 fine, the maximum under his misdemeanor conviction, but suspended both. ``I'm sure deep down he is very shameful,'' the judge said of Hazelwood. A 12-member jury found Hazelwood guilty Thursday of a misdemeanor charge of negligent discharge of oil into state waters.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Airline Stops Selling Budapest Tickets To Jewish Immigrants
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 4th `Soviet TV...' with new Israeli reax; pickup graf 5 pvs `Budapest, the...' ^By SERGEI SHARGORODSKY
DOC.TEXT: The national airline Aeroflot closed one of the main routes for Jews emigrating to Israel, halting ticket sales to Budapest on Friday, and denied it had opened another one through Egypt, Soviet media reported. The closure followed a decision by Hungary's Malev airline to stop flights of Soviet Jews to Tel Aviv via Budapest because of the threat of terrorist attacks. Israeli officials denounced it as a ``classic example of terrorist blackmail.'' On Thursday, Malev appealed to Aeroflot to stop bringing Jewish emigres into Hungary. Soviet TV said Aeroflot would not sell tickets to emigrants wanting to travel to Budapest from Moscow, Leningrad and the Ukrainian capital of Kiev. It said it would still transport businessmen and tourists. Malev also will continue selling tickets to tourists. Foreign Minister Moshe Arens said on Israel TV late Friday that the Hungarian move surprised him. He said the state-run Hungarian airline was ``surrendering to terror.'' Arens said he had been unable to speak to Hungary's foreign minister, but that if the reports are true, he will ask Hungary to reverse the decision. Budapest, the Romanian capital of Bucharest and several other European cities have become the transit points for Soviet Jews using Aeroflot. No figures have been available on how many Soviet Jews have used those routes. Malev began transporting the immigrants last year following Hungary's resumption of diplomatic ties with Israel. Hungarian officials said they cut off ticket sales to emigrants because of threats from Palestinian extremists. The pro-Iranian Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine has threatened airlines of all countries involved in transportation of Soviet Jewish immigrants to Israel. Immigration activists expressed their disappointment with Hungary's decision, demanding that authorities open as many routes as possible. Palestinian and Arab leaders view the immigration of Soviet Jews to Israel as a grave threat and have launched an unprecedented anti-immigration campaign. Their concern is based on statements by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir suggesting Israel needed to retain the occupied territories to settle Soviet Jews. Israel last month imposed censorship on immigration figures, routes of exit and the projected number of immigrants, citing a danger of attacks by Palestinian extremists. Israeli media also quoted security sources as saying Israel has beefed up security for immigrants. According to official Israeli figures, about 16,700 Soviet Jews emigrated to Israel from Jan. 1, 1989, to Feb. 1, 1990. They joined about 180,000 of their brethren who have come to the country since 1967. Israeli officials say they expect 750,000 Soviet Jews to arrive in the next decade as the result of the Soviet Union's more liberal emigration policies and stricter U.S. entrance requirements. About 200 new immigrants have joined 70,000 Jews who live in the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip, home to about 1.7 million Palestinians and the scene of the 27-month uprising against Israeli rule. Israel says it has no policy of directing immigrants to the territories, which it captured from Jordan and Egypt in the 1967 Middle East War. Transportation problems and the difficulties in obtaining tickets to European destinations prompted suggestions some immigrants may be coming to Israel via Cairo. Egypt is the only Arab country at peace with Israel. The deputy head of Aeroflot's Cairo office, A. Ananyin, told the newspaper Trud on Tuesday that the company has added a second flight each week to Cairo. He said there would be one additional flight every two weeks in March and then more frequently. But Ananyin denied Aeroflot carried any emigrants to Egypt. ``We meet and see off every flight, and I can state with full responsibility that no emigrant has so far traveled to Israel via Cairo.'' He said the flights were carrying some Soviet Jews who traveled to Israel for short-term family visits. He justified the additional flight by citing an increase in tourism and business traffic. Trud, published by the Soviet labor unions, said official Soviet figures indicated a threefold increase in Soviet tourism in Egypt and said the number of businessmen traveling there has recently doubled. Soviet First Deputy Foreign Minister Yuli Vorontsov said Aeroflot had no plans to make direct flights to Israel, the government newspaper Izvestia said. Last year, Aeroflot concluded an agreement with Israel's El Al airline on direct flights, but Soviet authorities have refused to ratify it, citing Shamir's ideas on the settlement of Soviet Jews in the occupied territories. Vorontsov dismissed Arab demands that Jewish emigration be stopped completely, saying that the Soviet emigration policy and its expected further liberalization ``conform with international standards.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says U.S. Taking New Look At California Shipping Lanes
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Friday his administration is taking a ``whole new look'' at the possibility of shifting shipping lanes off the coast of California to get oil tankers farther away from beaches. But spokesmen for the departments Bush said were dealing with the matter were caught by surprise by the president's statement, made at a White House gathering with out-of-town newspaper editors, and said they knew of no new study other than Coast Guard efforts to revise complex shipping rules proposed a year ago. Bush's assertion followed a proposal on Thursday from an environmental group that a 25-mile-wide ``vessel-free zone'' be established along the central California coast to lessen the damage from crude oil tanker spills. A study by the Natural Resources Defense Council said a buffer that keeps oil tankers away from the shore would allow additional response time for cleanup teams before oil hits the beaches. Bush said the Coast Guard, the Environmental Protection Agency and the Transportation and Energy departments were trying to take ``a whole new look ... as to shipping lanes, to see what is the best _ whether there is a way to shift the shipping lanes to avert proximity to the beaches as much as possible.'' The president said it would not be possible to deny oil tankers access to the California coast because the oil is needed. ``The answer is: Make it as safe as possible,'' he said. Bush said the federal agencies are cooperating with California environmental authorities on the issue. ``But if you're saying to me, `Can the federal government guarantee that no tanker will ever again have a leak or spill oil?' no, I can't do that,'' Bush said. ``But we can go the extra mile in terms of environmental protection, safeguarding the sea lanes and all of that.'' A Coast Guard spokesman, Cmdr. John McElwain, said 299 letters were received on a proposed rule last April to set sea lanes off portions of the California coast, and ``289 didn't like the proposals.'' Public hearings in California also brought mostly criticism, he said. McElwain said the agency is now awaiting the results of an environmental study of the impact of shipping lanes on wildlife before proposing a new rule. The spokesman said, however, that he was not aware of a specific study on setting shipping channels farther from shore. Currently, only limited sea lanes are defined and ships rely on ``rules of prudent seamanship'' along most of the coast, McElwain said. Transportation Department spokesman Bob Marx and Energy Department spokesman Phillip Keif said they were not aware of a new study on the matter. A call to the EPA's public affairs office was not returned before the office closed on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Says Moscow Unlikely to Use Force
With AM-Lithuania
DOC.TEXT: Despite escalating tensions, a Lithuanian independence leader said Friday he still believes Moscow will avoid force and eventually negotiate with the breakaway republic. Lithuania on Friday accused Moscow of waging psychological warfare to force the republic to renounce its declaration of independence on March 11. The Kremlin has moved troops in a show of force, confiscated weapons, called for abolishing local defense units, and demanded that Lithuanian deserters return to the Soviet military. ``I think this absurdity is a duel of David and Goliath that is understandable for the whole world and in the end Moscow, sooner or later, will agree on negotiations,'' said Virgilijus Cepaitis, a deputy in the Lithuanian parliament and secretary general of the Sajudis independence movement. Asked at a news conference if he thought Moscow would abide by public declarations it would not to use force, Cepaitis replied, ``Yes, I believe in this.'' Deputies attending a regular session of Poland's parliament gave Cepaitis and another Lithuanian leader a standing ovation when they entered the legislature's main chamber. Cepjaitis' colleague was Kaziemeras Motieka, vice president of the Lithuanian Supreme Council. The pair also reported on the standoff between Moscow and Lithuania to members of the Solidarity delegation of the Polish parliament. The Lithuanians were given a copy of a declaration passed by the Polish parliament Thursday welcoming the Baltic republic to the family of free nations. The Lithuanian cause has won great sympathy among the Polish, who have long historial ties with Lithuania. More than 100 students on Friday demonstrated in Warsaw to support the Lithuanians.

DOC.HEAD: Romania Backtracks on Accusations against Hungary
DOC.TEXT: Romania retracted on Friday accusations made by authorities that Hungary fueled ethnic tensions that led to deadly riots in Transylvania. And strikes that nearly paralyzed this ethnically split Transylvanian town all week ended Friday as government emissaries replaced both the city and Mures county leaderships, which had been accused of failing to prevent this week's clashes between Romanians and ethnic Hungarians. The government issued a statement denying accusations made Wednesday after Premier Petre Roman met in Bucharest, the capital, with representatives of Mures and other areas affected by the unrest. ``It is not true that ... citizens from Hungary incited the ethnic Hungarians to violence,'' said the statement read on evening television news. It also said the government was dissociating itself from ``charges being brought against'' ethnic Hungarians that they want to secede from Romania. ``The government will call to account all those who disseminate lies,'' the declaration said, adding that the Ministry of Education will act immediately to ensure that the Hungarian language is introduced in schools in Transylvania, where most of the 2 million ethnic Hungarians live. In a TV interview broadcast late Friday, however, Roman blasted Hungarian Foreign Minister Gyula Horn for criticizing the conduct of Romanian authorities during the violence in Tirgu Mures, where seven people died and 300 were hurt. Tirgu Mures, where riots peaked Tuesday night, was calm Friday after a commission of inquiry agreed that the Hungarian minority has a right to education in their native tongue, an issue that contributed to the clashes. Life appeared to have returned to normal and industrial enterprises were reported to be operating again. Elementary schools were closed because of fears of renewed violence, Rompres news agency reported. Shops reopened and city buses, the target of attacks earlier this week, were back on the streets. But tension still ran high in the outlying villages of Mures province, where youths armed with sticks roamed the countryside. ``I still don't dare to drive out into the (nearby) Hungarian villages,'' said municipal bus driver Constantin Buciu. Mountainous Transylvania has about 2 million ethnic Hungarians and about 5 million Romanians. Hungary ruled the region for hundreds of years until the end of World War I when Transylvania was ceded to Romania by the victorious Allied powers. Some Romanians accuse ethnic Hungarians of trying to separate the region from Romania in order to rejoin Hungary. Hungarians deny that they harbor separatist sentiments and say they only want cultural and other ethnic rights. They, along with other national minorities, were oppressed under longtime Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, who was ousted and executed in December.

DOC.HEAD: Search Called Off for Nine Missing From Sunken Fishing Trawler
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with fishing vessels suspending search, quote from executive; Coast Guard hearing set for Saturday; picks up 9th graf, `The Seattle-based ...; INSERTS 1 graf after 15th, `From there ..., to UPDATE with no records of ship in Coast Guard and OSHA files.
DOC.HEAD: LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: The Coast Guard on Friday suspended its search for the bodies of nine men presumed drowned after their fishing trawler capsized and sank in the frigid Bering Sea. Fishing vessels rescued 22 crew members who had abandoned the sinking ship on life boats. They were reported in good condition aboard a trawler that was taking them to Dutch Harbor, about 250 miles southeast of the accident site. The nine, including a federal fisheries observer, were lost Thursday when the 162-foot Aleutian Enterprise sank, according to the Coast Guard, which said there was little chance their bodies would be found. ``We had a very good search yesterday,'' Lt. Brian Flory said Friday in Juneau. ``We think we would have found anyone who was afloat.'' Several fishing vessels remained in the area to look for bodies Friday, but they also gave up, said Dan Roberts, executive vice president of Arctic Alaska Fisheries Corp. in Seattle, whic'' Haley said. The Coast Guard will convene a formal board of investigation into the accident at noon Saturday in Anchorage, Haley said. Roberts said some survivors and company officials would attend, weather permitting. The Seattle-based ship sank about 60 miles south of the Pribilof Islands town of St. Paul, which is north of the Aleutian Islands chain and southwest of the Alaska mainland. Roberts agreed that continuing the search would be useless. ``The boats searched for seven hours yesterday, they searched all night. With the water temperature 32 to 34 degrees, it's doubtful they would have survived,'' he said. The Coast Guard earlier reported that 10 people were missing, but the figure was revised to nine after officials discovered one crewman apparently had stayed off the ship at its last port. None of the crew was wearing survival suits, said Haley. Coast Guard officials said a person couldn't survive the frigid water more than 30 minutes without insulated survival gear. The survivors were transferred to the Bristol Enterprise, which wasn't expected to arrive in Dutch Harbor until late Friday, Haley said. From there they were to be flown home as soon as possible, weather permitting, Roberts said. Most of the crew members are from the Seattle area, he said. Lt. Cmdr. Richard Blaze of the Coast Guard's licensing and inspection office in Anchorage said the agency has no file on the Aleutian Enterprise. Nor does another inspection agency, the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration, said Victor Brandt of the OSHA office in Anchorage. The Aleutian Enterprise was part of a fleet of so-called factory trawlers that fish for cod and pollock in the remote Bering Sea between Alaska and the Soviet Union. The large vessels catch the bottom fish, process and freeze them on board. The vessel is owned by Aleutian Enterprise Ltd., a California-based partnership that contracts with Arctic Alaska for management and marketing services, Roberts said. The company the identitified the nine men presumed drowned as Joseph J. Alaimo, 45, Yakima, Wash.; Javier Martin V. Castro, 27, Seattle; Robert W. Davis, 26, Renton, Wash.; John A. Dieterich, 31, Seattle, chief engineer; Jeffrey A. Houston, 21, Warren, Ore.; David J. Jefferies, 19, Fontana, Calif.; Nello Marciel, 55, San Diego; Robert McCord, 35, Englewood, Colo., fisheries observer; Matthew J. Schneider, 22, Issaquah, Wash., foreman.

DOC.HEAD: Duchess of York has 7-Pound Daughter by Caesarean
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with Duchess of York's father's comment, minor editing. Picks up 11th pvs, `For Beatrice's...
DOC.TEXT: The Duchess of York gave birth to a 7-pound, 1{-ounce daughter by Caesarean section Friday night, and mother and child are both well, Portland Hospital announced. It was the second child and second girl for the 30-year-old duchess and her husband Prince Andrew, and is the sixth grandchild of Queen Elizabeth II. The new baby, daughter of the queen's second son, is sixth in line to the British throne after her sister, Princess Beatrice of York, who was born Aug. 8, 1988. Andrew was present at the delivery at 7:58 p.m. (2:58 p.m. EST), the hospital statement said. The Caesarean section was carried out because the baby was in a breech position, a Buckingham Palace spokesman said. ``It was the wrong way round,'' he said. The duchess, the former Sarah Ferguson, had spent the last week at Buckingham Palace in London instead of her country home. She arrived at the London hospital nearly four hours earlier in a chauffeur-driven car and entered through a side entrance, avoiding photographers waiting at the front. Her husband joined her two hours later after driving the 150 miles from Devonport naval dockyard, where he is based as a flight commander on the Royal Navy frigate Campbeltown. As tradition dictates, a notice was posted on the railings at Buckingham Palace giving news of the birth. It read: ``Her Royal Highness the Duchess of York was safely delivered of a daughter at 7:58 p.m. today. Her Royal Highness and her child are well.'' The birth was greeted by cheering and the cracking of champagne corks by a small crowd of well-wishers outside the hospital. The Duchess of York's father, Maj. Ronald Ferguson, said at his home at Dummer, a village 53 miles southwest of London: ``I am delighted for the mother and daughter.'' For Beatrice's birth, the duchess was admitted shortly after 10 a.m. and gave birth at 8:18 p.m. No name was announced immediately for the new baby, but she will be known as Her Royal Highness, Princess (baby's name) of York. Andrew's elder brother Prince Charles, 41, is first in line to the throne, followed by his sons Prince William and Prince Harry of Wales. Then comes Andrew, 30, then Beatrice. The queen's unmarried youngest son, Edward, 26, is now seventh in line of succession. Her 39-year-old daughter Anne, the Princess Royal, is eighth and has a son and daughter, Peter and Zara, who are ninth and tenth. The duke's ship has returned to Britain after exercises and is to remain in home waters until July. The queen went to Windsor Castle, 21 miles west of London, for the weekend and has been notified of the birth.

DOC.HEAD: Diplomats Ordered Out of Lithuania; Bush Warns Against Violence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 12-13: ``Fitzwater said,'' with committee observing developments; ADDS one graf Powell comment
DOC.TEXT: U.S. diplomats were ordered out of Lithuania by the Soviet Union on Friday, the White House said, as President Bush cautioned the Soviets that using force against the breakaway republic would be ``bound to backfire.'' U.S. officials said other foreign diplomats and some journalists also had been told to leave the Lithuanian capital. Bush declared that the United States stands with ``the brave men and women of Lithuania'' in their struggle for self-determination. And, in his strongest words yet on the situation, he said, ``Any attempt to coerce or intimidate or forcibly intervene against the Lithuanian people is bound to backfire. That is inevitable.'' Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the United States would comply with the order for its two diplomats to leave but would formally protest to the Soviet Union. ``This action certainly adds to our concerns,'' Fitzwater said. ``The situation appears to progressively get worse,'' he said. Indeed, late in the day the Soviets' Tass news agency said the situation was approaching ``anarchy in all its manifestations,'' the sort of language that in the past has been used to prepare Soviets for major actions. The U.S. diplomats, Douglas Wake and Jon Purnell, said Friday night in Vilnius that they had heard nothing about the order for them to leave. Fitzwater said the diplomats, both State Department foreign service officers, were in Lithuania only temporarily in any case. They were returning to the U.S. consulate in Leningrad. The spokesman said, ``It is unclear what specific actions have been taken against journalists. But we are opposed to any infringements on freedom of the press.'' Other U.S. officials, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said other foreign diplomats and journalists had been ordered out of Lithuania. Fitzwater said the ``deputies committee'' of high-ranking officials of the Pentagon, State Department, CIA and other agencies was keeping track of developments in Lithuania, but ``It's not being treated in a crisis-like way from our standpoint.'' U.S. options, beyond appeals for a peaceful settlement, are limited, and the administration wants to ``keep the rhetoric down,'' Fitzwater said. Meanwhile, Soviet Ambassador Yuri V. Dubinin said after a meeting with Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger that he had no information from Moscow about the expulsions. He indicated that Eagleburger raised the issue but that the problem generally was being handled by the Soviet Foreign Ministry and the U.S. Embassy in Moscow. His meeting with Eagleburger had been arranged before the expulsion order became known. Earlier, Bush said at a luncheon meeting with out-of-town news media representatives, ``We know that the Soviet Union has a longstanding interest in Lithuania, but those interests can only be addressed through dialogue and negotiation.'' With tensions steadily escalating, Bush said, ``We have made clear to the Soviet Union that the situation in Lithuania can only be solved peacefully.'' Fitzwater said the two U.S. diplomats had arrived in Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital, only Tuesday and had planned to leave on Sunday. They were given 12 hours to leave, and ``they will comply,'' he said. Fitzwater said that the United States was not given a reason by Moscow for the expulsion. He said that the Soviet chief of protocol relayed the expulsion notice to officials at the U.S. Embassy in Moscow. He said the two officials were in Vilnius ``on routine reporting and analysis as they do for the embassy.'' ``They are staff people in our consulate in Leningrad,'' he said. ``They're not spies,'' he added. Word of the Soviet action came shortly after Bush took questions at the White House from the out-of-town reporters and editors. The president later flew by helicopter to the presidential retreat in Camp David, Md., where he was to spend the weekend. Fitzwater said that Bush was informed of the Soviet action shortly before he left the White House. Fitzwater said that the United States ``has not acted in any way to exacerbate tensions'' in Lithuania. On reports that journalists had been expelled, the White House spokesman said: ``he expulsion of journalists undermines the spirit of glasnost.'' Bush's words came a day after he had declined to specifically criticize Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev for his order to Lithuanians to surrender all firearms. On Thursday, Bush had appealed to Lithuanians to recognize ``certain realities'' of Soviet control. But, with Soviet armor rumbling through the streets of the Lithuanian capital and other evidence of an intensified crackdown by the Kremlin, the president on Friday appeared to toughen his message. ``The brave men and women of Lithuania have made known their desire to reestablish the sovereignty of the Republic of Lithuania. The United States stands with them and supports their right to self-determination,'' Bush said. He said the situation was ``complex and sensitive'' and required ``realistic, level-headed leadership'' on both sides. ``Lithuanian leaders have consistently demonstrated their capacity in this regard, and the United States will do nothing that will make their task more difficult,'' Bush said. In the same vein as Bush, Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said in a Los Angles appearance Soviet use of force would be a ``major setback,'' and said Soviet intentions were unknown.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Patrol Bogota, Election Delay Sought Following Shooting
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers patrolled the capital Friday and three political parties sought to delay May's national elections following riots sparked by the assassination of a leftist presidential candidate. Also Friday, Pablo Escobar, the billionaire godfather of Colombia's cocaine traffickers, denied government accusations he was ordered the killing Thursday of the candidate, Bernardo Jaramillo of the Patriotic Union Party. However, an army general dismissed the denial as nonsense. The president of the Patriotic Union, Diego Montana, said in a televised interview Friday on the midday news program Cinevision that his party was withdrawing from the presidential elections. The Patriotic Union, Conservative and Communist parties all asked the governing Liberal Party of President Virgilio Barco to postpone the May 27 general elections, saying they feared for the safety of the candidates. A telephone caller who claimed the assassination for the Medellin cocaine cartel said the drug traffickers were renewing their war with the government. They had said Jan. 18 they were defeated and appealed for an end to extraditing suspects to the United States. The caller also said Cesar Gaviria, the Liberal Party presidential candidate, would be the next victim. Meanwhile in the southern city of Pasto, members of the Patriotic Union held Mayor German Guerrero and an undetermined number of city councilmen at the city hall, police there said in a communique. There were few details, but no violence was reported. The disorder began when Jaramillo was mowed down with a burst of submachine gun fire in Bogota's international airport Thursday. The alleged gunman, 16, was wounded and captured, but three other attackers reportedly escaped. Shortly after the killing, protesters took to streets, and unrest continued into the predawn hours Friday in some poorer neighborhoods of the capital. Bursts of submachine gun fire from snipers in one neighborhood killed a soldier, the army said in a statement. It also reported four policemen and a civilian were wounded. In addition, five buses were burned, army Gen. Ramon Niebles said in a communique. Rioters smashed windows at dozens of stores. Police on Friday cleared streets of roadblocks made from the burned vehicles, burning tires and other debris. Soldiers in armored cars with 20mm cannons patrolled the streets of Bogota. They also rode in jeeps and armored personnel carriers mounted with machine guns. Schools were closed Friday. In the central Colombia city of Barrancabermeja, the site of Colombia's main oil refinery, workers of the state oil company Ecopetrol reacted to the assassination by staging a 48-hour walkout beginning Thursday afternoon. Another 48-hour strike was declared in the northwestern banana-growing region of Uraba, where Jaramillo got his start in politics. In the western city of Pereira in Colombia's coffee-growing region, members of the Patriotic Union mounted a sit-in at the federal attorney general's office. Right-wing death squads have been blamed for previous slayings of Patriotic Union members. In the past, the Patriotic Union has claimed that Colombia's army and police are involved in the death squads. On Friday, the National Security Council reaffirmed that Escobar, head of the Medellin cartel, had ordered Jaramillo's assassination. A communique from the council said security forces had monitored a telephone call in which Escobar ordered the assassination and authorized $750 be paid for the job. The killer, a teen-ager who said he was hired in Medellin to kill Jaramillo, was wounded and captured, but investigators said he would not talk about who hired him. On Friday, Escobar sent a letter by fax to Colombian news media denying his complicity. But army Gen. Harold Bedoya said the army's proof leaves no doubt that Escobar ordered the killing.

DOC.HEAD: Alaska Governor and Coast Guard Collide on Spill Effects
With AM-Hazelwood Trial
DOC.TEXT: Alaska's governor and the commander of the U.S. Coast Guard disagreed Friday over how much environmental damage remains in Prince William Sound on the anniversary of the nation's worst oil spill. ``There is a lot of cleanup work left to do this summer,'' Gov. Steve Cowper told reporters at a news conference. ``The indications are that there is biological damage. We hope it isn't long-term,'' Cowper said after a visit Thursday to shores blackened when the Exxon Valdez ran aground spilling nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil. Coast Guard Commandant Adm. Paul Yost, who also revisited Prince William Sound this week _ almost a year after the March 24, 1989 spill _ disputed the governor's generally negative portrayal in another news conference 90 minutes later. ``There is a tremendous improvement in the situation,'' Yost said. Cowper released state Department of Environmental Conservation preliminary data indicating dramatic biological impacts on salmon and herring fisheries in some streams that enter the sound. He said major measures may be required in this summer's oil-spill cleanup program to save the fisheries and other resources. Exxon is proposing a cleanup plan that the state considers inadequate. At one heavily polluted site, a normally rich salmon stream on Latouche Island, ``not a single small salmon exists this spring,'' Cowper said. Though results of the state data are not definitive, he said, ``it indicates that the oil in the substrata killed whatever was there.'' The governor also said 90 percent of herring roe at another site have shown aberrations. Cowper also called on Exxon to settle out-of-court all valid spill-related lawsuits with the federal government, the state and private parties. If that is not done, he envisions up to a dozen years of litigation, he said. Yost said he doubts the existence of state biological data mentioned by Cowper. He said if the state is holding ``secret'' data it should released it immediately. The Coast Guard chief he learned from his visit to four heavily oiled shorelines this week that a cleanup is still needed, but said Exxon's 1989 efforts and the effects of winter storms and wave action had made a ``major, major difference.'' Yost said a ``fairly major'' cleanup effort will begin May 1 after the Coast Guard determines on a ``mile-by-mile basis'' the proper kind of treatment that will be required this year. In a separate letter to the Coast Guard's on-scene coordinator, Rear Adm. David Ciancaglini, released Friday by Cowper, Alaska DEC Commissioner Dennis Kelso criticized Exxon's general plan for 1990's cleanup effort. Exxon, which released the plan on March 15, contended that last year's heavy equipment-aided cleanup, followed by winter tides, allows the company to use milder cleanup techniques this year. But the state said Friday the plan is ``far too limiting.'' ``We cannot afford to base our work plan and our standards on unsupported conclusions, public relations strategies, and solely short-term `fixes,''' Kelso wrote. Cowper said the state will support more intrusive cleaning techniques _ including such unproven tactics as bulldozing shorelines _ if they are proven effective and allow micro-organisms and other life forms to re-establish themselves over the long term. Yost said the federal on-scene coordinator will make the final decisions on future cleanup activities and Exxon officials have assured him the company will do everything ``reasonable'' it is asked to do. Economics also will be a factor in determining what can be done, Yost said. ``I don't think you can require anybody to spend an unlimited amount of money,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Restorer Opposes Removing Loincloths from `Last Judgment'
LaserPhoto ROM2
DOC.TEXT: The loincloths painted on some nude figures in Michelangelo's ``Last Judgment'' on orders of Pope Pius IV should be left on the 16th-century masterpiece, Vatican restorer Fabrizio Mancinelli said Friday. ``To remove them, we would have to make a hole in the wall, and frankly I don't want to make a hole in the wall,'' said Mancinelli, who is directing the cleaning of Michelangelo's Sistine Chapel frescoes. The ``Last Judgment'' is a 60-by-30-foot painting on the wall above the chapel altar. Mancinelli spoke at a news conference presenting a Vatican exhibit on Michelangelo and the 11-year-old project of wiping away centuries of soot, grime and dust from the Renaissance work. The Sistine Chapel restoration has long been surrounded by controversy. Critics, led by Columbia University art historian James Beck, charged the restorers were removing some of Michelangelo's retouchings and altering the colors of the frescoes. But Mancinelli said the Vatican team left Michelangelo's original work intact, removing only glue-varnish added to the painting by 17th and 18th century restorers. Restorers recently finished cleaning the 5,533-square-foot vaulted chapel ceiling, revealing bright and dynamic colors. Early next month, they will begin the four-year restoration of the ``Last Judgment.'' Some 16th-century church officials were shocked by the nude figures in the ``Last Judgment,'' and in 1564, Pius IV ordered those found most offensive to be covered up by artist Daniele da Volterra. Some art experts argue the loincloths should now be removed, but Mancinelli said the rules of Italian restoration call for all essential elements of an artwork to be maintained, including da Volterra's reworkings. He noted previously that the whole issue may be moot, since some historians think the nude parts were removed when da Volterra made his additions. If they are correct, taking away the loincloths would reveal bare spots on the wall. The issue is expected to be debated by 50 international scientists, restorers and art historians meeting at the Vatican next week to discuss plans for the ``Last Judgment'' restoration. Carlo Pietrangeli, director of the Vatican Museums, said the results of the ceiling restoration had eliminated the bitterness he felt over the ``unjustified criticism'' of the project. There has been talk of limiting the number of tourists in the chapel, which on peak days can attract up to 19,000 visitors. But Pietrangeli said it would be ``practically impossible'' to turn back tourists. Pope John Paul II is scheduled to inaugurate the Michelangelo exhibit on Saturday in the Braccio di Carlo Magno in St. Peter's Square. Entitled ``Michelangelo and the Sistine Chapel _ Technique, Conservation and Myth,'' the exhibit will open to the public Sunday and run through July 10. The exhibit includes a selection of Michelangelo's drawings showing how he planned the Sistine Chapel decoration; a scale model of the scaffolding he used; a video on the cleaning techniques; and drawings by Raphael, Rubens, Caravaggio and others underlining Michelangelo's impact on other artists.

DOC.HEAD: Hazelwood Sentenced to Help Clean Sound, Pay $50,000
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 12-15, bgn `After the...,' with 7 grafs to UPDATE with lawyers accusing judge of `Hazelwood Bashing.' Picks up 16th graf pvs, `Even if...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AG3
DOC.TEXT: Former Exxon Valdez Capt. Joseph Hazelwood was sentenced Friday to help clean up Prince William Sound and pay $50,000 in restitution by a judge seeking to soothe outrage over the nation's worst oil spill. Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone, in sentencing Hazelwood to 1,000 hours of community service by cleaning beaches, said he was disappointed that the fired skipper had not publicly apologized for his role in the disaster. ``I'm sure deep down he is very shameful,'' the judge said. Johnstone, however, acknowledged that Hazelwood had been advised by his lawyers to keep silent because of the many civil lawsuits he still faces. Hazelwood's attorneys said they thought the sentence for a single misdemeanor conviction of negligence would be overturned on appeal, in part because the order to pay $50,000 in restitution to the state was illegal. The defense attorneys said Johnstone chose an arbitrary figure without measuring Hazelwood's ability to pay. The judge also gave Hazelwood the maximum jail term of 90 days and fine of $1,000, but suspended both sentences, saying he felt prison would not deter Hazelwood. ``Imprisonment is not going to restore the environment,'' the judge said. ``But there is community outrage and something has to be done to provide condemnation and reaffirmation.'' Johnstone, who presided over Hazelwood's seven-week trial, said he felt the captain was wrong to drink before he boarded his ship and believed he violated at least some Coast Guard regulations in the grounding a year ago Saturday. A 12-member jury found Hazelwood guilty Thursday of a charge of negligent discharge of oil into state waters. But he was acquitted of three other charges, including a felony, that he was reckless and drunk during the disaster that blackened the rocky shoreline of Prince William Sound. Had he been convicted of all four, Hazelwood could have received a maximum 7\ years and a $61,000 fine. Hazelwood's lawyers said they would appeal the conviction as well as the sentence, and Johnstone said he would stay the sentence as soon as that appeal is filed. One of Hazelwood's lawyers later issued a statement accusing the judge of ``Hazelwood bashing'' and said Johnstone's criticism of the skipper for drinking and being off the bridge of his ship improperly tried to override the jury's verdict. ``In light of the jury verdict this type of demagoguery should stop,'' said attorney Thomas Russo. He said 90 percent of Johnstone's comments Friday were directed at what the jury already had decided, absolving Hazelwood of recklessness and intoxication. Another Hazelwood attorney, Dick Madson, told reporters after the sentencing, ``The restitution is illegal, I think. The judge has no right to set an arbitrary figure like that.'' Madson said that in almost any crime a judge can assess a figure for restitution, an amount that goes to the victim rather than to the state as would a normal fine. He said, however, such an assessment always involves measuring the defendant's ability to pay and degree of responsibility. Johnstone made no such inquiry, and the Madson asserted this would invalidate the the assessment. Madson called the order to perform community service ``a novel way to come up with a fair sentence,'' but he and another Hazelwood attorney, Michael Chalos, said they thought the 1,000 hours were excessive since the sentence would exceed the maximum 90 days in jail allowed under the law. Even if Hazelwood worked 8 hours a day cleaning beaches, they said, he could not finish 1,000 hours within 3 months. The judge's decision also meet with the disapproval of the jury forewoman, Lori Wing, who was in the courtroom along with four other jurors for the sentencing. ``I had high hopes he would walk out of here a free man and get on with his life,'' she said. Hazelwood had no immediate comment on the sentencing. Madson said Hazelwood had come to court expecting the worst: jail time. After Thursday's verdict, Hazelwood had commented, ``I'd like to go back to the sea. That's what I do.'' Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole, in remarks before the sentencing, cited Hazelwood's history of two drunken driving convictions and declared that ``Captain Hazelwood is probably, on a scale of 1 to 10, a 3 or 4 as to his likelihood of rehabilitation.'' The skipper's future also is clouded by more than 100 lawsuits filed by assorted victims of the spill. The Exxon Valdez, a 987-foot tanker, ran aground on March 24, 1989, and gushed nearly 11 million gallons of oil into the pristine sound. It killed countless birds, fish and wildlife in the scenic area, and Exxon came under bitter criticism for failing to respond quickly with a clean up effort. Hazelwood was charged last year with a felony, criminal mischief, and three misdemeanors, reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated, and negligent discharge of oil. Jurors took only 10{ hours in deliberations to reject all but one count. Two of them said afterward that they rejected the state's contention Hazelwood was impaired by alcohol when the ship grounded because blood alcohol tests were performed on the skipper 10{ hours after the tanker hit the reef. In his ruling, however, Johnstone condemned Hazelwood: ``I think Captain Hazelwood knows that no reasonably prudent person would have had those drinks or left the bridge. In my opinion, he violated at least a couple of Coast Guard regulations and that constitutes negligence. ``I think Captain Hazelwood knows the buck stops with him and he has to take responsibility,'' the judge said. But Jim Morakis, an Exxon spokesman in New York, said Thursday that the verdict ``would seem to confirm the view that the grounding of the Exxon Valdez was an accident.'' Alaska Gov. Steve Cowper said Hazelwood's acquittal on the most serious charges shows that someone other than the veteran mariner was responsible for the grounding. ``The result bears out the fact that there are other people responsible for this, other than Captain Hazelwood,'' said Cowper.

DOC.HEAD: Guam Abortion Law Delayed; Md. Compromise Tripped Up By Committee
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS the first graf and grafs 8-11, beginning ``But the House...,'' with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Maryland measures apparently dead for this session.
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. judge in Guam on Friday blocked the territory's new abortion law, the nation's most restrictive, and a legislative package that would let Maryland voters decide the abortion issue lost a vote and appeared doomed. In Idaho, more than 50 junior high school students staged a brief sit-in in the office of Gov. Cecil Andrus, protesting the Legislature's passage of a law that would ban more than 90 percent of the abortions performed in the state. They demanded that the governor veto the legislation, which was approved Thursday and is the most restrictive abortion measure passed by any state legislature. Pro-choice interests in California, Michigan, Wisconsin, Rhode Island and North Carolina have threatened to boycott Idaho potatoes if Andrus fails to veto the bill. ``Women can fight back,'' said Anne Nicol Gaylor, administrator of the Madison based-Women's Medical Fund Inc., based in Madison, Wis. ``We do not have to beg and plead for our rights any more.'' Either the Guam law or the Idaho law could provide the basis for a direct challenge to the U.S. Supreme Court's landmark 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision that legalized abortions. The Maryland Senate early Friday approved and sent to the House of Delegates a complicated compromise to end an eight-day filibuster on the abortion issue. But the House Environmental Matters Committee voted 13 to 12 against the package Friday night. There had been a possibility that an attempt to revive the proposal would be made on the House floor, but because of House Democratic leadership opposition, the committee action most likely ends the matter for the 1990 session. John S. Arnick, chairman of Environmental Matters, told that panel before he cast the tie-breaking vote that the leadership's recommendation was to defeat both bills ``for the sake of the system.'' He said the compromise involved a ``convoluted system that doesn't make sense in a lot of ways'' and warned that ``the public would be cursed with confusion.'' Under the compromise, an abortion rights bill permitting unrestricted abortions during the early stages of pregnancy would have become law. Voters would have been able to call a referendum on the law in November through a petition drive. If voters then rejected it in the referendum, then a bill sponsored by anti-abortion senators would have become law _ unless it also was defeated by voters. That bill would have allowed abortions in cases of rape or incest, to protect the mother's life or if the pregnancy would produce serious and adverse effects on the woman's health. The compromise required that both measures be passed by the House and signed by the governor. If one of the measures was rejected, the other one aldo would have died, but the committee vote made all that moot. In Agana, Guam, U.S. District Judge Alex Munson issued a temporary restraining order blocking enforcement of the territory's new law, a few hours after a group of Guam residents and medical groups filed a class-action lawsuit. He scheduled a hearing for Monday on whether to extend his order. The plaintiffs included ``Maria Doe,'' a Guam woman who is eight weeks pregnant and wants an abortion, the Guam Society of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, the Guam Nurses Association, an Episcopal priest and three doctors. Defendants include Gov. Joseph Ada, who signed the bill into law Monday, and territorial Attorney General Elizabeth Barrett-Anderson, who advised the Legislature that the bill was unconstitutional before it was approved. Rachael Pine, staff attorney for the American Civil Liberties Union's Reproductive Freedom Project in New York, said the lawsuit cites violation of constitutional guarantees of right to privacy, due process, free speech, equal protection, guarantees of religious freedoms and freedom from slavery. Guam's law prohibits abortions except when a pregnancy endangers the life of the mother. It makes it a felony to perform abortion or aid in the procedure, and a misdemeanor for a woman to solicit or have an abortion, or for a person to solicit a woman to have an abortion. The law provides for a referendum on the Nov. 6 ballot for Guam voters to decide whether to retain or reject the law. Guam's law is more restrictive than the bill passed by the Idaho Legislature. The Idaho bill would ban abortion except in cases of non-statutory rape reported within seven days, incest if the victim is younger than 18, severe fetal deformity or threat to the mother's life or physical health. It would ban more than 90 percent of the 1,500 abortions performed in Idaho annually. ``Idaho was one of the first states to give women their rights, and now they want to take them away from us,'' said 15-year-old Michele May, one of those protesting at the governor's office in Boise. ``We can't let them do that.'' If Andrus signs the bill, the law would take effect July 1, and abortion rights groups have promised a quick court challenge. The governor has not said what he would do. In Washington, D.C., Guam's congressional delegate worked to head off retaliation from colleagues resulting from the abortion law. Rep. George Miller, D-Calif., sent a letter to colleagues Thursday, urging them to withdraw support for a bill to provide commonwealth status for Guam. ``States and territories may have the right to pass laws that deny women the right to choice, but no government has the right to deny its citizens freedom of speech,'' Miller's letter said.

DOC.HEAD: Maryland House Committee Rejects Abortion Filibuster Compromise
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with attempts to revive the bills unlikely, picking up 6th graf pvs, ``Under the ...''
DOC.TEXT: A state Senate compromise to end an eight-day filibuster over an abortion rights bill was narrowly rejected by a state House committee Friday night. Because of House leadership opposition, the action by the Environmental Matters Committee most likely ends for the 1990 session an abortion debate that has dominated the deliberations of the Maryland General Assembly for several weeks. The Senate approved the compromise earlier in the day, agreeing to pass both a pro-choice bill and a more restrictive measure favored by abortion opponents. Lawmakers expected that at least one of the bills would be petitioned to a referendum, which would essentially give voters the final say on the issue. Normally, Friday night's 13-to-12 vote by House Environmental Matters would doom the compromise. However, there was at least a possibility that an attempt to revive the proposal would be made on the House floor, which was to meet later Friday night. Another possibility would be for a move from the floor to revive the pro-choice bill only, approve it and pass it back to the Senate, which would then have to deal with the abortion issue again. But the House Democratic leadership was opposed to any revival attempt. John S. Arnick, chairman of Environmental Matters, told that panel before he cast the tie-breaking vote that the leadership's recommendation was to defeat both bills ``for the sake of the system.'' He said the compromise involved a ``convoluted system that doesn't make sense in a lot of ways'' and warned that ``the public would be cursed with confusion.'' Under the compromise, an abortion rights bill permitting unrestricted abortions during the early stages of pregnancy will become law unless voters reject it in November. Voters must sign petitions to get it on the ballot. If it is rejected, then a bill sponsored by anti-abortion senators will become law _ unless it also is defeated by voters. Under that bill, abortions could be performed in cases of rape or incest, to protect the mother's life or if the pregnancy would produce serious and adverse effects on the woman's health. Both measures would have to be passed by the House and signed by the governor. If one of the measures is rejected, the other one dies.

DOC.HEAD: New Study Says Hydrogen Could Explode In Tanks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with new information and details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Hydrogen gas building up in nuclear waste storage tanks at the Hanford nuclear reservation could explode, possibly spewing radioactivity into the atmosphere, the U.S. Department of Energy warned Friday. The hydrogen buildup has been spotted in 20 storage tanks at Hanford and is the result of the decomposition of organic wastes introduced into the tanks in the 1970s, said Hanford manager Mike Lawrence. The wastes, in the form of a slurry with a surface crust that traps gases underneath, are byproducts of production of nuclear weapons materials at Hanford. The chance of an explosion is low, Lawrence insisted Friday, but added scientists do not know enough about the problem to rule it out. ``We taken every precaution we can think of but I can't give you an absolute guarantee,'' Lawrence told a hastily called news conference. ``The worst case is any explosion that could cause the dome to collapse and send the contents up to the air,'' he said. ``I can't sit here and say it's not going to happen.'' The tanks are built of 1{-foot-thick reinforced steel and concrete and are buried under six to eight feet of dirt. There has never been a storage tank explosion at Hanford, but nuclear waste storage tanks have apparently exploded in the Soviet Union. A 1989 Tass report said 10,000 people were evacuated after a 1957 explosion. But other reports of the 1957 accident indicated that hundreds had died. The Hanford danger came to light in a study performed by the Westinghouse Hanford Co., main DOE contractor at the reservation. The study was prompted by concerns raised by Congress late last year about the possibility of ferrocyanide exploding in the tanks. Ferrocyanide was added to the liquid waste stream from 1954-1975 to concentrate the waste and produce additional storage space in the tanks. While the ferrocyanide threat was ultimately ruled to be very low, scientists discovered that hydrogen gas buildup in the tanks was a greater danger than previously thought, Lawrence said. He said he first learned of the study's conclusions Thursday. No copy of the study was immediately available. One of the newer, double-shell storage tanks is of particular concern, Lawrence said. That million-gallon tank, known as 101-SY, has seen its waste level rise and fall by as much as 33 inches because of hydrogen gas buildup, he said. Hydrogen concentration in the tank has been measured at as much as 5 percent at an exhaust vent and may have been higher elsewhere in the tank, Lawrence said. A 5 percent hydrogen buildup is considered potentially flammable, while an 18 percent buildup is considered potentially explosive, he said. The waste rise was first noticed in 1977, and scientists since 1984 have tried various methods to reduce the tank's gas buildup, including injecting water into the slurry and lancing the surface crust with pipes to relieve pressure. None of those measures worked, Lawrence said. Hanford workers have now stopped all transfers of waste in or out of the tank and conduct no maintenance work that would create heat or sparks in the area, he said. Lesser hydrogen buildup has also been spotted in four other double-shell tanks, and in 15 of the older single-shell storage tanks, he said. In addition to hydrogen, the decomposition of the organic wastes is producing nitrous oxides and nitrogen, with the combination of gases increasing the risk, DOE said. Scientists will not have a plan for dealing with the problem until June, Lawrence said, but added the explosion danger is not imminent and precautions are being taken. The storage tanks contain a mixture of wastes. The organics were added in the 1970s when they were used as solvents to recover radioactive strontium from some of the taks, Lawrence said. While past analysis of the possiblity of a hydrogen explosion has indicated that the giant tanks would remain intact and contain their radioactivity, Lawrence stressed that Hanford scientists will conduct new studies because they feel the new danger is greater than that previously analyzed. Westinghouse scientists are seeking outside help from industry experts with experience in fire and explosion prevention, DOE said. The ferrocyanide investigations were prompted by Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, who last year released a 1984 report raising the possibility of explosions in the tanks.

DOC.HEAD: Advancing Cold Air Spreads Snow Across Northern States
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with snow in Mont. and Mo., one traffic death, picking up 5th graf pvs, ``Almost 2 ...''
DOC.TEXT: Snow fell from the Northwest across the Plains on Friday while cold air pushed southward, stirring up a tornado in Utah and dumping a foot of snow on Montana, but temperatures hit record highs in Arizona and Connecticut. At midday, snow was falling across north-central Oregon, south-central Washington state, the Idaho Panhandle, north-central Utah, Wyoming, Montana, northern Colorado, southern and western Nebraska, western South Dakota, northern Kansas, southwestern Iowa, northern and west-central Missouri, and west-central Illinois, the National Weather Service said. Southern Montana suffered the worst of the storm, with Red Lodge reporting 12 inches of snow. Morning temperatures were no higher than the mid-teens. Billings had a record low of just 7 degrees and Jordan had a morning low of just 1 degree. Northerly wind gusting to 30 mph produced a wind chill effect of 32 below zero at Dillon, Mont. Northern Missouri got 5 inches of snow Friday, with several more inches forecast for Saturday. One traffic death was blamed on hazardous driving conditions, which also prompted officials to close some rural schools. ``We had literally hundreds of cars off the road and lots and lots of fender-benders,'' said Missouri highway patrol Sgt. Myron Garrett at St. Joseph. Almost 2 inches of snow overnight and freezing temperatures created hazardous driving conditions on many roads around Spokane, Wash., and state police reported many minor accidents The heaviest snowfall during the six hours up to noon was 3 inches at Norfolk, Neb., and 2 inches at Cheyenne, Wyo.; Helena, Mont.; Lincoln, Neb., and Walla Walla, Wash. Winter-like weather was expected to force its way as far south as Oklahoma and the Texas Panhandle, with gusty wind pushing temperatures 30 to 40 degrees lower than those of the past several days. To the east, snow was scattered around the Great Lakes and in parts of Vermont and New Hampshire. South of the snow belt, freezing rain extended over northwestern Oklahoma, the northern Texas Panhandle, southwestern and central Kansas, and southeastern through east-central Colorado. The collision of the cold air with warm air produced thunderstorms Friday over Utah and a rare tornado ripped off a storage shed roof near Vernal, in northeastern Utah, and slammed it through a bedroom wall. ``When it hit our trailer, it felt like an earthquake had hit,'' said Tina Harrison, whose mobile home was damaged by the twister. ``We were waiting for it to knock our trailer off its cinder blocks. It was scary.'' Showers and thunderstorms also reached from north-central and southwestern Oklahoma, the southern Texas Panhandle and northeastern New Mexico. Thunderstorms produced half-inch diameter hail south of Guthrie, Okla. Weather was warmer east and west of the advancing cold wave. Bridgeport, Conn., hit a record high of 68 and Tucson, Ariz., hit a record high of 91. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 7 above zero at Butte and Livingston, Mont., to 93 at Palm Springs, Calif. Friday's low for the Lower 48 states was 3 below zero at International Falls, Minn.

DOC.HEAD: Compromise Saves Lebanon Government
DOC.TEXT: A compromise has been worked out to avert the collapse of the 5-month-old mixed Cabinet of Moslems and Christians over an attempt to arrest the Central Bank governor, Prime Minister Salim Hoss said Thursday. His statement came after President Elias Hrawi's office said Interior Minister Elias Khazen offered his letter of resignation late Wednesday. ``The president decided to keep the letter of resignation,'' Hrawi's office said, without specifying if Khazen would remain in the post. A government official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the president's neither accepting or rejecting the resignation was ``a face-saving exit'' for both Khazen and Hoss. ``Any other decision would have toppled the government. Had Khazen's resignation been accepted, several ministers would have resigned in solidarity with him. Had it been rejected, Hoss would have resigned,'' he explained. Hoss demanded the resignation after Khazen sent police to arrest bank governor Edmond Naim on March 15. Central Bank guards foiled the attempt, though a bank administrator suffered a minor wound in the brief shootout. Hours after the compromise was worked out Wednesday, the Central Bank announced it has approved the payment of $1.5 million to the London-based company, Thomas de la Rue, for printing 1 million Lebanese passports. The Central Bank's original refusal to finance the deal on the ground it received an offer from a Swedish company to do the job at half the price prompted Khazen's attempt to arrest Naim. The fate of the Swedish deal was not disclosed. Also Thursday, Hoss instructed the foreign, interior and defense ministries to check out thoroughly reports about Israeli settlement activities in south Lebanon. Salah Staitieh, chief of the Foreign Ministry's political department, said ``a diplomatic effort will be launched if it was confirmed that the enemy's troops were building roads or annexing Lebanese territory.'' Israeli troops and allied militiamen control a 6-to-10-mile-deep strip of territory in south Lebanon. Christian militia chieftain Samir Geagea on Thursday meanwhile repeated a cautious welcome for an Arab League-brokered peace plan to end Lebanon's civil war. Geagea's rival, Gen. Michel Aoun, has rejected the accord along with Hrawi's election as president Nov. 24. Almost 800 people have died in fighting between Aoun's soldiers and Geagea's militiamen since Jan. 30. Hrawi, Geagea and Aoun are Maronites, the Catholic community that has dominated Lebanon since independence from France in 1943.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Approves Genetically Engineered Cheese-Making Enzyme
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS ``renin'' to ``rennet'' in grafs 2 &e. FYI, ``rennin'' in graf 5: ``It is,'' is CQ
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators on Friday declared safe a genetically engineered enzyme they said was identical to the naturally occurring substance _ the same stuff that made Little Miss Muffet's curds and whey. The Food and Drug Administration said it received no objections to the addition of bacterially produced chymosin, the active ingredient in rennet, to its list of foods ``generally recognized as safe.'' The only two objections received by the agency raised the question of whether the dairy industry needed additional sources of rennet, a question the agency said was irrelevant to the safety issue and one it could not consider, FDA said in a notice published in the Federal Register. Rennet makes milk clot and forms curds and whey, and is used to make cheese and other dairy products. It is derived from the fourth stomach of calves, kids or lambs as a solution of prochymosin, and treated with acid to break down the prochymosin into chymosin, the active ingredient in rennet. Chymosin is sometimes called rennin. The pharmaceutical firm Pfizer Inc. petitioned FDA two years ago to approve its manufactured chymosin as ``generally recognized as safe,'' or alternatively to approve it as a food additive. The food additive petition was withdrawn Friday when the safety petition was approved. Pfizer uses the K-12 laboratory strain of Escherichia coli, a common human intestinal bacterium, to make the chymosin. The K-12 strain has lost the ability to live in humans. The gene that directs the manufacture of prochymosin is inserted into the bacterial genes, and works there instead of in the animal. The prochymosin solution that results will have different impurities, but the agency said Pfizer had shown those impurities ``do not provide any basis for concern.''

DOC.HEAD: Agency Disputes Senate Panel's Findings on Alleged Oil Theft From Indians
DOC.TEXT: The federal Bureau of Land Management is disputing a Senate subcommittee's finding that the nation's largest independent oil producer stole more than $30 million worth of crude oil from Indian lands. The agency said it took independent measurements on oil shipments from one-quarter of the 917 Indian land leases involving Koch Industries Inc. across the country and found just three minor discrepancies. The company had been accused of deliberate mismeasurements to avoid paying royalties. In a report published Wednesday, the agency said it carried out 460 inspections on leases and lease agreements involving Koch Industries both before and after the May 1989 hearings by the Senate Select Committee on Indian Affairs. On another 42 randomly selected leases, the bureau compared purchaser and producer measurement records with the production figures reported to the federal government, and no discrepancies were found, the report said. And on Monday, the Osage Tribal Council said it completed a review of Koch Industries Inc. purchases in Osage County, Okla., for 1987, 1988 and the first five months of 1989 and found that ``overpayment of royalties by Koch were made as well as underpayments.'' The net amount owed was about $22,000, plus $7,057 in late penalties, the council said. During that period, Koch Industries bought 10 million barrels of Osage oil and paid $33 million in royalties for it, it said. The discrepancy amounted to less than one-tenth of 1 percent. Koch Industries's executive vice president for legal and corporate affairs, Donald L. Cordes, said both investigations were ``in marked contrast to the shallow, selective and biased investigations reported to the Senate subcommittee in the sensationalized hearings of last spring.'' Two former Koch employees told the subcommittee they were pressured to steal oil from wells on Indian land. The company expected them to mismeasure oil from the wells so that Koch did not have to pay for all it got, they testified. The company rebutted the allegations, saying the subcommittee's figures were inaccurate. Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., who was chairman of the subcommittee, was not available for comment Thursday, a secretary in his office said. Koch officials maintained from the start of the controversy that factors such as temperature, crude oil composition and holding tank conditions make precise measurement of crude impossible. The company also suggested an ongoing Koch family feud might have led to the subcommittee's findings. The subcommittee heard testimony from an investigator hired by William Koch, the son of the company's founder. Koch sold his interest in Koch Industries in 1982 as part of the out-of-court settlement of a lawsuit in which he and others attempted to gain control of the company. His brother, Charles Koch, is Koch Industries' board chairman. Koch Industries, based in Wichita, has interests in energy, real estate, manufacturing and cattle. It is one of the nation's largest privately held corporations with annual revenues estimated at $16-18 billion, and employs more than 7,000.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Offers High-Level Talks With Britain
With AM-Baker
DOC.TEXT: African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela has offered to hold high-level talks with Britain, the Foreign Office said Thursday. It said Mandela made the proposal when he met Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd at an independence banquet Wednesday night in Windhoek, Namibia. Mandela offered to meet Hurd for talks Thursday, but Hurd had to return to Britain, the Foreign Office said. It said no mention was made of a possible meeting with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who invited Mandela for talks when his 27-year imprisonment ended last month. Mandela is to visit London at Easter for an international rock concert and rally celebrating his freedom. The ANC disagrees with Britain's call for easing sanctions against South Africa following Mandela's release, and critics of Mrs. Thatcher claimed Mandela was signaling his displeasure by not replying to her invitation.

DOC.HEAD: Revolutionary's Letter to Lenin Auctioned
DOC.TEXT: A handwritten 1918 letter from Russian revolutionary Leon Trotsky to V.I. Lenin was auctioned Thursday for $27,500, an ``extreme bargain'' in the view of the buyer, a California book dealer. But an original manuscript of drawings and writings by the late actor Orson Welles failed to draw a bid after being offered for $11,000 at the Swann Galleries auction. Louis Weinstein, owner of the Heritage Bookshop Inc. of Los Angeles, bought the one-page Trotsky letter, and said he planned to offer it for resale at a New York book fair this weekend. ``It was very cheap. I expected it would go for $60,000 to $70,000,'' he said. The letter, addressed to ``Dear Vladimir Ilyich,'' is considered historically significant because it outlined Trotsky's own plan for a ``no war, no peace'' settlement with the so-called Central Powers, led by Germany, near the end of World War I. It was also intended for Lenin's cohort, Josef Stalin. The day's most successful bid was $57,750 for a 1663 collection of William Shakespeare's ``Comedies, Histories and Tragedies,'' a price nearly three times the initial bid of $20,000. Caroline Birenbaum, a spokeswoman for the gallery, said the buyer, who bid by telephone, wanted to remain anonymous. Neither the Trotsky letter nor the Welles manuscript had a estimated price in the catalog, but it was evident that Swann officials were disappointed at the response to the two highly publicized items. However, George Lowry, the president and chief auctioneer of Swann Galleries, disagreed with Weinstein's estimate on the letter. ``We figured it at between $20,000 and $30,000 and it came in right in the middle,'' he said. Lowry said he thought the Welles material was ``the victim of its own advance publicity.'' Several prospective buyers were on the telephone but did not bid, and others evidently could not get through, Lowry said. Birenbaum said later that ``several expressions of interest'' had been received after the auction for the Welles manuscript, a 68-page collection of sketches and written text done by the actor in 1956 as a gift to his daughter, Rebecca, who consigned it for sale. It deals with the Bravades, a three-day festival held each year at the French resort city of St. Tropez. The Trotsky letter, written during the turbulent period just after the abdication of Czar Nicholas II and the seizure of power by the Bolsheviks, has been quoted in previous writings on the period but had not itself been available to scholars of the Russian Revolution. It was offered for sale from the estate of Adele Bernstein of Binghamton, the daughter-in-law of Herman Bernstein, a noted American foreign correspondent who obtained the letter in Russia. In the letter, Trotsky outlined his views of what Russia's position should be in regard to German demands that it withdraw from the allied side in the war. ``It is impossible to sign their peace,'' Trotsky wrote, adding that he would propose instead an end to Russian involvement without signing any agreement. This ``no war, no peace'' position has been likened to the Cold War following World War II. In fact he took that stance as head of the Russian delegation at Brest-Litovsk a month later, a strategy that backfired by allowing the Germans to drive farther into Russia. The Russians were forced to sign a less advantageous treaty, but were saved by Germany's eventual defeat.

DOC.HEAD: Liberia Lifts Ban on Newspapers, Radio Station
DOC.TEXT: The government said Thursday it is lifting bans on two newspapers and a Roman Catholic radio station that had been accused of reporting false information. President Samuel Doe decided to remove the ban Wednesday in honor of Namibia's independence that day, according to a Ministry of Information statement. The southern African nation became independent after 75 years of white South African rule. Footprints Today and Sun Times newspapers were banned in April 1988, when the government also barred radio stations from broadcasting reports of the British Broadcasting Corp. and the U.S.-funded Voice of America. Footprints Today was accused of fabricating a letter to the editor signed by an alleged army officer who said secret killings and arrests were increasing in Liberia. Offending stories in the Sun Times reported the arrest of a Ghanaian for possession of explosives and the firing of the commander of a government anti-terrorist squad. ELCM community radio was ordered closed in June 1989 for reporting one person was crushed to death and hundreds were injured in a stampede at a Monrovia football stadium where Liberia lost to Malawi. The independent press of this West African nation, which was founded by freed American slaves in 1847, expressed anger Saturday over the burning down of the independent Daily Observer newspaper building. Four armed men in military uniforms reportedly doused the library, darkroom and newsroom with gasoline, then set them ablaze. Newspaper editors said the act was intended to intimidate them. Also last week, the managing director of the Independent News, Klon Hinneh, was detained for several days under a court order for printing Chief Justice Emmanuel Gbalazeh's picture on the back page instead of the front page.

DOC.HEAD: Radical Retirement Home Celebrates Victory Against Oblivion
DOC.TEXT: Residents of a retirement home for aging political activists held a victory celebration Thursday, the day they had faced a deadline for moving out of the stately, Spanish-style mansion. The home's nine remaining residents applauded the resignations of 10 board members who wanted to sell the home to a developer for $1.2 million _ a deal originally set to close March 26 _ and the appointment of a new board Tuesday.
