The residents and the new directors promised to press their struggle to keep open Sunset Hall, which has been a home to socialists, radicals, communists and liberal religious activists. ``It was a very joyous occasion in which we were able to declare a total victory to our struggle,'' said Jan Goodman, the new board president. ``We now have a new board totally dedicated to keeping Sunset Hall open.'' That won't be easy, she acknowledged. It costs $30,000 a month to run the 36-bed facility, but the nine residents bring in only about $7,200 a month. They pay between $900 and $1,400 a month, although some are charged less because of need. The home has $15,000 in reserve. The home has operated at a deficit for nearly 20 years, said administrator Thomas E. Brandlin. Some longtime residents moved out after the old board announced in July that it was going to sell. But other residents went to court earlier this month and obtained a temporary injunction, a 20-day reprieve of the March 22 deadline for moving out. Residents claimed the board had failed to do enough to keep open the home, which they call a special place to live, where lively discussion, music and social activism remain a way of life. Then the 10 board members resigned after it became apparent they would not be able to muster enough votes from members of the non-profit group that runs Sunset Hall to approve the sale at an April 1 meeting. Founded in 1924 by the First Unitarian Church of Los Angeles, Sunset Hall was intended for elderly religious liberals. The church no longer runs it. Among the home's past residents have been Ruben Burroughs, editor of socialist Uptoin Sinclair's newsletter during Sinclair's 1934 run for governor. Other residents helped with union causes in the 1930s and fought McCarthy-era blacklisting in the 1950s.

After Soviet armor rumbled through Lithuania's capital, leaders of the breakaway republic issued a worldwide appeal for support and expressed concern that increasing Kremlin pressure would lead to violence. The appeal came Thursday, following the Red Army maneuvers through Vilnius and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's call on Lithuania to stop signing up its own volunteer forces. A day earlier, Gorbachev told Lithuanian citizens to hand over all their firearms within a week. The Kremlin has said it would not use force to bring Lithuania back into the fold after its declaration of independence March 11. But Lithuanian officials were afraid that an effort to round up deserters might give Moscow such an excuse, said Algirdas Saudargas, head of the Lithuanian Parliament's foreign affairs committee.

President Bush is steering away from strong statements on the volatile situation in Lithuania and declining to criticize Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's order for secessionists to surrender their weapons. ``What possible good would come from the president of the United States, standing halfway around the world, speculating on something that he doesn't want to see happen,'' Bush said Thursday. He spoke as Soviet armored personnel carriers moved through the Lithuanian capital of Vilnius in a show of force Thursday and leaders of the rebellious Baltic republic appealed for world support. The president, at a news conference, urged the Soviets to refrain from using force to put down Lithuania's independence move.

Flushed with a feeling of victory after three acquittals and a conviction on a minor misdemeanor, Exxon Valdez skipper Joseph Hazelwood says he longs to return to the sea as a ship captain. His lawyer, Michael Chalos, said he will start negotiating with Exxon to regain the skipper's job with the shipping company that hired him out of college and fired him after his tanker grounded a year ago, causing the nation's worst oil spill. ``I'd like to go back to the sea. That's what I do,'' Hazelwood said Thursday after jurors absolved him of accusations he was reckless and drunk during the disaster that blackened the rocky shoreline of Prince William Sound. The misdemeanor charge of negligent discharge of oil on which Hazelwood was convicted carries a maximum sentence of 90 days in jail and a $1,000 fine, far less than the 7\ years and $61,000 fine he could have faced if found guilty on all four charges.

Response to an oil spill as big as the one that polluted Prince William Sound, Alaska, a year ago wouldn't be much better today than it was then, officials say. ``We don't believe recovery capability is where it should be,'' Larry Dietrick of the Alaska Department of Environmental Conservation told a congressional hearing Thursday. C.M. Harrison, executive vice president of Exxon Corp., said his company is concentrating on spill prevention, but also has upgraded response procedures. However, he said he couldn't guarantee that an 11-million-gallon spill, like that from the tanker Exxon Valdez on March 24, 1990, would be fully recovered or kept off the shore.

The Idaho Legislature's approval of the most restrictive state abortion law sets the stage for a possible test of the U.S. Supreme Court's commitment to legalized abortion. ``The people of Idaho have said strongly what millions of Americans believe, that abortion is not an acceptable means of birth control,'' said National Right to Life Committee legislative director Doug Johnson. But the American Civil Liberties Union and Planned Parenthood announced they would challenge the measure passed Thursday if it becomes law. ``It's got a wide-ranging impact beyond the understanding of the people who voted for this here,'' said Jack Van Valkenburgh of the ACLU.

Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's candidate suffered a spectacular defeat in a special parliamentary election, losing a Conservative Party stronghold in a rebuke of a new tax and high interest rates. The opposition Labor Party today rejoiced in seizing the prosperous central England district of Mid-Staffordshire, overturning a majority of more than 14,000 for the Conservatives' worst loss in a special election in half a century. The Conservative loss Thursday was likely to renew speculation that worried rank-and-file legislators might try to dump Mrs. Thatcher as leader before the next general election, due by mid-1992. Labor leader Neil Kinnock today called the victory ``monumental'' and said it marked a turning point for the Conservatives who ``are going to have to make up their minds how quickly they get rid of Mrs. Thatcher.''

DOC.HEAD: Vietnamese Refurbish Historic Hotel
DOC.TEXT: It may have been the best-known 500 square yards of the Vietnam War: the Continental Hotel terrace, where spies, soldiers and journalists met at sunset to swap tales and numb the horror with drink. After years as a military headquarters and extensive remodeling, the Continental and its ``Shelf,'' as the terrace was called, are open again and catering to the business crowd. The Continental was built between 1910 and 1915, in the French era, and initially welcomed a colonial cast of rubber planters and Foreign Legionnaires. Then the Americans came to fight, and to spend their dollars on the Shelf. Every night, they were ambushed by prostitutes, crippled beggars, pickpockets and the doe-eyed urchins selling flowers, whom hardly any could resist. That era ended in April 1975, when North Vietnamese tanks rolled into Saigon. Saigon became Ho Chi Minh City. The French-owned Continental was summarily nationalized, as was the Rex a block down the street, where American officers lived and played. Vietnamese military officers occupied the Continental for 13 years while communist authorities tried to impose their will on the free-wheeling southerners, with less than gratifying success. Six months ago, the Continental began its fourth life. After two years of renovations, the hotel opened its 72 rooms to tourists and the foreign businessmen who are flocking to economically liberalized Vietnam. War and its traditional intrigues are gone from the Shelf. The talk on the terrace these days is of investment opportunities, cheap labor, bureaucratic snags and how to get around orthodox communist functionaries. Military green and safari jackets are the stuff of ghosts, replaced by the once-scorned jacket and tie. The rooms on the three floors above are occupied by company executives and deal makers. They come from Taiwan, Japan, Hong Kong, Thailand, Western Europe and from the United States, although Americans are barred by their government from doing business in Vietnam. Old-timers notice other changes, sometimes with regret. The Shelf has been glassed in, air-conditioned, adorned with neo-Grecian columns and crystal chandeliers. ``What I remember most about the Continental is the open terrace, the ceiling fans, the colonial atmosphere,'' George Belcher said. ``Now that's all gone.'' Belcher, back on a visit, spent four years in Vietnam with the U.S. aid mission. Dao Huu Loan, the manager, said the Continental's history and architecture were of prime concern in the renovation. ``These days, around the world, there is a tendency to pull everything down, destroy tradition and the beauty of the past,'' he said. ``We have made some changes, but the basic structure is the same.'' Rooms cost an average of $70 a night, payable in U.S. dollars, and Loan said the occupancy rate was 85 percent so far this year. He hopes the Vietnam Year of Tourism proclaimed by the government will attract more non-business travelers. ``The most important thing is to improve the service every day,'' the manager said. He told an interviewer the 120 hotel employees receive above-average salaries, plus bonuses for good performance. Loan's government-run parcel of history competes with a capitalist oasis of luxury its general manager, A. Patrick Imbardelli, calls ``a monument to the new era in Vietnam.'' Imbardelli's Saigon Floating Hotel is a 200-room steel behemoth that may mar the exotic atmosphere of the Saigon River, but offers foreigners direct- dial telephone service, French cheeses, California wines and a business center with personal computers. Most of the guests so far have been businessmen, said Imbardelli, the first foreigner to run a hotel in this communist country. His hotel used to be anchored at Australia's Great Barrier Reef, but did less business than its owners expected and was moved to the Saigon River docks last year. It is an Australian-Japanese venture.

DOC.HEAD: Wall Street: What A Mess
DOC.NOTE: Eds: retransmitting to fix numbering
DOC.TEXT: The investment community is looking messy. The domestic securities industry has been forced to cut tens of thousands of workers since the great crash of October 19, 1987, and still some of its members are hurting financially. In the final quarter of 1989 the industry lost about $92 million. Almost half the brokerage house members of the New York Stock Exchange were in the red. The price of a seat on the Big Board is down. The junk bond market has just about collapsed. Takeovers, buyouts and mergers, which helped some of the firms, have declined in number recently and are likely to continue to do so. The investment community's reputation has been tarnished by scandals, questionable practices and volatile prices. The public is upset. The amount of stock held by individual investors shrank last year by $104 billion. Individuals aren't the only sellers. Federal Reserve figures show private pension funds, the biggest bundle of funds in the world, cut their U.S. stock holdings last year by $20 billion. Many were attracted to foreign stocks. Some big institutions, generally friends of Wall Street, have been hurt. Hard as it might be to believe, insurance companies and pension funds, usually the most conservative investors, hold 45 percent of all junk bonds issued. Some of those bonds are selling for less than half their purchase price. Moreover, some of the issuers are in deep financial difficulty and find it difficult to maintain the huge interest rates they promised to pay. Adding insult, foreigners seem to be doing OK. They became wary right after the big collapse in 1987, but now they seem to be moving back in. Last year foreigners were net buyers of $8 billion worth of stocks. More significantly, foreign brokers seem to be thriving right in the same territory vacated by domestic brokers. While American brokers hold wakes, some British, Japanese and Swiss firms celebrate by hiring and expanding. The future is liable to be more competitive for the domestic industry. Competition from foreigners isn't the sole reason. As important, perhaps, is the fact that there are far fewer shares to sell than there used to be. A lot of fee money poured into the investment community via takeovers, mergers, leveraged buyouts. But that big money came at a big price. Those very activities shrank the amount of U.S. equities outstanding by $472 billion. It was accomplished through the departure of some very large companies with their very large equities, gobbled up by other companies that substituted debt for equity, junk bonds for shares. Not all is lost. You may be sure that imagination and nerve are still alive in the investment community. There are those, for example, who'll bundle up those junk bonds and somehow peddle them in a package. Moreover, it shouldn't be forgotten that companies that took their shares off the market by going private might go public again. It is often observed that when a broker convinces you to sell, he or she has made more than one transaction. The sale is one, the purchase of another stock is the second, the sale of that is the third, and so on. Buy or sell, the commission is the same. It's the same with going private and then returning as a public company. There is money either way. It has the appearance of what they call a win-win situation, but it isn't, because an already wary public is bound to become further disenchanted with the whole buisness.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Friday, March 23.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Another Look: Mount St. Helens, Adv 26,1282
DOC.NOTE: $Adv26
For Release Mon PMs, March 26, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Quake 10 Years Ago Was First Sign Mount St. Helens' Fuse Was Lit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Donal is cq in 25th graf, ``For Crandell...'
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: At 4.1 on the Richter scale, the earthquake on the afternoon of March 20, 1980, was no great shakes. It knocked snow off the north face of Mount St. Helens but went virtually unnoticed in the surrounding counties of southwestern Washington. Nearly 130 miles to the north, the line traced by a wandering pencil on a seismograph at the University of Washington was first interpreted as evidence of a tremor 75 miles southeast of the dormant volcano. But on closer inspection, seismologists determined the quake had occurred under the mountain, and relatively close to the surface. It was the first recorded sign that Mount St. Helens' volcanic fuse was lit. One week later, on March 27, the volcano belched steam and ash in its first eruption in 123 years. The accompanying 4.7-magnitude quake sent seismic needles skittering. Fifty-two days after that, on May 18, 1980, the mountain exploded spectacularly. The eruption killed 57 people and sent ash around the world. In an instant, 1,300 feet of the mountain disappeared, fully a fifth of its towering majesty simply blown away. The smoking, raw-edged crater left behind stunned residents of Washington and Oregon used to gazing out at a symmetrical, snowcapped peak. ``It woke people up to the fact that having a volcano in your back yard can be dangerous,'' said Dwight Crandell, retired from the U.S. Geological Survey. In 1978, Crandell helped write a report that predicted an eruption at Mount St. Helens this century. The blast was also a wake-up call for volcanologists around the world. In the 1970s, only two countries with volcanic mountains were examining the dangers of nearby human settlements. Today 16 countries have active studies under way, Crandell said by telephone from his home in Denver. ``It's clear that the 1980 eruption was a sensation for the science of volcanology,'' said geologist Steve Brantley, stationed at the USGS Cascade Volcano Observatory in Vancouver, Wash., about 45 miles southwest of Mount St. Helens. About 80 scientists work at the observatory, built after the eruption. UW seismologist Steve Malone said the March 20 earthquake was strong enough to draw attention to the area but not so unusual as to make scientists suspicious that molten rock was squeezing into crevices deep under the earth. ``Earthquakes at the volcano are not unheard of,'' Malone said. ``They generate a bit of interest but not immediate alarm.'' But quakes kept coming, increasing in number and strength. Three days after the initial quake, UW seismologists warned the USGS about a ``potentially serious situation.'' ``This was when we first suspected we might be on to something other than just a small earthquake swarm,'' Malone said. Teams of geologists arrived to set up equipment to monitor ground movement and the gases emitted each time the volcano burped. Seismologists stayed close to their machines. The Forest Service began warning people to stay clear of the mountain because of avalanches. But the scientists were not working in isolation. Scores of eager newspaper and broadcast reporters joined the crush. Researchers accustomed to working in geologic time, in a science where more is unknown than known, were being asked to provide instant answers for that evening's news and the next morning's newspapers. ``I remember ... being a bit overwhelmed by the media interest this was already generating,'' Malone said. ``All we had was data and some possibilities and a lot of questions.'' Meantime, the ground was moving at postcard-perfect Spirit Lake, at the mountain's foot. Chuck Tonn, who ran the Forest Service desk at the lake, hung a pencil from a string to show the faint shaking. The lake was evacuated Tuesday morning, March 25. ``I was glad to leave that morning,'' Tonn said. ``That last night, I don't think any of us slept. ... It seemed like there was always some movement going on.'' Not everyone left. Harry Truman, the 83-year-old owner and keeper of rustic Spirit Lake Lodge, dug in his heels. Truman said he would stay on the mountain that had been his home for 50 years, the mountain that eight weeks later would kill him. In the media catering to the nation's rising anticipation, Truman became a cantankerous folk hero. Another local, Stan Lee, 67, owner of the Kid Valley Store about 20 miles from the peak, snorted at talk of a possible eruption and accused the Forest Service of plotting to squelch development. Two days later, the mountain blew. That first eruption shot a black plume almost a mile and a half high. By mid-April, the stark gray and brown hollow of a crater had replaced the mountain's snowy point, once 9,677 feet above sea level. Ashfalls in the region were commonplace, with fickle winds determining who got dusted next. May 18, 1980, the day the mountain finally blew its top, is now designated Eruption Day in Geological Survey books. On those who were there and experienced the power and awe and terror, Mount St. Helens has left its mark as clearly as the eruption scarred the landscape. ``I feel fortunate to have been at Mount St. Helens from the beginning all these 10 years,'' said Tonn, who now manages the Forest Service's visitors' center west of the 110,000-acre National Volcanic Monument. ``It (eruption) kind of puts me in my place. It puts me in awe of what can happen.'' For Crandell and fellow USGS geologist Donal Mullineaux, the eruption was right on time. After studying dormant Cascade Range volcanoes in the 1960s and 1970s, they predicted in 1978 that Mount St. Helens would likely erupt relatively soon. ``Everything we found indicated it was a very young volcano, and a very explosive volcano, and a frequently active volcano,'' which last erupted in 1857, Crandell said. ``We felt almost sure the volcano would erupt, and sooner rather than later. That is what the history told us.'' While some public officials greeted their hazard report seriously, there were also snickers, the two scientists said. ``A lot of people made fun of it, of course,'' Mullineaux said. Crandell said he was gratified that many countries with volcanoes have since made use of their work in hazard assessment, including New Zealand, Japan, Italy, Mexico, Equador and Colombia. The eruption of Colombia's Nevado del Ruiz in November 1985 provides an example of how hazard assessment could have helped, Crandell said. An assessment had been completed, and hazard zones had been laid out, including likely flood and mudflow zones at the town of Armero. But word never reached local officials. There were no evacuations and 25,000 people perished. Mount St. Helens prompted gains in both volcanology and seismology. Since 1980, scientists have learned to better predict volcanic eruptions by studying earthquake activity, including the ``harmonic tremors'' that indicate movement of molten earth. Other volcanic mysteries are also better understood, Crandell said. These include the devastating sideways force of the May 1980 eruption, the fast-moving and deadly mixtures of matter and gas known as pyroclastic flows and surges, and the mudflows that let loose in minutes after vibrations turn snowfields into walls of water. Mullineaux and Crandell retired in the mid-1980s, but both remain active in research on Mount St. Helens. ``I can't leave it alone,'' Crandell said.

DOC.HEAD: Veteran Hollywood Observer Observes Oscar Night
DOC.TEXT: In 1969 and 1970, veteran Hollywood observer Harry Shearer covered the Oscar Awards show as a member of a radio comedy troupe, Credibility Gap. They had press credentials and everything. They did deliberately what some reporters do accidentally on Oscar night, he recalls: ``We went with the avowed purpose of asking the most inane questions anybody could ask of winners, like, `Have you ever been to New York?''' Alas, Shearer won't be covering tonight's Oscar show, which starts at 9 p.m. EST and will be televised live by ABC. He's not even going, even though he once co-wrote and appeared in the noted rock documentary film, ``This Is Spinal Tap.'' But he'll be back in journalism, sort of, on April 18, reporting results of a national celebrity poll in an NBC special, ``Spy Magazine Presents How to Be Famous.'' The magazine's mission is to poke fun at those in need of poking. Shearer, a contributing editor to the publication, say the NBC show ``is about the whole idea of being a celebrity in America, what it takes to be one and to stay one. ``The SPY study is pretty scientific _ at least as scientific as the research film studios do to discover what movies to make,'' he said. ``They go into a shopping mall and ask three people, `Would you like to see three men and an alien? Three aliens and a baby?' '' Shearer knows whereof he speaks, having been born in Los Angeles and in show business since he was a tyke. His big break was the 1953 film classic, ``Abbott and Costello Go to Mars.'' A veteran of ``Saturday Night Live'' and various cable ventures, including his own HBO special, ``The Magic of Live,'' he currently does various voices on Fox Broadcasting's hit ``The Simpsons.'' He also conducts a weekly National Public Radio show, ``Le Show,'' from KCRW-FM in Santa Monica, Calif. He may or may not use the radio show as a forum for thoughts on Monday's Oscar festival. It depends. However, he says, ``I'm uniquely qualified to comment on the Oscar show because I followed my usual policy of not seeing any of the nominated pictures.'' Shearer has an alternate-year policy. One year he avoids the Oscar show, the next year he's watching the thing on TV with friends, ``just laughing our way through the evening.'' ``Because to me, the best thing about the Oscar show is the marvelous bad fit between the joke-writing and the people who have to say the lines. The writing and the performances come from two different planets.'' But he isn't against the Oscar show. Far from it. ``Actually, of all the unnecessary award shows that seem to have proliferated ... this is the only one that makes any sense at all,'' he submits. ``Because it's the only one where, immediately afterwards, whoever wins an award gets more money.''

Elsewhere in television: AND THE WINNER IS, PART 14: Another awards show will arrive April 25, the 26th annual ``Academy of County Music Awards.'' To be shown on NBC, it will originate from ... Nashville? Nooo. Hollywood. ANOTHER REASON TO CONTINUE LIVING: CBS on April 3 will show a TV movie of high drama, ``Laker Girls.'' CBS says it is about three young women ``whose lives change when they become part of the famous dance squad that performs at home games'' for the Los Angeles Lakers.

DOC.HEAD: Squatter Camp Defies Government
DOC.TEXT: When the bulldozers came to raze Mohammad Massoud's home, the call for help went out to his squatter neighborhood and men from 30 houses answered. They attacked the bulldozer drivers, forcing them to flee. Paramilitary troops arrived, wielding sticks and truncheons, but Massoud's friends drove them off. The battle for Massoud's house was one of a hundred skirmishes that have earned the squatter settlement of 5,000 people the name Zorabad, or ``People Power Village.'' ``With nothing but our bare Afghan fists, we took on the government and won,'' said Massoud, seated in his sparsely furnished house built of mud bricks. ``That is how we got our name.'' For the time being, at least, Zorabad is ahead. In late 1989, the government abandoned almost seven years of efforts to remove the people and their single-story mud houses from government land. Now the community's elders are negotiating with officials to supply electricity. The name Zorabad brings a smile to the lips of many Afghans, whose tradition is one of independence and casual regard for authority. In a capital closely patrolled by military and intelligence forces, the squatter village on the northern outskirts represents a rare victory of the people over those in charge. Zorabad also has a wider significance. It illustrates the return of President Najib's Soviet-sponsored government to the old Afghan ways, in which local tribes pledge loyalty to a central government but retain control of local affairs. After abandoning efforts to evict the squatters, officials generally have ignored Zorabad. A new effort to collect taxes is made now and then, but the people say they won't pay unless they get services. Zorabad has no schools, garbage collection, doctors, running water or electricity. One city official, who would not discuss the situation unless his name wasn't used, said the government's main desire was that Zorabad's politically sensitive name be changed to Nawabad, or ``New Village.'' Disputes within Zorabad are resolved by elders. One of the elders, Said Mahmoud, explained: ``Only when we have a serious crime do we ask for police, and then they don't really like to come here. Last week, two clans had a fight over food. There were many casualties, but we handled it alone.'' Most residents come from northern Afghanistan, which was heavily bombed during the nine years of Soviet combat support for the government's war against Moslem guerrillas. Soviet bombing raids seven years ago leveled Shakardarah, Mahmoud's home village 18 miles north of Kabul. He lost four sons, his small pharmacy and several acres of grapes. ``We had no place to go,'' he said. ``We didn't want to go to Pakistan or Iran, so we came here.'' Millions of Afghans have fled to the two neighboring countries. Hundreds of other families from Shakardarah came to Kabul with a horde of refugees from all over the country, looking for work and shelter. Kabul's population had more than doubled, to 2.25 million, by the end of the Soviet intervention on Feb. 15, 1989. It seems to be declining now, as some people return home to areas where fighting has eased. When refugees were streaming into Kabul, demands on the government's scarce resources were overwhelming and it did little or nothing to help them. So, Mahmoud said, ``some of us from my village had a meeting, and we decided to seize government land.'' Their chosen site is adjoined on two sides by comfortable government housing and adjacent to Kabul's dog-fighting fields. Refugees from other villages joined Massoud's people, built homes and found jobs. Many now are truck drivers, engaged in the lucrative smuggling trade with Pakistan, and others work in auto repair shops or as street sweepers. The government sent emissaries to ask the squatters to leave Zorabad, apparently at the urging of officials living in the neighboring apartment complex. Massoud and the others refused and continued to build, expanding their small clusters of houses into a warren of thousands. Alleyways twisted this way and that; small shops opened, selling dried fruits and nuts. Then the bulldozers came. After the paramilitary troops were turned back, officials arranged a truce in an effort to avoid bloodshed. That was in late November. No more bulldozers have appeared. Residents say they're happy to be left alone, but would like to tap into the power lines that carry electricity past them to the government apartment buildings. At night, when the apartments blaze with lights and television serials flicker through the windows, Zorabad looks like an old ruin. ``We call ourselves `People Power Village','' Massoud said, ``but our power is not enough.''

DOC.HEAD: Americans Like the Death Penalty in Theory, But Not in Practice
With AM-California Execution, b0467
DOC.TEXT: Each time the U.S. Supreme Court issues a major capital punishment ruling, a blood bath is predicted at the nation's death houses. But execution statistics do not bear out those fears. California, which has the country's third-largest death row population, is preparing for its first execution in 23 years, set for April 3. Capital punishment opponents say the prolonged period between executions is indicative of Americans' ambivalence about the death penalty: They support it in theory, but not in practice. A recent survey indicated 79 percent of Californians polled favored the death penalty in general. But 67 percent preferred the option of life in prison without parole combined with a work program, an alternative not currently available in the state. ``When people are given the alternative of life rather than the death penalty, people will (choose) life,'' said Ramona Ripston, director of the American Civil Liberties Union of Southern California. ``I think the poll shows people don't want to kill people.'' States have executed 121 people since the Supreme Court allowed the revival of death penalty statutes in 1976. Thirty-six states have death penalty laws, under which some 200 people are sentenced each year. Sixteen murderers were executed nationwide in 1989, up from 1988's 11 but down from 1987, when 25 men were gassed, electrocuted or poisoned intravenously. The Supreme Court has issued three major opinions in the past three years that opponents feared would speed the rate of executions. In 1989, in two separate rulings, the justices refused to call a blanket halt to the execution of retarded people or convicts who committed capital crimes as 16- and 17-year-olds. And a 1987 ruling in a Georgia case held that death penalty laws can be valid even if statistics suggest they are carried out with racial bias. ``The reason that the floodgates did not open following those landmark decisions, in my opinion, is that reason prevails in matters as serious as capital punishment,'' said Stephen Merrill, former attorney general of New Hampshire, a state with a death penalty statute but no one on death row. ``Even those of us who favor capital punishment are very slow and very cautious concerning its use as a tool within the criminal justice system,'' Merrill said. The court this year is reviewing more than a half-dozen death penalty cases, but none is expected to yield a ruling with dramatic results. Americans generally favor the death penalty when surveyed, but once people start dying, fewer folks support the process, said Wellborn Jack Jr., a defense lawyer in Shreveport, La. ``Until the death penalty came back and we started having executions, it was a real easy thing to say, `I'm for the death penalty,''' Jack said. ``You had to kill some people. Now that we've killed them, and we did have the floodgates open up, people don't want to be a part of it.'' In July 1989, the latest national figures available, there were 2,264 men and 25 women on the nation's death rows. Florida had the most with 294, followed by Texas with 283, California with 247 and Georgia with 102. Louisiana had 39. Texas has executed 33 convicts, Florida 21, Louisiana 18 and Georgia 14, said Karima Wicks, research director of the capital punishment project of the NAACP Legal Defense and Education Fund in New York. The South is by far the deadliest region for condemned killers, she said. ``We are a more bloodthirsty region,'' Wicks said. ``Executions in the South are sort of latter-day lynchings.''

DOC.HEAD: Campaigns and Causes Try New Tactics To Raise Cash
DOC.TEXT: For $2 a minute, anyone with a phone can hear a ``Beat Helms'' message sponsored by a critic of Sen. Jesse Helms of North Carolina. For $12.50 a month, anyone with a bank account can support Helms and other Senate Republicans by allowing automatic deductions from their bank books. In the competition for campaign cash, candidates and political groups are trying out new fund-raising gimmicks and dusting off reliable old ones. ``It gets intense out there when everyone is asking, so sometimes being different works,'' said Michelle Davis, executive director of the Republican Governors Association. Davis describes the traditional fund-raiser like this: ``You dress up, you go to a dinner, you listen to people give speeches, you write your check and you go home.'' The big money in politics still comes from these big-name fund-raising dinners and from the huge ``soft money'' contributions that corporations and labor unions make to party organizations. But some of the newest fund-raising methods rely on high-tech gimmicks such as 900-number telephone lines and electronic fund transfers that allow fast and easy access to contributors' bank accounts. The Republican governors' group, meanwhile, is adding a little glitz but sticking to basics as it tries to offer contributors more than a chicken dinner for their checks. The group is holding smaller, more intimate sessions at which donors can chat with governors and other prominent Republicans. ``We have to do more than we have in the past _ to add a little cachet,'' Davis said. The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, which helps elect Democrats to the House, this year added the Preakness to the lineup of big sporting events for which it offers tickets in exchange for contributions. Super Bowl parties long have been fund-raising favorites. The committee, hard pressed for cash, also is raising more money than ever from Democratic incumbents who have cash to spare in their huge campaign war chests. The anti-Helms effort, sponsored by a North Carolina State University professor, is but one example of the growing popularity of 900 phone lines as a political tool. The National Rifle Association started the trend a year ago and quickly raised $2.5 million. Kent Hance, defeated in the Texas GOP gubernatorial primary this month, charged $3.95 a call for a message from his anti-tax group. The campaign pocketed $2 a call. The Helms and Hance phone lines come cheap when compared with the two 900 lines set up by Republican Sen. Phil Gramm of Texas, the Senate's 1989 fund-raising king. The senator charged $25 and $50 for two 900 lines that gave callers recorded voter registration information and details about a fund-raiser Gramm was holding with President Bush. The Federal Election Commission has looked at a number of legal questions related to political use of 900 lines, which critics say can easily be used to avoid or bend contribution limits. Democrats also are raising questions about the National Republican Senatorial Committee's ``Candidate Escrow Funding'' program _ the $12.50 a month direct-deposit gimmick. Participants get a $25 check in exchange for authorizing monthly bank debits that will increase 10 percent a year. ``Leave it to the Republicans to figure another way to con you,'' Texas Democratic Chairman Bob Slagle said of the GOP effort. The Republicans have revised the fund-raising letter that goes with the $25 check to make it clearer that people will pay out more than that in the long run and have set up a toll-free telephone line to answer questions. Some more traditional fund-raising gambits also still stir controversy from time to time, such as mailings that cash in on someone's name without their permission. Some 200,000 letters mailed out by ``Friends of Dan Quayle'' late last year sought contributions to support the conservative agenda, yet Quayle had nothing to do with the mailing and gets none of the money. The donations go to the Congressional Majority Committee, a conservative political action committee that used Gramm's name in a similar pitch several years ago. Provided such fund-raising letters include a disclaimer, there isn't much Quayle or any other politician can do to stop the practice. Railing against enemies is another proven fund-raising gimmick, and Democrats put it to use with a new twist late last year. The party jumped out ahead of the Republicans by soliciting money to counter anticipated attacks against its candidates by GOP operatives Lee Atwater, Roger Ailes and Ed Rollins.

DOC.HEAD: O'Connor's Vote Often the Deciding One on High Court
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3 grafs for 24th graf pvs, Critics are ... court redress., to update with Idaho abortion law passage
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX12 of March 22
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court's nine members are among the most private of public officials. They wield enormous political power but rarely hold news conferences or give interviews. Recent polls indicate only one in three Americans can name any of the nine. This, the fifth in an occasional series, offers an up-to-date look at one member of the nation's high court.

The night before she was to undergo cancer surgery in 1988, Sandra Day O'Connor drove nearly seven hours to keep a longstanding commitment to deliver a college lecture. Completing that chore seems hardly suprising for the hard-working and strong-willed Supreme Court justice who, as she turns 60 on Monday, is arguably the nation's most powerful woman. The high court's first and only woman, she is unquestionably a figure of historic significance. O'Connor can exert unusual influence over divisive issues confronting American society, particularly abortion rights. As the most moderate member of a new but slender conservative court majority, her vote often holds the key in 5-4 rulings that define American law. Feminists and civil libertarians are disappointed she has not wielded her power more forcefully for women's rights, minorities and the poor. But her performance sometimes leaves conservatives, including a fellow justice, less than fully satisfied. Few question her energy or independence. ``From the get-go she's called her own shots,'' said Robert Jerome Glennon, a law professor at the University of Arizona. ``I find her a fascinating figure,'' he said, noting she is the only justice who ever held elective office and apparently still draws on that experience. She was a member of the state Senate in her native Arizona in the early 1970s and rose to majority leader, the first woman in the country to hold such a position. O'Connor, who declined to be interviewed for this article, says she averages 60 hours a week on the job, including Saturdays. She also often takes work home with her. She had a breast removed in cancer surgery in 1988, followed by months of chemotherapy treatment. It hardly seemed to slow her, and she reports she is fully recovered. The night before the operation O'Connor drove to Lexington, Va., to lecture at Washington & Lee University. She was back on the bench 10 days later. She and her lawyer husband, John, maintain an active social life that includes tennis, golf and frequent appearances on the Washington party circuit. She also organized an exercise class at the court and works out first thing in the morning. ``It's just part of my routine and has been for a very long time in Arizona,'' she has explained. O'Connor may have acquired her resilience growing up on the family's 162,000-acre cattle ranch in Arizona, where as a child she learned to ride a horse, mend fences and shoot a rifle. She was thrust into the national spotlight in 1981 when then-President Reagan chose her, a relatively obscure state judge, to end 191 years of male exclusivity on the high court. ``My first year on the court made me long at times for obscurity,'' she said years later. Her prominence grew last year as the justices once again were asked to overturn their 1973 Roe vs. Wade ruling that women have a constitutional right to abortion. The court, including O'Connor, gave states new power to limit abortions. But she refused to provide the fifth vote conservatives needed to overturn Roe vs. Wade. An exasperated Justice Antonin Scalia, often an O'Connor ally, called her stand irrational. O'Connor never has cast a high court vote to overturn a state regulation on abortion. But Glennon, the Arizona law professor, sides with scholars who believe she never will cast the deciding vote to overturn Roe vs. Wade. ``Is Justice O'Connor, the first woman on the Supreme Court, going to provide the fifth vote to overrule the most important women's rights decision in the history of court? I think the answer is no,'' he said. A definitive answer may not be that far off as state legislatures enact restrictions on abortions that under Roe vs. Wade are clearly unconstitutional. For example, the Idaho Legislature passed a bill last week outlawing abortions except to protect a woman's life or physical health and in some cases of rape, incest and fetal deformity. If the bill is signed into law, it certainly will prompt a constitutional challenge that could reach the high court. On many issues, critics are troubled by O'Connor's willingness to limit individual rights and limit federal court redress. Nan Aron, director of the liberal Alliance for Justice, said O'Connor, who early in her career gave up practicing law for five years to stay home with her three sons, is an admirable role model for working women determined to be good parents. But O'Connor ``has not been a fighter for justice,'' Ms. Aron said. ``She's part of a majority on the court that seeks to limit and constrain the court's role in society. It's a disappointing trend.'' O'Connor has personal experience with sex bias. When she graduated third in her law school class at Stanford University in 1952, the only California law firm that wanted to hire her offered her a job as a secretary. On the court during oral arguments, she appears stern and straight-laced, sometimes sounding impatient as she interrogates lawyers with well-prepared questions. But friends say she drops the reserve in less formal surroundings and is gracious, caring and humorous. A couple of years ago O'Connor returned to El Paso, Texas, where she attended school as a child. Presented a key to the city, she got a laugh when suggesting that her ``frightening'' school principal, now deceased, might not have wanted her to have the key. O'Connor, who lives in Chevy Chase, Md., recently told her local paper, the Gazette, that she expects more women to be appointed to the court. ``And I hope I'm still on it when the first one arrives,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Successes, Setbacks, and `A Thousand Points of Hype'
An AP Extra
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The Census Bureau's attempt to count the homeless last week focused attention on the unknown numbers of Americans with nowhere to live. A decade after street people first captured the nation's sympathy, has real progress been made toward helping them?

The story of the home that Jack built is in many ways a typical tale of the homeless, except that it has a happy ending. Out of work in the Midwest where he grew up, Jack heard about jobs in Colorado. En route, his old car broke down and he finished the trip by hitchhiking, dropped off finally at the Greyhound bus station in Denver. ``I had two dollars and some change in my pocket. I was in a position in my life that I'd never been in before: I had no idea what to do,'' said Jack, who declined to give his surname because he doesn't want his fellow workers to know about his past. ``I prayed that night, I'll tell you,'' he recalled. Through providence or the luck of the draw in a lottery for limited space, he got a bed _ and a new start _ at a shelter called Samaritan House. Its jobs program helped steer him toward temporary work moving furniture as he looked for a job with a future. Samaritan House helped him save money, too, with budget counseling and the opportunity to stay on even after he was working. These days, Jack has his own apartment. He's shopping for furniture. He's working as a fast-food restaurant manager, and, says Kathy Rembert of Samaritan House, ``now he's calling me when he has openings.'' There have been successes in the 10 years or so since Americans first recognized that thousands of their fellow citizens were homeless _ victims of circumstance like Jack as well as de-institutionalized mental patients, vagrant alcoholics and drug addicts. At the same time, there have been setbacks, even tragedies. Last November in Boston, a homeless Vietnam combat veteran was moved from the streets to a nursing home after his frostbitten hands and feet were amputated. Stubbornly, homelessness remains _ visible on the streets of every major city, hidden in rural shacks with neither heat nor water. It persists despite billions of dollars spent for shelters and emergency aid, despite polltakers' evidence that Americans want an urgent response from the government. President Bush has called homelessness a national tragedy. After years in which advocates for the homeless accused the government of indifference, the Bush administration has pressed for full financing of programs under the Stewart B. McKinney Act, the main homeless aid effort, which Congress passed in 1987, and has proposed other initiatives targeted at the homeless mentally ill, drug abusers and alcoholics. Those projects are part of a program called HOPE, for Home Ownership and Opportunity for People Everywhere. Bush's budget proposal for the coming year seeks about $1.2 billion for this program, including nearly $250 million for the ``hard-to-serve'' homeless. The remainder would be mainly to increase low-income housing. The homeless component would provide up to five years of rent subsidies for individuals, with the stipulation that communities match this assistance with rehabilitative services. ``The administration is committed to ending homelessness,'' said Anna Kondratas, assistant secretary of housing and urban development. ``And we're going to be prepared to do what it takes to get the homeless into permanent housing and to get them the kind of services they need to stay in that housing.'' Some homeless advocates are less than impressed. ``It's a turnaround of extremely modest proportions'' from the Reagan years, said Maria Foscarinis, who heads the National Law Center on Homelessness and Poverty in Washington. The low-income housing portion of Bush's proposal, she said, is ``extremely small ... when you consider all the cuts that have been made over the past few years.'' Advocates say a drop in appropriations for new housing for the poor in the 1980s contributed to homelessness, although HUD officials assert that spending merely shifted from construction to rent subsidies. Also blamed for causing homelessness are the loss of rooming house-type apartments to ``gentrification'' or deterioration, ``economic dislocation'' when unemployed people move in search of work, and the release of thousands of mental patients to the streets when institutions scaled back care. Last week's census in shelters and the streets was intended to provide a better guess at the number of homeless people, as estimates now range from 250,000 to more than 3 million. A survey by the U.S. Conference of Mayors last year found demand for shelter up by 25 percent in a year. Those who provide shelter say that's continuing. ``Seems like it's a never-ending thing,'' said Joe Flaherty, whose shelter in Little Rock, Ark., found 254 full-time jobs for residents last year and 211 the year before. It is expanding its quarters. Evan Doss, who oversees a shelter in Port Gibson, Miss., spoke of rural homelessness. ``We have people in abandoned cars and abandoned shacks ... living without electricity, without heat, without plumbing.'' Since 1987, McKinney Act and other federal funds for the homeless have amounted to more than $1.78 billion, according to HUD, with state, local and private spending adding even more. Still, said Fred Griesbach, executive director of the National Coalition for the Homeless in New York, many basic issues still go unaddressed. Seemingly large allocations such as the HOPE proposal need to be put in perspective, he said. ``People look at $250 million and say that's a lot of money,'' he said, but not when compared to amounts federal officials spent on the savings and loan failures. ``They're willing to put billions and billions to bail out the S&Ls, because that was a `crisis.' Homelessness is not perceived as a crisis.'' The administration's response, Griesbach said, has been ``a thousand points of hype.'' Although public sympathy has run high for the homeless, as indicated by polls, there have been signs of frustration that after years of work and billions spent, the homeless re-appear every day on corners. A number of cities, including Minneapolis and Tulsa, Okla., have passed ordinances regulating panhandling. Business owners in Atlanta, Philadelphia and other cities have complained. In New York, a man was charged with manslaughter in the death of a beggar he said attacked him and his young son. ``Do I see a backlash in the country? Yeah,'' said Ken Smith, who runs a shelter for homeless veterans in Boston. ``Why? Because I think they're becoming aggravated by the fact that they can't walk a city block without being asked for money.'' If the thousands of dollars given daily to panhandlers went to charitable programs for the homeless, some of those who support themselves by begging would be forced instead to go to those programs and get help, he said. Griesbach calls a backlash inevitable after all these years: ``Homelessness didn't go away. And there is a large number of people who felt, well, wait a minute _ we volunteered, we did our bit in church basements, we contributed to programs like Hands Across America. ``How come these people are still here?''

DOC.HEAD: Novelist Puts Prestige on Line in Campaign for Presidency
DOC.TEXT: Mario Vargas Llosa, the acclaimed novelist, has put his prestige on the line in trying to become president of his violent, troubled homeland. Vargas Llosa is the strong favorite to win the April 8 election and replace the populist Alan Garcia on July 28. Why does an urbane, international figure often mentioned for the Nobel Prize fight so hard for the mandate to govern an impoverished, chaotic nation bloodied by a savage leftist insurgency? Vargas Llosa says he overcame his distaste for politics and ignored the warnings of friends because he felt a responsibility to those who supported his campaign against the attempt to nationalize the banks in 1987. He organized a rally of 100,000 people against the bank takeover and told the crowd Garcia's plan was a totalitarian threat. That catapulted Vargas Llosa into the political arena. The author of ``The Green House,'' ``Conversation in the Cathedral,'' ``Aunt Julia and the Scriptwriter'' and many other works, has been there since. The maker of tales about Peru's jungle mysteries, its urban decay, its corrupt dictators and failed revolutionaries has not written a line for publication in two years. He acknowledges being frightened by the prospect of governing a nation that seems increasingly ungovernable. ``Peru's situation is enormously difficult and it's going to grow worse in coming months,'' he said during an interview in the second-floor library of his home on a cliff overlooking the Pacific. ``At the same time, I think Peru has a chance to recover precisely because of the magnitude of the crisis,'' he said. ``Paradoxically, a profound crisis leads a country to deep reforms. When it is a middling crisis, the illusion remains that what failed was men and not the system.'' His nation's crisis could not be much deeper. The output of the economy has shrunk 20 percent in two years. Inflation soared to 2,775 percent in 1989. Hundreds of thousands of people have lost their jobs. The decade-long rebellion of the Shining Path guerrillas, a fanatical Maoist group, has taken nearly 20,000 lives. Many Peruvians look to Vargas Llosa as a savior. They did the same with Garcia, who campaigned in 1985 as ``the president of hope'' and now is viewed as having failed miserably. ``It frightens me when I hear phrases like that at rallies; that is why I try not to make promises I can't keep,'' said Vargas Llosa. ``On the contrary,'' he said, ``I always say there is going to be a period of great sacrifice before Peru can begin to recover.'' Vargas Llosa, 54, preaches that a free market will halt the slide into anarchy. He contends government intervention has caused 20 years of economic decline and eliminating the thick net of controls is the only way to reverse it. ``When the market is allowed to operate freely, it produces great creative development,'' he said. Campaigning as the candidate of the Democratic Front, a center-right coalition, Vargas Llosa has spelled out the radical reforms he says are needed to make Peru a ``modern nation.'' He has avoided the slogans of previous presidential campaigns, preferring to risk votes with frankness about the social cost of his program. ``If I reach the presidency, the only thing that will give me sufficient strength to do what must be done is if the Peruvian people have elected me knowing exactly what to expect,'' he said. Vargas Llosa promises to sell all 232 state enterprises, most of which lose money, and slash hundreds of thousands of jobs from the bloated bureaucracy. A Vargas Llosa government would ease restrictions on foreign investment to create jobs and would end price controls, reduce import restrictions and force Peru's flabby, protected private enterprise to compete. ``I believe in competition,'' he said. ``I believe that our national industries should be competitive, efficient industries, not parasitic industries.'' He expects fierce resistance by business leaders who have profited from government favors and by Communist labor bosses who represent the country's bureaucrats. ``There are going to be many problems because a society in which the state has been the great distributor of privileges creates a dependent mentality in people,'' said the candidate, who came home in 1974 after living and writing for 15 years in Paris, London and Barcelona, Spain. His campaign takes him through streets piled high with rotting garbage, where children in rags and mothers with babies in their arms beg on every corner, where tear gas chokes innocents caught in clashes between riot police and striking workers. He visits public markets to talk with housewives who despair over food prices that are 25 times higher than 12 months ago. The author said he does not like politicking. ``I don't feel comfortable with it,'' he said. ``I try to take it in a sporting spirit with good humor, but it's hard work for me. You need a certain quota of histrionics, and I don't have it. I have to force myself to do these things.'' Vargas Llosa's image as a political amateur and his frankness about his plans for the country appeal to Peruvians fed up with easy promises, say analysts for polling firms. Surveys show him with about 45 percent of voter support in a field of 10. His closest competitors are Luis Alva Castro, former finance minister in the Garcia government, with 16 percent, and Alfonso Barrantes, a Marxist and former mayor of Lima, with 12 percent. Presidents of Peru are limited to one 5-year term, so Garcia could not run again. A majority is needed to avoid a runoff, and Vargas Llosa is confident of attracting enough undecided voters to get it. If a second round is necessary, polls show him winning by a landslide. Opponents have accused Vargas Llosa of tax evasion and planning an ``apocalyptic'' economic program to fulfill his pledge of cutting annual inflation to 10 percent. Nightly television commercials predict 30,000 percent inflation, food riots, mass starvation and escalating terrorism if he is elected. The spots show vultures walking through pools of blood. ``The campaign has confirmed my worst instincts about politics,'' Vargas Llosa said. ``It's a world that brings out the dirtiest things in men. Power attracts men and makes them willing to do anything to achieve it and hold on to it.'' When he opposed Garcia's attempt to nationalize the banks, a group of political independents rallied around Vargas Llosa and formed the Liberty movement. It later joined with the centrist Popular Action and conservative Popular Christian Party in the Democratic Front. ``At a certain point it became difficult to reject this candidacy,'' he said. ``It seemed to me unethical to say to people, after I had encouraged them to get involved, that this was as far as I was going, to say that I didn't want to risk my career as a writer.'' Will there be a novel about this some day? Vargas Llosa laughed and said: ``I don't know if it will be a novel, but if I survive this experience, I will have great material for a book. No doubt about it.''
