DOC.HEAD: New Cigarette for Women Angers Anti-Smoking Groups
With BC-Smoking-Troubles, b0756
DOC.TEXT: Anti-smoking activists say a tobacco company is exploiting femininity to sell poison by marketing a new cigarette designed specifically for women. Golden Tobacco Co. introduced the brand, called Ms, last month with a campaign aimed at career women. ``Who says a woman wants to be like a man?'' say advertisements that show young Indian women dressed in Western skirts and blouses instead of traditional saris. They appeal to the female smoker with ``an independent mind ... a liberated lifestyle ... who competes in a man's world.'' One critic, Taposh Roy, responds: ``Women who smoke like men will die like men.'' ``Why should a woman have a separate cigarette for herself?'' Roy asked. ``How is it less dangerous than a so-called man's cigarette?'' He said the company was exploiting femininity in a developing country at a time of increasing pressure against smoking in the West. Roy heads the anti-tobacco program of the private Voluntary Health Association of India. No figures are available on the number of women smokers in India, but a government survey found 25 percent of women 15 or older use tobacco by smoking, chewing, or eating it with betel leaf. Women in villages commonly smoke ``beedis'' or ``chuttas'' _ hand-rolled leaves stuffed with uncured tobacco _ but Ashis Nandy, a social scientist, said smoking is rare among urban women. Pinaki Pan of Golden Tobacco said the company decided to introduce a cigarette for women because ``there was a sizable market out there. Our market research showed that 50 percent of the target group bought imported brands.'' He said Ms offers women an alternative, and is ``a feminine cigarette _ sleeker, whiter and milder.'' ``We are not making a conscious attempt to entice non-smokers,'' Pak said. ``It is only the smokers, especially the career women, who are our intended consumers.'' Nandy said women smokers were considered ``liberated or of loose character'' until a few years ago, a view reinforced by Indian movies that showed female accomplices of the villains smoking and drinking liquor. ``The social stigma led to women smoking in the privacy of locked bedrooms or office bathrooms,'' said Padma Rao, a 34-year-old journalist who began smoking at 18. Ms. Rao said she smokes openly at home or at parties where it is acceptable, but still slips into the restroom at the office. Roy said women who were hesitant about smoking in public would be encouraged by the Ms ads to indulge openly. ``The closet smoker will come out, and the market is so rich that other companies will introduce their women's brands,'' he said. ``This is crazy, especially at a time when the tobacco industry is dying in the developed world.'' Twelve companies make cigarettes at 18 plants in India, which ranks third in tobacco production after China and the United States. The industry employs 20,000 people directly and millions indirectly. ``It is a woman's business if she wants to smoke, but to sell cigarettes only to women is nothing but asking more and more ladies to try smoking, a direct invitation to adopt cancer,'' said Ravinder Kumar, president of the National Salvation Front, an anti-corruption social group. Cigarette consumption in India increased 400 percent from 1970 to 1980, the latest decade for which figures are available, said Usha Luthra of the official Indian Council for Medical Research, A study by Ms. Luthra said 20 percent of adult deaths in India were traceable to health hazards related to tobacco use. ``Every effort should be made to make tobacco use an antisocial habit, be it at home, at work, in public places or at social gatherings,'' she said. She said treating tobacco-related cancers, cardiovascular diseases and chronic lung diseases cost the equivalent of $1.5 billion a year, $403 million more than the government earns in taxes and foreign exchange from tobacco sales.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, March 25

DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp.'s board of directors agreed to negotiate with United Airlines' labor unions on a proposed employee buyout of the company and threw the bidding open to other suitors. In a two-paragraph statement issued Thursday after a special meeting in New York, the board said it had directed its financial advisers to develop a plan for selling company assets, to consider buyout proposals from other parties and to address all other alternatives for increasing the value of its shares. Chicago-based UAL is the parent of United Airlines, the nation's second-largest carrier after American Airlines.

A jury acquitted Exxon Valdez skipper Joseph Hazelwood of being drunk and reckless in connection with the nation's worst oil spill but convicted him of a minor charge of negligent discharge of oil. After deliberating for just 10{ hours, the jurors on Thursday absolved Hazelwood of one felony and two misdemeanor counts stemming from the disaster, in which his tanker ran aground, spilling nearly 11 million gallons of oil into Prince William Sound on March 24, 1989.

The founder of 7-Eleven, a pioneer of convenience shopping and one of the best-known store chains, said it's selling control to a Japanese company because of crushing debts from a junk bond-financed buyout. The announcement Thursday by Southland Corp., which owns 7,000 7-Elevens in the United States, is one of the most dramatic examples yet of the problems facing U.S. companies that participated in the junk-bond craze of the 1980s. Southland said it agreed to sell 75 percent of its common stock for $400 million to Ito-Yokado Co. Ltd., Japan's second-largest supermarket operator, and longtime Southland affiliate 7-Eleven Japan, which Ito-Yokado controls.

The Bush administration asked a federal appeals court to dispell a legal cloud that could delay the president's savings and loan bailout and cost taxpayers millions of dollars. The Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision appealed on Thursday an order from U.S. District Judge Royce C. Lamberth blocking the takeover of a suburban Chicago savings institution, which has $1.1 billion in assets. Lamberth sided with Olympic Savings and Loan Association of Berwyn, Ill., in ruling Wednesday that acting thrift office director Salvatore R. Martoche and his predecessor, M. Danny Wall, were unconstitutionally appointed.

Eastern Airlines and its pilots union have agreed to an interim contract calling for a 25 percent wage cut and benefit concessions, the company announced. But the pact announced Thursday did not resolve the issue of rehiring more of the pilots who engaged in a sympathy strike with the Machinists union in March 1989.

A federal judge delayed accepting a guilty plea from General Development Corp. and ordered an independent expert to review a plan to monitor the company and repay thousands of people allegedly overcharged for its homes. U.S. District Judge Lenore Nesbitt gave conditional acceptance Thursday to guilty pleas from the home builder and two former executives pending review of pre-sentencing reports.

American farmers have been guaranteed a major portion of the Soviet Union's grain import market for another five years, officials announced. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter and U.S. Trade Representative Carla A. Hills said Thursday the new accord would increase the annual minimum shipments of U.S. grain to the Soviets to 10 million metric tons from 9 million tons.

IRS employees are answering correctly 78 percent of telephoned tax questions they address this year but barely one-third of calls are being answered at all, government auditors said. The accuracy rate is up significantly from 66 percent last year, the General Accounting Office said Thursday. But only 34 percent of callers are getting through, compared to 61 percent a year ago, it said.

President Bush is counting on the Soviet Union to limit its borrowing from a development bank being proposed to finance a Marshall Plan-type rebuilding of Eastern Europe, administration officials said. Under Secretary of the Treasury David Mulford said Thursday the Soviets are aware of U.S. concerns after meetings between the top finance and banking officials of the two countries here last week.

Stock prices fell Thursday for the third straight day on the New York Stock Exchange, as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials lost 32.21 points to close at 2,695.72. The dollar declined against most major currencies except the Japanese yen. Bond prices finished higher. Copper futures prices fell from five-month highs; precious metals advanced; grains and soybeans were mixed; cocoa futures surged; sugar retreated; energy futures fell; and livestock and meat futures were mostly higher.

DOC.HEAD: Small Businesses Get a Boost, But `Bush Sauce' Gets Canned
DOC.TEXT: When the government gets involved, can politics be far behind? Maine is spending $250,000 this year promoting Mexican hot sauce, Scottish scones and other native creations, but a small businessman who stirs a mean brew of ``Bush Sauce'' isn't getting any help. The state-run Maine Products Marketing Program publishes a catalog of crafts made by businesses with just a handful of employees. The state says last year's listing boosted sales by $9 million. A recently published second edition includes 130 products. ``The state's efforts, we feel, have been very, very productive,'' said May Davidson, who along with her husband, Jim, sells backyard wind chimes from North Country Wind Bells in Round Pond. ``I can think of one absolutely major account that we can attribute to them, and several other regular accounts, probably about a dozen accounts in all,'' she said. Don't tell that to Paul Hagen. The maker of ``Bush Sauce'' _ a green-tomato concoction said to be ``excellent with quail'' _ complains that politics kept him out of this year's catalog. ``What they're doing is a pretty rotten trick,'' said Hagen, whose one-man operation in Ogunquit churns out Bush Sauce in three flavors: original, wicked good and kinder, gentler. ``I wonder how they'd feel about Lincoln Logs.'' The state explains it has prohibited religious, political or sexually suggestive items from the catalog. But the new book features a picture and description of a limited-edition miniature of President Bush's summer home on Walker's Point in Kennebunkport that is produced by the Cheryl Spencer-Collin Studio in Eliot. ``Is that right?'' Department of Economic and Community Development spokesman Jim Thompson said Thursday. ``I didn't know about Walker's Point. Apparently, the committee let this one go. I don't know what the difference is.'' The state screens entries for the catalog, which is sent to numerous major distributors who are encouraged to buy things from Maine. Several businesses report good results from the program. Judith Monroe, an author who also bakes and sells Scottish oat scones at her Belleweather business in Hallowell, said the state has promoted her product through the catalog and a toll-free number stores can call, and helped with ideas on design, shipping and pricing. ``I've had people call from New York and say they've gotten my name from the Department of Agriculture,'' Ms. Monroe said. The Maine Department of Economic and Community Development said the program costs $250,000 a year. The program also provides money to let entrepreneurs show off their wares at out-of-state trade events, runs marketing sessions and even helps design labels to show that products are made in Maine. The catalog includes solid-wood furniture, musical instruments, toy lobsters and other products made by the state's craftsmen. There's even Mexican hot sauce made with pure chilis by The Mex restaurant in Ellsworth. But not the presidential poison. Hagen said Bush Sauce is doing well enough on its own through a marketing strategy that includes putting his name and address on each bottle so people who run across the sauce can find out how to get more. Democrats often send it to Republicans and vice versa, he said. Hagen even sent a bottle to President Bush and got a thank-you note from the White House staff. ``I wish he would try it on his broccoli,'' Hagen said, referring to the president's widely publicized disdain for the green vegetable. ``He might like it better.''

DOC.HEAD: `Texas Chain Store Massacre II' Gets Mixed Reviews
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Chriss in 3rd graf is cq
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Southland-Debt Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Southland Corp.'s plan to sell control to a Japanese company could face strong opposition from creditors who must approve a restructuring of $1.8 billion in junk bonds and other debt, analysts say. But the proposal by the owner of the 7-Eleven convenience store chain gets different views from opposite sides of the Pacific: Japanese analysts say the deal should go smoothly while some in the United States say it's shaky. ``The exchange offer ... will ensure a rapid descent toward bankruptcy,'' said Chriss Street, a managing director with Seidler Amdec Securities Inc. in Los Angeles. Southland said Thursday it agreed to sell 75 percent of its common stock for $400 million to Ito-Yokado Co. Ltd., Japan's second-largest supermarket operator, and longtime Southland affiliate 7-Eleven Japan, which Ito-Yokado controls. 7-Eleven is the world's largest convenience store chain, offering items ranging from milk and frozen foods to newspapers, hot coffee, video rentals and ``Slurpee'' slushed ice drinks. It began in 1927 as a Dallas ice house. Southland, which sought the Japanese buyer, said the deal hinges on the company's ability to get 32 bank creditors to restructure terms of its outstanding preferred stock and $1.8 billion in debt. Much of the debt is in high-interest junk bonds used to finance the $4.9 billion leveraged buyout by its founding Thompson family in 1987. Under a restructuring, the debt would be exchanged for new bonds and stock with a much lower face value. ``The Japanese acquisition asked the bondholders to put themselves at tremendous risk if Southland files for bankruptcy reorganization,'' Street said. ``It is a `trust me' situation. Bond holders and Southland are suffering from their original acquisition.'' A recent court ruling limiting bondholders' claims in a bankruptcy proceeding to the bonds' fair market value at the time of the exchange offer will hurt the deal's acceptance by creditors, he said. Mark Yim, an analyst with Baring Securities Inc. in Tokyo, said the deal makes good sense for Ito-Yokado, which is flush with cash after a successful introduction of point-of-sale systems for tracking inventory at check-out counters. ``Their profitability is among the highest in Japan,'' Yim said. ``That is all the more remarkable because what they sell _ food _ traditionally has a lower (profit) margin. Their cash position is very, very strong.'' Southland, to raise money for paying debt, sold its 58 Hawaiian stores to 7-Eleven Japan Co. Ltd. for $75 million cash last November. 7-Eleven Japan, Japan's largest convenience-store operator, operates 3,940 licensed stores. Ito-Yokado owns 50.3 percent of 7-Eleven Japan. Yim said the Japanese company and its affiliate ``could easily finance this whole deal out of what they have right now.'' ``We have been in a consumption boom for the past three years in Japan and all the retailers have been doing really well,'' he said. ``The retailers have very conservative management.'' The agreement, besides the company-owned 7-Elevens, includes Southland's six food processing centers and five distribution centers. Street said 7-Eleven, the world's largest convenience store chain with more than 47,000 full-time employees in the United States and Canada, is troubled not only by great debt but by an eroding competitive position. ``They were great pioneers in convenience stores,'' he said. ``But in the last number of years they have been a follower rather than a leader in serving the customer's needs.'' Under the agreement, the family of John P. Thompson, Southland's chairman, would retain a 15 percent stake in the company and positions on the board of directors. Street said that at the time Southland borrowed $2.5 billion for its 1987 buyout, the economic outlook was rosy during a takeover binge. ``Unfortunately, in the years since, Southland has had its competitive position eroded _ its competitive position in providing the customer convenience,'' he said. Soon after the buyout, dubbed by Wall Street as the ``Texas Chain Store Massacre,'' the company had problems meeting huge debt payments. It attempted to raise cash partly by selling such assets as a half-interest in Citgo Petroleum Corp., a major refiner. Southland lost $243.7 million in the first nine months of last year. Company officials acknowledged last November that Southland would not be able to meet debt payments by 1991 and was considering a financial restructuring.

DOC.HEAD: Thrift Adds Check Insurance to Customer Inducements
DOC.TEXT: A California thrift has lobbed a new grenade in the war to lure customers into banks and savings and loans: free insurance on many items purchased with personal checks drawn on its accounts. The offer by Coast Savings is akin to services already provided by American Express Co. and other credit card companies' ``gold cards,'' and a small but growing number of banks. ``We had had to do it. There's such a fierce competition for the checking account,'' Coast Savings President Gerrald D. Barrone said Thursday. ``There are more branches of S&Ls in the state than supermarkets.'' Analysts and bank and thrift officials said that if Coast succeeds, it may well trigger a new round in the customer-service battle. Since last summer, California banks have extended their Monday through Friday hours, opened on weekends, created branches in supermarkets and even started paying bonuses to customers if service lags. ``Everybody is after market share,'' said Dan Williams, a banking analyst with Sutro & Co. in San Francisco. ``If (deposit insurance) works for Coast, it may get to the point where everyone will have to do it.'' Barrone said a quarter of Coast's customers now have checking accounts, about 200,000 in all. The thrift hopes to improve that figure by 50 percent this year, taking in about $20 million a month in new checking accounts, he said. Purchases included in the program and paid for in full with Coast Savings checks are insured for 90 days against theft, loss, accidental breakage and fire. Manufacturers' warranties are doubled up to a year, so a 90-day warranty is good for 180 days. Claims can be filed through a toll-free, 24-hour number. The program begins Monday. Some items, such as vehicles, dwellings, coins, services, art objects, items used for business, and consumables such as fuel and food, are excluded from coverage. Coast, a savings and loan with $11.2 billion in assets and 125 branches around the state, is the first major California financial institution to provide such insurance. California's Napa Valley Bank and Valley National Bank of Arizona offer the service. Barrone said Coast pays an insurance company 86 cents per year per checking account for the insurance service. Checking accounts are a cheaper source of deposits than savings accounts and certificates of deposits. Financial institutions also try to provide multiple services to customers, and checking accounts are a good way to cement such an approach. ``We try to cross-sell _ it's the old idea of offering more services, like being a drug store instead of a pharmacy,'' Barrone said. Financial services consultant Bert Ely said the country is glutted with banks and thrifts. Coast's new program ``is taking place in the context of an extremely competitive industry,'' Ely said. Barrone said there are 56 financial institutions for every million people in the United States, compared to one per million in Japan and eight per million in Europe. Bigger banks were watching carefully. ``It's definitely something we're looking at and we're aware it's gaining in popularity, but we have no plans for a similar program at this time,'' said Kathleen Shilkret, a spokeswoman for San Francisco's Wells Fargo Bank, which set off the rush to extended hours last year. ``We currently offer the same type of program with our gold Visa and Mastercards,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Accountant Settles Charges in Pillsbury Case
DOC.TEXT: The head of accounting for a hotel corporation has agreed to settle charges that he allegedly traded on inside information about Grand Metropolitan PLC's bid for The Pillsbury Co. Without admitting or denying wrongdoing, Stuart A. Godfrey, agreed to pay more than $30,000 in fines and restitution, and to cooperate with investigators. In a civil complaint filed in New York, the Securities and Exchange Commission accused Godfrey, manager of corporate accounting at Inter-Continental Hotels Corp., of buying call option contracts on Pillsbury stock based on confidential corporate information. A call option is the right to buy 100 shares of a stock at a previously agreed-upon price by a predetermined date. Investors who buy call options are betting that a stock's price will rise sharply, enabling them to make a big profit on a small investment. Inter-Continental was a wholly owned subsidiary of Grand Met at the time and IHC's executive offices were located in the same building as the U.S. headquarters of Grand Met, a British food and beverage producer. Grand Met acquired Pillsbury in January 1989. According to the SEC, Godfrey, 31, of Larchmont, N.Y., violated his fiduciary duty to his employers when he allegedly utilized the non-public information about the bid for Pillsbury for his own profit. The SEC alleged he made $14,221 on call option contracts purchased before Grand Met's bid for Minneapolis-based Pillsbury was announced publicly on Oct. 4, 1988. Earlier this year, the SEC charged a Minneapolis lawyer, James H. O'Hagan, with making $4.3 million in alleged illegal profits using inside information misappropriated from his former firm, which was representing Grand Met. O'Hagan has not settled with the SEC, said Harry J. Weiss, an SEC attorney in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Simmons Fights Battle Over Lockheed on Lockheed Turf
DOC.TEXT: Texas investor Harold C. Simmons says he likely would sell about $1 billion worth of assets in Lockheed Corp.'s technology and electronics services businesses if he wins control of the company. Though a final decision would not be made until after a review of the company's financial records, Simmons said Thursday he probably would pressure managers to improve profits in the divisions, then sell unprofitable parts. Lockheed, the nation's sixth-largest defense concern, has deployed more than $2 billion in assets in the technology and electronics services divisions, which have produced scanty profits. Chief among the problem divisions is Sanders Inc. in Nashua, N.H., the second-largest employer in New Hampshire, according to Simmons and his chief lieutenant, J. Landis Martin. The defense electronics company was purchased by Lockheed in 1986. ``They spent $1.2 billion for Sanders,'' Martin said. ``That's far too much _ 1.4 times sales and 57 times earnings.'' He said annual return has been just 3.9 percent. Simmons, who heads NL Industries, a specialty chemicals concern, is trying to unseat Lockheed's board of directors at the company's annual meeting March 29. He contends current management has wasted money in attempts to diversify the company away from its core missiles, space and aeronautical divisions. On Thursday, Simmons took his crusade for control of Lockheed to an airport near where the aerospace giant developed the SR-71 ``Blackbird'' spy plane and stealth fighter. ``I don't consider myself a corporate raider. I consider myself a corporate builder,'' said Simmons, who has spent $530 million buying about 19 percent of Lockheed's stock and so far has lost about $100 million on that investment. Despite the loss and problems facing defense contractors as world tensions ease, Simmons maintained he was a long term investor in Lockheed. He purchased his stock at an average share price of $44. Lockheed closed Thursday up 25 cents at $35.62{ on the New York Stock Exchange. Simmons told reporters it was ``absolutely false'' his only interest in Lockheed was seeing his share price rise enough to get out without losing money. ``That's not my record,'' he said. The news conference, held near the super-secret ``skunk works'' where Lockheed became famous for developing secret military planes, was the latest in a nationwide series for Simmons. He has argued his case before securities analysts in New York and reporters in Georgia and New England, where Lockheed is a big employer. Lockheed Chairman Daniel Tellep has criticized Simmons, who also controls sugar and oil and gas servicing companies, as having no experience in aerospace and no clear vision for Lockheed. Simmons contends he had no experience in earlier businesses he purchased, but had made them profitable by concentrating on maximizing profits instead of emphasizing sales. Tellep has acknowledged that Lockheed has concentrated on increasing revenue in recent years. He has said he and his top managers now are focusing on profits instead.

DOC.HEAD: Infuses More Than $450 Million Into Failed Thrift
DOC.TEXT: Pinnacle West Capital Corp. said it injected about $465 million into MeraBank Federal Savings Bank and was released from obligations from its 1986 purchase of the savings and loan. Richard Snell, chairman of the $7 billion holding company, said Thursday the transfer of funds, including interest, consisted of about $310 million in cash and a $155 million unsecured note, payable in 12 years. He said the infusion ended Pinnacle West's obligation to MeraBank, which federal regulators seized Jan. 31. ``We have now put the MeraBank issue behind us. This ends a very difficult period for Pinnacle West and our shareholders but is only the beginning of the company's recovery plan,'' Snell said in a statement. Pinnacle West bought MeraBank in December 1986. Before it got rid of the state's largest thrift, it was forced to restructure $676 million in debt. The S&L, known as MeraBank before the Resolution Trust Corp. took over, lost over $200 million in both 1988 and 1989, leading to Pinnacle West's $551.4 million loss last year. Last Dec. 6, the RTC, the Office of Thrift Supervision and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. agreed to release Pinnacle West from a ``keep-well'' agreement in exchange for injecting $450 million into MeraBank to meet capital requirements. Snell said that before completing the infusion Thursday, the company closed an agreement with a consortium of financial institutions to provide long-term financing for the $310 million. Salomon Brothers Inc. of New York served as Pinnacle West's investment banker in the transaction. Pinnacle West previously had arranged interim financing through a group of New York banks to satisfy the agreement. Those funds were not used, Snell said. He added that he hoped to sell Malapai Resources Co., a uranium-mining company, by mid-year. Divestment of Malapai would leave Pinnacle West with just three subsidiaries, Arizona Public Service Co., the state's largest utility, Suncor Development Co., and El Dorado Investment Co.

DOC.HEAD: UAL Board To Negotiate With Unions on Employee Buyout Bid
DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp. has agreed to negotiate an employee buyout proposal with United Airlines' labor unions despite what it calls ``serious deficiencies'' in the latest offer. The company's board announced the talks Thursday in a statement issued after a special meeting in New York. But UAL also said the board had directed its financial advisers to develop a plan for selling company assets. It said advisers also should consider buyout proposals from other parties and discuss other alternatives for increasing the value of UAL shares. Chicago-based United Airlines is the nation's second-largest carrier after American Airlines. It has been the target of several employee buyout proposals in the past three years. The fourth and latest proposal, for more than $3.8 billion, was announced Monday by unions representing United's pilots, machinists and flight attendants. The bid, supported by UAL's largest shareholder, Coniston Partners, would give UAL employees, including non-union workers, 75 percent ownership of the company. There was no comment Thursday on the board's action from the unions, which have joined forces as the United Employee Acquisition Corp. UAL's board said the unions and Coniston had asked on Wednesday that negotiations begin in hopes of reaching an agreement and to avert a proxy fight threatened by Coniston. ``Despite serious deficiencies which the board believes exist in the buyout proposal, including its value and financeability, the board has instructed its advisers to enter into the requested negotiations,'' the board said. Coniston principal Paul Tierney said the New York investment group endorsed the negotations. ``The unions sent a letter requesting (negotiations), we endorsed the letter and we think it's worth trying,'' he said. As for the threatened proxy fight, he said Coniston has ``filed materials, we have our nominees'' for a replacement board of directors. He said the firm is waiting for the Securities and Exchange Commission to approve the materials, probablt within 10 days. The board's reference to the possible sale of assets could refer to certain United routes, UAL's 50 percent stake in a computerized reservations system and some planes. United owns a larger portion of its fleet of jetliners than most airlines. Industry analysts have speculated UAL might sell those assets as part of a takeover defense. ``Asset sales are pretty much antithetical to the objectives of the unions,'' said Samuel Buttrick, an airline analyst at Kidder Peabody & Co. in New York. ``Labor unions don't like to see chunks of their company sold.'' ``I think an outright rejection (of the bid) at this stage is unlikely under the threat of a proxy fight,'' he said. Under the offer, shareholders would receive $150 per share in cash, $25 in debt securities and stock in the new company. To help defray the cost of an acquisition, the unions are offering wage and benefit concessions in five-year contracts that contain no-strike clauses. In proposing the buyout, Coniston also threatened a proxy fight to replace the UAL board of directors at the company's April 26 meeting. The New York investor group owns 11.8 percent of UAL's outstanding stock. If the unions are successful, they likely would dump UAL Chairman Stephen Wolf, who has irked some union leaders with his hard-line bargaining tactics and lucrative personal compensation arrangement. Airline industry analysts are divided on the chances of UAL employees acquiring the company, which has been at the center of control struggles for more than seven months. UAL stock fell $1 to $152 a share Thursday on the New York Stock Exchange. The board's announcement was made after the market closed.

DOC.HEAD: Smith Plans to Retire, Murdoch Exec Eldredge Named Newsweek Publisher
DOC.TEXT: The worldwide publisher of Newsweek magazine plans to retire at the end of the year, while a Murdoch Magazines executive was named to head Newsweek's U.S. edition. Howard W. Smith said Thursday that Peter W. Eldredge, an executive with Murdoch Magazines, would become publisher of the U.S. edition of Newsweek on April 2. Eldredge and Peter Luffman, president of Newsweek International, each will report directly to Newsweek President Alan G. Spoon, with no new worldwide publisher to be named. The newsweekly, which is owned by the Washington Post Co., is in a fierce battle with Time and U.S. News & World Report for advertising and circulation. Newsweek's circulation was 3.2 million at the end of 1989, which puts it between Time at 4.3 million and U.S. News & World Report at 2.2 million. Its ad revenues rose 5 percent to a record $253.8 million last year, according to a spokeswoman for the publication. In a telephone interview, Smith, 55, said he has worked for Newsweek for 25 years and decided last year that ``25 years is enough.'' He said he planned to retire to a ranch he owns in Nacogdoches, Texas, but will remain a consultant to the magazine. ``Howard Smith is a one-of-a-kind,'' Spoon said in a statement. ``His contributions to Newsweek's success have been both far-ranging and of fundamental importance. We will miss him greatly.'' Smith took over as worldwide publisher at Newsweek in September 1988 after running the international division for five years. By announcing his retirement nine months in advance, Smith will be able to provide some guidance to Eldredge, who has been vice president for group sales at Murdoch Magazines, a unit of News Corp. Ltd. of Australia. Eldredge, 45, said he has no immediate plans to make any changes at Newsweek. ``It is one of the best edited and best designed publications around,'' he said in a telephone interview. The post of U.S. publisher has been vacant during Smith's tenure as worldwide publisher. One of the problems Newsweek faces in competing for ad revenue is that Time is one of several publications of Time Warner Inc. and Time's ad salesmen are able to offer packages of space in all of them. Washington Post Co. owns four television stations, several cable TV systems and The Washington Post newspaper. ``I think there is an opportunity there'' to sell ad packages involving two or more of those properties, Eldredge said. ``It is something we have to explore.'' Eldredge joined News Corp.'s U.S. publishing arm, News America Publishing Inc., in 1984 as advertising director of New York magazine. He was publisher of Star magazine from 1985 to 1987, and publisher of Premiere magazine from its debut in 1987 to earlier this year. Prior to joining News America, he worked at Sport, New Times and Money magazines.

DOC.HEAD: Spill Response Time Hasn't Improved in Year, Officials Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Response to an oil spill as big as the one that polluted Prince William Sound, Alaska, a year ago wouldn't be much better today than it was then, officials say. ``We don't believe recovery capability is where it should be,'' Larry Dietrick of the Alaska Department of Environmental Conservation told a congressional hearing Thursday. C.M. Harrison, executive vice president of Exxon Corp., said his company is concentrating on spill prevention, but also has upgraded response procedures. However, he said he couldn't guarantee that an 11-million-gallon spill, like that from the tanker Exxon Valdez on March 24, 1990, would be fully recovered or kept off the shore. Walter Parker, chairman of the Alaska Oil Spill Commission, said protection against spill damage was better in 1977 than it is now. The three men and Coast Guard Rear Adm. Joel Sipes appeared before the House Interior subcommittee on water, power and offshore energy resources, which is investigating whether any improvements have been made since the spill. Dietrick said Alyeska Pipeline Service Co., the company responsible for managing spills in Prince William Sound, says it can do a complete clean-up on a 2,000 barrel spill within 48 hours. ``The Department of Conservation is asking for a 48-hour cleanup capability for a much larger minimum spill of at least 250,000 barrels,'' the size of the Exxon Valdez disaster, said Dietrick. He said the Alaska legislature is considering a bill requiring a plan for handling very large spills. More than half of the oil lost by the Exxon Valdez still soils the waters and shores of the once-pristine sound, according to estimates by Dietrick's department. Harrison said Exxon, which has already spent $2 billion trying to restore the area, would resume clean-up in early May. He could not estimate the final cost. The company official said workers would be picking up tarballs and oil debris, diminishing oil sheens and using a process called bioremediation through which fertilizer is applied to the shore to enhance growth of naturally occurring organisms that speed the breakdown of the oil. Harrison said other more intrusive techniques, such as spot hot-water washing and tilling, may be used in some places. He said the methods will require fewer workers than last year and were recommended by scientists. Sipes said the Coast Guard has made a national effort to incorporate lessons learned from the Exxon Valdez spill. ``The Coast Guard is installing better equipment, instituting new procedures and increasing research and development in marine environmental protection,'' he said. The controversy over whether double hulls and double bottoms on oil tankers would be better protection against spills surfaced during the hearing. ``Exxon spent $30 million to repair the hull of the Exxon Valdez but did not include a double hull,'' Rep. James McDermott, D-Wash., noted. Harrison said the tanker was not designed originally for a double hull and ``did not have the structural integrity to support a double hull design.'' A House-Senate conference committee is trying to find a compromise between two bills on oil spill liability that have been passed and are wrestling with the double hull-double bottom issue. The House version would require double hulls and double bottoms. The Senate says other procedures of equal safety value could be used. Two environmental groups, the Natural Resources Defense Council and the Center for Marine Conservation, released separate studies Thursday that called for tighter standards governing tankers, pilots and tug escorts. The center suggested that the Coast Guard establish a network, much like the air-traffic control system, to monitor traffic off the Florida Keys and the central California coast and advise mariners of danger spots so they can avoid running aground as the Exxon Valdez did.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Slightly Lower, Gold A Bit Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: version on on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar was slightly lower in European trading this morning as attention turned to other major currencies. Gold prices were slightly higher. ``There is no evidence of a trend in the dollar right now,'' one Milan trader said. Traders said attention continued to focus on the weakness of the Japanese yen. Anticipation was strong that monetary authorities would move to shore up the Japanese currency after the market shrugged off an increase in Japanese interest rates earlier this week. Traders said the West German mark was suffering from continuing uncertainty about the costs of German reunification. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 0.24 yen to a closing 155.07 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 155.00 yen. In London, the dollar fell against the British pound, which was quoted at $1.6040, compared with $1.6015 late Thursday. Other dollar rates at midmorning in Europe, compared with late Thursday's rates included: 1.7050 West German marks, down from 1.7054; 1.5105 Swiss francs, down from 1.5150; 5.7490 French francs, down from 5.7505; 1.9177 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9210; 1,256 Italian lire, up from 1,255.50, and 1.1765 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1757. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $393.40 a troy ounce, up from $393.05 bid late Thursday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $393.60. In Zurich, the bid price was $393.75, up from $393 late Thursday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose 13 cents to close at a bid $393.65. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $5.09 a troy ounce, from Thursday's $5.08.

DOC.HEAD: Victorious Hazelwood Wants to Return to Sea As a Captain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos AG1,NY4
DOC.TEXT: Flushed with a feeling of victory after three acquittals and a conviction on a minor misdemeanor, Exxon Valdez skipper Joseph Hazelwood says he longs to return to the sea as a ship captain. His lawyer, Michael Chalos, said he will start negotiating with Exxon to regain the skipper's job with the shipping company that hired him out of college and fired him after his tanker grounded a year ago, causing the nation's worst oil spill. ``I'd like to go back to the sea. That's what I do,'' Hazelwood said Thursday after jurors absolved him of accusations he was reckless and drunk during the disaster that blackened the rocky shoreline of Prince William Sound. The misdemeanor charge of negligent discharge of oil on which Hazelwood was convicted carries a maximum sentence of 90 days in jail and a $1,000 fine, far less than the 7\ years and $61,000 fine he could have faced if found guilty on all four charges. Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone set sentencing for today. A grand jury indicted him last year on a felony, criminal mischief, and two other misdemeanors, reckless endangerment and operating a vessel while intoxicated. Jurors took only 10{ hours in deliberations to reject those counts. ``The state just didn't have the evidence,'' said juror Terrill Smith, a hardware store manager. Alaska Gov. Steve Cowper told a news conference that Hazelwood's acquittal on the most serious charges shows that someone other than the veteran mariner was responsible for the grounding. ``The result bears out the fact that there are other people responsible for this, other than Capt. Hazelwood,'' said Cowper, who learned of the verdict Thursday while touring Prince William Sound by helicopter. Alaska Attorney General Douglas Baily disputed suggestions that the state had tried to make Hazelwood a scapegoat. ``It was always my view that the captain of that vessel is ultimately responsible,'' he said. The normally taciturn Hazelwood smiled broadly for the first time in the two-month trial when the verdicts were announced two days short of the oil spill's first anniversary. ``I'm not used to being in the limelight,'' Hazelwood told reporters. ``I was a pretty anonymous character until a year ago.'' Chalos said he would fight expected efforts by the Coast Guard to revoke Hazelwood's master's license. The skipper's future also is clouded by more than 100 civil lawsuits filed by assorted victims of the nation's worst environmental disaster. Jim Morakis, an Exxon spokesman in New York, said the company, which has fired Hazelwood, was ``pleased that the ordeal of the trial is over for Capt. Hazelwood and his family.'' ``The verdict would seem to confirm the view that the grounding of the Exxon Valdez was an accident,'' Morakis said. ``In light of pending litigation any other comment would be inappropriate.'' Another lawyer for Hazelwood, Dick Madson, said even the misdemeanor was wrongly filed and would be appealed. The heart of the case against Hazelwood was alcohol, and jurors said the state failed to prove he was drunk. Juror Jeff Sage, a grocery store manager, said the panel didn't buy a prosecution expert's backward calculations which tried proving intoxication without physical evidence. A blood test of the skipper was taken too late to be conclusive. ``The jury felt there were just too many variables to pinpoint whether he was drunk at all,'' said Sage. Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole conceded his prosecution would have been easier if a timely blood test was taken. He said he hoped the case had discouraged tanker captains from drinking before they sail. The Exxon Valdez, a 987-foot tanker, ran aground and spilled almost 11 million gallons of oil into Prince William Sound on March 24, 1989. It killed countless birds, fish and wildlife in the scenic area, and Exxon came under bitter criticism for failing to respond quickly with a clean up effort. Sage said jurors concluded that Hazelwood was negligent to leave the bridge of his ship during an icy transit. But he also said they felt that ``all his orders were prudent. He was in command.'' ``To this day, we're never going to know exactly what caused the accident,'' Sage said. But he found no fault with the state's decision to put the skipper on trial. ``I think that someone had to be tried,'' he said, ``and he's the captain. He was in charge.''

DOC.HEAD: IRS Will Probably Give Right Answers _ If Taxpayers Can Get Through
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Internal Revenue Service blames a budget squeeze for its inability to answer two of every three taxpayer telephone calls for help. But if you can get through to the agency, you have a better chance than last year of getting the correct answer to a tax question. The General Accounting Office says IRS employees give the right answer 78 percent of the time, up from 66 percent last year. The bad news is that only 34 percent of callers are getting through to the IRS, down sharply from 61 percent in 1989, Jennie S. Stathis of the congressional investigative agency told the House Ways and Means oversight subcommittee Thursday. ``It bothers the hell out of me that taxpayer service has declined that way,'' IRS Commissioner Fred T. Goldberg testified. He said the inability to take phone calls resulted from a decision by the agency to cut its service _ rather than the quality _ because of a shortfall in its 1990 budget. He said the IRS is also getting calls from 7 percent more taxpayers than had been expected. Goldberg said the IRS budget that President Bush proposed for the fiscal year starting Oct. 1 is reasonable. He cautioned that any reductions would harm efforts to collect $80 billion of delinquent accounts, force more cuts in taxpayer services and lead to further deterioration of a computer system that already has outlived its usefulness. ``The only hope we have of meeting legitimate taxpayer expectations in dealing with their government is to modernize our systems,'' Goldberg said. The administration has proposed a $6.1 billion budget for the IRS, up 12 percent from the 1990 fiscal year. But Goldberg said the agency is still suffering from previous tight budgets. ``I am afraid that the tax system will continue to pay the price of the 1989-1990 hiring freeze and failure to provide adequate training and support for our employees for years to come,'' he said. Ms. Stathis gave this rundown on how the IRS is doing this filing season: _The GAO telephoned 20 tax questions to 29 IRS offices and scored 1,261 responses; 78 percent were correct. _Through March 17, taxpayers had called the IRS 31.5 million times and the IRS had picked up the phone 10.7 million times. During a similar period last year, there were far fewer calls _ 19.3 million _ but 11.8 million of them were answered. _Processing of returns is 12.5 percent ahead of last year's pace; returns received are up 3.5 percent; the number of refunds is up 16.7 percent. _The percentage of returns with taxpayer errors or IRS processing mistakes is dropping, from 16 percent last year to 14 percent this year. _Ordering forms and publications by phone can be as troublesome as calling with a tax question. But once a caller connects, the IRS is prompt in mailing requested items within the promised 14 days. The agency is not as reliable for items ordered by letter. Members of the subcommittee were concerned that the percentage of taxpayers being audited has declined to only about nine per 1,000 returns this year. ``Congress may be forced to mandate a minimum audit level,'' said Rep. J.J. Pickle, D-Texas, the panel's chairman. Goldberg said that with a larger budget, the IRS might be able to boost the current level to about 13 audits per 1,000 returns by 1993. He noted that about 40 million individual returns, whose incomes are solely from wages, interest and dividends, receive the equivalent of an audit every year through a computer matching program.

DOC.HEAD: Abrupt Grain Agreement Reflects Long-Term Soviet Interest in US Trade
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A tentative long-term grain agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union was reached unexpectedly and without any last-minute major concessions from either side. As recently as Tuesday, reporters were told negotiators were not expected to settle quickly on a new five-year agreement to replace the 1983 accord that will expire Dec. 31. The talks were scheduled for Wednesday and Thursday in Vienna. An earlier round last December was inconclusive. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter downplayed the negotiations on the eve of this week's talks, indicating it was unlikely a package would be finalized soon. But on Thursday, Yeutter and U.S. Trade Representative Carla A. Hills announced in Washington that an agreement in principle had been reached on a new five-year grain pact. The official signing is scheduled for June when President Bush meets with Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev. ``They just came to agreement much quicker than anyone anticipated,'' said Kelly Shipp, Yeutter's press secretary. ``They were just able to wrap it up.'' No major obstacles were suddenly overcome, nothing like that, she said. The new agreement, in fact, tracks pretty well with the current version. In December, the Soviets wanted to add grain prices to the new pact, Shipp said. That was rejected by the U.S. negotiators. The current agreement and those in the past omitted those prices. ``We've always stuck to competitive pricing or world markets, something like that,'' she said. ``When they went into this, it was expected there would be additional meetings.'' Shipp said the sudden decision by Moscow to settle the grain question suggests the Soviet Union wants to be around a long time as a customer of the American farmer. ``They still want to be in our long-term market,'' she said. Shipp said there have been rumors of growing Kremlin disinterest in the U.S. agricultural market, partly because of financial programs and possible commitments to other suppliers. The major change from the current agreement, she said, will be to increase the annual minimum shipments of U.S. grain to the Soviets to 10 million metric tons, from nine million tons under the current agreement. That will guarantee 50 million tons over the five years, compared with 45 million tons under the old terms. Soviet purchases in most years have exceeded the required minimums. In 1988-89, for example, sales were more than double the specified minimum in the current pact. Howard Lyman, a lobbyist for the National Farmers Union, said the new pact was in line with the group's support of such long-term agreements. ``We think it's great,'' he said. John A. Schnittker, a private analyst and consultant, questioned whether the agreement with Moscow is needed at all. The new version, he said, is ``a little more flexible, a little bigger'' and will provide ``some assurance and some stability'' for American farmers. ``But I've never considered these agreements to be necessary for continuation of trade,'' he said. ``In my opinion, we would be selling just as much. They need the stuff, we've got the stuff, they're going to buy it when they need it.'' The Kremlin will have some greater year-to-year flexibility under the new arrangement by being allowed to choose between wheat and feed grains, although the minimums will have to be met over the life of the pact, officials said. Under the new agreement, the Soviets are committed to buying at least four million tons each of wheat and feed grains. However, in any one year Moscow can substitute up to 750,000 tons of one commodity for the other. Also, for the first time, the agreement includes barley and sorghum along with corn under the definition of feed grains. Additional flexibility also was provided by giving Moscow automatic permission to buy up to 14 million tons of grain annually without further discussion with Washington. The automatic limit under the current pact is 12 million tons, although the United States has routinely increased that lid to fit Soviet needs. As of March 8, the Soviets had bought more than 13.8 million tons of U.S. wheat and corn under the current agreement for delivery this year. Last year's sales totaled a record 21.7 million tons. Over five years, U.S. farmers will effectively be assured a Soviet market for at least 20 million tons of wheat and 20 million tons of feed grains, with an additional 10 million tons that can be made up of wheat, feed grains, soybeans or soybean meal. Although it makes up a hefty share, the Soviet Union's grain purchases by no means tell the whole story of U.S. grain exports. Total wheat shipments in 1989-90 are currently forecast at 35.4 million tons, and so-called coarse grains, or feed grains, at 66.4 million tons.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil's Emergency Economic Plan Faces Growing Complaints
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Cash-strapped companies laid off thousands of workers and Brazilians deserted shops and restaurants in the week since new President Fernando Collor de Mello's decreed a drastic economic plan. The 40-year-old conservative leader, inaugurated March 15, says his sweeping program to bring down 2,700 percent inflation is not negotiable. Police stood guard in banks nationwide Thursday to ensure clients were allowed to withdraw $1,200 from savings and $600 from money markets, the legal limits set in the 18-month freeze on withdrawals. Many banks said they didn't have the ready cash to honor withdrawal requests. About $115 billion, or 80 percent of bank deposits, have been frozen under the harsh plan, which has overwhelming support among opposition leftist politicians and the public. ``This was the greatest blow to Brazil's elite since the slaves were freed (in 1889), and the slaveowners weren't indemnified,'' Rio's best known gossip columnist, Ibrahim Sued, wrote in Globo newspaper. ``If we had won and done this, the presidential palace would have been surrounded, and many people, including me, would be headed for exile,'' Rep. Roberto Freire, the Brazilian Communist Party candidate in the Nov. 15 presidential election. The money crunch caused a steep drop in business activity. Restaurants and stores were almost deserted and cash-strapped companies fired workers in droves. Collor de Mello warned that companies firing workers would have account books examined by federal tax investigators. In the southern state of Parana, 19,000 construction workers were laid off this week while scores of employees in the auto parts, banking and weapons industries have been fired or forced to take early holidays. All week clients formed long lines outside banks nationwide to withdraw their legal limit from savings and money market accounts. At least five bank managers have been arrested since Wednesday for setting withdrawal limits below the legal maximum. They were charged with ``white collar'' crimes, punishable under the new measures by up to six years in jail. In Sao Paulo, several supermarket owners were also arrested for disobeying the plan's 30-day price freeze. The emergency plan, decreed by Collor on his first full day in office, also included a new currency, steep income tax increases and drastic spending cuts to eliminate a budget deficit. Collor also limited payments on the country's $115 billion foreign debt _ the largest in the developing world _ to $5 billion this year. The $5 billion is about half the amount paid in 1989. Union leaders are worried by the layoffs and Collor's promise to sell state companies to the private sector. They also say workers' buying power will be slashed by below-inflation increases. Earlier this week, 1,000 workers marched through downtown Rio demanding job protection and a bigger pay boost. The measures take effect immediately but must be approved by Congress within 30 days, with a 30-day extension possible. Congress has begun discussing the package and by Thursday, more than 1,000 amendments had been offered. Collor said he will not back down. ``Either we win ... or we win,'' he said. While about half of all congressmen unofficially back Collor, the president's National Reconstruction Party has only 24 seats in the 570-member Congress and will be forced to seek alliances. Most members are up for re-election in October. ``The poor are demanding I vote for the package but the middle class will kill me if I do,'' said Rep. Luiz Henrique of the centrist Brazilian Democratic Movement Party, the largest party in Congress with 189 of 570 seats. ``We don't accept that the plan is untouchable. It should be preserved in general but Congress has the competence and authority to make changes,'' said Robson Marinho of the center-left Brazilian Social Democracy Party, Congress' third-largest. He said his party would work to increase limits on withdrawals from bank accounts, support a larger wage increase and demand the government prevent wide layoffs. Congressional leaders said would back such modifications. In addition, a half-dozen lawsuits have been filed against the government by people who say the confiscation of savings accounts represents a ``compulsory loan,'' outlawed by Brazil's 1988 constitution. ``The plan is unconstitutional.'' said Marcio Thomaz Bastos, former head of the Brazilian Bar Association.

DOC.HEAD: Boeing To Issue Layoff Notices
DOC.TEXT: The Boeing Co. plans to issue layoff notices to about 360 hourly workers today, well below the 1,700 employees the company had said would be furloughed by this month. The company did not explain why the figure was significantly smaller. Two weeks ago Boeing had warned 600 employees that they might lose their jobs. Boeing spokesman Paul Binder said some affected employees may have already left their jobs or found work elsewhere at the company, adding that Boeing's overall forecast for cutting 5,000 jobs this year has not changed. Boeing has said the layoffs are needed to increase production efficiencies at its Everett plant and because of the decrease in federal defense spending. Separately, Boeing announced on Thursday plans to expand its commercial jet plant in Everett by more than 4 million square feet over the next decade. The 747 jumbo jets and 767 widebodies are currently assembled there. Boeing is considering assembling its new 777 jet there.

DOC.HEAD: Ingersoll Newspaper To Buy Back Junk Bonds
DOC.TEXT: Ingersoll Newspapers Inc. has offered to buy back $159 million of its junk bonds at discounted prices as it tries to meet interest payments. Ingersoll Newspapers offered Thursday to buy the bonds at between 25 percent and 55 percent of the principal amount. One series of bonds has been trading at about $400 per $1,000 in face value. A separate series is trading at about $200 per $1,000. Ingersoll Newspapers is a subsidiary of Ingersoll Publications Inc. Its properties include the weekly St. Louis Suburban Journals, the Try (N.Y.) Record and several other medium-sized papers. Community Newspapers operates newspapers mostly in monopoly, medium-sized markets, inclduing the Lorain (Ohio) Journal outside Cleveland. Junk bond analyst Ned Zachar of Duff & Phelps Inc. in Chicago said Ingersoll, like other newspaper companies in the northeastern United States, is facing financial problems from an overall economic slowdown. Ingersoll spokesman Mark Harnett said earnings have fallen off. Zachar said bondholders should accept some kind of offer to avoid pushing the publishing company into bankruptcy, but he expected a higher purchase price to result from any negotiations. ``I think there's a pretty good chance Ingersoll will suceed with a tender offer,'' he said. ``But whether it will be at this price or another remains to be seen. The bondholders will likely push for a little more.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Leans Toward Group's Bid for Ailing Appliance Maker
DOC.TEXT: A federal bankruptcy judge said availability of cash and credit is the key to a New York investment group's $650 million bid to restructure financially ailing Allegheny International Inc. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Joseph Cosetti said Thursday he likely will approve Japonica Partners' plan for to acquire the company, rather than a $570 million bid by the company's managers, if Japonica can deliver the money. Pittsburgh-based Allegheny International, which makes Sunbeam and Oster appliances, is operating under Chapter 11 protection from its creditors. Japonica proposes paying creditors and shareholders in cash. The partnership has said it has a $120 million line of credit. The management bid, meanwhile, would pay off creditors and shareholders with stock in a reorganized company. Company spokesman Edward Romanoff said the managers received a $250 million loan commitment from Chemical Bank of New York. Cosetti told lawyers for creditors he would ``vote for the cash plan because that's what most of you seem to want.'' The judge, however, questioned whether Japonica could obtain financing. ``I have reservations about whether any American banks are going to raise money for a corporation that's been in bankruptcy for two years,'' Cosetti said. The court has approved the management plan and the company has sent it to stockholders for a vote. Cosetti said the court will allow stockholders to vote on Japonica's plan even if the first vote has been tallied. An investment arm of PNC Financial Corp., a Pittsburgh bank-holding company, has agreed to contribute to Japonica's bid as well but in an unspecified amount.

DOC.HEAD: Report: U.S. Offers 200 Trade Suggestions to Japan
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. government has given Japan a list of more than 200 suggested policy changes aimed at eliminating barriers faced by foreign firms operating in Japan, a news report said Friday. Quoting unidentified U.S. government officials, the nationally circulated newspaper Asahi Shimbun said the list included recommendations ranging from an increase in public works spending to the release of the minutes of business group meetings. The newspaper said the proposals were more detailed and far-reaching than the Japanese side had expected and amounted to a plan to ``remake Japan.'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe declined to comment during a regular news conference Friday. The newspaper said the recommendations were presented as part of talks, begun last year, concerning the bilateral trade imbalance. The United States has called for tighter enforcement of Japan's Anti-Monopoly Law, controls on high land prices and higher public works spending. The list of recommendations included proposals to consolidate the 13 government offices that deal with land policy, the creation of a special antitrust division to strengthen enforcement of the Anti-Monopoly Law and abolising legislation that protects small shops from competition, the newspaper said. Also included was a proposal to reduce the amount of shares that banks or trading companies can hold in outside firms in order to weaken the close financial links within Japanese business groups, it said. Japanese media have reported that the government has responded to some U.S. requests, but no formal agreements have been announced. The United States is pressuring Japan to take action before an April deadline for the release of an interim report detailing progress made in the talks.

DOC.HEAD: Political Friction May Prompt Conference Move From Vienna To Geneva
DOC.TEXT: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries apparently is considering moving a key conference from Vienna to Geneva, after the Austrian government canceled a meeting last week with the Iraqi oil minister to protest the execution of a British journalist. The journalist, Iranian-born Farzad Bazoft, was executed in Iraq March 15 after he was found guilty of espionage by a tribunal. His execution drew outrage and protests from around the world. Iraq is one of OPEC's largest oil producers. There was no official comment from OPEC, but a source close to the organization said it was ``very, very likely'' the ministerial conference on May 25 would be shifted to Geneva, where the cartel often holds its meetings. The source, who demanded anonymity, said Algerian Mines Minister Sadek Boussena, who serves as OPEC's president, has to make a request to other ministers to approve a change in the meeting site. Earlier in the week, Ecuador's oil minister, Diego Tamariz, said the ministers had decided at their weekend talks to hold the mid-year conference in the Swiss city. He gave no reason. The effort to move the meeting was apparently sparked by the Austrian government's snub of Iraqi Oil Minister Issam Abdul Raheem al-Chalabi, according to the source. A scheduled meeting with him by Austrian Trade Minister Wolfgang Schuessel was canceled last week without explanation. Chalabi was in Vienna for a meeting on Friday and Saturday of a special monitoring panel of the 13 OPEC nations. The cartel's headquarters is in Vienna but it often holds its meetings in other European cities. It had announced at its ministerial conference last November that the May meeting would take place in the Austrian capital. At that meeting, the oil ministers will decide their production and pricing guidelines for the last six months of the year. OPEC meetings, which attract hundreds of oil traders, analysts and journalists, are lucrative for cities hosting the sessions.

DOC.HEAD: Colt Strikers Rejoice After State Steps in to Aid Buyout
DOC.TEXT: Unbroken after a four-year strike, workers from Colt's firearms division rejoiced when the state joined in a buyout that ends the strike and gives workers $13 million in back pay. State Treasurer Francisco L. Borges announced the terms of the buyout Thursday to a room packed with reporters, investors and union officials. The state joined with striking workers, Colt managers and private investors to buy the firearms division, which had been up for sale for 11 months. Borges said the state would contribute $25 million from pension funds and would own about 47 percent of the new company, which will be called Colt's Manufacturing Company. ``Let me emphasize that this is a carefully thought out, carefully structured, potentially very profitable business venture,'' Borges said. ``The state's participation is not a bailout, not a handout, and not a subsidy.'' The new company's first official act was to write out a check for $10 million in back pay to the 1,050 workers who struck Jan. 24, 1986. About 50 striking workers broke out in applause when the company produced the check at a news conference in Borges' office. Under the terms of the buyout, striking workers will be put back to work based on seniority, and will receive a total of $13 million in back pay, a 13 percent wage increase, and a stock ownership plan that will allow United Auto Workers members to own 11.5 percent of the company. In return for the $13 million in back pay, the United Auto Workers dropped its lawsuit against Colt Industries for unfair labor practices. The National Labor Relations Board said the settlement was the largest in its 55-year history. The previous high was a $12 million settlement given in 1979 to chemical plant workers in Westwego, La., who had been unlawfully locked out of their jobs for three years. Salaried Colt managers will own about 12 percent of the company, as will C.F. Holding Corp., an investment group headed by Hartford businessman Anthony Autorino. Neither Borges nor Autorino would release the total amount paid for the firearms division. Autorino said the final amount remains subject to negotiations with Colt Industries. Borges said his office will eventually release the total cost. The agreement came 11 months after Colt Industries put its firearms division up for sale. At the time, the division was ravaged by a three-year-old strike, and had just lost the contract to produce M-16 rifles for the Pentagon. With no buyer in sight, the striking workers won a major victory in September 1989 when an administrative law judge from the National Labor Relations Board ruled that the strike was caused by Colt's unfair labor practices. The judge ordered the company to reinstate the workers and pay them lost wages, which were estimated as high as $40 million. In November, Connecticut-based C.F. Holding Corp. announced it had signed an agreement to buy the firearms division. There was no mention at the time of union ownership or a state contribution, but both were expected to be part of a final agreement. Union leaders praised the agreement and said they expected their members to resume working next week. Union members will replace approximately 600 non-union replacement workers. The strike began when workers walked off the job after working 10 months without a contract. Eight months into the strike, the workers offered to return under the terms of their old contract, but Colt refused. Colt was founded in Hartford in 1836 by Samuel Colt, the inventor of the first successful repeating pistol. The company later developed the six-shooter _ the legendary gun that won the West. In addition to the M-16, the standard Army-issue rifle still used today, Colt makes the Colt 45 handgun, the King Cobra magnum revolver and the AR-15 rifle. In announcing its intention to sell the firearms division in April 1989, Colt Industries said it wanted to concentrate its efforts on its aerospace, automotive and industrial service operations.

DOC.HEAD: GM's New Minivans Get Incentives
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. is offering a $1,000 rebate on its new line of three minivans just four months after the vehicles were introduced. The rebates, along with a sliding scale of low-interest financing, became effective Thursday and run until May 2 for the Chevrolet Lumina APV, Pontiac Trans Sport or Oldsmobile Silhouette. Typically, incentives are offered on cars or trucks whose inventories rise because of slow sales, overproduction or a combination of both. None of these reasons, however, seems to be the case with the GM minivans. ``I have heard that they are selling relatively well,'' said senior economist Tom Webb of the National Automobile Dealers Association in McLean, Va. Production at GM's minivan plant in North Tarrytown, N.Y., still is accelerating toward a goal of about 175,000 vehicles this year and 225,000 after that. When asked why GM would offer a rebate on something selling well, Webb said, ``Good question.'' Yet dealer Herb Adcox, owner of Herb Adcox Chevrolet in Chattanooga, Tenn., likes the incentives. He estimated that he had a Lumina APV supply of about 75 selling days on his lot, mainly because of a recent large purchase. ``I felt like once they got production up, you were going to get an incentive,'' he said Thursday. ``The numbers just justify it.'' GM's minivans went on sale last October. Since then, GM has sold 30,891 of them, with the Chevrolet model making up more than half. ``We could see that there is a need in today's market to have incentives on just about anything,'' Pontiac spokesman Ed Lechtzin said. ``Because people are coming in and like the vehicle, but look at the price and say, `How much (rebate) money am I getting?''' Lechtzin said there was some concern that production at the plant may outpace demand. But Oldsmobile spokesman Ross Ruehle said the sales demand is a little stronger than anticipated for the Silhouette. Chrysler Corp., whose minivan sales command more than half of the vehicle's market segment, offered rebates on the vehicles for the first time between Dec. 15, 1989, and Jan. 31, 1990. Sales of the Plymouth Voyager, Dodge Caravan and Chrysler Town and Country soared during the incentive period. Since then, the minivan sales pace has dropped. ``What we think is we have been out there trying to sell something up against someone with an incredible rebate,'' said Chevrolet spokeswoman Mary McElyea. Ford Motor Co. is offering a $500 rebate on its Aerostar minivan. That offer expires April 2.

DOC.HEAD: Federal, State Charges Filed Against Northwest Flight Crew
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A Northwest Airlines pilot fell out of his barroom chair and couldn't find his motel the night before he and two others in his cockpit crew were arrested on suspicion of flying while intoxicated, authorities say. The three, who have been fired by Northwest, were charged Thursday by federal and state officials with operating an aircraft while under the influence of alcohol. Charges were filed by the U.S. attorney's office in Minneapolis and by North Dakota officials against Capt. Norman Prouse, 51, of Conyers, Ga.; First Officer Robert Kirchner, 35, of Highland Ranch, Colo., and Second Officer Joseph Balzer, 34, of Antioch, Tenn. Prouse, Balzer and Kirchner piloted Flight 650 from Fargo, N.D., to Minneapolis with 91 passengers on March 8 and landed safely. However, federal authorities had received a tip that the crew had been drinking the night before the flight and the three were arrested when they got off the plane. According to an FBI agent's affidavit, Prouse bought 14 rum drinks at a Moorhead bar over about six hours the evening before the flight left Fargo, and another patron bought five additional drinks for him. The affidavit said the other two crew members were served seven pitchers of beer. Witnesses said Prouse fell out of his chair and had trouble getting up, and he returned to the bar about 20 minutes after leaving, saying he was lost and could not find the nearby motel where the crew was staying, the affidavit said. ``Balzer appeared to have had difficulty focusing his vision and both Kirchner and Balzer were unable to walk steadily,'' the affidavit said. Tests taken soon after the three were taken into custody showed they had blood-alcohol levels ranging from 0.06 percent to 0.12 percent, Arnold's office said. Federal regulations prohibit pilots from flying if they have alcohol levels higher than 0.04 percent. The legal limit for driving a vehicle is 0.10 in most states. The three pilots are scheduled to be arraigned Thursday on the federal felony charges of operating a common carrier while under the influence of alcohol or drugs. The maximum penalty is 15 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. In North Dakota, the three were charged in Cass County Court in Fargo with operating an aircraft while intoxicated and acting as an aircraft crew member within eight hours of drinking. The charges are misdemeanors punishable by a $1,000 fine and one year in prison under North Dakota law. The Federal Aviation Administration has revoked the men's pilot licenses. The three plan to appeal their license revocations, their attorneys have said. Mark McDermott, Kirchner's attorney, said he will ``do whatever we have to do to defend his rights.'' Bruce Hanley, Balzer's attorney, said his client will plead innocent. He said it was too early to comment on the allegations in the government's affidavit. Prouse has an unlisted telephone number and could not be reached for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Mosbacher: Opening of East Europe Should Help U.S. Trade Decicit
DOC.NOTE: EDS: UPDATES with latest comments on high-tech sale rules, no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. commerce secretary on Friday predicted that reforms in Eastern Europe will have a favorable impact on the U.S. trade deficit in the coming decade. But Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher said an immediate impact will be limited due to the lack of hard currency available to Eastern European countries. ``Short term, they don't have the hard currency to do a huge amount of buying,'' Mosbacher said. But the goal is to globalize free trade and integrate all geographic regions into one trading family. Mosbacher said newly opened markets in Eastern Europe could help ``bring us very close to a trade balance.'' Mosbacher declined to discuss prospects for the dollar but noted that the U.S. currency is just one component of the trade equation. Mosbacher also forecast the U.S. economy will become increasingly less dependent on defense-related industries because of East-West disarmament. He said non-defense exports would have a growing role. Separately, he said Western nations could reach an accord as early as June on relaxing restrictions on the sale of high-technology goods to Eastern Europe. Mosbacher said he and West German Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann have agreed there must be ``differentiation'' on COCOM restrictions for East European countries and those applied to the Soviet Union. COCOM is the acronym for the 17-nation Coordinating Committee for Multilateral Export Controls that restricts Western high-technology exports to East bloc countries.
