DOC.HEAD: UAL Board To Negotiate With Unions on Employee Buyout Bid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Davis Agreement, early stock price, editing to conform; Picks up 4th graf pvs, Chicago-based United...
DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp.'s board of directors said today it would allow former suitor Marvin Davis to again purchase UAL stock, raising the possibility of a rival buyout offer to the $3.8 billion bid by the company's unions. UAL's board on Thursday agreed to negotiate over the proposal by United Airlines' labor unions and an investor group, despite what it called ``serious deficiencies'' in the offer. The board also instructed management to explore other alternatives for increasing its share values, including buyout proposals from other parties, and directed its financial advisers to develop a plan for selling company assets. Today, the board said it had modified a standstill agreement with Davis, the Los Angeles billionaire who last year made a buyout offer for UAL, to permit him to purchase UAL stock. Rob Doughty, UAL spokesman, said he could not elaborate on a brief statement the company issued announcing the move. Davis spokeswoman Mary Conway in New York also had no comment and neither would say if Davis had a new buyout offer on the table. UAL stock jumped $4.37{ higher to $156.37{ in mid-day New York Stock Exchange trading. In January, the board said it would consider offers from Davis, but the agreement had blocked him from purchasing stock. Also in January, the board lifted an agreed-to restriction that would have kept Davis from making an offer at less than $300 a share. Davis opened bidding in the long-running battle for UAL last August with an unsolicited offer, which was not accepted, of $200 a share or $4.32 billion. The company later accepted a $300 a share offer valued at $6.75 billion from a group led by United's pilots union and senior management, but the deal collapsed for lack of financing. Chicago-based United Airlines is the nation's second-largest carrier after American Airlines. It has been the target of several employee buyout proposals in the past three years. The fourth and latest proposal, for more than $3.8 billion, was announced Monday by unions representing United's pilots, machinists and flight attendants. The bid, supported by UAL's largest shareholder, Coniston Partners, would give UAL employees, including non-union workers, 75 percent ownership of the company. There was no comment Thursday on the board's action from the unions, which have joined forces as the United Employee Acquisition Corp. UAL's board said the unions and Coniston had asked on Wednesday that negotiations begin in hopes of reaching an agreement and to avert a proxy fight threatened by Coniston. ``Despite serious deficiencies which the board believes exist in the buyout proposal, including its value and financeability, the board has instructed its advisers to enter into the requested negotiations,'' the board said. Coniston principal Paul Tierney said the New York investment group endorsed the negotations. ``The unions sent a letter requesting (negotiations), we endorsed the letter and we think it's worth trying,'' he said. As for the threatened proxy fight, he said Coniston has ``filed materials, we have our nominees'' for a replacement board of directors. He said the firm is waiting for the Securities and Exchange Commission to approve the materials, probably within 10 days. The board's reference to the possible sale of assets could refer to certain United routes, UAL's 50 percent stake in a computerized reservations system and some planes. United owns a larger portion of its fleet of jetliners than most airlines. Industry analysts have speculated UAL might sell those assets as part of a takeover defense. ``Asset sales are pretty much antithetical to the objectives of the unions,'' said Samuel Buttrick, an airline analyst at Kidder Peabody & Co. in New York. ``Labor unions don't like to see chunks of their company sold.'' ``I think an outright rejection (of the bid) at this stage is unlikely under the threat of a proxy fight,'' he said. Under the offer, shareholders would receive $150 per share in cash, $25 in debt securities and stock in the new company. To help defray the cost of an acquisition, the unions are offering wage and benefit concessions in five-year contracts that contain no-strike clauses. In proposing the buyout, Coniston also threatened a proxy fight to replace the UAL board of directors at the company's April 26 meeting. The New York investor group owns 11.8 percent of UAL's outstanding stock. If the unions are successful, they likely would dump UAL Chairman Stephen Wolf, who has irked some union leaders with his hard-line bargaining tactics and lucrative personal compensation arrangement. Airline industry analysts are divided on the chances of UAL employees acquiring the company, which has been at the center of control struggles for more than seven months.

DOC.HEAD: New US-Japan Trade Proposal Would Open Door to Supercomputer Sales
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; no pickup; moved general news wires also.
DOC.TEXT: The United States has gained major concessions from the Japanese that should boost sales of American-made supercomputers to Japan, U.S. officials said today. Officials at the U.S. Trade Office said that negotiators from both sides bargained late into the night Thursday, hammering out details of the proposal. The announcement represented the first breakthrough on a host of contentious trade disputes between the two countries. The dispute over sales of supercomputers centered around American demands that the Japanese remove various restrictions that effectively barred U.S. companies from selling supercomputers to Japanese universities and government agencies. ``If implemented, we think this will give us full and effective access to the Japanese government market,'' said Timothy O'Leary, an official at the U.S. Trade Office. Under the agreement reached during two days of talks in Washington, the Japanese promised to open up the procurement process for supercomputers to foreign firms and to base government decisions on purchases on quality as well as price. The market for supercomputers was one of three areas targeted last year when the Bush administration put Japan on a ``hit list'' of countries with the most onerous barriers to the sale of American products. Talks have also been proceeding on the two other products on the list _ U.S. satellites and lumber products. But negotiators on those issues have reported that both sides remain far apart on American demands to open up those markets. Still, there have been reports from Tokyo that Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu is preparing an array of trade concessions in these areas as well. Kaifu and President Bush met last month in California for a hastily arranged summit meeting where both leaders pledged to make greater efforts to reduce America's huge $49 billion trade deficit with Japan. Access to the government supercomputer market has long been a point of contention between the two countries. U.S. firms, in particular Cray Research Inc., have dominated the market for the sophisticated machines around the world but have been unable to sell their products to the Japanese government. U.S. negotiators estimated that the potential for sales to the Japanese government was about $130 million annually. Dennis McGrath, a spokesman for Cray, said his company would withhold its comment until reviewing the details of the agreement. ``We hope this is more than just a process thing, but something that will translate into sales in the marketplace,'' McGrath said. The Japanese are under pressure to make concessions on satellites, supercomputers and wood products before a June 16 deadline, at which time the Bush administration has the authority to retaliate by imposing higher tariffs on Japanese products. The talks on specific industries are being conducted under a section of the 1988 trade law known as Super 301. The administration is also conducting discussions on broader structural impediments to trade. Negotiators on these issues met at a remote hideaway in the Virginia countryside earlier this week in hopes of making progress in advance of more formal discussions scheduled for Washington on April 2 and 3. However, U.S. officials said the discussions near Warrenton, Va., had failed to make any progress.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Group Says Pork Not as Healthful as Advertised
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 3rd graf, It said... to UPDATE with petition filed; also moved general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: In a town where the pork barrel is considered a treasured commodity, one consumer group says producers and advertisers of ham, bacon and sausage are going too far. The Center for Science in the Public Interest said Thursday that it wants the federal government to halt advertising by the National Pork Producers Council it says is ``deceptive and dangerously misleading.'' It filed a petition today with the Federal Trade Commission challenging various ad claims that pork is low in fat, low in cholesterol and low in calories. The center said the industry's 3-year-old campaign touting pork as ``the other white meat'' is misleading because it claims pork ``is as nutritious as chicken, turkey and fish.'' To that, Barry Pfouts, director of marketing for the council, replied: ``We're confident that our advertising is accurate and can be backed up by substantial scientific evidence.'' ``All we have said all along is that our products ... are nutritionally comparable to other accepted white meats,'' he added. Bruce Silverglade, legal director for the science center, said, ``The pork industry is trying to dupe consumers into thinking that pork is as healthful as chicken, turkey and fish. However, government data show that almost all cuts of pork are considerably higher in fat, saturated fat and calories.'' The amount of cholesterol in a four-ounce serving of cooked pork is virtually the same for similar servings of chicken and turkey, Charles Mitchell, a spokesman for the consumer group, acknowledged. But Mitchell said the amount and percentage of fat and the number of calories is substantially higher for pork. He said four ounces of pork, trimmed of all visible fat, averaged 14.8 grams or 13 percent fat, while an identical serving of skinless chicken averages 8.4 grams or 7.4 percent fat. Turkey weighed in at 2.9 grams or 2.6 percent fat per serving, according to Mitchell. Similar servings of pork, chicken and turkey contain 264 calories, 215 calories and 171 calories, respectively, said Mitchell. The science center said the ads also violate Agriculture Department requirements that average servings of ``low-fat'' foods must be 10 percent or less fat to make the claim. Pfouts, of the pork producers council, said the average three-ounce serving of tenderloin, the best cut of pork, has about the same 140 calories as a similar serving of skinless white-meat chicken. And Mike Simpson, executive vice president of the National Pork Board, said nutritional assessments of pork are based on 10-year-old data that don't take into account recent research and improvements in breeding. The consumer group said that in addition to filing the FTC petition, it will ask Congress to pressure the industry to increase its spending on research to reduce fat in pork. Money for the pork advertising comes primarily from the approximately $25 million collected annually from producers under the 1987 Pork Promotion and Research Act. The science center contended that 70 percent of the money is spent on advertising and other promotional activities, and just 10 percent is spent on research that could lead to ``safe, low-fat and good-tasting products.'' Simpson responded that in the early years of the program the council may have spent that much on promotion. But in the 1990 budget of $26 million, promotion takes up 55 percent, research is 19 percent and consumer information is 26 percent, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Cleveland-Area Publisher Sues New York Times Over Magazine Title
DOC.TEXT: A suburban Cleveland publisher has filed a $10 million lawsuit against The New York Times Co., contending its trademark rights were violated when a Times' subsidiary used the name ``NOW'' for some new magazines. The civil complaint by Mall Network Publications Inc. was filed Wednesday in U.S. District Court in Cleveland against The New York Times Co. and two of its companies, The New York Times Co. Magazine Group and The Family Circle Inc. Family Circle recently launched ``Family Circle NOW!'' which it described as a ``new concept in women's magazines'' that involves publication of a series of single-subject magazines on topics such as cooking and outdoor living. But Mall Network of Beachwood said in its complaint that it obtained a registered trademark for the title ``NOW'' in 1987 for a fashion and lifestyle magazine the Ohio company publishes. The suit asks for $10 million in punitive damages and for orders barring the Times from promoting and selling the ``NOW'' magazines. June Golden of Family Circle's public relations department deferred questions to the parent company. Nancy Nielsen, spokeswoman for The New York Times Co., said she could not comment because she had not seen the lawsuit. Mall Network said the first edition of the new Family Circle publicationspping malls, direct mailing and newspaper inserts, is more than 7 million.

DOC.HEAD: Boeing Seeks Shareholder OK To Double Stock
DOC.TEXT: The Boeing Co. is seeking sharegholder approval to more than double the number of outstanding common shares to 600 million, but the company said in its proxy statement that it has no immediate plan to issue more stock. Boeing has 230.6 million common shares outstanding. ``What they're doing is a little long-range housekeeping,'' said Paul Nisbet, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York. ``They're approving authorization just in case they want to use it at a later date.'' Shareholders and the board of directors will vote on the proposal at the company's annual meeting on April 30. Bill Whitlow, Dain Bosworth's aerospace analyst in Seattle, said the authorization would given Boeing greater financial flexibility and bolster its already formidable hostile-takeover defenses. The additional shares could be issued, if needed, to dilute the holdings of a hostile party. ``It would give them one more weapon,'' he said. Less than a year ago the stock split 3 for 2. Even though the stock has reached that level, Boeing probably will not split it for at least another year, Nisbet predicted. A split reduces the value of each share but it doesn't reduce shareholders' investment position. The lower price for each share following splits generally opens up investment in a company to a broader range of investors. Wolfgang Demisch, an analyst with UBS Securities in New York, said Boeing usually likes to split its stock or float some sort of financing issue when it gets ready to launch a new airplane. Boeing is expected to decide by this summer whether to build its proposed new 777 wide-bodied airliner. In its proxy statement, Boeing said a stock sale could be used to obtain additional funds, allow the company to acquire other companies, or adopt additional employee compensation plans. The proxy also noted the 1989 salaries of the company's leading executives. Chairman and Chief Executive Frank Shrontz was paid $910,000, a 7 percent increase over his 1988 wage.

DOC.HEAD: General Mills Begins Food Delivery Business
DOC.TEXT: General Mills Inc. has begun an experimental business delivering casual foods such as chicken wings, roast chicken and sandwiches to customers ordering by telephone. Called Bringer's, the service is provided only to people who live in southwest Minneapolis and parts of suburban Edina, Richfield and Bloomington. The Bringer's venture fits the General Mills strategy of experimenting with concepts for several years before launching them nationally. DOC.HEAD: Big Three Sales Tumble Again
With BC-Auto Sales-Table
DOC.NOTE: Eds: AMs version planned.
DOC.TEXT: Car and light-truck sales by the nation's Big Three automakers fell 12.2 percent in mid-March compared with the same time last year as the 1990 spring buying season got off to a less-than-dazzling start, the companies said Friday. The automakers used incentives and temporary plant closings earlier this year to balance production and sales levels, but consumer demand appeared to be flagging as the March and April buying season got under way. Chrysler Corp. led the slide, with its combined car and truck sales down 26.6 percent during the period. General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler said they sold an average of 31,918 cars and trucks during March 11-20 this year, compared with a daily rate of 36,321 during the same period last year. Car sales this year were 13.2 percent lower than last year and truck sales were down 10.5 percent. It was the third consecutive 10-day period that sales dropped compared with last year. Typically, car and truck sales get a shot in the arm in the spring as Americans head for the road. But last year, after automakers offered attractive incentives in January and February, the hoped-for spring buying blitz fizzled. The companies may find themselves in a similar situation if early indications hold. So far this month, Big Three car and truck sales were down 9.6 percent compared with the first 20 days of March last year. For the year so far, combined car and truck sales for the three companies were down 3.9 percent, with a 0.4 percent increase in truck sales offset by a 6.6 percent decline in car sales. Chrysler's mid-March car sales tumbled 29.9 percent while its truck sales fell 23.3 percent. Through March 20 of this year, Chrysler's combined car and truck sales were down 3.5 percent compared with last year. GM said sales of its cars and trucks in mid-March were down 9.5 percent, with car sales down 10.4 percent and truck sales off 7.8 percent. So far this year, GM's cars and trucks were selling at a pace 1.9 percent behind last year's. Ford's mid-March car and truck sales didn't suffer quite as much as GM's, dropping 8.2 percent, with car sales down 10 percent and truck sales off 5.5 percent. So far this year, Ford's combined car and truck sales were down 6.8 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Ampco-Pittsburgh Increases Stake in Midway Airlines
DOC.TEXT: Ampco-Pittsburgh Corp., previously rebuffed in its bid for a seat on the board of Midway Airlines Inc., said Friday that it had increased its stake in the Chicago-based carrier to 12.4 percent. The disclosure came in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The filing stated that Ampco-Pittsburgh purchased an additional 280,300 Midway shares since March 8 at prices ranging from $11.50 to $11.75 per share. It now holds 1.2 million Midway common shares. The filing indicated that Ampco-Pittsburgh's intentions toward Midway had not changed since January, when it said it was exploring options after its request for representation on Midway's board was rejected by the airline. Ampco-Pittsburgh did not say what those options were. Ampco-Pittsburgh has been given permission by the Federal Trade Commission to acquire up to 15 percent of Midway's shares. In August, Ampco-Pittsburgh said in an SEC filing that it was acquiring Midway shares for investment purposes and that it may seek to acquire control of the airline. A spokesman for the Pittsburgh-based heavy manufacturing concern said the company had no comment beyond what was contained in the brief filing with the SEC on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Holmes a Court Threatens Lloyd Webber's Plan
DOC.TEXT: Stoll Moss Theaters Ltd., the entertainment company of Australian businessman Robert Holmes a Court, said Friday it has acquired a 6.61 percent stake in Really Useful Group PLC, threatening Andrew Lloyd Webber's plan to take the company private. Under British law, the British composer can force remaining shareholders to tender their shares to him only if he gains control of more than 95 percent of the company. A call to Really Useful's office seeking comment Friday evening was answered by an answering machine. Lloyd Webber, who serves as a director of Really Useful, is offering 233 pence, or the equivalent of $3.73 a share, for all of Really Useful's 33.2 million shares outstanding. The total value of his offer is 77.4 million pounds, or $124 million. Lloyd Webber already owns 82.5 percent of the stock. Lloyd Webber has said he wants to switch his attention to movies from theatrical musicals without worrying about the company's stock price. Really Useful's shares fell 6 pence, or 10 cents, to close at 234 pence, or $3.74, Friday on London's Stock Exchange. Analysts said Holmes a Court might be seeking to bargain with Lloyd Webber over both Really Useful's theater assets and copyrights on Lloyd Webber's productions. Really Useful seeks to exploit the copyrights it owns to Lloyd Webber musicals such as ``Cats'' and ``Phantom of the Opera.''

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Slide On Profit-Taking, Brazil Concerns
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices closed substantially lower Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade on profit-taking prompted in part by ideas that Brazilian soy exports may resume soon. Grain futures prices fell modestly. Exports of Brazilian soybean meal and oil have been on hold this week while the government implements economic reforms aimed at halting runaway inflation in the South American nation. The reforms include a new currency with free-floating foreign exchange rates and limits on bank account withdrawals. When they were announced a week ago, many market analysts said the measures might result in a flood of export sales of Brazilian commodities. Brazil is the world's second-largest soybean grower and the largest exporter of soy products. William Biedermann, research director with the commodities brokerage Allendale Inc. in Crystal Lake, Ill., said soybean speculators sold contracts Friday to reduce their risk to a reopening of Brazilian exports. ``There is some concern that if Brazil's problems are resolved, they would be a heavy seller over the weekend,'' he said. The decline in grain futures reflected pre-weekend profit-taking and slack export sales of U.S. grains. At the close, wheat futures were 1 cent to 4{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in May at $3.56} a bushel; corn futures were \ cent to 1\ cents lower with May at $2.58{ a bushel; oats were 1\ cents to 2} cents lower with May at $1.47} a bushel; soybeans were 5 cents to 6{ cents lower with May at $5.98{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Official Plans to Sell State's Interest In Colt
DOC.TEXT: State Treasurer Francisco Borges just announced a deal to make the state's pension fund a major owner of Colt Firearms, but he's already talking about selling that interest because he doesn't like guns. ``What I have is an exit strategy to get me out of this thing,'' Borges said Thursday, the day he announced a deal that gives new life to the 154-year-old gun maker after a bitter, four-year strike. Asked why he would want to get out of it so quickly, Borges said simply, ``I don't like guns.'' Under terms of the buyout, the state will put up $25 million from pension funds and will own about 47 percent of a newly created company called Colt's Manufacturing Co. In addition, strikers would be put back to work based on seniority and would receive a total of $13 million in back pay, a 13 percent wage increase and a stock ownership plan that will allow United Auto Workers members to own 11.5 percent of the company. In return, the UAW dropped a lawsuit charging Colt with unfair labor practices. Borges, who described the deal as a ``carefully structured, potentially very profitable business,'' said his distaste for the Colt product was outweighed by his concern for the striking employees and his conviction that the investment would be good for the pension fund. But now that the company has been saved, Borges said he would like to curtail his role in it. The plan is still evolving, but it calls for the creation of a new state program sponsored by the Department of Economic Development and financed by selling bonds. Borges and Stephen B. Heintz, economic development commissioner, said the new program would help the state save manufacturing firms that might go out of business or move out of the state. Although its first beneficiary may be Colt, the main purpose would be to position the state to step in quickly should another company get into serious trouble. ``All of this is still in the exploratory stages,'' Heintz said. A bill to create the program is before the Legislature's Finance, Review and Bonding Committee. Depending on its final form, Borges said it might enable him to sell much of the investment in Colt at a profit within a short period of time.

DOC.HEAD: Bondholders Cautious About Ingersoll Bond Buyback
DOC.TEXT: Looming, junk-bond related debt problems are threatening Ingersoll Publications, owner of the new St. Louis Sun newspaper and a host of other publications. And so far, a plan by owner Ralph Ingersoll II to buy back some of the company's junk bonds at cut-rate prices is not receiving a warm welcome from analysts and bondholders. ``The bonds are not worth 100 cents on the dollar, but they're certainly worth more than what the company is offering,'' Stephen Unterhalter, senior analyst with R.D. Smith Co. in New York, said Friday. Ingersoll Publications Inc., whose newspaper holdings include the St. Louis Sun, the New Haven Register and other dailies and weeklies across the country and in Europe, offered this week to buy back up to $158.6 million of its debt at a big discount. Privately held Ingersoll, which is based in Princeton, N.J., has been struggling to pay rising costs from last fall's startup of the Sun and from increased interest expenses. The offer to buy debt comes three months before the troubled Ingersoll subsidiary, Community Newspapers, faces what analysts say is the impossible task of ``resetting'' its $125 million worth of bonds. The bonds, issued at 13 percent interest, have been selling at 40 cents on the dollar. The reset provision for them would require Ingersoll to raise the interest rate on June 30 so that the bonds would sell at 101 cents. ``There is no way to reset them,'' said James Rubin, who has organized a group of bondholders to negotiate with Ingersoll. ``The interest rate is so high it's unrealistic. It would seriously impair the credit worthiness of the bonds.'' Ingersoll has offered to buy back up to 80 percent of the $125 million worth of bonds for 55 cents on the dollar. The company also has offered to pay 25 cents on the dollar for 51 percent of $114.9 million in bonds that won't start paying interest until next June. Bondholders can't evaluate the offer because they haven't been able to get information on the company over the past several weeks, said Rubin, who works for Sass, Lamle, Rubin & Co., a New York-based investment firm specializing in financially distressed companies. ``We think it's understandable that company officials haven't been able to talk with us. They've been tied up trying to resolve their problems,'' Rubin said Friday. ``We don't look at it as a problem, but as a hurdle to overcome.'' Ingersoll Publications declined to comment on the bond buyback, referring questions to its financial adviser Goldman, Sachs & Co. The financial problems hitting Ingersoll Publications are based partly on the sagging state of the junk-bond market, where prices have fallen widely _ boosting interest rates _ since the highly publicized failures of several junk-financed companies, such as Campeau Corp.'s Federated and Allied department store chains. The market also has been hit hard by the collapse in February of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., its main underwriter and a key source of financing for Ingersoll acquisitions in recent years. Analysts say Ingersoll also suffered because it paid too much and took on too much debt to buy Community Newspapers in 1987, analysts said. Since the much-ballyhooed launch of the brash new tabloid Sun, which has been spending money on a slew of promotions but has attracted limited advertising, Ingersoll has been buying and selling newspapers. He bought the New Haven Register from Goodson Newspapers Inc. in December for $255 million. That same month, he bought 50 percent interest in three newspapers in Dublin, Ireland. In January, he sold 10 small dailies in Massachusetts, Ohio, New York, Michigan, Indiana, North Carolina and Wisconsin. Analysts speculated that Ingersoll sold some of the newspapers to help pay interest expenses. But company spokesman Arthur Wright said Friday the sale was part of the company's new corporate strategy to sell small dailies that aren't near a metropolitan area. Ingersoll owns 19 daily newspapers in the United States and Great Britain and also operates a dozen chains of weekly newspapers, most of them located in the same cities as Ingersoll daily newspapers.

DOC.HEAD: Precede DALLAS
Federal Mediators Met Today with Greyhound Negotiator; No New Talks Set
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material, editing throughout. CORRECTS spelling from Lanney to Lannie in graf 2, Greyhound's chief negotiator. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A Greyhound Lines representative met with federal mediators today in an effort to solve a drivers strike but the meeting produced no plan for further bargaining sessions, according to a source close to the negotiations. Greyhound's chief negotiator, Anthony P. Lannie, met with mediators at the National Mediation and Conciliation Service to discuss the company's position on wages and grievance procedures. ``The meeting did not result in plans for a new bargaining session,'' said a source close to the mediation process. The company broke off talks in the three-week old strike Sunday in Tucson, Ariz. The company has said it would not bargain with the union until attacks on buses stop. Since Wednesday, shots have been fired at four Greyhound buses driven by replacement drivers and a fifth was pelted by rocks. Nobody was seriously injured, authorities said. Early today, someone shot an arrow at a bus carrying 59 passengers in Cleveland. The arrow hit a window on the passenger side. No one was injured. Unions representing 6,300 drivers and an estimated 3,000 other Greyhound workers walked out over wages, job security and grievance procedures. Greyhound operates the only nationwide intercity bus service, and the strike has stranded many smaller communities for which buses are the only public transportation. There have been 20 shootings at buses nationwide since the strike began March 2, the company said Thursday. The Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions in Washington released its own list Thursday, saying 55 pickets have been injured over the three weeks by being struck by buses, hit by security guards, or in other incidents. Greyhound spokesman George Gravley said Thursday the violence pushes Greyhound away from reopening talks. ``It's impossible to reach an agreement while this violence and terrorism is going on,'' Gravley said. Nelson said any suggestion that violent acts have tacit approval from union leaders is ``absolutely ridiculous.'' There have been no serious injuries in the 20 shootings. But on the second day of the strike a veteran Greyhound driver was crushed to death on the picket line by a bus driven by a replacement in Redding, Calif. No charges were filed. In the most recent shootings: _The company said a Dallas-bound bus with no passengers aboard was fired upon 15 miles east of Lake Charles, La., Thursday evening. The bullet penetrated a rear air filter, the company said, but police in Calcaiseu Parish said it appeared that a van had a tire blowout as it passed the bus near the Iowa exit of Interstate 10. _Earlier Thursday in the St. Louis area, gunfire hit the windshield of a bus carrying 19 passengers from St. Louis to Memphis, Tenn., on Interstate 55, and four shots struck a bus carrying eight passengers from Chicago, Greyhound spokesman George Gravley said. There were no injuries in either shooting. _On Wednesday, a bullet was fired at a bus carrying 30 people in San Antonio. The bullet struck but did not penetrate a service door. _A Greyhound bus en route to Los Angeles was pelted by rocks on Interstate 15, west of the Las Vegas Strip on Wednesday, said police. An elderly passenger was slightly hurt by flying glass. Federal and state authorities were investigating the shootings. Nelson said the union issued letters Wednesday afternoon asking members to refrain from violence. ``Whoever has committed these crimes should know that the union will support prosecution to the fullest extent of the law,'' Nelson said. ``These are extremely unfortunate incidents.''

DOC.HEAD: Huge Demand Forces KFC to Drop Ads on New Product
DOC.TEXT: Kentucky Fried Chicken's new Hot Wings have proven too hot to handle. The Pepsico Inc. subsidiary said Thursday it was suspending a 2-week-old national television advertising campaign for the spicy chicken product because sales are running 50 percent above projections and it needs time to rebuild its supply. ``It's an absolute success. Consumers love 'em,'' said KFC spokesman Gregg Reynolds. ``We just hope people will be patient when they run into short supply.'' Kentucky Fried Chicken could use a lift, as the chain has proven a drag in recent months on earnings from Pepsico's restaurant division. In the fourth quarter ended Dec. 31, Pepsico said its restaurant business posted a 9 percent increase in operating profit to $114.3 million. But while quarterly earnings rose 21 percent at Pizza Hut and 33 percent at Taco Bell, they fell 12 percent at Kentucky Fried Chicken. KFC launched Hot Wings, which are breaded and deep-fried chicken wings, on March 5. The national advertising campaign began a week later. KFC had either rescheduled its ads or was working on doing so. The suspension reportedly affected TV contracts worth about $4 million. KFC has also ordered its company-owned restaurants to remove promotional banners and signs while it rebuilds supplies. The fast-food chain is promoting Hot Wings as a snack to younger consumers and those who are not regular customers in an effort to increase customers. They are are sold in two sizes _ six pieces for $1.89 and 18 pieces for $4.99. KFC originally projected that it would sell 6.2 million pounds of Hot wings during the first two weeks of national promotion. Instead, the total will be close to 9 million, officials said. Hot Wings are expected to make up 17 percent of total sales, said John Inwright, director of food for KFC National Purchasing Cooperative Inc. But he said some KFC restaurants are reporting more than half of their sales from Hot Wings alone.

DOC.HEAD: Sales Slide in Mid-March As Rebates Dwindled
With BC-Auto Sales-Table
DOC.TEXT: Sales of North American-built cars and trucks tumbled 9.5 percent in mid-March compared with a weak period last year as the absence of big rebates, especially on trucks, showed its effect, automakers said Friday. The nine major automakers with U.S. plants said they sold cars and trucks at an average daily rate of 35,497 during March 11-20 this year, compared with a rate of 39,225 during the same period last year. Car sales slipped 8.9 percent while truck sales were down 10.6 percent. The slide in truck sales, which make up 38 percent of all vehicles sold in the United States, may end soon. On Thursday, General Motors Corp., for the first time, offered $1,000 rebates on its three-vehicle line of front-wheel-drive minivans. Ford Motor Co. already was offering a $500 rebate on its Aerostar minivan. When Chrysler Corp. offered incentives on its market-leading minivans in late December and January, sales soared. But since the incentives expired, sales have plummeted. Chrysler led the decline in mid-March sales with a 29.9 percent drop in car sales and a 23.3 percent decline in truck sales, combining for a 26.6 percent overall sales skid. ``The minivan incentives probably created a lot of sales for them, but pulled sales from March,'' said auto analyst Douglas Laughlin of Bear, Stearns & Co. of New York. ``More definitively, the Omni-Horizon has been discontinued, so they are not pushing those.'' Chrysler stopped making those subcompact cars, which accounted for about 79,500 sales last year, in early February when the No. 3 automaker closed a plant in Detroit. The company currently has no large-volume subcompact car. Mid-March sales at GM and Ford fell less drastically than at Chrysler. GM's combined car and truck sales were 9.5 percent lower during the period and Ford's were down 8.2 percent. Sales in mid-March last year were below what proved to be the trend for the entire year, and this year the demand appears down from that. The overall sales rate in mid-March, Laughlin said, ``still reflects weakness in the industry and the fact that interest rates are rising.'' Usually, March and April are hot car and truck selling months as Americans prepare for spring and summer road trips. But as automakers move incentive offers in and out of the market, trends tend to vanish. ``You look at the first two 10-day periods (of March) and it would seem that way,'' Laughlin said. For the first 20 days of the month, the car and truck sales rate was 9.6 percent behind last year's pace. Since the first of the year, Chrysler's combined car and truck sales were down 3.5 percent compared with last year. The strong January minivan sales helped soften the blow of weak car sales. GM said its car sales were down 10.4 percent and truck sales were off 7.8 percent in mid-March. So far this year, vehicles made by the world's largest automaker were selling at a pace 1.9 percent behind last year's. No. 2 Ford's mid-March car sales fell 10 percent and truck sales dropped 5.5 percent, the smallest decline of the Big Three. Ford's combined car and truck sales were down 6.8 percent through March 20 this year compared with last.
