DOC.NOTE: $adv26
For release Monday March 26
DOC.HEAD: U.S. Automakers Increasingly Compare Themselves to the Japanese
DOC.TEXT: Lee Iacocca, the Chrysler Corp. chairman who's talked frankly with Americans for years, leans forward and peers over his bifocals. He's just spent 52 seconds of national television advertising time emphatically reminding lieutenants in the Chrysler boardroom that the company's cars are just as good as Japan's, but there's a problem. ``Nobody knows it,'' says Iacocca, ``and that's going to change.'' His pitch to change Chrysler's image is perhaps the boldest example of a theme that has dominated Detroit's effort to contain the foreign assault on the U.S. car market, of which Japan commands a 25 percent chunk. The Big Three are telling consumers to buy American cars because they're just as good as Japan's. What Iacocca's message doesn't tell consumers is that many cars with Big Three nameplates are now either produced in Japan, designed by the competition or built in partnership with the increasingly mighty rivals across the Pacific. General Motors Corp.'s Chevrolet Division, for example, markets its four small Geo vehicles as ``import inspired.'' Actually, two of the cars are made in Japan, and the other two are assembled in GM-Japanese joint venture plants in the United States ana corral of new Chrysler cars serving as a backdrop while executives talk about the company's cars and make themselves available to the press. In Atlanta last week, Iacocca repeated his message saying he wants to take the ``Teflon kimono'' off Japanese automakers. ``We have a perception that in the '80s we built lousy cars and guess what? We built lousy cars,'' he said standing in front of some of Chrysler's 1990 models. Ford is doing basically the same thing with the Escort, a car that won't be a big profit-maker but one the company calls critical in efforts to meet federal fuel efficiency regulations. Automakers shouldn't expect too quick of a bang out of their Japanese comparison advertising or road shows, said auto analyst Charles Brady of Oppenheimer & Co. of New York. Their advertising may not make too much of a difference anyway, he said. ``The crux of the matter here is that people buy cars on what they've experienced and what they've heard other people have experienced,'' Brady said. ``It doesn't matter if you think you're equal today. ``If you've proven to be inferior in the recent past, you will have to pay a price for that.'' Japanese automakers themselves fought a similar battle in the 1970s. ``It was hard for them to gain a toehold in our market because their products were cheap and inferior,'' Brady said. ``And they kept chipping away.''
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Monday March 26

DOC.HEAD: Petroleum Futures Rise
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures ended higher Friday led by strength in gasoline, after a choppy week of trading sparked by concern about seasonal demand weakness. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the May contract for West Texas Intermediate, the key grade of U.S. crude oil, rose 39 cents to finish at $20.39 a 42-gallon barrel after a 4-cent rise on Thursday. Contracts for later delivery also advanced. Among refined products traded on the exchange, wholesale unleaded gasoline for delivery next month, which fell 0.56 cent in the previous session, advanced 0.28 cent to 57.66 cents a gallon. May unleaded gasoline jumped 1.56 cents to 63.54 cents and June gained 0.98 cent to 62.77 cents. No. 2 heating oil for April delivery ended at 55.46 cents a gallon, up 0.45 cent, while May gained 0.70 cent to 53.67 cents and June rose 0.89 cent to 52.98 cents. Analysts said two consecutive weeks of lower gasoline inventories was bullish for the gasoline market and helped buoy the crude and heating oil markets. Tighter gasoline supplies around the Gulf of Mexico became more noticeable late Thursday, they said. ``Demand for gasoline is picking up in the Gulf. Apparently there's not as much available as people thought so gasoline led the market up,'' said Tom Bentz, director of futures trades for United Energy Inc. Analysts attributed the lower gasoline supplies partly to seasonal refinery maintenance, when big oil companies close refineries for annual repair. During the maintenance period, refineries use less crude oil and make fewer fuel products, such as gasoline. Oil prices have sagged in recent weeks due mainly to increasing supplies and slowing demand. OPEC is believed to be producing about 1 million barrels a day more of crude oil than the market can absorb.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Higher, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mostly higher in domestic and foreign trading Friday but fell sharply against the yen as investors regained some confidence in the Japanese currency. Gold prices were lower. Analysts said a rise in interest rates in Japan and a recovery on the Tokyo Stock Exchange after a string of steep losses helped support the yen, which itself has fallen sharply in recent weeks. Jack Barbanel, president of First Global Asset Management Inc., said traders believed Japanese yields would go even higher, which would make the yen even more attractive. The dollar fell to 154.30 yen in New York from 155.095 late Thursday. In Tokyo early Friday, the dollar rose 0.24 yen to a closing 155.07 yen, and in London, it was quoted at a sharply lower rate of 153.85 yen. Overseas dealers said the dollar was hit in afternoon dealings by a report, later denied, that Japan was moving to issue dollar-denominated bonds in a bid to add a layer of intervention to help the sagging yen. The dollar also was hit by profit-taking before Friday's talks between Treasury Secretary James Brady and his Japanese counterpart, Ryutaro Hashimoto, in Los Angeles. Barbanel said the dollar's strong showing against other currencies was due partly to higher interest rates in the United States, and also to concerns about tensions between the Soviet Union and Lithuania. The dollar is seen as a safe haven in times of international political strife. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's quotes, included: 1.7135 West German marks, up from 1.7028; 1.5200 Swiss francs, up from 1.5120; 5.7720 French francs, up from 5.7415; 1,260.25 Italian lire, up from 1,255.50; and 1.17505 Canadian dollars, down from 1.17575. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's prices, included: 1.7100 West German marks, up from 1.7054; 1.5179 Swiss francs, up from 1.5150; 5.7645 French francs, up from 5.7505; 1.9249 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9210; 1,258.50 Italian lire, up from 1,255.50; and 1.1751 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1757. The pound recovered somewhat from its recent slide on Britain's economic woes and political uncertainty. In London, the pound rose to $1.6040 from $1.6015 late Thursday, but it fell in New York to $1.6010 from $1.6040. Gold fell $5.10 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York, closing at $388.90. Later, Republic National Bank of New York quoted a bid of $389.10 a troy ounce, down $4.90. Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $386.95 a troy ounce from $393.05 bid late Thursday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $391.50 from $393 late Thursday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose 13 cents to close at a bid $393.65. Silver fell 4.1 cents to $5.043 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange. In London, silver fell to a late bid price of $5.04 a troy ounce, down from Thursday's $5.08.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market rose modestly Friday, recovering from three straight days of declines. Analysts said the market was bolstered by a moderate gain overnight in the Tokyo stock market and an advance Friday in the U.S. bond market. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials gained 8.56 points to 2,704.28. The blue-chip barometer slipped from its levels earlier in the day, however. Advancing issues outnumbered declining ones by around 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 884 up, 571 down and 527 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board totaled 132.07 million shares, down from 175.93 million in Thursday's session. ``We were really set for a bounce,'' said Alfred E. Goldman, a vice president of A.G. Edwards & Sons Inc. in St. Louis, Mo. In Tokyo, stock prices seesawed but managed to finish moderately higher, ending a week of heavy losses on an up-note. The Nikkei index of 225 selected issues, which had lost nearly 6 percent Thursday before rebounding to end the day with a 3.1 percent loss, gained 1.77 percent Friday. The index added 528.82 points to close the week at 30,372.16. Wall Street declined on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, partly in response to the Japanese slide. The report that U.S. orders for ``big-ticket'' durable goods rose 3.3 percent in February lifted stock and bond prices, since the increase was smaller than most economists expected. ``That was good news,'' said Hugh Johnson, senior vice president at First Albany Corp. in Albany, N.Y. ``It suggests that we're in that no-boom, no-bust trajectory.'' The perception that inflation is under control in the United States was one of the factors supporting Wall Street's recent impressive rally. It was reflected in the dollar's strength against other major currencies such as those of Japan and West Germany, where faster economic growth has fueled inflation fears lately. Among actively traded issues on the NYSE, AT&T was up [ at 41{, Philip Morris rose ~ to 39], General Electric gained ] at 63} and Exxon edged up [ to 46[. IBM was down 1{ at 105. A newspaper report said the computer giant has told customers it won't deliver an upgrade to its line of mainframe computers this year. Amoco declined ] to 52[ and Ames Department Stores was unchanged at 4~. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 158.55 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market gained $11.72 billion, or 0.36 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index edged up 0.75 to 185.45. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 1.78 to 381.34, and S&P's 500-stock composite index advanced 1.53 to 337.22. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market was up 2.74 at 437.25. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index rose 1.13 to 361.61.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Post Tiny Gains
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices posted small gains Friday after a volatile session during which prices climbed on new signs of economic weakness and fell on worries that the Japanese may start issuing dollar-denominated securities. The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose [ point, or about $1.25 per $1,000 in face value. Its yield slipped to 8.47 percent from 8.48 percent late Thursday. Analysts said bond prices initially rose after the government announced a 3.3 percent gain in durable goods orders last month. ``The durable goods report was weaker than expected, and showed there is still some sluggishness in factory sector,'' said Steven A. Wood, economist for BankAmerica Capital Markets Group in San Francisco. The 30-year bond rose more than } point, or $7.50 for every $1,000 in face value, on that news. But Wood said prices lost ground after a news report from Japan indicated the Japanese government may be considering issuing dollar-denominated securities in an effort to support the sagging yen. The report raised fears that the market would be unable to absorb the extra bond supply. ``That took prices down, but as the market discounted those fears, prices came back again,'' Wood said. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term governments rose by between 1-32 point and 3-32 point, intermediate maturities gained [ point and long-term issues rose 1-16 point to [ point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point equals a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, rose 0.76 to 1,154.80. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds rose 1-32 point to 91 9-16. The average yield to maturity held steady at 7.49 percent. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 8.12 percent as the discount lost 4 basis points to 7.86 percent. Yields on six-month bills slipped to 8.24 percent as the discount fell to 7.82 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 8.27 percent as the discount declined 2 basis points to 7.70 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8\ percent, unchanged from late Thursday.

DOC.NOTE: $adv26
For release Monday March 26
DOC.HEAD: Old Factories, Grain Elevators Targeted For Preservation
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: From Buffalo's rusty waterfront to the steel-mill hulks of Pittsburgh, a small but growing movement is underway to save examples of industry from the ravages of the post-industrial age by preserving them as national parks. The thought may startle those for whom the term ``national park'' conjures up images of jagged mountains, foaming waterfalls, boiling geysers and other pastoral scenes. ``A revolution is going on that I think is as significant as the industrial revolution of the late 1800s,'' said Eric N. DeLony, head of the National Park Service's Historic American Engineering Record unit. ``We're in the process of completely redefining our economic base.'' In that process, old factories, canals and warehouses that no longer have an economic role to play face the threat of a wrecker's ball. DeLony said if he had his way, sites like the baker's dozen of grain elevators along the Buffalo waterfront would be preserved as parks. ``It's this cluster of 13 huge concrete monoliths along the lake shore,'' he said. ``They are representative of industry in America. We are one of the largest grain producers and have been so historically, and elevators are a stop in the process of moving grain from the heartland east.'' The grain elevator was invented here in 1842, and Buffalo's specimens include the 92-year-old Great Northern, one of only two surviving brick-and-steel elevators, and the quarter-mile-long Concrete Central, big enough to handle three lake freighters simultaneously and the largest in the world when built in 1918. Buffalo remains the country's flour-milling capital, and half the elevators are still in use. But Concrete Central stands vacant, and the crumbling Great Northern has been threatened with demolition by owner Pillsbury Inc. To architecture students from Canada and Europe who take boat tours of the elevators each summer, such buildings are an important landmark in the development of 20th century architecture, their stark walls inspiring modernist architects such as Erich Mendelsohn and Le Corbusier. ``It became known as the form-follows-function school of architecture _ very clean, simple lines, as opposed to the Victorian style which was very decorative,'' said Lorraine Pierro, president of Buffalo's Industrial Heritage Committee. But many Buffalo residents, when they think of the elevators at all, see them as just a hazy part of the industrial wasteland. ``I think it's partly a fault of the educational system,'' Pierro said. ``Many people said to me, they've lived in this area all their lives and never knew where the Buffalo River was.'' The preservation movement is more advanced in Lowell, Mass., 25 miles north of Boston, where twin national and state parks incorporate much of the city's downtown. ``We have a representative sample of the important buildings in Lowell's history,'' said Chrysandra Walter, superintendent of Lowell National Historic Park. ``We have a mill building. We have a boardinghouse, where the mill girls and the immigrants lived. We have an agent's house, where the mill agent and his family would have lived. The state has 11 or so gatehouses along the canal, that house the mechanism for running the canal.'' The park has become Lowell's main tourist attraction, partly because industrial New England is not the sort of place visitors expect to find a national park, said Michelle Hatem, executive director of the Northern Middlesex Convention and Visitors Bureau. ``People at first say, `What do you mean it's a park?''' she said. ``They expect green space, nature and all.'' Other industrial heritage parks in existence or in the works incorporate the Lake Michigan-Illinois River canal system in Chicago; the steel mills of Pittsburgh's Monongahela Valley; and the coal, steel and railroads of northeastern Pennsylvania. Parks have also been proposed for the copper industry of northern Michigan, Washington state's hydroelectric plants and even the Cape Canaveral space center. The first step in preserving something like Buffalo's grain elevators is for a crew of students, under the direction of DeLony and his full-time staff of seven, to make architectural drawings. ``This is a very pedantic, scholarly exercise,'' DeLony said. ``I'll have two or three students up there this summer, if the funding comes through, measuring and drawing.'' The drawings will be a permanent record of the buildings in the event they are destroyed, but the exercise also sends a message, he said: ``Look, Buffalonians, if the federal government and the National Park Service are interested enough to send a special team to your city to document these structures, they're worth saving.'' While the federal government is interested enough to spend $380,000 a year on documenting historic buildings, it's usually up to local governments and preservationists to raise the larger sums necessary to acquire and preserve historic buildings. DeLony, who grew up in Cleveland and visited Buffalo frequently as a child, said Buffalo's preoccupation with enhancing its national image could be used in the project's favor. ``My image of Buffalo was Niagara Falls, first of all, but the other image was these magnificent grain elevators,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Monday March 26

DOC.HEAD: Gold Futures Resume Slide on Dollar Strength
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices tumbled to 4{-month lows Friday on New York's Commodity Exchange amid heavy European selling as the dollar resumed its advance against most other major currencies. On other commodity markets, silver also retreated; grains and soybeans fell; energy future advanced; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Gold futures settled $5.30 to $5.60 lower with the contract for delivery in April at $389.40 a troy ounce, the lowest settlement for a near-month gold contract since Nov. 10. Silver futures ended 4.1 cents to 4.7 cents lower in New York with March at $5.043 a troy ounce. Analysts said buying interest in gold has faded as prices have skidded from near $430 an ounce over the past six weeks. April gold fell by $11.50 in this week alone. Gold is traded in dollars on the world market, so a stronger dollar makes the metal more expensive in terms of other currencies, discouraging foreign buying. But analysts said gold's decline in the face of global political and economic uncertainty suggests other factors are also at play. Gold traditionally has been viewed as a safe haven for investors during times of inflation and political crises such as the current showdown between the Soviet Union and the breakaway Lithuanian republic. But instead of buying gold, international investors have shunned the metal, preferring to buy U.S. dollars. ``The dollar is becoming the safe haven,'' said John Jonat, a precious-metals trader with Deak International Inc. William O'Neill, research director with Elders Futures Inc., said the gold market ignored a bevy of traditionally bullish developments during the week, including rising U.S. retail prices, predictions for high inflation in Britain, a sharp drop Thursday in the stock market and the increasingly tense Lithuanian situation. At the same time, the dollar has surged in value. ``You can see that the focus here is on the dollar more than anything else,'' O'Neill said. Soybean futures prices fell substantially on the Chicago Board of Trade on profit-taking prompted in part by beliefs that Brazilian soy exports may resume soon. Grain futures prices fell modestly. Exports of Brazilian soybean meal and oil have been on hold this week while the government implements economic reforms aimed at halting runaway inflation in the South American nation. Wheat futures settled 1 cent to 4{ cents lower with May at $3.56} a bushel; corn futures were \ cent to 1{ cents lower with May at $2.58{ a bushel; oats were 1\ cents to 2 cents lower with May at $1.47} a bushel; and soybeans were 5 cents to 7 cents lower with May at $5.98 a bushel. Petroleum futures advanced in technically inspired trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 7 cents to 39 cents higher with May at $20.39 a barrel; heating oil was .45 cent to .70 cent higher with April at 55.46 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .15 cent to 1.56 cents higher with April at 57.66 cents a gallon. Expectations for stronger cash markets next week prompted buying of livestock futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Pork bellies ended mixed ahead of the Agriculture Department's monthly cold-storage report, which showed a lower-than-expected amount of pork bellies in commercial freezers as of Feb. 28. Belly prices are expected to rise in reaction to the report when trading resumes Monday. Live cattle futures settled .20 cent lower to .38 cent higher with April at 77.20 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .08 cent lower to .22 cent higher with March at 82.65 cents a pound; live hogs were .05 cent to .73 cent higher with April at 53.75 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .58 cent lower to .50 cent higher with March at 50.87 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: UAL Opens Door To Davis Stock Purchase; Analysts Play Down Development
DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp.'s board of directors said Friday it will let former suitor Marvin Davis again buy company stock, raising the possibility of a rival buyout offer to the $3.8 billion bid by UAL's unions and a major shareholder. Davis sparked a bidding war for UAL last August but later withdrew his buyout proposals after the company, the parent of United Airlines, accepted a higher offer from a group led by senior management and its pilots union. That plan later collapsed. UAL stock finished up $5.12{ at $157.87{ Friday on the New York Stock Exchange, although Coniston Partners, UAL's biggest shareholder and the backer of the union buyout, expressed skepticism that Davis would make an offer. ``I'm not sure what they (board members) were trying to accomplish or what the implications might be,'' said Keith Gollust, a principal in Coniston, a New York-based investment group. Gollust said that more than two months ago, Coniston urged the UAL board to lift the restriction on Davis' purchase of stock as a way to enhance shareholder value. ``I don't see why anyone shouldn't be able to buy the stock,'' he said in a telephone interview Friday. ``As a practical matter, I don't expect him (Davis) to make a bid. ...It's very speculative.'' Rob Doughty, UAL spokesman, said he could not elaborate on a brief statement that the company had modified a standstill agreement with Davis to allow him to buy stock. Davis spokeswoman Mary Conway in New York also had no comment. Neither would say if Davis has a new buyout offer on the table. In January, the UAL board said it would consider offers from Davis, but the agreement had blocked him from purchasing stock. Davis, a Los Angeles billionaire, last August made an unsolicited offer, which was not accepted, of $200 a share or $4.32 billion for UAL. The United Airines pilots were the first employee group to propose buying the company, three years ago. The fourth and latest proposal was announced Monday by Coniston and the unions representing United's pilots, machinists and flight attendants. Representatives of those unions were not immediately available for comment on Friday. Under the offer, shareholders would receive $150 per share in cash, $25 in debt securities and stock in the new company, and the unions would make wage and benefit concessions in five-year contracts that contain no-strike clauses. The bid would give UAL employees, including non-union workers, 75 percent ownership of the company. The UAL board on Thursday said it would negotiate on the latest offer by the Coniston-union group, even though it believed the offer had ``serious deficiencies,'' including its value and the group's ability to finance it. The board also said it had directed its financial advisers to develop a plan for selling company assets. It said advisers also should consider buyout proposals from other parties and discuss other alternatives for increasing the value of UAL shares. In proposing the buyout, Coniston also threatened a proxy fight to replace the UAL board of directors at the company's April 26 meeting. The group owns 11.8 percent of UAL's outstanding stock. Robert J. Joedicke, advising director of Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York, said he did not think lifting the standstill restriction on Davis changed the buyout situation significantly. Joedicke said a takeover of UAL would be so complicated that Davis likely would have to join forces with other parties. But he added, ``If he got involved, all indications are he'd want to be more than one of the players.''

DOC.HEAD: Producers Agree to Extension of Pact with Consumers
DOC.TEXT: The world's key cocoa-producing countries agreed Friday to back a two-year extension of the present International Cocoa Agreement, with all price-support provisions frozen for the duration, a producer spokesman said. The producers accepted in all details the plan for the extension put forward by Peter Baron, the West German chairman of the 41-nation International Cocoa Organization, said producer spokesman Kouame N'Guessan of the Ivory Coast. But he said that his side at a separate meeting Friday did not reach a view on how the money needed to implement the extension could be guaranteed, and needed more time to study the question. Money is required to finance the storage of the cocoa organization's stockpile of 250,000 metric tons, which under Baron's plan would be frozen during the extension period. Delegates said that financing would be the key issue when the two sides begin a further week of discussions on the cocoa pact on Monday. The European Community and the cocoa organization's other leading consumers earlier this week accepted in principle Baron's plans, but officials said they wanted the extension linked to guarantees of adequate funding. The plan calls for the cocoa pact to be extended for two years starting Oct. 1, with all its present dormant powers to support prices officially suspended. ctober, but cash-in-hand Sept. 15 is forecast at $15 million. The shortfall is the result of unpaid producer debts to the organization totalling $140 million. Consumers have informally proposed that producers should either pay some of their debts, or agree that in an emergency some of the stockpiled cocoa could be sold to raise cash. They have suggested a token debt repayment of $15 million, or permission for the cocoa organization to sell 20,000 tons if necessary.

DOC.HEAD: Posts Loss of $298.5 Million for 1989
DOC.TEXT: Trans World Airlines Inc. said Friday it lost $298.5 million in 1989, contrasting with a profit of $249.7 million the previous year. The company, which was taken private by investor Carl Icahn in October 1988, said it had an operating profit of $24.3 million for the year ended Dec. 31, down sharply from $259.3 million in 1988. It said its operating revenue rose 3.4 percent to $4.51 billion in 1989 from $435 billion a year earlier. But operating expenses rose at a 9.3 percent rate to $4.48 billion from $4.11 billion in 1988. Icahn, who is TWA's chairman, in recent months has been pushing for wage concessions. He has asked pilots, for instance, for $80 million in wage and benefit concessions but talks have not produced any agreement. The company, based in Mt. Kisco, said the full-year loss reflected the sharp decline in operating profit and the absence in 1989 of $190.5 million in onetime gains related to its sale of stock in another company and a cash judgment in a longstanding legal dispute. TWA said its net interest expense in 1989 was up $193.9 million from the previous year. The company said its operating expenses rose mainly to a snapback of wage concessions from the machinists' union, higher salaries for other employees, a 12 percent increase in the average price of jet fuel and increased costs attributed to service improvements.

DOC.HEAD: Sells Norwegian Oil and Gas Operations for $322 Million
DOC.TEXT: Unocal Corp. said Friday it had agreed to sell a Norwegian oil and gas subsidiary for $322 million, the latest in a series of asset sales by the parent of Union Oil Co. of California. Total Marine Norsk AS, a subsidiary of a French company, is the buyer of Unocal Norge AS. Its petroleum exploration and production operations are in the Norwegian sectors of the North Sea. Unocal Norge is owned by a Unocal subsidiary, Unocal International Corp. Legal paperwork must still be completed and government approval obtained in Norway, but Unocal said the deal was expected to close this May. Unocal spokesman Michael Thacher described the sale as part of a company-wide redeployment of Unocal's $10 billion in assets, not a retreat from the North Sea. He noted that last year, Unocal was awarded seven offshore exploration blocks in the United Kingdom segment of the North Sea. Unocal is still suffering the effects of a heavy debt burden acquired while fending off a hostile takeover attempt in 1985 by corporate raider T. Boone Pickens, which forced it into a major restructuring. Last year, Unocal got out of the coal business, selling its Obed Mountain coal mine at a loss that contributed to a 46 percent decline in yearly profits.

DOC.HEAD: RF&P's Independent Directors: Let Shareholders Vote on CSX Merger
DOC.TEXT: RF&P Corp.'s independent directors reversed themselves Friday and voted to terminate a $385 million merger deal the railroad reached Feb. 19 with CSX Corp. Earlier in the day, the committee of independent directors said termination of the $34.50-a-share deal would not be in the best interests of RF&P shareholders. The panel's final action followed the enlargement of the committee to include RF&P's two new directors, Jacqueline G. Epps and Mark T. Finn. The two were recently appointed by the trustees of the Virginia Supplementary Retirement System, which owns RF&P common stock. ``Following discussion with the new members of the committee, the other members of the committee concluded that shareholder approval of the CXS proposal was highly unlikely, and for that reason, further pursuit of that proposal would not be in the best interests of the RF&P and its shareholders,'' the companies said in a joint release. The reconstituted special committee voted unanimously to accept the CSX proposal that the agreement be terminated. All six CSX-affiliated directors abstained from voting on the matter, and the action was later ratified by the full board, including the six CSX-affiliated directors. Friday's decision came three days after CSX announced it wanted to pull out of the deal because of controversy surrounding the merger. Under the terms of the proposal, both companies' boards must agree to terminate the merger. After CSX made its offer in February, numerous stock analysts criticized it as too low considering the potential value of RF&P's real estate holdings. The deal also was questioned by Gov. L. Douglas Wilder. The state owns 20 percent of RF&P common stock through its Supplemental Retirement System. Some observers said the CSX bid was tainted by conflicts of interest among RF&P directors. Wilder fired retirement board chairman Charles B. Walker, who represented the retirement system on the RF&P board and supported the merger. CSX argued that the special committee that weighed the proposal was composed only of RF&P directors who were not associated with CSX and that its offer was a good deal for RF&P, whose shareholders could take the $34.50 a share or exchange them for CSX shares on a 1-for-1 basis. Richmond-based CSX operates 19,000 miles of track in 20 states, the District of Columbia and Ontario, Canada. RF&P has 113 miles of track between Richmond and the northern Virginia suburbs of Washington, D.C. Both companies also have extensive commercial real estate interests.

DOC.HEAD: Lockheed Chairman Blasts Back at Simmons Over Proposed Sales
DOC.TEXT: Lockheed Corp. fired back at its chief assailant Friday, saying now is a bad time to sell assets from the military contractor's technology services and electronics systems groups. Texas investor Harold C. Simmons' proposals to do so are ``simplistic'' and show how poorly Simmons understands Lockheed, the aerospace giant's chairman, Daniel M. Tellep, said in a statement. Simmons is trying to unseat Lockheed's board of directors at the company's annual meeting March 29. He has purchased about 19 percent of Lockheed's stock at a cost of $530 million, and has shown a paper loss of about $100 million on his investment as the stock price has fallen. He said Thursday that if he wins control of Lockheed, he likely would sell $1 billion worth of assets in its technology and electronics services businesses _ sales he said would help boost the stock price. Simmons said Lockheed should concentrate on the core business it knows: missiles, space and aeronautics. Though no final decision would be made until after a review of the books, Simmons said Tellep's public statements lead him to believe that only small portions of the non-core divisions are profitable enough to merit keeping. Tellep said Simmons is ``fundamentally uninformed'' about the technology services and electronics systems groups, adding that there's no way to get a good price for them at present even if selling them were a good idea. ``These simplistic Simmons proposals are, we believe, typical of his attempt to sound constructive when he and his team in fact understand very little about our businesses,'' Tellep concluded. On another front in their battle, Simmons' chief lieutenant, J. Landis Martin, renewed his complaint Friday that Lockheed had denied Simmons access to Lockheed employees. The workers own 19 percent of Lockheed through a stock-ownership plan, and Simmons hopes they will back his slate of directors at the annual meeting. Martin said Lockheed promised to allow a Simmons videotape to be shown to employees, then reneged because it lasted 24 minutes, twice as long as a video presenting Tellep's side. Martin said he would book time at a Los Angeles television station to show the video, calling that ``a woefully inadequate substitute for equal access to employees at the workplace.'' Lockheed spokesman Bob Slayman said the Calabasas-based company felt it had ``bent over backward'' to accommodate Simmons ``and offered them an equal amount of time as our videotape.'' Simmons said Thursday that Lockheed's management is unable to face the fact that its deployment of more than $2 billion in assets in the technology and electronics services divisions has largely failed. Tellep said Friday that the interdependence of Lockheed's units was far greater than Simmons claims. ``Our Electronic Services Group provides critical technologies that are an integral component of our missiles, space and aeronautical businesses,'' he said.

UAL Corp.'s board of directors said it will let former suitor Marvin Davis again buy company stock, raising the possibility of a rival buyout offer to the $3.8 billion bid by UAL's unions and a major shareholder. Davis sparked a bidding war for UAL last August but later withdrew his buyout proposals after the company, the parent of United Airlines, accepted a higher offer from a group led by senior management and its pilots union. That plan later collapsed. UAL stock finished up $5.12{ at $157.87{ Friday on the New York Stock Exchange, although Coniston Partners, UAL's biggest shareholder and the backer of the union buyout, expressed skepticism that Davis would make an offer.

Former Exxon Valdez Capt. Joseph Hazelwood was sentenced to help clean up Prince William Sound and pay $50,000 in restitution to the state by a judge who criticized his lack of contrition. Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone, in sentencing Hazelwood to 1,000 hours of community service by cleaning beaches, said Friday he was disappointed that the fired skipper had not publicly apologized for his role in the nation's worst oil spill.

Negotiators reported the first breakthrough in a host of contentious trade disputes with Japan: an agreement designed to open the Japanese market to American-made supercomputers. Officials at the U.S. trade office said Friday they achieved major concessions that should boost supercomputer sales in the important Japanese government market, estimated to total about $130 million annually.

Sales of North American-built cars and trucks tumbled 9.5 percent in mid-March compared with a weak period last year, reflecting the absence of big rebates, especially on trucks. The nine major automakers with U.S. plants said Friday they sold cars and trucks at an average daily rate of 35,497 during March 11-20 this year, compared with a rate of 39,225 during the same period last year. Car sales slipped 8.9 percent while truck sales were down 10.6 percent.

Orders for home appliances, machinery and other major durable goods rose 3.3 percent last month, the government said. The Commerce Department said Friday that orders to U.S. factories for durable goods _ items expected to last more than three years _ totaled a seasonally adjusted $121.6 billion.

President Bush's savings and loan bailout got a reprieve when a federal appeals court paved the way for the government to seize a suburban Chicago thrift institution. The U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit lifted a lower court order Friday that had barred the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision from taking control of Olympic Savings and Loan Association of Berwyn, Ill. However, it forbade regulators from liquidating the thrift and selling its $1.1 billion in assets.

Looming, junk-bond related debt problems are threatening Ingersoll Publications, owner of the new St. Louis Sun newspaper and a host of other publications. So far, a plan by owner Ralph Ingersoll II to buy back some of the company's junk bonds at cut-rate prices is not receiving a warm welcome from analysts and bondholders. ``The bonds are not worth 100 cents on the dollar, but they're certainly worth more than what the company is offering,'' Stephen Unterhalter, senior analyst with R.D. Smith Co. in New York, said Friday.

A Treasury Department official nominated to the Federal Reserve Board promised he would exercise independent judgment rather than serve as an agent of the administration's push to lower interest rates. David W. Mullins Jr. made the pledge Friday before the Senate Banking Committee. He is assistant Treasury secretary and one of the architects of President Bush's savings and loan bailout.

The pork people say their products are just as nutritious as chicken, turkey and fish, but a private group says that's hogwash and is asking the government to do something about it. The Center for Science in the Public Interest said an advertising campaign by the National Pork Producers Council _ which touts pork as ``the other white meat'' _ is ``deceptive and dangerously misleading.'' His group filed a petition Friday asking the Federal Trade Commission to stop the pork council's claims and require advertising corrections. ``We're confident that our advertising is accurate and can be backed up by substantial scientific evidence,'' said Barry Pfouts, director of marketing for the pork council.

The stock market rose modestly Friday, recovering from three straight days of declines as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials gained 8.56 points to 2,704.28. Bond prices posted small gains after a volatile session. The dollar fell sharply against the Japanese yen but finished higher against other major currencies. Gold futures prices tumbled to 4{-month lows; silver retreated; grains and soybeans fell; energy future advanced and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Judge Tosses Out Much of $150 Million Xerox Lawsuit Against Apple
DOC.TEXT: The bulk of a $150 million lawsuit accusing Apple Computer Inc. of pirating pioneering Xerox Corp. designs to create the revolutionary Macintosh computer was thrown out Friday by a federal judge. Xerox immediately announced it would appeal. U.S. District Judge Vaughn Walker dismissed five of six counts. The only count remaining asks for a declaratory judgment stating that Xerox is the owner of copyrights pertaining to its Star computer. Xerox said in a statement from its Stamford, Conn., headquarters: ``This ruling does not mean Apple has not taken substantial portions of Star and claimed them as their own. The court merely held, we believe erroneously, that Xerox did not have standing to present facts in support of that contention. ... We intend to appeal.'' ``We welcome the ruling in every way,'' said Apple spokeswoman Carleen LeVasseur. ``We're pleased that the Xerox case was dismissed today. I'm confident that the sole remaining issue will be dismissed in the near future.'' Referring to the remaining accusation, Lavasseur said, ``Apple has never disputed the validity of Xerox's (copyright) registration.'' The suit, filed in December, alleged that Apple derived the software for its Lisa and Macintosh computers from Xerox computer programs. The suit said Steven Jobs, co-founder of Apple, had seen a demonstration of a Xerox program called Smalltalk at Xerox's Palo Alto Research Center in 1979, and that he and other Apple employees were impressed with the concept and copied it. Smalltalk was the first computer language to use a mouse, a small, hand-held devise used to manipulate information on a computer screen. Jobs left Apple in 1985. The suit also claimed Apple employees saw the Xerox Star program at a trade show in Houston in June 1981, and copied substantial portions of it into its Lisa and Macintosh, including the design and appearance of such on-screen devices as applications windows, dialogue boxes and menu, and some exact symbols from the program. The suit asaid Xerox never licensed Apple to use the Star computer program or its graphics, and alleged that Apple gained unauthorized access by hiring several Xerox employees in the late 1970s and early 1980s, including Star software developers. Apple was granted a license in June 1981 to participate with Xerox in a project to implement Smalltalk into a hardware system to be developed by Apple, the suit said. Apple responded at the time of the suit that Xerox's software concepts were not protected by copyright any more than images of birds or trees were protected by the copyright on a painting. Software industry officials hoped the lawsuit would clarify issues surrounding the right to copyright certain aspects of computer programs, such as their ``look and feel.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Owens-Corning Workers Can Sue Wickes Corp. in Failed Takeover
DOC.TEXT: A judge on Friday cleared the way for a union representing Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corp. employees to sue Wickes Corp. for damages stemming from a failed 1986 takeover attempt of Owens-Corning by the retailing conglomerate. A spokeswoman for Santa Monica, Calif-based Wickes said it would appeal the decision by Superior Court Judge Raymond F. Drozdowski. The judge denied Wickes' request to dismiss the case. The Glass, Molders, Pottery, Plastics & Allied Workers International Union, based in Media, Pa., filed suit against Wickes, contending the company ``interfered with economic expectations'' between union members and Owens-Corning. Wickes, best known for its home improvement centers and furniture business, abandoned a 2{-week-old takeover attempt for Owens-Corning in August 1986 after its $2.1 billion tender offer apparently was beaten out by a more lucrative restructuring plan proposed by the Toledo, Ohio-based company. In October 1986, Owens-Corning announced it would lay off 5,000 workers nationwide, including 500 at its Barrington, N.J. facility, to thwart the hostile takeover. Wickes made a $30 million profit after expenses in its unsuccessful takeover bid. ``The union will persist in our efforts to win just compensation for our members harmed by the Wickes takeover attempt,'' James E. Hatfield, the union's international president, said in a statement. Union officials could not be reached Friday for additonal comment. Owens-Corning is the world's largest manufacturer of glass fiber materials and is a major producer of polyester resins and high-performance composite materials used in construction, autos and boats.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Finance Minister Meets With Brady
With AM-US-Japan Trade, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady on Friday praised Japanese concessions that will lead to the sale of U.S. supercomputers in Japan, saying, ``We're showing that we can make some progress.'' Brady emerged from talks with Japanese Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto to say he hoped the agreement would mollify a protectionist-minded Congress and head off possible trade sanctions against Japan. Topics at the wide-ranging talks included reunification of East and West Germany and the April 6 and 7 special meeting in Paris of the seven Western industrialized nations, Brady said. He said he briefed Hashimoto on his conversations with other leaders in preparation for that meeting, including details of a French proposal for a European Bank for Reconstruction and Development that will lend money to Eastern Europe. American trade negotiators said Friday in Washington that Japan had agreed to remove various restrictions preventing U.S. companies from selling supercomputers to Japanese universities and government agencies. Those concessions came during talks on specific industries being conducted under a section of the 1988 trade law known as Super 301. Brady said he had no progress to report on the other Super 301 industries, lumber and satellites. ``Are they (supercomputer concessions) all we want?'' Brady asked. ``No. Are we going to get more? Yes. When, I can't say. I hope soon.'' At an evening news conference following Friday's session, Brady said ``It really was just a meeting to talk.'' A joint statement issued said Brady and Hashimoto discussed ``a range of bilateral and multilateral issues.'' Those included the Structural Impediments Initiative _ proposed changes to eliminate broad trade impediments in both countries _ and the proposed international bank to lend to Eastern Europe. It would be led by Western European nations and would include the Soviet Union. They also said they discussed global financial markets and remained committed to ``cooperation in the exchange markets'' _ a reference to attempts to keep the Japanese yen from continuing its slide against the dollar. Asked about a report Friday from Japan that the Japanese government might be considering issuing dollar-denominated bonds to support the sagging yen, Brady replied, ``The matter never came up.'' Analysts said that report held back bond prices on Wall Street Friday. Brady declined to say what Hashimoto said about the Tokyo stock market, which has plummeted in recent months. He noted that other international markets, including the U.S. stock market, had not fallen and said that stability elsewhere was a good sign. ``Even though there has been roughly a 20 percent decline in the Tokyo markets, the rest of the world has operated pretty much in a stable way.'' Brady said. The recent plunge of the yen against the dollar has continued even after the Bank of Japan raised the discount rate this week by 1 percent to 5.25 percent. In the currency market, the dollar closed the week at 155.07 yen, up 0.24 yen from Thursday's close of 154.83 yen. ``The demand for the dollar basically remains strong,'' said Toshio Takahashi, a dealer with the Industrial Bank of Japan. ``The American economy is good, despite cautiousness over inflation'' among U.S. monetary authorities, he said. The meetings between Hashimoto and Brady took place against a backdrop of chaotic action on the Japanese stock market, where the closely followed Nikkei average of 225 stocks has fallen more than 25 percent since the beginning of the year. Prices seesawed again Friday but finished with a moderate gain after a week of heavy losses. ``The market is slowly but gradually recovering, helped by relative stability in the currency and bond markets,'' said Akira Shimoda, an equity analyst with Yamaichi Securities.
